I never saw a way to cook on a fire, but also fire causes cannibals to spawn; so you're best not ever making a fire. You cannot sleep. You'll just be sitting in pitch black, waiting to die, as once the sun goes down your shelter only allows you to save. 

It might be fun in MP, like I said, but I don't have friends; so this isn't my game

I really wanted to give this game a chance because of the huge amount of positive reviews it has, but I really don't see what people see in it.

There are significant bugs everywhere and the gameplay is very shallow, for example all combat in the game (*ALL*) is circle strafe to win or simply hold block w/ any max block weapon. This is true even on the hardest difficulty setting. Cheese combat is mainly driven by the fact that literally everything in the game is faster, tougher, and does more damage than the player. They have to be because their pathing is pretty horrible and easily exploited by the player. If you can stand on a rock or cliff, you can pretty much guarantee a win against anything, as it will either fling itself off the cliff while running around at full speed, or stop dead and wait for you to attack it assuming the rock is tall enough.

Key items are hidden in extremely dark caves with zero information in game on how to progress (No where, how, or even why for anything), making it virtually impossible without an astronomical time sink to make forward progress because it is basically done by blind chance without a Steam or Google guide. Not even a decent "bread crumb trail" to slowly direct you towards where you need to go.

The huge amount of "stumble through until you figure it out" would be bearable if the game had meaningful progression outside of those key items your expected to find, but it doesn't, you can build a base that will carry you through the entire game within the first couple hours. Once again, even on the hardest difficulty setting. Base building itself seems very basic as well, they give you the tools to make a bigger base, but a bigger base is quite pointless as all the buildings are basically the same and there is no functional reason to make one large.

The atmosphere of the game and the environmental storytelling are pretty decent but they unfortunately do not make up for the design problems.

The game simply needs more to do for as open as it is, or a better system of guiding the player through the content that it does have.

This is one of those instances where a theoretical 'neutral' review rating would be preferred. This is more of a critique rather than a binary recommendation.

I appreciate games that can be hardcore...through options. It's not the way I usually like to play, but I appreciate the option for those that want that experience. If you go in blind this game can be brutal in a few ways.

Despite a whopping 340K reviews, 70% of players have played some amount of multiplayer. That's impressive. Unfortunately there is a key difference between the solo experience and multiplayer. In single-player when you 'die' the first time you get dragged to a cave. This specific cave has a map and a compass, two of the most important items in the game. This is obviously intentional and I think is a nice way of giving the player a map but first allowing them to naturally explore. In multiplayer though, you just die.

If you jump straight into multiplayer like me then good luck finding the map organically. Some people would prefer this, but my problem is that there are tons of trees and hills on this island that obscure your vision and there aren't many distinct landmarks compared to some other open-world games. It's clearly intentional to get the map in single-player, so why didn't they do it for multiplayer when you both die? At least give me an option.

The map itself isn't very detailed, which is fine, but there is a problem. When you die the map completely resets. This makes no sense and is one of those 'hardcore' design choices that I can't believe isn't an option.

If the concern is 'immersion' then why are we able to see icon indicators of our sleeping-buildings regardless of our location? Why are we able to change the lighting/color rendering to significantly brighten caves? Why are we able to hold an insane amount of items in our backpack? Why can we hold two logs in one arm while sprinting?

I'm hoping the sequel has more landmarks and gives more options for details that would otherwise default to 'hardcore'.

I thought this game was about a plane crash survivor looking for his child on an island inhabited by cannibal mutants and frightening creatures like you've never seen. And it is exactly that until it's not, and its about random labs full of random experiments, and alien laser beam launchers that shoot down other planes with children on them. Then it's just some stupid ugly child with a terrible haircut having seizures on the Black Jimmy Fallon show then growing up to have live testes growing in his arms. And his haircut still trash. Sons of the forest better be good and actually make coherent sense narrative wise or I might have to intervene fr.

Incomplete game.
I waited for years, expecting this game to be yet another permanent early access survival that just stops being developed but is sold otherwise. Surprisingly, this one did finally reach its release, and the reviews were even positive, so I went ahead an got it.
Well...

Honestly, I feel scammed. For someone who expects games to have some minimum quality, and don't just turn a blind eye because all others in the genre are the same, this game is not playable.
Everywhere you look, there are details that have never been cared for. If a game is developed over years, and being honest, this one was just like it is now for a while, I do expect not to feel like I'm playing a game made by a highschool student as a homework assignment. Yes, the scale is way larger, but the gameplay feels pretty much as unpolished.
Let me give a few examples that I can make out from memory:
-Mobs that spawn under you, but to make it fair, they might despawn pretty much the same way (it's not very common, but not that rare either)
-Freaking alligators that simply stay still while you murder them for skin. Really? Is this the final release, when the **** alligator's AI doesn't have any way to attack? Unreal.
-Enemies that stand still as you attack them time and time again. But don't worry, their friends do just so. (I believe this one is intentional, for balancing purposes... but needing this method already shows how uncared for it has been)
-You can't even cook well, or dry meat for instance. You take the dried one, try to leave a new one, and have no way of selecting which to leave, so you leave again the dried one.
-The inventory management is complete crap. Not a bug by itself, but a clear indicator of the little maintenance it has received.

It's pretty sad, to be fair. The game looks amazing visually in many ways. The theme is well achieved, if the enemies weren't completely ret*rded, but it really is dark and decently thrilling sometimes. It's just sad that it is not enjoyable if you don't play with people to make up for the game itself.

 ruined the entire game for me

The Forest feels like two different games combined. There's "The Forest" or the outdoors survival crafting part of the game that takes place above ground and then there's "The Caves" or the part of the game that takes place underground.

The above ground half is my least favorite. You get a lot of cool options for things to build but the more complicated something is, the less likely it is you'll be able to finish and enjoy it before a swarm of cannibals shows up and ruins your day. You are meant to believe the cannibals are constantly patrolling the island and there's some sort of logic that leads to them finding you but I swear they just spawn behind me when I'm chopping trees sometimes. It doesn't help that the sound design is lacking; you are completely deaf to things happening behind you. Also, the cannibals sound weird? Like they're low bitrate or muffled somehow? Is that just me? I found trying to establish a base of operations to be a futile exercise in single player. I ended up setting up a bunch of small huts with meat drying racks all over the island and wouldn't spend too much time at any single location. It seems like the longer you spend in an area, the more likely it is for a patrol to just spawn on you so moving around a lot is the best bet. This also means you're never going to bother with the cooler buildings like all the walls and the... gazebo? 

In fact, the building isn't the only mechanic I got through most of the game without engaging with. Once I knew I was near the end, I started googling lots of questions I had about various things. Turns out, you can make stews using the metals pots you find that give you 10 minute buffs to your stats. Also, there are stats!? Like strength and athleticism??? The game never tells you these things. You don't even find recipes for the different stews which makes it feel like an afterthought. The game will tell you that being covered in blood is an infection risk but it never explains what "infection" does. I'll save you the trouble; infection prevents your strength stat from leveling up. It's very likely I went through like 90% of the game without being able to level my strength stat. That sounds pretty bad but the projectile weapons don't scale with strength so it's manageable.

At this point, you probably think it's weird I gave this game a thumbs up. Well, the underground half of this game is EFFIN' RAD. It's like a dungeon crawler based on the movie "The Descent" and probably the best game about spelunking made. At some point, I came to see the above ground as the place where I prep for my underground dungeon crawls. Not sure why they even named this game "The Forest" in the first place. The caves are where it's at! The look of the caves, the sounds of the caves, the more scripted encounters that don't randomly spawn cannibals behind you, the light metroidvania elements where you find items that redefine weird features of the environment you saw a few tunnels ago; That's why the caves feels like a different (and better) game than the above ground experience. Furthermore, the cannibals in the cave stay in their rooms until you aggro them but will never leave the caves; the cannibals above ground will chase you all over the island but never go into the tunnels. This makes no sense to me and adds to the feeling that there are two different games here. It's an oversight that also means setting up camps just inside the entrance of a cave is the safest plan. Cannibals will never find you there unless you go further in and kite the cave cannibals back to your camp.

Overall, I had a great time. Maybe if you play with friends, you can just brute force your way through the cannibals on the surface and build some cool shit but it seems like the meta strat is to never build anything substantial and just live in the caves as much as possible. To me, that makes this a weak survival crafting game, but it's still a very cool spelunking horror game! Look at it this way, there's lots of room to improve for the sequel!

I am a 51 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

An average survival game. Graphics are just tight fixed for a sandbox world, but sometimes shows glitches even with low quality, but demanding powerfull hardware anyway. The mouse buttons cannot be binded, so without a gamepad or jostick, many important actions must be asigned to keyboard. 

Mechanics of crafting are good, easy to learn and with many items and builds to made, working fine as good wood & stone survival building simulator. But this product have remarkable issues. The worst is the fact that player cant choose what kind and how many things he want to carry with him, ruining all sense of realism: he can carry lot of big and heavy garbage as skulls, enemie's body parts (?), rocks, bad weapons... but limites basic things as water or ammo. There are more important issues that downgrade the product, as system of water potabilization and map marking stop working, or the excessive speed of cycles for hunger, thirst, day, night.

Enemies are very well depicted, can provoque fear and even can be smart in their madness, are best of the game, but some of them causes excessive damage with bare hands and close combat system ever feels really clumsy. There are two kinds of enviroments: surface and undergrounds. The first are pretty nice open and enlighted fields, coastal and forestal places, but many zones are empty of something of interest except virgin nature; exploring for searching oddities is not specially rewarding far away from small camps. The second are caves, claustrofobical, dark and twisted, with many levels of deep, gore, dangerous places for fighting, and the most of useful things and  best rewards. 

To complete all objectives, build a strong camp and explore all map in normal level, takes about 70 hours. Is a product very extreme, with great pros and contras, its more famous and expensive than deserves compared with other titles, maybe because it has enjoyed one of the finest hype job from fans ever seen, surely by multiplayer, as proof that even a rudely designed and bugged game can be good with friends. But a single player will see it as really is, naked in its glorious mediocrity.

On your first playthrough...

Do: 
-Utilize the To-Do List
-Explore the caves for loot.
-Block cannibal attacks.
-Kill the skinny dirty ones if they won't leave you alone.
-Kill every mutant you see.
-Burn bodies for bones.
-Make temporary shelters to save your game (often) then destroy the shelter and move on.

Don't:
-Settle in one place
-Build a big base
-Cut down trees
-Chase the cannibals
-Sleep

The forest is an Indie masterpiece infected with bugs that are a bit frustrating and can subtract from the overall magnificent game. 

You are tasked with a seemingly impossible mission, save your son from an island that is set to kill and rip you apart. Crafting is fun, base building allows and expects you to be creative in order to solve the constant attacks, the survival mechanics enhance the game without being tedious or overly taxing. The AI of the enemies is most of the time amazing, they will coordinate, they will patrol around your base and leave markers for others to come attack, they will plan sieges with mutants and will prioritize your food racks and walls. The caves feel oppressive but fair, the water exploration is mostly safe while making you feel like you could drown at any minute, the forest is plentiful with opportunities to eat but only for those that learn where to look.

My only negatives are: Bugs, bugs and more bugs.
Skinning deer or driving sleds sometimes sends you flying and kills you, mutants that push you, can and most definitely will make you fall through the world. In multiplayer only the host is allowed to raise more than 2 points of stats per play through, the other players will not be able to raise their strength more than 2 points. If they want to, they will need to leave and reconnect. If both go on a boat house the fire can glitch and become invisible, the boat house will seemingly disappear for no reason to then comeback. Items will disappear and become unavailable and render impossible the crafting of that item (happened with the gun). If you build a lot the game will tank while near or in your base.

If you can look pass the bugs this is an amazing, must-play title for everybody who likes survival games with building and crafting.

I killed an ate a man. To survive. I mean yeah, I had berries sure. And yeah some turtle meat and deer and all that.  But that's not gonna last forever. I had to do it, judge. So I mean yeah, am I "guilty"? Well I did it, but I'm not guilty. You would have done the same in my situation. 

Now I don't know what I did exactly. I originally just planned on retiring to the seashore, next thing I know I'm elbow deep in the torso of this man I just met trying to get all of his organs out. I never field dressed a person. You? It's pretty difficult. Anyway yeah, I killed him. And yes I used a club made out of the skull of another man, but I promise that's just totally coincidental. I FOUND that skull, you see. At first I thought it was a halloween decoration, but no. Real skull. Can you believe it? 

Anyway he kept hooting and hollering at me from a distance for god knows what reason. I've never been catcalled before, much less followed and catcalled. I know I have a rather feminine build compared to most men who are starving but this is just kind of ridiculous. I was offended, mortified, and scared all at the same time. What am I, a piece of meat? An object? Do I not have dreams, hopes, and ambitions? Overcome with empathy for the struggles of women across the world on account of my own exposure to toxic masculinity that I thought I'd give this wolf whistling boar a piece of my mind. 

"Hey you!" I sez, "Did you not stop for a single minute to see how I would feel? How your behavior impacts others around you? How it perpetuates feelings of insecurity and shame throughout our society? I have a right to exist without wondering what kind of abuse I will suffer at the hands of sexist and dehumanizing men?". And frankly your honor, screw them double. My build is not THAT feminine. I was on the wrestling team. Okay I wasn't exactly on the wrestling team, it was the ultimate frisbee team. But I was on a team, is what I mean. I had comradery with those fellows only rivaled by soldiers in the thick of battle. 

I had to WORK for that trophy. Well, it wasn't a trophy. More like a gift card. To whole foods. 

I digress. Your honor after giving this rude man a talking to he gave me a whole speech about Alphas and Betas and then said something about an ethno-state and lobsters. I don't know, it was all very odd. And he kept talking "them" but he never said who "they" are. Clearly this man was out of his mind. And racist. And I can't get behind that at all. He worked himself up into a misogynistic tizzy trying to explain that women only go for black men because the white man has become weak and feeble. He again gestured to my round hips and said "SOY!". I was afraid for my life at this point, he kept getting angrier and was frothing at the mouth. He had to be stopped before he endangered my life, your honor. He said I was a shill. A shill! Can you believe it? Me who worked at a business hired by the Biden campaign to spread awareness of pressing issues on social media. It was a well paying job and I was glad to do it. Not that that has anything to do with anything. 

He made an aggressive motion towards me and, again, fearing for my life, I bopped him upside the head with my skull on a stick thing. Then I ate him. I was always taught not to let things go to waste, and modern burials are actually very bad for the environment. 

What was that? I'm on trial for abusing steams review feature? 

Well yeah I did that, too. The game's okay.

The Forest

Well, everything begins with you crash landing on a hostile island, your given limited supplies to start and must quickly get to work on the tutorial basics with the handy Axe you get once leaving the wreckage.

You will find there is very little to no hand holding at all, story progresses as you find details and explore, I got swepted away in building the best base possible, nice and close to the water for protection, finally got a zip line in my forest for maximum wood production, food was solid and the gardens were growing, I made better weapons and actually went on the offensive with the cannibals you encounter, yes.. this is a survival horror game, just wait till you go spelunking down the cavern depths, bring a friend as you will sh*t yourself otherwise.

Unfortunately my buddies and I never finished the story, I think we got pretty far and discovered a bunch of stuff, we will hopefully finish the game before Son of the forest comes out.

Game trailers looks incredible for sure, look forward to playing sons of the forest soon.

A ray of light shines down on a leather-bound storybook. The book opens and a voice begins reading its text:

SHREK: Once upon a time there was a lovely princess. But she had an enchantment upon her of a fearful sort which could only be broken by love's first kiss. She was locked away in a castle guarded by a terrible fire-breathing dragon. Many brave knights had attempted to free her from this dreadful prison, but none prevailed. She waited in the dragon's keep in the highest room of the tallest tower. For her true love and true love's first kiss.

The voice laughs. A big, green hand rips out a page of the book and shuts it closed.

SHREK: Like that's ever gonna happen. What a load of -

We see an outhouse and hear the sound of a toilet flushing. Out steps SHREK, an ogre, who tugs at his underwear and shakes his foot of the page still stuck to his shoe. He looks lovingly at the swamp he calls home, and goes about his daily routine. This includes taking a mud shower, brushing his teeth with bugs, bathing in a muddy pond, gathering giant slugs for dinner, and painting a warning sign.

In a nearby village, an angry mob gather up to go after Shrek. At night they gather their torches and pitchforks and enter the swamp, trampling over Shrek's warning signs. Shrek sees them after investigating the commotion, rolling his eyes. The villagers stop outside Shrek's home, unaware that Shrek is sneaking up behind them.

NIGHT - NEAR SHREK'S HOME

Villager 1: Think it's in there?

Villager 2: All right. Let's get it!

Villager 1: Whoa. Hold on. Do you know what that thing can do to you?

Villager 3: Yeah, it'll grind your bones for its bread.

Shrek chuckles, revealing himself to be standing behind the mob.

SHREK: Yes, well, actually, that would be a giant.

The mob gasp.

SHREK: Now, ogres, oh they're much worse. They'll make a suit from your freshly peeled skin...

Shrek slowly approaches as the villagers back away in fear.

Villagers: No!

SHREK: They'll shave your liver. Squeeze the jelly from your eyes! Actually, it's quite good on toast.

Villager 1: Back! Back, beast! Back! I warn ya!

The villager waves his torch in Shrek's face. Shrek casually licks his fingers and pinches the flame, extinguishing the torch. The villager drops it.

Villager 1: Right...

Shrek terrifies the mob with a great frightening roar, his spit extinguishing all the remaining torches. He wipes his mouth and waits for the villagers to stop screaming.

SHREK: (Whispering) This is the part where you run away.

Shrek laughs as the men drop their torches and pitchforks and run away as fast they can.

SHREK: And stay out! (

He looks down and picks up a wanted poster dropped by one of the villagers. He reads it aloud.

SHREK: "Wanted. Fairytale creatures"?

He sighs and walks off. dropping the poster to the ground.

THE NEXT DAY - FOREST

Fairy tale creatures are put in chains and led into wagons by Duloc Guards. The Captain of the Duloc Guards sits at a table paying a line of people their rewards for turning in the fairytale creatures. Those waiting in line include Peter Pan, who is carrying Tinkerbell in a cage, Geppetto who is carrying Pinocchio, and a farmer carrying the Three Little Pigs.

GUARD: All right. This one's full. Take it away! Move it along. Come on! Get up!

THE CAPTAIN: Next!

GUARD: (Taking the witch's broom) Give me that! Your flying days are over. (breaks the broom in half)

THE CAPTAIN: That's 20 pieces of silver for the witch. Next!

The captain hands over the reward to the villager who turned the witch in. The villager mutters to himself.

Villager: Lousy twenty pieces...

GUARD: Get up! Come on!

Waiting in line is Donkey on a leash and his owner. He looks in horror at the witch and a group of dwarves being loaded into a wagon.

GUARD: Sit down there! Be quiet!

Mama Bear and Papa Bear are locked inside giant cages, with Little Bear in his own cage.

LITTLE BEAR: (crying) This cage is too small.

DONKEY: (To his owner) Please, don't turn me in. I'll never be stubborn again. I can change. Please! Give me another chance!

OLD WOMAN: Oh, shut up. (Smacks Donkey)

DONKEY: Oh!

THE CAPTAIN: Next! What have you got?

GEPPETTO: This little wooden puppet.

PINOCCHIO: I'm not a puppet. I'm a real boy. (his nose grows)

THE CAPTAIN: Five shillings for the possessed toy. Take it away.

PINOCCHIO: Father, please! Don't let them do this! Help me!

Geppetto takes the money and walks off. The old woman steps up to the table.

THE CAPTAIN: Next! What have you got?

OLD WOMAN: Well, I've got a talking donkey.

THE CAPTAIN: Right. Well, that's good for ten shillings, if you can prove it.

OLD WOMAN: Oh, go ahead, little fella. (Donkey stays silent).

THE CAPTAIN: Well?..

OLD WOMAN: Oh, oh, he's just...he's just a little nervous. He's really quite a chatterbox. (Smacks Donkey again) Talk, you boneheaded dolt, talk!

THE CAPTAIN: That's it. I've heard enough. Guards!

OLD WOMAN: No, no, he talks! He does. (Moving Donkey's lips) I can talk. I love to talk. I'm the talking-est damn thing you ever saw.

THE CAPTAIN: Get her out of my sight.

OLD WOMAN: No, no! I swear! Oh! He can talk!

The guards grab the old woman and she struggles with them. One of her legs flies out and kicks Tinkerbell out of Peter Pan's hands, and her cage drops on Donkey's head. He gets sprinkled with fairy dust and starts floating upwards.

DONKEY: Hey! I can fly!

PETER PAN: He can fly!

THREE LITTLE PIGS: He can fly!

THE CAPTAIN: He can talk?!

DONKEY: Man, it's good to be free.

Shrek turns and regards Donkey for a moment before loudly roaring in is face.

Game is not bad, but

Mechanics feel very disconnected
there are 3 main mechanics in the game:
- base building
- story processing
- survival

and it feels like devs were trying to figure out the game while releasing it

and if initially it shuold have been base-building survival
then later they switched to story focused action game

so these two parts are very disconnected and half-developed

base building is pretty superficial and in the end - meaningless
in Valheim, for example, you have your "primary base of operations" and "supplementary bases", and all of them make sense - you have to constantly teleport between them, gather resources etc

here you build the base, then figure out there is a story, and just abandon the base and go through the story

storyteling is really undeveloperd.
you find some peaces of "info", which gives you zero info in actuality, so you basically just "search for trophies" with no point at all (except of couple minor things)


in the end thats how you gameplay looks:
- you spend first day building the base
- second day to figure out how to develop a base
- figure out there is story content
- abandon the base
- go through the cases in order to finish the story

thats it

Description: A gory first person game in a forest filled with cannibals.

Pros:
+ Good Graphics 
+ Convincing Atmosphere 
+ Realistic Feeling Enemies
+ Online Co-op

Cons:
- Repetitive Gameplay
- Building is Irrelevant
- Survival is an Afterthought
- Confusing Inventory System
- Poorly Optimized 

Details: 
While the game definitely looks amazing, and the atmosphere really sells the survival horror element well, the game suffers from a lack of content induced by repetitive gameplay.

There is really only two things you can do in this game. You either go underground to explore identical looking caves, or you stay above ground and get zerged by cannibals every 5 minutes. Everything else advertised by the game is pretty much irrelevant.

Forget about building large fortresses, as you will get constantly attacked by cannibals whether day or night. You'll end up spending hours constructing even the most modest of bases, only for the cannibals to casually destroy your structures in a few punches.

Don't fret about survival either, as you can simply perform some cannibalism yourself to fill your hunger with virtually no negative consequences, removing any need to hunt, gather, or farm for food. And should that not be enough, there are plenty of edible snacks from other plane passengers simply laying around on the island for you to find.

Exploration might have been interesting, if you weren't constantly forced into encounters with the cannibals. And while the combat isn't exactly "bad", it nevertheless only serves to get in the way of story progression.

All in all, if you just wanted a combat heavy game where you fight off waves of cannibals over and over, then this might be the game for you. But if you want to do anything else you would expect from a game of this genre, like building, exploring, and surviving, then this game is simply not it.

Rating: 2.5 / 5.0

I can't believe, why this game has 95% positive reviews?!? From over 300k people?!? It is at best a mediocre game. I would not recommend it to anyone. I only played it longer than 4 hours, because I'm playing it together with my friends.

Pros:
- The game utilizes real darkness, which I would like in general

Cons (there are a lot, just to name the most annoying):
- Zombies are constantly spawning and attacking you - very annoying
- Fighting is totally uninteresting and boring
- The game should be renamed to "The Cave", as you are in caves most of the time
- Caves are completely dark, which I would like, but the light sources are terrible or do even blind you even more. You really can't see anything and the cave experience is really unpleasent
- The game is buggy, but I encountered nothing game breaking at least (the level of polish is kinda late early access stage)
- In multiplayer, every player has to manually save in bases or random tents (otherwise -> rollback)
- The inventory system is a horrible gimmick
- The building system is horrible and building in general is completely useless
- Crafting is completely useless and very tedious (everything you really need is found in caves in masses)

TL;DR
To sum it up the game breaks down to a story/exploration game in complete darkness with bad and useless survival and building elements thrown on top of it, where the story is cryptic and the exploration is no fun.

It's pretty fun at times, but horribly uninutitive when it comes to the UI and objectives. The game doesn't tell you when you've cleared the caves fully and the crafting system should've been reworked. As well as the inventory, it's some gimmicky inventory screen instead of a traditional easy-to-use inventory, when you wanna drop food for example you have to combine it with a metal tray to give it to your friends. It's a dumb feature.

If you play it with your friends it'll be worth it for 10 or so hours before the mystery factor expires. Then it's just repetitive classic survival gameplay like Valheim.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 18 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

one of the best games out there. an absolutely phenomenal story that concludes with you feeling fulfilled, yet still has you eagerly waiting for the sequel. A simply stellar combination of a balanced story, building system and combat. The advanced AI of the cannibals makes every playthrough something different, and the building is enough work to feel accomplished, but not too grindy. The atmosphere of the beautiful landscapes, and terrifying yet intriguing cave systems are unmatched in any other open world story game. While a little bit buggy, it is entirely understandable from an indie game studio, especially with Sons of the Forest on its way. I have never in my entire life been more excited for a game to release, and few games have been able to create such an amazing story, environment, combat, and building mechanics in one game, especially an indie game studio. The game is wonderful and exciting in singleplayer, but in mulitplayer it is an absolute masterpiece.

It's a fun game but should not be priced at 19.99 for the state of the game it's in. This game has a ton of bugs. Several game mechanics are unresponsive.

Concerns
- Game is non-linear, first time play-through you'll find yourself wasting a lot of time going back because you don't have the required tools to proceed.
- I don't understand why they couldn't of just made a simple hotkey system.
- Some items get in the way of others when picking them up, a pick up customizable filter would of been nice.
- Axe doesn't always hit luggage, misses trees often, when you run out of stamina while swinging you get stuck in the animation anyways (this should have been fixed along time ago...)
- Re-breather auto-equips at times where you don't need it and you start freezing just because you entered the water with it.
- Picking up things like pictures animation is buggy as if you swap items it will swap back to the picture (this should of been fixed along time ago...)
- Stamina drain is a bit much
- Can only rotate buildings 1 way.
- Underwater blurriness I would rank as one of the top worst design choices I've ever seen in video games.

Despite these things, there are some mods that make this game much more enjoyable.

The game starts of kind of slow as you're trying to get your feet on the ground. Crash landing. Son gone. Then you see your first real encounter with the natives... and you panic... quickly trying to find a place to set up your smaller base... fast forward a couple nights you're starting to get your life together. Base is coming along and getting bigger... bigger brings more attention... more natives... and likely mutants at this point... you hear them stomping around in the forest... you're hiding behind your walls... panicking... they leave you alone for now... so you start venturing out and find caves and its just terrifying... panicking always... you see a lot of mutants... you leave.. you go back to your base... and more mutants come... destroy your base.... no more base... 10/10 would recommend.

The Forest is a unique experience, the studio behind it is seriously passionate about the project and it shows. Deep lore (to a creepy level), fitting OST, great immersion and ambience. The building system could use some improvements as it's quite limiting. I think the game is worth the full price for sure, and I cannot wait to see how the sequel will play out. One thing that I must definitely add is that this and Phasmophobia are probably my two favourite horror-esque video-games to co-op with friends. The immersion remains, even with friends. Very interesting game. Its hard to get into it in the begging, since you have no clues to anything. Its up to the player to explore the map and find resources, items and hints as to what is happening.

Be aware, it is a somewhat big world, with lots of caves and exploration to do. But it feels very rewarding when you finally start to make some sense out of things. The lore of the game is quite amazing, although most of it is discovered more towards the end-game. 

I'd advise to use find some guides/tutorials on the internet to make it a slightly easier experience. The mechanics of the game might be a little broken, but they're also quite in-depth, so you'll probably find other things that you can do with the items by looking around the web.

Overall it's a very fun and interesting experience if you're willing to put in the time to figure out the story for yourself it.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn.
Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is

[b] Introduction [/b]
The Forest is a game like no other. It provides a mix of realistic survival, horror, combat, building, and story in one nice package. If you are a fan of other realistic survival games like Stranded Deep then The Forest will not feel much different in terms of graphics and survival. You have your standard food, water, energy, and health bars that you have to manage and straight-forward crafting system. Moreover, you can build some pretty impressive creations with the building system but it is a very time consuming process to get all the necessary materials. 

[b] Horror [/b]
The horror elements of the game are very strong early on but tend to fade as time goes on. Unfortunately the cannibals and late mutants of the game, while quite terrifying in visual design, lack in the AI department. After your firs couple encounters with the cannibals, you will find that they become pretty stale to fight against. There isn't much variation in how the enemies fight you and can be downright annoying in their inconsistent and somewhat dumb AI. This isn't to say that the enemies fall completely flat as they still do a good job in providing a sense of dread in the player. I just would've liked to see them behave with less clunkyness. 

Another aspect of horror and spooky factor that the game excels in are the caves you have to explore. There are 10+ underground caves that you have to explore to progress the story of the game. Along the way you get better equipment and find clues about the lore and story of the game. I must say that the level designer of the caves did a great job! I really felt like I was in an actual cave system and enjoyed using the map to track my progress. However, one big downside to the caves was the abysmal light sources provided to the player. Your lighter that you get is pathetic and barely provided enough illumination to see your own body. You do find a flashlight that helps with seeing further out in front of you, but the batteries are scarce and drain quickly. I really would've liked to see some better lighting options in the game. I get that having things dark helps set the atmosphere but the default settings for the game are just too dark. I had to turn up the brightness settings in caves to about 1/3 from the default 0/3 setting. This helped and still required me to use the flashlight to get around. 

[b] Combat [/b]
The combat in this game is both very satisfying and equally frustrating. Pretty much everything can be used as a weapon but as with most games on of them are actually worth a damn. Something that really started to drive me nuts while playing was the poor animation telegraphing from the enemies. Anyone that has played dark souls knows exactly what I am talking about when I say how crucial it is to be able to read your enemies attacks. Many times the cannibals would do attacks that wouldn't look like they hit me but somehow did. On the flip-side, many of my attacks would fail to hit as the hitboxes for the weapons are small and quite difficult to connect with the enemy. Some weapons like the spear are borderline useless because of how the hitboxes function. I definitely don't think the combat is bad but it lacks polish and can feel repetitive as all fights pretty much boil down to either shoot them with arrows and throw bombs or hit them as fast as possible with a melee weapon.

[b] Building [/b]
The building elements of the game are weaved into the survival aspects with structures such as water collectors and drying racks. However, you can also build you own custom structures or some pre-built ones. While this seems great and fun to do at first, you will quickly realize that base building has very little impact on the game and is, in my opinion, actually more frustrating than worth it. The game requires you to perform the tedious task of collecting all of your resources to build defensive walls, rock walls, and wood walls. Though in the end all you get to put in your structures are decorations, a bed, and a fire. There are no workbenches like other survival games and thus base-building is mainly for the more creative folks and not a requirement of progression in the game. Note you do need to build a shelter to save and sleep. This can be done quite cheaply and doesn't require defenses to ensure its survival.

If you watch the trailer for the game then you wouldn't be wrong in thinking that making traps to defend you base is a big part of the game. Thought the is far from the truth. The cannibals and mutants don't actually attack your structures unless you are around them. This lead me to not even bothering continuing to make my main base as it was easier to just fight the enemies in the open with some traps. Moreover, the traps themselves basically have a 1/4 chance of actually working as intended. Most the time the enemies just glitch past them but still set them off. The only exception to this is the deadfall trap which you can use to kill all the enemies quite easily with if you build a few in a line. 

[b] Story [/b]
Last but certainly not least to cover is the story. I honestly think that this is more fascinating part of the game that really set it apart from all your other survival games. The Forest is careful to never share too much about the plot. It uses very few cutscenes and rather relies on video tapes, notes, and your own observations to infer what is going on. You do get a lot of closure at the end of the game which left me feeling very satisfied and excited for Sons Of The Forest. I wish more games used the storytelling techniques of The Forest to keep you immersed.

One potential downside to the way The Forest handles the story is its asymmetry. There are very few actually blockers in place to prevent you from exploring the caves in all sorts of different orders. You will eventually reach the end of the game the same way, but the caves themselves all have unique rewards for exploring them. I feel like this can be frustrating to the player as without much direction, you may find yourself making things harder than they need to be. A good example of this is the map that can be found in one of the caves. There is no guarantee the player will explore that cave first and get the map. Thus they may spend most of the game exploring without even having a map for the caves! That sounds that a very frustrating experience and may even turn some people off from the game.

[b] Performance [/b]
It should go without saying that you need a beefy PC to play this game at high graphics. However, there isn't much a of a disclaimer regarding hard bad this game actually runs. I pretty much had a lot of stuttering while I walked around on the above ground area and it got to be almost every other second when fighting lots of enemies. While this is not game breaking, it is very annoying and is unacceptable for a 3070 and i7 10700K and with the game on an SSD. I suspect the devs that made didn't know much about optimizing it and it seems that newer tech hasn't really helped it making it run better. 


[b] Conclusion [/b]
I think overall this game is definitely something you should play is your like survival games. The story engaging and original which is a real breath of fresh air in the gaming world. It seems like this game could've done with some more experienced developers when it comes to optimization, AI, and some of the pacing & balancing. However, EndNight hasn't been in the game dev industry long. Hopefully Sons Of The Forest will be everything this game could've been and more!

~90 minutes in and so far, this is one of the most infuriating games to play right off the bat. Building and collecting is fun, but don't expect to be able to do very rudimentary things like drink water from a freshwater river directly (using your hands or just sticking your face in is not possible) and put rocks down. Like, just let go of the rock. You can't remove most items from your inventory for no reason. You are required to make a storage to stockpile anything. There are things that don't have storage like body parts, so I hope you're cool with being forced to carry rotten limbs around. You can't just have a pile on the ground. There is a guidebook to build buildings, but there is nothing to tell you how to craft specific things in your inventory. Enemies start out way too strong even on the lowest difficulty with four people. Two hits, you're down, zombies take 10+ hits with the axe, like 7 with a club made of bone (??? axe is supposed to be able to remove limbs, but a club is more powerful for some reason). 4 of us got wiped twice in less than 60 seconds because there was non-stop spawning for an entire day and night cycle. Spawning is random so night time is pointless, exists only to prevent you from doing anything but fight around your campfire for 20+ minutes at a time because it's impossible to see otherwise. Animals sometimes run away from you, sometimes they just chill and have no awareness of your presence so you just walk up and whack em dead. When the game is in fullscreen, somehow the cursor isn't confined to the game so if you look too far in any direction and click, your game minimizes and you maximize and you're dead because you were trying to fight 10 zombies.  It takes almost 90 logs just to build the log cabin so I hope you enjoy doing tedious and repetitive shit for an hour before you can even start to not die and play the game. Not to mention you need walls that are a log a piece. Cannibals also knock them down with a couple hits so it's hardly helpful. All these glaring issues are prominent in less than 90 minutes of gameplay. Trees have a weird hitbox, sometimes you hit them, sometimes you don't and you've been standing in the same place the whole time. Bugs galore, clipping, animation glitching, randomly launching characters/items, falling through the world, etc. Basic shit that shouldn't be present in a 4yo game that is supposed to be updated. Nothing anymore is released as-is so this shit is unacceptable. This game needs serious work yet it will never receive the TLC it needs. Going to keep playing, hopefully mid/late game is less shitty.

Compared to many of the Games out there this one is superb - they get a lot of things right. One has to focus on many things at once but it does not become tedious or overwhelming. There is a lot of replayability even though there is one map because each time you start over you can go anywhere you wand and build whatever you want which adds for much variation. 

The Forest Wiki has much needed information in it. There is no tutorial and though there should be at this point there is no basic getting started guide. 

One of the most important thing is to go to Options > Graphics > Color Grading and set this on TEXAS - you may not like this one the best as there are about 20 different options .. leaving things on default provide a pitch black night for the most part. 

In order to not get slaughtered by the bad guys you will need to research this online about hot to fight in close quarters combat or figure it out for yourself. 

THIS IS NOT TURNBASED  BUT IS REAL TIME AND CLOSE QUARTERS IN YOUR FACE COMBAT. 

So if you like this sort of thing great. 

Spoiler Alert:  - The enemy .... They never ever get wiped out .. it would be great if there were a fixed number of bad guys or repawns for the enemy if this was an option. Also you are basically in constant combat so if you play solo it can be overwhelming. 

Multijplayer is a completely different experience worth pursuing after Singleplayer but overall could be better. 

So Compared to other games regarding the menus and how to do stuff Great,  Replayability Great, Learn all the cheats which is explained in the Wiki this way you can tailor it to how you want it. 

Learn the Hidding game setup options ... 

You can enemy only come out at night if ya want some peace and quiet, ya can have no enemies, you can have building destruction on or off so all your hard work does not get destroyed in seconds. 

So you can play this your way the only downfall though and its a major one the enemy cannot be extinct. 

There is a story mode which you can easily get pulled away from as you find yourself having other concerns.
No accessibility.  Can't bind mouse controls or many other keys.

[h1]Synopsis[/h1]
The Forest is an open world, crafting, survival, and horror game.

[h1]Story[/h1]
Your plane crash lands on an island. You have survived the crash, but there are no other survivors around when you gain consciousness. You quickly discover that you have to fend for yourself and your landing site is crawling with cannibals looking to make you their meal. 

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The remains of the plane can be at different locations, all close to the same area, but different starting experiences. As you emerge from the plane you pick up a Plane Axe and a survival manual that gives you the blueprints to build most of the basic things you need to survive. It includes, fire, shelter, food and water gathering, and much more.

Start off by building yourself some shelter. This is very important as saves are restricted to shelters and the bed. I found the small cabin to be the most convenient shelter, not a lot of materials to build it being the biggest benefit. After you have your shelter you can save your game.

Your book also has a todo list and a notes section. The todo list will be updated with things you need to do in order to progress the story. You start off with some basics, Find Timmy (your son), Set up camp, Find and cook food.

As the game progresses you'll have to build defenses to protect yourself from the cannibals. My personal favorite is the Happy Birthday trap, a wall of spikes that spring up and hit your enemy when they trip it. Even if it doesn't damage or kill them it acts as a wall after it is triggered. Unlike the small cabin, the Happy Birthday traps are expensive to build, but so worth it.

If you fight the cannibals, don't expect a fair fight. Most of the time there will be more than one of them and they don't take turns attacking you. If your health goes down to zero there are two possible outcomes, one you are captured and hung in a cave, like Luke Skywalker on Hoth, or you die and the game ends. It seems that the longer between your losses the more likely you are to end up in the cave.

There are day and night cycles. This was one of my least favorite parts of the game. There is a sleep ability, but it has a timer on it, you can't just sleep through the night, which is something that bothered me. I would understand if you couldn't sleep if cannibals were nearby, but not for an arbitrary timer. Staying up through the night allows you to sleep the next night. There is no penalty, other than food usage for staying up through the night. I found that the night was the perfect time to explore caves as they are going to be dark no matter the time of day.

In addition to the items in the survival manual you can also craft other items like combining two sticks to make a spear. You can create weapons and armor. Unfortunately none of this is covered in the survival manual, I think the game would be a bit better with some kind of crafting guidance.

There are a number of improvements that could be made to the game, such as marking locations on the map. When you build a house or marker it shows up on your screen as an icon in the distance, while this is great to help you find your shelters, it blinds you at night. Being able to mark them on the map and set a way point would be a huge improvement.

At night you can use your lighter to see, it doesn't give much distance. You can find a flashlight that gives you distance, but is focused. You can also craft a torch, unfortunately it isn't held aloft, it is held at eye level essentially blinding you, making it worthless.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
The Forest is a very good survival horror game where you are able to survive if you use your wits. Hearing a cannibal near you in the dark will really get your blood pumping.

[h1]System Specs[/h1]
Intel i7-8086K Coffee Lake 6-Core 4.00GHz CPU
Crucial Ballistix Sport AT 2666 MHz DDR4 RAM (16GB x 2)
ASUS GeForce RTX 2080 Overclocked 8G GDDR6

A star is an astronomical object comprising a luminous spheroid of plasma held together by its gravity. The nearest star to Earth is the Sun. Many other stars are visible to the naked eye at night, but their immense distances from Earth make them appear as fixed points of light. The most prominent stars have been categorised into constellations and asterisms, and many of the brightest stars have proper names. Astronomers have assembled star catalogues that identify the known stars and provide standardized stellar designations. The observable universe contains an estimated 1022 to 1024 stars. Still, most are invisible to the naked eye from Earth, including all individual stars outside our galaxy, the Milky Way.

A star's life begins with the gravitational collapse of a gaseous nebula of material composed primarily of hydrogen, along with helium and trace amounts of heavier elements. Its total mass is the main factor determining its evolution and eventual fate. A star shines for most of its active life due to the thermonuclear fusion of hydrogen into helium in its core. This process releases energy that traverses the star's interior and radiates into outer space. At the end of a star's lifetime, its core becomes a stellar remnant: a white dwarf, a neutron star, or‚Äîif it is sufficiently massive‚Äîa black hole.

Stellar nucleosynthesis in stars or their remnants creates almost all naturally occurring chemical elements heavier than lithium. Stellar mass loss or supernova explosions return chemically enriched material to the interstellar medium. These elements are then recycled into new stars. Astronomers can determine stellar properties‚Äîincluding mass, age, metallicity (chemical composition), variability, distance, and motion through space‚Äîby carrying out observations of a star's apparent brightness, spectrum, and changes in its position in the sky over time.

Stars can form orbital systems with other astronomical objects, as in the case of planetary systems and star systems with two or more stars. When two such stars have a relatively close orbit, their gravitational interaction can significantly impact their evolution. Stars can form part of a much larger gravitationally bound structure, such as a star cluster or a galaxy.

This game seems like it will be good, but in the end is lackluster in pretty much every category. 

The survival mechanics seem quite fun at first, but they quickly lose their depth. Resources are plentiful and very easy to obtain, leaving no challenge in the attempt to survive at all. Alongside that, things such as items within suitcases respawning frequently and animals being very easy to kill by just running at them take a lot of the feeling of authenticity, as well as any aspects of resource management or progression out of the game. After one gets a 2 or 3 days into the game, survival is just a chore with no purpose. 

Which moves onto the second part of the game, which is cave exploration. Cave after cave after cave. This is where the combat and horror aspects come into play... but like the survival it also falls flat. The AI is bad, to the point where it feels like just running past them is the best option. The enemies aren't easy, but they feel like they are just a hindrance rather than a threat or something to strategically deal with. 

Overall, this game starts off feeling great, like it could be a really fun survival adventure. But, once one has played it for a while it just constantly feels like it falls flat.

Fun to wander about and knock the teeth out of the locals, but this is a [b]survival[/b] game first, and the crafting, base-building, and exploration elements are secondary. Don't expect to build a grand home in the wilderness within your first week. This is not a relaxing stroll in the woods.

Materials are scarce, and you'll have to spend many days clearing dozens of trees and transporting materials via sled in order to get a simple and defensible home base. And emphasis on [b]defensible[/b], because almost everything you do gradually attracts the attention of any nearby flesh-eating mutants. 

Like I said, it's a good bit of fun. But most of your time will be put into keeping yourself healthy and fed. And the more time you spend doing that, the harder it becomes, as more tribes and more horrid mutants try to claim your delicious, nutrient-laden flesh.

The Hog Rider card is unlocked from the Spell Valley (Arena 5). He is a quick building-targeting, melee troop with moderately high hitpoints and damage. He appears just like his Clash of Clans counterpart; a man with brown eyebrows, a beard, a mohawk, and a golden body piercing in his left ear who is riding a hog. A Hog Rider card costs 4 Elixir to deploy.

Strategy
When he is jumping over the river, he cannot be targeted by any ground attacking units. The Log and Earthquake will fail to damage a Hog Rider while he is jumping. Air troops can still attack him though, and the Inferno Tower and Inferno Dragon will continue to ramp up their damage.
When countering Hog Riders, obviously use buildings. But be wary as it the offender would usually play around it with cards such as Earthquake. Air swarms such as Minion Horde can help due to the Hog's usual support tools not countering them.
On the offender's side, a powerful move is to accompany him with an Earthquake, obilerating almost every building, and also grounded swarms. To a lesser extent, Lightning could also be used, retaining the same point of almost destroying every building while also crippling troops such as the Wizard or the Hunter.
The Log could also be an effective first play as a cycle, but it only kills swarms and sometimes a non-center-placed Tombstone.
The Hog Rider can be paired with the Lumberjack as both a swarm bait and damage combo. It is a very fast combo with an extremely high damage output potential, so the defender will likely try to counter it with a swarm. If this happens, the offender should use a spell like Arrows to render the defender poetically defenseless. If they manage to defeat the Lumberjack, the dropped Rage will make the Hog Rider even more dangerous than it normally is.
A fast and deadly combination is the Hog Rider and Mini P.E.K.K.A. combo. Both units are fast but the Mini P.E.K.K.A. does much more damage and does not attack only buildings so the Mini P.E.K.K.A. can deal with troops like the Executioner and Musketeer. However, this combo can be defeated with swarms like Skeleton Army, which will defeat both of them since neither of them can deal area damage. They are also unable to target air troops, so the Minion Horde can stop this easily.
A Hog Rider combined with a Goblin Barrel can be awkward for the opponent to defend against. Timing it so that the Hog Rider is tanking the tower shots for the Goblins is the most effective way to deal damage.
A Barbarian Barrel can shut this down with minimal Tower damage for a positive Elixir trade, as long as the Goblin Barrel was placed directly on the Tower. Use another card to counter the Hog Rider if it is necessary.
His fast move speed can boost forward mini tanks like an Ice Golem in a push. At the same time, he can also function as a tank for lower hitpoint troops such as Goblins as he still has a fair amount of health. However, the Hog Rider struggles with swarms, as they can damage him down and defeat him quickly while obstructing his path. Barbarians in particular can fully counter him without very strict timing on the defender's part, though they are vulnerable to spells. Swarm cards like Skeleton Army, Goblin Gang, and Minion Horde can also very easily counter him.
Use this to your advantage by placing a bulky swarm dealer in front of the Hog Rider (eg. Ice Golem, Valkyrie) so that the Hog Rider can transport it to the tower faster and also get protection from swarms.
Most cheap swarms complement the Hog Rider well, as they are nearly as fast as him and usually force more than one card out of the opponent's hand.
The Hog Rider in conjunction with the Freeze can surprise the opponent and allow the Hog Rider to deal much more damage than anticipated, especially if the opponent's go-to counter is a swarm, or swarms are their only effective counter to him. Skeletons and Bats will immediately be defeated by the spell, while Spear Goblins, Goblins, and Minions will be at low enough health to be defeated by a follow up small spell.
Against non-swarm troops, it can deal a lot of damage during the freeze time, but this can allow the opponent to set up a massive counterpush. For this reason, players should either only go for a Hog Rider + Freeze when they have other units backing it up from a counterattack, or if the match is about to end and they need to deal as much damage as possible. The exception to this is an Elixir Collector placed in front of the King's Tower. If a Hog Rider placed at the bridge, he can destroy the Collector for a positive Elixir trade, though the damage from both Princess Towers will usually mean he does not survive to deal any damage to them. However, if the opponent sends in defending troops, it can be an opportunity to gain spell damage value.

Story Wise: Not your typical survival simulation type of game. This game is full of lore and plot twists. It's a dull chest full of treasure to discover. I love how well optimised the game is with such good graphics. Even with a low-spec computer, it is able to handle it very smoothly, which is surprising.

Gameplay: Well, I noticed there are some bugs or glitches that can make the player fly sometimes. From my first POV, it's kind of hard to figure out the game mechanics. The game is literally too dark, like very serious and makes no sense, even if it's in real life, it not that dark lol (This is only my complaint). The rest is really good and awesome as you play more and it becomes quite addictive to play with friends or others, ngl.

Overall: Awesome and can't wait to play the sequel!

I've played hundreds of games in my life but nothing like the forest. I approached it with no expectations but within the first 10 minutes I was transported to a world I found difficult to break away from. The emotional impact of the sounds that unexpected visitors made - I will never forget. The ability to build bases became like a drug that took the edge off of the fearful reality that I was not alone here. Exploration was always rewarded and the unyielding need to survive that drove me again and again outside the "safe" confines of my base and in the forest produced emotions that I have never experienced in a game and memories of travel, fighting, desperation, looting, surprise, mystery and fear that I will never forget. The pacing was PERFECT. I have never played and finished a game that has left me, immediately, wanting to go back in the way the forest did. I can't believe I found and finished this game with Sons of the Forest dropping in a month or two. I cannot wait.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 18 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

When I got the survival fever, I tried many games from this genre and The Forest was still in early access, I had good memories and decided to play it again after its release from EA and eventually try the coop mode too. I have to say there are improvements but I had better memories, nonetheless it was still an enjoyable games with its pro. But nevermind my memories and let's check the best and worst features of this nice game.


[b][u]PROS[/u][/b]
[list]

[*][u]STORY[/u]: Usually I prefer survivals without a true story to make the game never-ending, I was surprised to acknowledge there's a game ending. Anyway the story is interesting, how we got into the forest and how we will eventually leave. The story could be expanded a lot more, but I appreciated the reasons behind the setting.

[*][u]GRAPHICS[/u]: Despite not so fresh, it has a decent graphics, perhaps not very well optimized at max details.

[*][u]COOP[/u]: I love coops in survival games! This one is decent and enjoyable, although it adds some bugs

[*][u]AI[/u]: Enemies have an interesting AI, they won't attack you straight, but study you instead: attack, retreat, react and interact with you and your constructions. Actually I enjoyed to study my enemies for minutes, until one of us would flee and ignore.

[*][u]MODES[/u]: Besides classic difficulties, there is a creative and pacifist mode, interesting to replay it in a different way.

[*][u]ACHIEVEMENTS[/u]: Achievements are good and possible, although a bit bugged. I had some fun hunting them but some were time consuming.

[/list]


[b][u]CONS[/u][/b]
[list]

[*][u]BUGS[/u]: Despite working decently, I encountered a generous amount of bugs, although I couldn't write them all down. The sledge can make you sky rocket in the air, creepy armore disappeared after loading a saved game a few times, interacting keys have wrong distance, sleep time was bugged and messed the day/night cycle, coop had quite some sync bugs too, some achievements are bugged and won't show up until a game restart, gooses look very bad and most of times lose their interaction once they are killed.

[*][u]ENEMY ATTACKS[/u]: You can easily encounter enemies while roaming, but after some time they will look for you and attack your base. That would be fine, if there weren't days I had to deal with their attacks everyday and play the game for two hours straight just to defend my base. When you finish the day with 15 corpses without sticking your nose outside your base, it becomes annoying, when it happens for more days in a row, it becomes frustrating, especially when playing with normal difficulty. Base attacks should be rebalanced, at least for single player.

[*][u]CAVES[/u]: This should be one of the most interesting features of the game: you must explore caves to advance the story and get some nice rewards and tools. Too bad Caves were so annoying, way too dark and mazy (even with a map), some very big. Whenever I had to explore one, I almost felt like playing anything else.

[*][u]CRYPTIC[/u]: You need to reach certain places and collect certain hidden objects to advance the story, if I didn't know the existence and the need for these, I don't think I could have done it in a blind run. I think some of them are way too hard to be found.

[*][u]REPETITIVE[/u]: Due to its setting, the game starts to get a bit repetitive too soon. Even with different biomes, you will feel like doing the same over and over, with no chances of changes.

[*][u]PRICE[/u]: Easily found with a very good discount, I think it's worth the money for a try!

[/list]

Final word: A very interesting survival that will glue you to the seat until you manage to find its bugs and repetitiveness, but if you like the genre, it won't let you down for giving it a chance. Recommended for its low price on discount and the positive experience after all.

Negative points:

First of all I would like to say that I LOVE The Forest. It has everything a survival horror game needs! Everything this game has done is ALMOST perfect, there is a few flaws in my own opinion that I will get to soon but first I want to praise this game. The Forest has a lot of things you can do and will keep you busy for a good little while!

The Pros:
Collectables - Timmy's drawings, the flintlock pistol, cassette tapes, camcorder tapes and much much more!! 

The Combat system - As you play the forest you will come across "Cannibals", among other things, that will try and kill you. The way they fight is pretty unique to me for a game made in 2017. They can climb trees, leap at you and throw "FIRE" at you. All your character does is swing left and right with a weapon, sadly but its done really well.

The Crafting system - Almost everything you find in The Forest can be put to good use. From flowers, to make healing salves, to sicks and stones, to make tools and weapons. It has alot more items you can craft and it is pretty extensive.

Survival Horror - The "light" little jump scares going in and out of a cave from bats, the cannibals screaming and shouting in pitch black caves, the complete and utter feeling of loneliness when exploring (if your playing solo). 

Base Building - I like to take base building to the next level and overbuild and to have that in The Forest.... I loved it! You can build almost anywhere you want. 

Enemy Variety - The game has a decent amount of different enemies, "Cannibals"/"Mutants". This one is a bit hard for me to enjoy as they seem copy and pasted but with different "Paints" and "weapons". The mutants however are indeed unique.


The Cons - AKA The things I thought could have been done better:
The lack of building options - There is almost next to no diversity in build options. You can build a "Custom" house with "Custom" walls, floors and a roof - ok this might seem good but listen - after you build your floor and walls you want to make your roof, right? After you build it you realise that there are huge holes to be filled up. You have got to be REALLY creative to fill these by MESHING "Custom walls" E.T.C to fill them up. 

Flares/Flare gun/Lighting - The amount of light that the flare and flare gun gives you is VERY disappointing. Flares - Pitch black cave, lights a flare, next to NO light given. Flare gun - pitch black night, fires flare gun in sky, next to no light given. The lighter and flash light are much better than these. Very disappointed in the lighting of this.

Base destruction - This one is  strange to me. So the devs allow the cannibals to destroy your base, right. The cannibals can climb trees, right. The can destroy "GROUND BASES" but the cannot, and i mean this, CANNOT destroy a measly treehouse. What the hell...


TL;DR/Outcome:
All in all, The Forest is a great survival horror game that has definitely peaked. I would recommend this game to anyone that is wanting a solid survival horror experience, solo or multiplayer. I would rate it a solid 9/10. Would have been a 10/10 if it had just a little bit more of a better building system and actually had worked on the "Flare gun" and "Flares".

What can I say, this game is a really excellent game, almost a masterpiece in my opinion. The Forest is a game that has all the essential principles of a really excellent game, a mysterious location, a simple undertaking becoming a much larger and more daunting task as it progresses, and a variety of things to do in the game.

The Forest is an open world survival horror and exploration game with prominent sandbox elements such as building. It opens up with you in a plane crash and your child being taken by some creepy red man. Retrieving your child is the primary objective, but as you continue through the game you begin to realize that it is more complicated than that, and that something big going on around this peninsula. You will spend the majority of the game learning about the world and building shelters and killing cannibals that roam the peninsula. 

The gameplay is simple but very fun and effective, building a house in the game can be done with virtually any way you want, you can use a prefab house or just lay a floor plan from scratch and build walls around it. Obtaining resources in the game is interesting, for most equipment items or pieces of furniture you need to hunt animals, there are different kinds of animals around the peninsula that you'll need to travel to find. The game has caves which are the main ways of obtaining special resources like soda, snacks, dynamite, etc. the caves respawn any special loot like this upon exit and re-entry, so you can grind, though it is usually not necessary or time-efficient.

The story of the Forest is presented in a very interesting way. In terms of direct story, there's very little, not much is really told to you outright until near the end of the game, however, the implied and greater story is much more in-depth. The story is out there on youtube, and i'd recommend watching some videos once you've completed the game because it is quite interesting.

Now for my issues:

The game is very janky, it is to be expected with an indie studio but it certainly is quite janky, especially in multiplayer. The animations are wonky and feel kind of machinelike, the cannibals are animated pretty well, though sometimes their movements seem too fast and hectic even for them. The combat is a little weak too, sometimes the combat can seem very unfair, and if you aren't prepared enough, your entire base can be completely torn apart in moments, especially early game. The cannibals have very little indication of how healthy they are, sometimes you'll knock them around for quite some time and they don't really seem to be changing in behavior until they suddenly just drop dead, whereas sometimes you'll get hit just a few times and be down immediately. However, these are the main complaints, almost everything else is workable and will certainly be improved up in the sequel.

This game is so much fun, especially in multiplayer and I am more hyped for Son of The Forest than I have been hyped for almost any game in the past several years. I would definitely recommend this to anyone who loves survival and sandbox games.
