The Forest is from about the same time as Subnautica, Green Hell, and The Long Dark and also has crafting and survival aspects. But in contrast to the other games, The Forest is very combat-heavy and wants to be a horror game. 
- Resource management (hunger, water) is only a minor aspect; 
- Items don't break due to usage
- Orientation is aided by a map featuring a live location marker (so you can't get lost);
- Sleep progresses time (if you sleep at the wrong time you end up awake at night with no visibility of your surroundings and have to wait until sunrise), you can skip sleeping altogether;
- The only resource you need to manage is your health. 
You will be (constantly) fighting a handful of enemy types in one of the numerous caves or above the ground.
While you can clear out the caves, there is an endless respawn of enemies above the ground. Enemy camps for taking out are absent. Which makes me wonder, where do they hatch?
As the combat is not rewarding and you can easily stun lock most of the enemies, this gets old fast, and encountering enemies becomes annoying. The only danger is becoming swarmed by multiple groups of enemies. You are a badass with many weapons and a pro in crafting stuff ;)

The crafting aspects (base building and equipment/items) are well done considering the age of the game.

Why no thumbs up? I expect some immersion; this one does not provide.
Here is why: 
The abundance of everything due to the constant respawn of consumables, crafting components, wildlife, and enemies breaks it for me. For example, when spearfishing in a tiny pond, fish can simply respawn at the exact same spot where you just pulled out a fish; same applies for game (deer, boars, squirrels, etc.); you can even hunt birds with your spear as many don't take off as you get close.
The game showers you with canned beverages and packaged food, so you hardly have to hunt for animals or craft a water skin. Maybe this is better balanced on a higher difficulty, but I can't bring myself to restart the game on hard.
More questionable design choices: you can craft warm clothing to prevent freezing once you go to the snow biome (~5% of the map). You can also go there without warm clothing, as freezing only drains your energy and gives no real penalty. To top it off, you have no incentive to venture into this area in the first place. It's completely pointless.
In caves, some sections can be accessed only after destroying a wooden wall, those walls apparently also respawn. 
Cannibals, although inhabiting the caves, cannot climb the numerous (and partially ridiculously long ropes) and easily get stuck on corners. So if you feel like it, you can safely kill them from a distance in many cases.
The story is basically non existant. Your journal gives you a to-do list with no explanation why. From time to time, you find some pictures that don't give any explanation either. Apart from a corrupted save, I did not encounter any major bugs.
It's got the atmosphere of all your favourite horror flicks. Staggering around in dark caves avoiding what lurks in the shadows. This game actually gave me goosebumps.

I thought it was not enjoyable because I was playing it on a high difficulty when I prefer hard games. Then I tried it on normal difficulty. Do not recommend because this game is not interesting for someone who pursued the game because it advertised some sort of story. This is a game centred on survival for the sake of survival, rather than some more interesting purpose of escaping the planet as in Subnautica. There is little direction in what you are supposed to do, which may be attractive for some, but when I am making my third trap while branching reasonably far from my camp without anything happening aside from encountering another lizard (on my new game apparently I had to build very specific shelters to unlock cannibals rather than my larger shelters and fires since I had experience) or finding myself dangling on the ceiling of some cave for the fifth time with the same cutscene, I understandably got bored. While I understand that the goal is to explore the caves, find Timmy, and perhaps learn of some mystery, there is little motivating me to do any of this. There is further little to the caves. While there are eventually body horrors, of which mine disappeared because I retreated for a short bit, a good game needs a hook early on with additional impetus to keep me moving forward. I don't need much because I enjoyed Subnautica, but the problem I had with this game is that it did not give me something interesting to keep me moving forward. It quickly became apparent that crafting was extremely limited in scope. The cannibals became just another obstacle. Survival mechanics became just another thing that could be done. Caves were just another reason to battle cannibals, except this time in the dark. While some may argue that the game gets better as you play it, I am not going to waste my time waiting for it to get good. I gave it another chance after initially writing this critical review, and while exploring the caves made it somewhat interesting again, there was no payoff after getting through my first one. I see no reason to continue it and would caution players looking for a game that makes the best use of their time.

TL;DR: It's mediocre. The forest tries to be both a horror-walking-sim and a survival-crafting game at the same time and fails at both. If you wanna buy it, read the entire review before you do.

The game looks like an open world crafting-survival game. And yes.. it has these elements. But to my surprise, i learned that they are all optional and don't progress the game in any way. If you wanna finish the game, there is no need to build a base, hunt animals or craft items. Turns out you spend most of your time walking through cave systems. Could be fun, right? Well it's not. The caves are so dark that you can hardly see where you're going (even WITH the lamp). They are designed badly, the engine is NOT suited to rendering light enclosed spaces and the occasional fights quickly become boring because the enemy AI is so dumb that they pose more of an annoyance than a challenge. Not that the sluggish and slow combat system would make fighting them fun anyway. You crawl your way through seven (!) huge cave systems, they all look the same, most of them take over an hour and all of them are soul crushingly boring. Their sole purpose is to have you find key items needed for the storyline. And if you miss one.. haha.. good luck going through ALL of it again to search for that sucker. You also find all your best items in the game in the caves. Why again can i craft items if all endgame gear is just lying on the ground? Nevermind..

Look.. it's not like exploring cave systems couldn't be fun in a game. But not if it's done like this. So you could just ignore the story and use this game only for the base building and crafting aspects, right? Well.. yeah.. but survival simply isn't a challenge. What about suriving against the cannibal raiders? Unfortunately they offer no challenge either. They just run against the walls of your base, occasionally fleeing and then running into your walls again. You know the zombies in minecraft? Yup. They have better pathing and better AI.

So is the forest any good? In my opinion.. no. If you want a good horror game you can just play Amnesia: The dark descent or Outlast. If you wanna craft and build.. get minecraft. Factorio. Satisfactory. Or any of the other games where survival and crafting isn't an optional feature but a the center focus of the game.

The Forest is one of these games that were doomed from the start because the entire concept of the game, the choice of engine and the games design simply do not align. It's a mix of different visions, ideas and features that do not form a coherent whole. And the resulting mess is fun.. but only for a dozen hours or so. Which isn't enough for this games pricetag imo.

The Forest is a refreshing take on survival horror game genre. Unlike most horror survival games, The Forest manages to be legitimately terrifying whether it be due to the disgustingly realistic creature designs, the smart AI on the cannibals of the island that make you feel like you're always being watched, or the generally eerie tone of the story. Nothing in this game is quite as horrifying as realizing that the cannibals are just watching your every move, silently. While the story is lackluster until the end and the survival elements are an afterthought after the first couple of days, The Forest is a game that should be in everyone's steam library as its a game that is both great for single and multiplayer fun.

I made a severe and continuous lapse in my judgement, and I don‚Äôt expect to be forgiven. I‚Äôm simply here to apologise.
What we came across in the woods that day was obviously unplanned. The reactions you saw on tape were raw; they were unfiltered. None of us knew how to react or how to feel. I should have never posted the video. I should have put the cameras down and stopped recording what we were going through. There's a lot of things I should have done differently but I didn't. And for that, from the bottom of my heart, I am sorry. I want to apologise to the internet. I want to apologise to anyone who has seen the video. I want to apologise to anyone who has been affected or touched by mental illness, or depression, or suicide. But most importantly I want to apologise to the victim and his family. For my fans who are defending my actions, please don't. I don‚Äôt deserve to be defended. My goal with my content is always to entertain; to push the boundaries, to be all-inclusive. In the world live in, I share almost everything I do. The intent is never to be heartless, cruel, or malicious. Like I said I made a huge mistake. I don‚Äôt expect to be forgiven, I‚Äôm just here to apologise. I'm ashamed of myself. I‚Äôm disappointed in myself. And I promise to be better. I will be better. Thank you.

The Forest is an open world survival horror video game developed and published by Endnight Games. The game takes place on a remote, heavily forested peninsula where the player character wakes up after a plane crash. The player is then left to survive in the wilderness, facing many dangers such as starvation, dehydration, hypothermia, wild animals, and cannibals. 

The Forest is an excellent survival horror game that offers a unique and harrowing experience. The game's open world design allows players to explore and survive in a variety of ways, and the many dangers present in the game provide a sense of tension and suspense. The game's graphics are stunning and the sound design is incredibly atmospheric, making The Forest a truly immersive experience. 

However, The Forest can be a bit challenging at times, and the player may need to put in a bit of extra effort to survive. Additionally, the game does not offer much in the way of guidance, so players may need to do some research outside of the game in order to progress. Overall, The Forest is a great survival horror game that offers a unique and challenging experience.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

The game itself is fun and I really enjoy the randomness of the enemies and the story. However, the game feels like it is still in early access. I bought this game in 2022 and bugs back from 2018 don't seem to be fixed. There are many of them, which makes the game annoying at times. They are not visual bugs either, for example I keep getting launched into the air when using log sled and losing my health for no reason. Same thing happened to the person I was playing with. The log sleds also keep clipping through the floor, making them unusuable until you fill them up with logs again, which seems to fix the problem. Once I fell through the map when entering the caves and had to load from early save. The building mode is really, really annoying. I bought it on 50% sale and it is not worth the full price in my opinion.

You play as a survivor of a plane crash, who just saw your son being taken away by some strange man painted in red. You soon find out that you are stranded in an island, that there are canibals, and that you can build a gazebo, because, priorities.

The game doesn't "tell" you the plotline, they provide some hints instead, which I found really refreshing. The fanbase connected the dots however, and the "clear" story can be found online. You wont get any objective besides "Find Timmy", your son, but you start getting new TODOs as you keep exploring the island.

The horror elements are GREAT! I got liters of adrenaline from canibals SCREAMING and chasing me when I least expected. The fighting is kinda one-dimensional but I think this is good - this is NOT an action game and most of the time you're grossly outnumbered. The survival aspect is good: you have to eat, drink and can get sick/poisoned.

Sadly, it is almost impossible to build something straight, everything gets skewed. Also most of blueprints are nothing but decoration - I wish they had some kind of purpose instead. I also wish I could do more with the herbs.

Achievements are great (except "Dont Save the Forest") but can get glitched. No Linux port but worked flawlessly with Proton - thanks Valve!

I am reviewing my single player experience. There's a good reason this game gets very good ratings. You cannot really say anything against this very well constructed and original game. I have never played a game that feels like this one, it captures the castaway vibe to phenomenal effect. You will be taken on a gritty, maddening adventure/exploration (depending how you play I guess). The graphics are overall nice. Now for the criticism: this game is a grind and can be frustrating. The objectives are quite unclear and you better hope you have a good working memory (or access to some kind of online guide if you want to have your life back). While this actually plays in favour of the game, I am just writing this as a warning. Another thing is that the game does not seem very well optimised at times. I initially had to switch to low settings and then to medium. The game is quirky, dark (to say the least) and grotesque if you actually try to finish it. That said, you can just play it sandbox style and avoid most of the traumatising exploration I guess. I finished the game with a bit of rushing in 26 hours. The ending was fairly dissatisfying for me. Happy to finally uninstall. The enemies are quite difficult on normal, especially if you are not well prepared. 8/10.

Low QoL survival game, requires high time investment or watching guides to progress as the game will not hold your hand on this picnic trip to the local park.
Low vertical freedom of movement = no climbing any cliff or wall you run into, other than some specific walls with a tool in late game.
Average building system, no height adjustment by scrolling or grids to snap to, only cursor guided and rotated.
Inventory UI is something you will likely only see in this game alone, i'd prefer that as its novelty wore off after a while.

Dont jump in if you have been spoiled by other sandbox survival/building games, due respect to those who are willing to trudge the grind to prosper in the forest.

Where Valheim takes classic open world survivals like minecraft, and adds a hint of hidden story, The Forest takes the next step giving the player a push towards a story. Its still open world, albeit not to the scale of the previous games mentioned, with an interesting and fresh take on crafting. The beauty is in the discovery of what has happened to you, the island, and its other inhabitants. I thought this was going to be a horror game, and it is not, which is good. It is still however stealth fueled as combat can be overwhelming both by number and difficulty of enemies. I cant wait for the sequel.

Game is a hot mess and I don't understand where all of these positive reviews are coming from. I bought this game on sale to be a fun game to play with my partners after work and it's not worth the 15$ (5$ each) I paid for all of us.

This game was made in 2014 and is extremely buggy and poorly optimized. Even on the lowest of settings it makes my higher end computer burn hot and this is coming from someone who plays a lot of high optimization survival games like Ark and Conan Exiles with no issues.

When you start the game you start with being on a plane that suddenly crashes in "The Forest." The game right off the bat doesn't do a good job at explaining your goals. You begin with a survival guide with a todo list that is glitched and doesn't always tick off your progress. (I cannot tell you how many times I made almost every type of shelter and couldn't get "set up camp" to tick off. Despite looking up on the Wiki what type of buildings I needed to build.) At the bottom of your screen you'll get notices saying your todo list has been updated with new goals, just for the guide to show blank when you open it. On normal difficulty it only takes two days before enemies will swarm your camp to the point of being annoying and besides "finding Timmy" (or just finding something else to do once you've set up) there isn't any reasons to leave the base you've built.

Your hunger and thirst go down rapidly and the stamina limiter is very harsh. Saving is only reserved for the host of the game and if they lose connection, several hours of progress can be wasted and the last time I played, I had it force me to start a new character when rejoining because the save file glitched.

I don't recommend this game and I would refund it if I could but instead I'm just going to remove it from my account.

I had a wonderful OBZH teacher at school. He taught me how to determine the side of the world by the moss on the trees, how to make a dwelling when there is an impenetrable thicket around; how to find food for myself... I managed to put something into practice, once getting lost with a full body of mushrooms in the forest.

But many years later, after playing alpha The Forest, I realized ‚Äî it's all wrong.


Lesson #1: Don't leave things unattended
You are not alone. Even in outer space, you are not alone ‚Äî let alone a huge island. It is worth going a little deeper into the thicket, and there will be crowds of rabbits and lizards around you. They crawl up trees and get in the way. They step into snares and traps, go under the axe themselves and even climb into the fire of your campfire. But don't let them fool you! It is worth gaping, and your life will hang by a thread: here you have thrown a raw carcass on the fire, but it has already been dragged away by an evil animal ‚Äî to eat or, what the hell is not joking, to bury. In any case, lunch can't be returned. That's an extra half minute of cooking!

Lesson #2: Finish what you started faster
The cruel world of The Forest knows no half measures. Do you want to light a fire, build a hut or set a trap? Climb into the survival guide, choose the desired item ‚Äî and first of all put its layout. Then you will carry everything you need to him.
And it's very convenient. However, no matter how many boards you insert into the fence ‚Äî until it is assembled, it does not exist. Even through the inserted boards, you can safely pass, which the owners of the island will be happy to take advantage of.

Lesson #3: Beware of the locals, they don't like you
They really do. But not in its raw form ‚Äî which automatically leads to conflict. Cannibals are the main and at the moment almost the only problem in The Forest. Do you want them not to find you? You can hide in some miniature cave, swim away to a broken yacht or wall yourself up in four walls. Otherwise, you will have to meet guests.
Local people walk in small groups of three or four individuals. But the longer you sit in one place, the more often you will be visited. Don't be surprised if you see about twelve hungry savages in one frame, say, in the dead of night. If you manage to survive such an invasion, then the whole coast will be littered with bodies ‚Äî but do not think that this will scare the others away.

Lesson #4: take advantage of the stupidity of the enemy
A long stay on the island leaves an imprint on a person. Firstly, the island people are short-sighted. Their eyesight is so unimportant that they will only see you at point blank range during the day. And the hearing is so lousy that they can pass by while you are chopping down a thick tree.
Perhaps the excess of human flesh in the diet is to blame. However, a healthy lifestyle makes cannibals incredibly tenacious. A blow to the head with an axe is not an argument for them ‚Äî it will take a long and tedious beating. And at any moment, the bully can run away and disappear into the forest thicket. Catching up with the scoundrel is not easy. And the devil knows if he'll come back or not! Most likely, he will return. It is possible that even with friends.
The intelligence of the local population is generally ambiguous. Having received a butt on the forehead, they keep their distance, try to come to your rear, wait for a convenient moment. At the same time, the psyche of cannibals leaves much to be desired. Like the little children from Lord of the Flies, savages put their heads on spikes everywhere, and in battle they can get carried away and run straight into a burning fire. They also like to rest their heads against the fence ‚Äî it looks especially pitiful when a naked man tries to escape. It beats against the wall like a moth against a window pane.

Lesson #5: Don't eat everything
Rabbits with lizards are, of course, nutritious. Chocolate bars and other junk food from chests that fell from the sky, too. They take up space in the stomach and restore energy (drinks do not clog the stomach). Good food can also replenish health, and reptile skins go to clothes and give additional protection from savage axes. There are mushrooms and berries in the game, both useful and poisonous. It is not difficult to distinguish one from the other ‚Äî "bad" berries will clog the stomach, but they will take away health. And the hero unequivocally groans.

And something can not be eaten in principle. The hero will not dare to shove raw meat into his mouth. Corpses of birds, sharks and turtles should not be touched at all. But most of all questions are caused by the mortal bodies of people. Completely inedible. Why? It's not entirely clear. They look very appetizing!

Lesson #6: Don't be too afraid of hunger
You can not keep crumbs in your mouth for at least two weeks ‚Äî and you will survive everything. Well, yes, you can't wave an axe on an empty stomach, and you can't escape or fight off cannibals. But you are not in danger of starvation. Perhaps the fresh sea air is so useful that it can feed and, most importantly, give the newly‚Äîborn Robinson Crusoe a drink. After all, water is not needed here at all. It would seem that the main concern of the islander is to arrange the supply of fresh, otherwise hello, dehydration! But no, it's all nonsense, we have enough rabbits with berries.

Lesson #7: Don't be afraid to die
If you stumble, get burned or take second place in a duel with a savage, life will not end there. Wherever you die, they will find you and drag you to the nearest cave, and there are a lot of them on the island. Why ‚Äî history is silent. But you can get out of the cave and run away wherever you look. However, the second time the number will not pass ‚Äî "you survived N days".

There's glitches, but all in all it's nice to play with your friends.

Some good and bad points about this game. 
The Good - It's atmospheric, the base designs near the end are good, the storyline isn't bad, game play is pretty good.

The Bad - There's no sort of tutorial or easing your way into the game, you crash, you're in the forest and you're on your own. I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

The forest desktop is extremely fun, and I love playing it with my friends, it can be buggy at times as there are a lot of glitches, but most of them are fixable, funny, or useful. But this review is going to be about the forest VR.
When I first tried the forest in vr, i did not like it that much (i have been spoiled by top tier VR games like HLA, boneworks, TWDSS so i was used to a lot of other things). I could not figure out how to turn on smooth turn and it got boring kind of quickly. (I was playing alone too, and i was very new to the forest as a whole). I ended up figuring out how to do smooth turn (set the snap turn thing to 0). But after I tried playing it with a bunch of my friends who recently got the forest (they only do desktop I am the only one with a VR headset) i decided to try to play it in VR with them. It is actually super fun to play when you are playing with friends and focusing on other things that what might be wrong with the game. One plus is that the flashlight is actually GOOD when in VR. Also you can cut trees and enemies super fast without stamina use. For a game that was not built for VR, it actually has amazing VR support. Anyways thats my review for the forest VR
very fun only better with friends

Truly a masterpiece of a horror survival game. The games exploration and atmosphere in the dense woods and claustrophobic caves are just the most greatest experience ever. It truly feels like danger with either all the darkness in the cave or with the dense forest and screaming of enemies. The enemies designes are truly horrific and just ugly that they give you chills just by looking at them. The unholy mess of flesh on the is truly something from a flesh nightmare. The Survival mechanic's are also great with some good crafting and building. The story was good for a survival game with all the mysteries.¬¥I cant wait for the second game where i can fight those fleshy abominations with a 12g shotgun while exploring a new atmosphere full world in the Sons Of The Forest.

The game is slightly unpolished, but an overall solid experience.  You feel stronger as you progress. The survival elements seem well balanced. The story arc while vague does reach a satisfying conclusion while leaving it open to the sequel to delve further into the lore.  The game does feel like some elements were cut from the final product. But that's inconsequential as the rest of the content is packaged well.
I like it but there are some weird persistent bugs I'd like to see fixed, especially in the way of not being able to see my teammates nametag or logos for home sites, markers etc

[b] The Forest: The most helpful review [/b]

[h1] GAMEPLAY [/h1]
the gameplay in the forest is actually quite scary and fun. the best part is not even the exploring part but the building part. 
i really appreciate the game for not giving you a compass and a map right away; this makes you use marks to identify your direction such as the sun and moon or the north mountain. caves are pretty scary and dark and the cannibals seem to be coming from no where. despite all of these positive points, there are lots of bugs and exploits such as building your base next to the plane to get infinite food every time you log in to your save. 8/10 gameplay

[h1] COMBAT [/h1]
this is arguably the worst thing about this game. the cannibals are literally the reincarnation of the hulk, they die for a shit-ton of swings. also the cannibals literally doge almost every swing. this game is supposed to be realistic but this is not realistic because how on earth did they learn to do that? actually, the one realistic thing about combat is how the layer violently swings the ax because they have not been trained for combat. 6/10 combat

[h1] Graphics [/h1]
there is not much to say about the graphics so this segment is going to be quick. the graphics hold pretty well today despite the game launching back 2014. graphics: 7/10

[h1] Verdict [/h1]
The game is really well made and i definitely recommend this game especially when it's on sale. The game is way more fun in multiplayer and absolutely less scary. i didn't mention the story but it's not bad especially for a survival game. i don't think the game deserves an overwhelmingly positive reviews(no hate tho) verdict: 8.5/10

Still haven't beaten this one, but so far I like the mix of exploration, survival and being deeply unsettled by what I find. Would've been nice if the tooltip for the "upgraded stick" said "you can use this as a torch" because I refused to go into any caves because I couldn't see in the dark.

Of course, given what I found IN the caves, I kinda think that maybe staying out might not have been a bad idea.
definitely recommend for those who wants to play survival game with friends. Not recommend for single player cause the content quit boring for single player

This game is more than worth the money. There is a lot to explore, build, and fight in this game. The enemies will keep you on the edge of your seat as you navigate the land and especially when you enter the caves. There is a bit of learning curve when it comes to crafting, but the game helps out in this area when you mouse over the cog wheel (it will show you what you can craft with the item and what other items are needed to craft it). Overall, I would highly recommend buying and playing this game!

That said I picked this up on sale for $5 bucks and for that kind of money it's a lot of fun, it's not a hardcore survival game but survival enough with horror that makes it fun and exciting especially with friends.

I'd definitely recommend picking it up if on sale.

I have fairly mixed feelings on this game. 60% good - 40% Not so good.

On the one hand, I really enjoyed  the survival gameplay and gathering of materials/resources. However the building system with structures could be a bit more polished. It's not bad, just a bit tedious with wall/building placements. I also think think the tool/item crafting menu needs to be a bit more organized and streamlined. It can be a bit overwhelming trying to figure out what combines with what. I also find favoriting an item to the 1-4 keys should be as simple as selecting the item and hitting "favorite". It's just a bit dumb with how you need to combine it with your backpack in the crafting menu. It really just comes down to a lot of unnecessary clicking.

Another thing this game does great though is its atmosphere. The dark and oppressive night cycle combined with the claustrophobic caves and murderous cannibals really sells that you're trapped with death clawing at you every chance it can. 

Overall, this game has a really solid foundation and premise that I think just needs to be ironed out a bit more for me to truly enjoy its full potential. the atmosphere and gathering of resources is a winning combination, but the lackluster inventory management and awkward building keep me from wanting to go on with the game. That being said, this game clearly has a strong following based on Steam reviews alone, so maybe my critiques aren't relevant. But this has just been my experience with the game and I figured any feedback would be helpful. I'm still going to recommend it to people, though. A game doesn't have to be perfect for it to be just fun enough.

I am a 44 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 12 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I've played a lot of survival crafting games. What can i say... On the highest graphics settings The Forest looks so ugly, that you might have suicidal thoughts, despite yours in-game Sanity level is still at max. Sound design is dumb, and AI is straight from the 8-bit era: enemies move primarily in one direction. There are a lot of unnecessary crafting and building which barely gives any advantage in the game...

Well, written above is some sort of being true, unless you you made it to the first cave in the game. After that you life would change forever. You will be haunted by the nightmares of unspeakable horrors of the Forest and by nightmares of you playing it. After that your main goal in life would be to finish this f*****g game as quickly as possible, to escape that madness. But no, even after watching all possible endings it will not be completely over. From time to time you will have those visions, flashbacks...

Conclusion is - while it has all those trashiness of indie game it's scary as hell, and it's overwhelmingly fun to play. I advise you play in coop. I've completed it with different people three times. At some point i felt like member of satanic cult pulling new innocent people into it. It's the best survival crafting game after ARK. That's it.

Cool game that doesn't outstay its welcome, looking at around 15 hours for the main story. 

It in the middle ground for building variety, you can build a base in the trees, on water and on land, you can build traps, temporary camps, decorations (I only dabbled in it a little as I played on normal, the base building was kind of pointless).

Love the AI system, it keeps you guessing with the enemies, makes for interesting combat (not seen anything like it before).

Had a few bugs when playing, but nothing that hindered gameplay:

Roped into a cave then ended up underneath the map, but it teleported me outside when I climbed back up the rope again (only happened once).
Minor stuttering when near my base for some reason??
When fighting enemies in caves, sometimes they get stuck on the surroundings

Overall a very good game, one of the best survivals I've played.

The only negative thing I can say about the game is that there was no save point past a certain area in the end level (I could have missed a save point or 2, but I feel like I fully explored the last level??).

I really don't understand what all that fuss for The Forest was about. I thought I would find a cool world to explore, rewarding base building and ressource collecting but i am really disappointed.

Technically the game feels like an alpha, the UI lacks information on many occasions and it does that thing all the time where you have to find the perfect pixel to aim at to interact with objects, which becomes quickly annoying. The game design is just sloppy.
The world feels so empty and unrewarding to explore. Compared to a Subnautica (which is awesome, go play that instead) for example you will almost never feel compelled by the discovery of a new environment. I explored most of the map and never found an interesting Point of Interest.
The caves have an interesting atmosphere very inspired by the movie The Descent but they feel soooo long and repetitive to explore. Sometimes you will think that you found a cool path that will lead maybe to a shortcut or a cool item but the game under delivers and disappoints once again.
The simplistic combat system makes every encounter frustrating and just not fun. 
Aesthetically i find The Forest to be bland at best. The game looks like it uses stock textures.

the survival and building can be grindy and boring at times, but the sense of achievement for some things and the mystery elements that climb to the story end make up for it big time. and the cannibals? well, they start off pretty scary at first, deliberately screwing with you, stalking and being a generally freaky lot to deal with, but they later just become a nuisance to spear to death and drop on top of fires when you run into them. the mutants are a different story however, with the real tension being hiding from groups of them shambling towards your camp, or going for the adrenaline rush of throwing molotovs and spearing them to death in what could be considered the most intense combat sections of the game. oh, and the caves are just straight-up nightmare fuel, don't even get me started.

would i recommend this game? yeah, if everyone i know didn't already know about it or has already played it. did i enjoy it? easy 6/10; it's really cool and fun, with a somewhat half-decent mystery buildup and the eventually full-on endgame part, but not one of my top favourites. getting to the end of the game was more of a relief that the amount of time i put into this actually got somewhere, for better or worse. i still kinda had fun though

The Hog Rider card is unlocked from the Spell Valley (Arena 5). He is a very fast building-targeting, melee troop with moderately high hitpoints and damage. He appears just like his Clash of Clans counterpart; a man with brown eyebrows, a beard, a mohawk, and a golden body piercing in his left ear who is riding a hog. A Hog Rider card costs 4 Elixir to deploy. Strategy His fast move speed can boost forward mini tanks like an Ice Golem in a push. At the same time, he can also function as a tank for lower hitpoint troops such as Goblins as he still has a fair amount of health. Most cheap swarms complement the Hog Rider well, as they are nearly as fast as him and usually force more than one card out of the opponent's hand. The Hog Rider struggles with swarms, as they can damage him down and defeat him quickly while obstructing his path. Barbarians in particular can fully counter him without very strict timing on the defender's part, though be wary of spells. A Hunter can kill the Hog Rider in 2 hits if placed right on top of it. However, if you place something in front of the Hog Rider, the Hunter's splash will damage the Hog Rider and hit the card in front of it more. The Hog Rider in conjunction with the Freeze can surprise the opponent and allow the Hog Rider to deal much more damage than anticipated, especially if the opponent's go-to counter is a swarm, or swarms are their only effective counter to him. Skeletons and Bats will immediately be defeated by the spell, while Spear Goblins, Goblins, and Minions will be at low enough health to be defeated by a follow up Zap or Giant Snowball. However, this strategy isn't very effective against buildings as the Hog Rider will take a while to destroy the building, giving the opponent ample time to articulate another counter. Against non-swarm troops, it can deal a lot of damage during the freeze time, but this can allow the opponent to set up a massive counterpush. For this reason, players should either only go for a Hog Rider + Freeze when they have other units backing it up from a counterattack, or if the match is about to end and they need to deal as much damage as possible. It is not a good idea to send in a Hog Rider simply to destroy a building, especially if it is the only building targeting unit available, as defeating Crown Towers becomes substantially more difficult. Spells or simply waiting out the lifetime of the building are more effective. The exception to this is an Elixir Collector placed in front of the King's Tower. If a Hog Rider placed at the bridge, he can destroy the Collector for a positive Elixir trade, though the damage from both Princess Towers will usually mean he does not survive to deal any damage to them. However, if the opponent sends in defending troops, it can be an opportunity to gain spell damage value. In a deck with several low-cost cards, it might be worth it to simply send the Hog Rider against one building. These decks shuffle their card rotation quick enough, that they will arrive to their next Hog Rider before the next building arrives in the opponent's card rotation. Long-ranged troops like Musketeer and Flying Machine can snipe those buildings, preserving some of the Hog Rider's health, possibly allowing it to get some Tower damage. When there are buildings placed in the middle to counter the Hog Rider, understanding the placement of the Hog Rider and the type of building placed can help the Hog Rider to bypass certain buildings. Passive buildings such as spawners and Elixir Collector have a larger hitbox than defensive buildings; which means that if a passive building was placed 3 tiles away from the river in the middle of the opponent's side, then it is impossible for the Hog Rider to bypass that placement as the Hog Rider will get pulled to that building. Defensive buildings have a smaller hitbox than a passive building, which means if that if a defensive building was placed three tiles away from the river in the middle of the opponent's side, a Hog Rider placed at the very left or right side of the Arena may be able to bypass it due to its smaller hitbox. If the player has a building already placed down in the center of the arena, and the opponent tries to bypass it with a Hog Rider at the edge of the arena, they can use certain air troops to push the Hog Rider towards the building as it jumps over the river, effectively denying the bypass attempt. They must be already hovering over the correct placement, as very quick reflexes are required to correctly perform this technique. For Bats, Skeleton Dragons, and Minion Horde, they should be placed right in front of the Hog Rider as soon as it is deployed. For Minions, Skeleton Barrel, Mega Minion, Flying Machine, Electro Dragon, Baby Dragon, Inferno Dragon, Balloon, and Lava Hound, stagger the above placement one tile to the right if the Hog Rider is placed on the left side of the arena, and vice versa. They can also use ground troops to achieve the same result. Something like an Ice Golem deployed at the Hog Rider‚Äôs landing spot will obstruct his path and force him to go around the unit, which causes him to be closer to the building instead of the Crown Tower. The Hog Rider can kite Very Fast non-building targeting troops due to his own Very Fast speed and building only targeting if he is placed on the fourth tile from the bridge, slightly into the opposite lane. He can also stall grounded units when placed right at the bridge. He will pull them towards him while deploying, and then be untargetable by them when he jumps over the bridge. After landing, he will pull them back. This can be useful when the player needs to deal damage in the same lane they are defending. It will also help separate troops behind a tank in a large push. A Tornado placed on the second tile front of the player's King's Tower and staggered two tiles towards the Princess Tower will activate it without any damage dealt to the Princess Tower, helping them in defending future pushes. This can also be a method of mitigating all damage dealt to a Princess Tower, but doing this more than three times may result in the King's Tower's health being low enough to be targeted directly, opening up the possible threat of a back door three crown. A better alternative is to pull the Hog away from the Princess Tower into the attacking range of all three Crown Towers, which will negate all damage as long as none of them are already distracted A very powerful combo is the Hog Rider, the Musketeer, and the Valkyrie, typically referred to as the Trifecta. The Musketeer will defend against most troops, while the Valkyrie can protect her and the Hog Rider from swarms or high damage units. The Hog Rider is used to deal damage to the tower. - [ ] This can be effectively countered by Lightning, one-shotting the Musketeer and severely damaging both the Valkyrie and Hog Rider. The Minion Horde is also effective, but the enemy can Zap them and the Musketeer will one-shot them all. Even if the Musketeer is defeated, the Hog Rider and Valkyrie will have enough time to severely damage the Tower. The Hog Rider should be placed behind the Valkyrie to give it a boost so that it stays in front of the Hog Rider, protecting it. A Hog Rider combined with a Goblin Barrel can be awkward for the opponent to defend against. Timing it so that the Hog Rider is tanking the tower shots for the Goblins is the most effective way to deal damage. However, a Barbarian Barrel can shut this down with minimal Tower damage for a positive Elixir trade, as long as the Goblin Barrel was placed directly on the Tower. Pairing the Hog Rider with the Balloon can deal devastating damage. If executed properly, the Hog Rider will act as a tank while the Balloon threatens to deal massive damage. The Hog Rider can also destroy any buildings attempting to slow down the combo. However, this combo is very vulnerable to swarms and anti-air cards as neither of the troops target anything but buildings.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week, he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character, and started playing but I was stuck on what I was supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Doesn't look like much when you walk past, but I was practically dying of hunger so I popped in. The definition of a hole-in-the-wall. I got the regular hamburger and wow...  there are no words. A classic burger done right. Crisp bun, juicy patty, stuffed with all the essentials (ketchup, shredded lettuce, tomato, and pickles). There's about a million options available between the menu board and wall full of specials, so it can get a little overwhelming, but you really can't go wrong. Not much else to say besides go see for yourself! You won't be disappointed.

OH MY GOD! I found my favorite survival game ever. I finished it in single player and now I am playing it with a friend. The story and atmosphere never gets old even if you have played it before. I recommend to play it in single player first so that you can experience the so called "true horror" and than you should invite friends. As i said the story is interesting and captivating, the island is beautifully crafted and the game design is great too. Enemies have AI unlike in any other game and the game can be scary even if you're not fighting. Sound design adds to the atmosphere too and the music just creeps in at the right moment. Only thing I have problem with is item spawning. It breaks the immersion at the start but you will get used to it. Overall it is one of the best games I have ever played and I recommend it to anyone who likes horror and survival/crafting games.

My honest opinions of The Forest. 

1.) I really like the building feature in this game. My friend and I will spend hours upon hours building cool bases to protect us from the hordes of cannibals.  The game also offers a bunch of gadgets that you can build on to your base such as Zip lines, Catapults, Defensive Spikes, and trophy's of dead mutants. 

2.) I think the map is huge and pretty beautiful. You have your wooded areas that contain, waterfalls, lakes, and abandoned cannibals camps. You also have your beach ares that usually have a lot of supplies scattered around, along with more cannibals camps. Then you have your mountain areas of which are littered with snow causing you character to freeze, unless you craft yourself a warm suit. That is a really cool feature that adds to the realism of a survival based game. Finally you have your caves which can usually be found is most areas. These caves are very dark and confusion sometimes. You will need to obtain some scuba gear if you plan on venturing deep into these caves. 

3.) I love/ hate the cannibals. The enemies in this game are none other than the hungry cannibals waiting to leap from the shadows. They usually hunt in packs of at least 4-5 and can be very elusive, and aggressive. But if swarms of angry, greasy cannibals weren't enough to rattle you. This game has mutated cannibals that are absolute bad asses. The most bad ass of them all is know as THE WORM!!! This thing is a base demolishing, dream crushing, time wasting, demon. You will spend real life days trying to make a ballin base, only to get stomped on by a giant worm that spreads itself around like an STD.
The best way to combat this monster is to have plenty of explosives, and or Molotovs.

4.) The combat in this game is 60/40 for me. Its pretty good until you accidentally try to do a charged up home run swing with your weapon causing you to miss, and get your ass kicked. Now maybe im just special but I really don't think i was trying to grand slam these fucking cannibals.

5.) i know its not realistic but i wish i had cross hairs on my bow or something. I'll admit that im not hawk eye but trying to hit these cannibals from long range with the bow is absolutely cheeks. 

Overall Rating : I give this game a 10/10 would recommend. Its fun by yourself, and with your friends.

This is a good survival horror game, worth playing if you like this genre. However, in my opinion, not at par with Valheim due to the following reasons (these are based on solo play at normal setting. Mild spoilers ahead):

1. The respawn rate is instant. If I leave a cave or an area and re-enter, the items like sticks, wristwatch etc will always reappear every time.  It defeats the purpose of searching or scavenging, which is the basis of a survival game. The respawn rate should be slower.

2. I can't hotkey the flashlight and the lighter separately. It's ridiculous to open the inventory every time just to switch use between them. Flashlight consumes batteries while lighter has unlimited use.

3. The lighter should consume some fuel from the red can. It shouldn't have infinite fuel, you know, for survival sake.

4. I fell off the cliff and died at the sinkhole. I reappeared in the same cave and hung upside down every time I die. Why the same cave? Why not other caves? I'm dead so I doubt the cannies will still hang me upside down. If this is so, then why the flight attendant still lies flat on the plane? She should be vertical too.

5. The melee fights and range attacks system are terrible. It's not smooth and thorough.

6. Near the crash site, I removed all the debris so that I can build my home and tidy it. After a day or two, all the debris decided to 'move themselves' back to the exact location as before, but this time in my new home!!

Other than those, I like the scenery, the dark caves and the crazy cannibals. It was refreshing to be killed by three homing babies who launched themselves at the same time towards me. Didn't see that coming in all the darkness.

FUN: Great
GAMEPLAY: Great
HORROR: Great
MUSIC: Great
SOUND/FX: Great
REALISM: Good
STORY: Good
VOICE/ACTORS: Good
EXECUTION: Great
QUALITY: Good

SUMMARY:
Solid horror, survival experience game. Game really makes you have to figure the mechanics out. Lots of exploring. Very difficult, even when playing on normal. The caves are nuts. Definitely recommend this game, and look forward to playing its sequel. 

ISSUES: 
No bugs or performance issues detected. 

CONCERNS:
Sometimes the world seems *a little* empty / not interactive. 
Armor gets destroyed very easily. 
Night time, its extra dark. 
Some resources are limited (ex: Pots, Flares, etc).
Too easy to damage / destroy your own stuff. 
Enemies are many, and very difficult, especially when starting out. 
Special tools are very difficult to find, even with Map.

Initially, The Forest wasn't something I could recommend to anybody due to the poor quality and limited amount of content during initial early access and the sequential updates. But after the reveal of a impending sequel, I figured few opportunities would be better to finally finish the game and fairly weigh it up as a completed product and experience anything new.

I was very pleasantly surprised to find a solid survival-crafting game with some interesting mechanics and a decent story as far as these style of games are concerned, not to mention full co-op story support so you can drag friends along to find out what exactly The Forrest has to offer.

This is one of those games that inspired new gameplay mechanics that then lead to rip-offs that are often pretty good themselves and well [u]Grounded.[/u]

Zelda games have the adventure gameplay mechanic of needing certain gear in order to proceed into areas that you have previously came across but couldn't continue unless you find the Grappling Hook, or Boomerang, or certain boots etc. This game also has that gameplay mechanic where you need a rebreather, or the climbing axe etc but you can also build and gather resources like a Survival game and defend your base with traps and walls etc.

If you're reading this then you already know this stuff but when you combine the right mechanics together you end up with a great game and this is one of them. I would recommend everyone who plays games to play this but maybe the gore and naked bodies might not tickle your fancy but for me that kinda makes me more driven to take the game a bit more serious like when I was a kid playing Doom back in the day and seeing hellish torture and gore as pixelated and cartoony as it may seem, especially nowadays. Can't wait for the sequel.

On one hand I understand the high score, it's survival, crafting and building game with an actual story. Except it also has quite a bit of bugs. In just 3 hours I encountered several including items (a pot) duplicating when the fire goes out and when loading a save the structure I made was suddenly moved a meter up in the sky. Lastly the developers don't seem active anymore, meaning these and many other bugs will simply never be fixed.

This game is just not fun. Most of your time seems spent either getting food or water with no time for doing anything else. It eventually eased after building a drying rack and gaining a turtle shell to collect water, but even then food and water management takes up a large portion of your time.

The game boasts building mechanics, but if you build anything, it attracts 'the locals' who take great umbrage and flatten it. I eventually gave up and looked online and the recommendations there are to either build on an island or to build 'minimilistically' to keep your footprint down. Where is the fun in that?

Indeed, all the advice on-line is that stealth is king and to keep moving. So if you like stealthy play and always being on the move, then this is the game for you. If you like to build a base/mansion/castle and forage out from there, don't bother, this is not the game for you. Buy/play Valheim instead, as it's more fun.

Oh, and the night cycle lasts for ages, absolute ages. You can sleep, but the forest re-grows whilst you do so, and if you like to build, then it's an absolute pain in the neck. The only way round it, is not to sleep. Leave the game running, tab out, go do something else, then come back when it's daylight again.

My game time is longer than the two hours recorded as I was playing off line, and it was on medium difficulty.

To quickly recap, if you like stealth shooter games then you might like this, if you like base building games or where base building is an integral part of the game, avoid.

This game has a large island to explore and a shockingly small amount of things to do. The gameplay loop of eat, gather, explore cave, repeat, gets old quickly. The base building and crafting is incredibly simplistic. Inventory management is a nightmare; by far the worst I've ever seen. The story is vague and confusing (although some people may enjoy its passive story telling style). The enemies have terrible AI, often running around in circles for no reason. Combat has some issues, but isn't completely terrible.
At the end, your payoff is about an hour of interesting content and then you're done.

I really don't get the fuzz about this game. It's exclusively fun with friends.

This game is filled with bugs, weird issues...

Cannibals just punch your walls down but okay, it's a small price to pay, would have been too hard to make something better.
Animals run away from you [i]some times[/i], and when they do, they can literally run inside the water. But hey, that's also too hard to do better, so we'll pass. Nevermind the map being static, they could have done some kind of boxes of where to not go, but hey, what do I know...
There's no crosshairs because throwable items go wherever they want on the screen, but always in the same exact direction so you can learn where to aim. Completely realistic, just like in real life, and not annoying at all.
Me and my friends just learned by playing how to make fire arrows and we just got on top of rocks to cheese the bosses. Just like we would in real life, so that's also realistic. Very well.
Picking up water with a cauldron... yeah good luck getting the exact pixel of where to get it before going completely mad. No, it's not that you can't pick certain water, it's probably just a bug since moving around a lake that looked like it had "uncollectable water" was just a mere troll, as my brother found the exact 2 cm of water where you could pick water (and the animation I did was facing inside so it looked like I picked sand, very realistic)

This game is the perfect example of a REALLY good idea with solid design, since at least it has some purpose and the crafting, etc. is well thought, being a fun experience. As for the technical part it completely got me off the immersion and we just did a mansion in the main camp to mog the cannibals.

And the framerate... lol, I'm gonna blame Unity for that one but I very well know I shouldn't.

9/10 design, 2/10 in the technical aspect. It should be a 5.5/10 but that's hardly recommended by me... Also, just like in SCP Pandemic a solid character controller doesn't make for an enjoyable game a solid design doesn't hide the fact this game is at times [b]very[/b] annoying to play.

I'll keep playing it to get to the end with a friend and my brother but, again, I don't get the fuzz.

I read the game description, I'm going to end up in a plane crash and have to survive. Okay. The game starts, I have a child. The child's name is Timmy. I didn't ask to parent a kid and would never name it Timmy, so sounds fake.
Turbulence, crash.
My mind goes "that escalated quickly" even though I knew I would crash. Oh wait, some person is dragging my kid away. Start exploring, find a camp with creepy heads and body parts, totally normal stuff. Find a water source and and roast some lizard over a fire, boom I'm surviving out chere. Third night some naked people attack me? I wake up in a cave, bodies everywhere, maybe a map, a bad drawing or two I exit the cave and go back to my camp
I open my backpack and see a photo of Tommy and two drawings maybe he drew? Kid seems traumatized based off the drawings.

So anyway, I started chopping trees.

The sap god protects all... Except from 6 legged mutant things, watch for those.

Really cool, I very much enjoyed my play through.

Except for one thing that really irked me.
We'd spent all this time building our cool base, full walls, spikes around the whole thing, traps at the entrances...
Then a couple big guys spawned and attacked, and destroyed it all. We had like half the walls left. Everything else was totalled.
Gave a weird feeling - do they want me to build a base or no? Cause the game plays like I have to protect the base more than it protects me.
From that moment, a bad taste was left in my and my co-op partners mouths, and we decided to go underground and just finish the story. We literally never needed to go back to the base. Food and water was plentiful in the caves.

Really weird. Hopefully the next one makes the base building actually somewhat necessary. You could play this game by just building the smallest shelter at the start then just doing the story.

This game was so fun and had so much replay value to me that I played it with a friend on Steam and a friend on PS4. There are a few little things I wished they improved like the aiming systems and picking things up, generally making the more mundane or precise things a bit easier, but I cannot deny it is fun to learn how to aim at something from far away. This game will definitely keep you on your toes, and I enjoyed the story.

Seeing that "Sons of the Forest", the sequel to this game, is coming out, I'd suggest picking this up to play through, so you are ready to play the sequel when it comes out.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

The Forest is mostly good. It's certainly a fun open world survival craft game with friends and can be a solid horror experience solo. The entire open world survival craft aspect is pretty excellent, especially compared to almost all the other games in this genre. There's tons of items to find and resources to gather and manage; as well as a large and detailed map to explore. I do like this game but there are some significant problems that should be pointed out. As a general rule of thumb you get what you pay for, and $5 was worth it but at $20 I'm not so sure.

Without any spoilers it has plenty of great elements but it still feels like an early access game even though it says it isn't; bugs and glitches are still fairly rampant and more than a few times they almost killed me and my drive to play the game. The game is missing some polish on fairly key elements like combat and world interaction. The game is also lacking a fair deal of instruction on mechanics that I found led me to looking at the wiki, which can be detrimental to the overall experience but necessary if you don't want to spend the first 3 hours getting ass-blasted over and over. Just a tiny bit more info would have helped this greatly. Also the in-game map you can find is not very accurate; some points on the map are off. Combat is 50/50. It's fun when you're stun locking enemies into a coma and trash when you're being stun locked into a coma. 

With SOME SPOILERS the story is rather lacking especially toward the end. It is very mysterious and cryptic at first, which leads you to push to learn more. But at a certain point you suddenly see where the story is going and the rest is very predictable. The game should really not be called the Forest since you spend comparably little time in the forest and instead most of your time in the caves. Also there are massive elements/sections of the game you can skip entirely and still beat it; the entire mountain section of the peninsula is pointless. Also enemy encounters in those caves are scripted, and will be the same enemies every time.

My biggest problem is that it still feels like early access but it isn't. If anything it feels like this whole game was a tech demo to lay the groundwork for The Forest 2 which they seemed to tease at the end of the story. I enjoyed this game for $5 but I'm very unsure of the replay value past the time I have spent, and I can't recommend the game to anyone but the most patient open world survival craft players out there. Maybe i will change to Recommended if the game gets some solid updates.

I'm hosting a game for a group of around 5 friends and we didn't realise that if someone exits the game before I save, their progress is lost. Okay, maybe we shouldn't have expected such an intuitive feature in the first place, but now that we know about this, we can at least deal with it and just save more frequently.

Anyway, we decide to go explore a cave again so that everyone can have their loot again. And everything goes just fine until we get to exit. I dive up first from the exit and wait for my friends - two of them crash, losing all progress made again. Sh*t.

Also, it's just a not a particularly interesting game after a few hours. There's only few enemy types, and killing the cannibals every fifteen minutes makes the combat boring. And as for the building, it's somewhat entertaining for a few hours while you're still figuring the system out, but the material gathering gets extremely tedious after a while, since you're mostly chopping trees. And because they're mostly made of wood and stone, don't expect much variety.

If you see this game go for 5 dollars and you don't have anything else to do with your time, maybe then consider buying it, but otherwise I can't recommend.

I hunt down cannibals with my nice bow and arrows. If there are too many, I shoot them from high up in my treehouses feeling safe and sound. Sometimes I burn them alive with molotoves and I burn their corpses again to get bones. I invade their territory, steal their items with my heads held high. I tried some of the caves to end the story, but I stopped because it was a little bit tiring to hunt cannibals - they also evolve and don't let me finish the story.

To be fair, I'd give a sideways thumb on this one if I could. I played with one other, and we enjoy playing coop survival games together. The reason I'm giving this a downvote, is that I feel it was pretty overrated.

The main game progression consists of going through caves to get necessary items to complete the game. The caves feel... pretty much the same. You run through, fight the same types of monsters (cannibals and a couple diffeerent types of mutants), and run around tediously looking for items to allow you to go to the next cave, etc. 

I did have enough curiosity to wanna finish the story, which was a more interesting part of the game. It's just that the gameplay was just hard to enjoy after a while.

We've played Valehim, Age of Conan, Raft, and more and I'd say this one ranks pretty low on my list (close to how I felt about Raft). By the way, I'm not speaking on behalf of my gaming partner, that seemed to enjoy the game more than I.

Genre: Open-World Survival Crafting Horror
Setting: An island. You're a survivor of a plane crash.

To do: Chop trees, gather plants, hunt animals, build camps, craft gear, explore dark caves, make friends with the local cannibals, pretend the mutants don't exist, look for other survivors along the way, and maybe more importantly find your son.

Tips / Guide: Loot the plane crash site and get out of there before night falls. You'll now have the axe, meds, food, drinks, alcohol, cloth,... Also gather stones, sticks, and leaves. Look up a map of the island online. The local cannibals have regular patrol routes. Build a hunting shelter and a firepit in a safe spot the cannibals don't patrol near. Save. It's actually safer to build more smaller camp sites spread across the island and run from place to place, than it is to building one big base, staying there and having to defend it endlessly from increasingly harder attacks. The patrols get larger as days go by. Nights are especially dangerous (and scary) as the cannibals will be looking for any fire light source. Craft a bow and arrows and/or a spear. Go hunt. Drink from puddles. Eat from bushes. Build some more shelters along the way. Craft the warmsuit armor, as it makes you immune to cold and wet. You're now prepared to explore the island, the cannibal villages, and the caves. Good luck on your adventure,... I mean your search for your son Timmy.

Why should you play this game? 1. there are TONS of weapons and tools in this game that can help you survive in The Forest. 2. mechanics like blocking attacks can help you survive against most of these horrifying monsters that are in The Forest. 3. most of the time when you start a new multiplayer game you will meet new people. before i started playing The Forest, i have only 2 friends. after playing The Forest, i have over at least 10 friends now!! 4. molotovs and fire everywhere.

This game has remained somewhat of a classic for me over the years. I've played it many times for hours on an end and beaten it every way you can imagine. Whether you want to just have a good old adventure in the forest without cannibals, or you want to basically commit war crimes - this is the game for you!

What a boring, monotonous game.  Explore for 5 minutes -- get hungry  and thirsty.  Find a way to gather things to satisfy those urges.  Explore for 5 minutes, become nervous that daylight is burning and need to build shelter and/or return to camp before night (as good luck doing anything productive at night).  Possibly explore for 5 more minutes before becoming hungry and thirsty again.  Rinse and repeat.

From other reviews, it seems like others have enjoyed it, so to each their own -- but not for this guy.
he has the best game of my life

its ok but boring unless you have alot of friends in which i dont
Great atmosphere, I love eating families <¬£¬£

it's just too difficult. impossible to find water, you're literally IN WATER and you can't drink it, there is a tiny spot within a couple of lakes where it allows you to drink, nowhere else. you're always dying of thirst. it's difficult to kill animals for food, but if you do, it doesn't cure "health" loss, just hunger. it's almost impossible to cure health once you've used up the little bit of free meds. aloe vera restores only a tiny bit of health, you can only plant one tiny plant in your garden and it takes a long time to grow, and if you're out exploring, that's not gonna do you any good anyway.

then there's the monsters. just constantly attacking and way stronger than you. even on "normal" mode. there isn't an "easy" mode, normal is the easiest. and it isn't easy at all. even with friends this game is mostly just frustrating, and not very fun. the "survival" idea is okay, but the monsters ruin it, and yet the world would get boring fast if you turn off the monster mode and all you do is survive.
NGL, but I think I am in a forest.

Ah the Forest
what can I say about the forest?
This game is very very fun, I've finished it a few times now
the story isn't the most compelling and the physics can be wacky at times but my FPS survival game loving heart cant recommend the game enough
every time I've played this its been with a friend and honestly, working together to beat up cannibals while trying to build a fort is a great bonding experience
especially if they're going into the game blind and have no idea what to expect
all-in-all I would say if you're looking for a chaotic game to play with a friend or two, this one may just be what you need
i only been playing it for one day and im scared a little kid asked me if he could skin my family then when i said yes AS A JOKE he said what state i live in

The Forest I'd say was probably one of first games to introduce proper survival and realism. Over the years it has updated quite a bit but after that came Stranded Deep and Raft. Kind of more similar games. I love The Forest, I had gotten the game way back around 2015 - 17 and I have been loving playing the game ever since.
Probably one of the best survival games ive played, has lots of good horror element etc. Hopefully second game can live up to its expectations (hopefully its not security breach all over again).

I [b]DO NOT CARE[/b] about Timmy.
They actually did [i]me[/i] a favour by taking him off my hands.. I was finally free.
I chopped many trees, chopped (and ate) many people, and unintentionally fell down many holes.
And yet- Timmy haunted me.
His terrible drawings and scattered toy pieces served as a reminder that in order to finish this game and become a true gamer girl I probably had to locate my hideous offspring.
So, I persevered.
I found there to be a lot of lore thrown at me really quickly towards the end and the only thing I was truly excited about was when I found the connection between a cannibal island and my beloved orange 'sodi-pops'.
Other than that, the ending was mostly straight up disappointment.
[spoiler]I wish there had been a spot to save (maybe there was) before choosing an ending so I could live out my Timmy-free dreams, but I honestly thought I would get to go grab people from another downed plane, so I saved him.....:( .[/spoiler]

This is one of the best games I have ever played. It doesn't hold your hand and shove tutorial messages and icons in your face; it lets you discover things for yourself. Its challenging but not frustratingly difficult. Its a great coop game as well as working just as well in single player. I started the game thinking it was just a cool zombie sandbox game with no story, boy was I wrong. Once I started uncover what is really going on I couldn't put the game down.

This is one of my absolute favorite games ever. The sandbox aspect combined with the lore and just going into it not knowing anything is one of the greatest things in a survival game. 10/10 I'm buying the second one. Tip for new players, it's a lot more fun if you don't know anything about the game, also you need to manually save at a house or bed so build that first.

This game I think is a whole different experience if you are playing alone or with friends, but both are compelling to do and I have tried it out both ways. I was pleasantly surprised with this and played it when it was in its earlier days, but it seems much more polished now. Its well worth playing and if you can get this on sale I highly recommend giving it a go, especially if you enjoy survival horror games. 

The singleplayer experience is much more intense an experience and traversing cave systems by the flame of a lighter whilst padding of footsteps can be heard in the darkness is enough to break you out in a sweat. Playing with friends can still be scary, but its more hilarious at times when you watch your friend running about in the dark screaming and flailing their torch at the monsters lurking in the shadows. If you wanted the horror experience I would recommend going it solo, but if you are looking for a fun time with friends then this can be very amusing at times. The game itself plays really well, looks good and the combat is balanced enough that you feel like a normal person fighting for their life rather than some warrior of the wilds slaying monsters everywhere you roam....I mean you eventually can become that, but in the beginning if you get ganged up on you will soon be running for your life. Crafting takes a reasonable amount of time to make more complex structures, but if you have friends you can build all kinds of forts and defences against the waves of enemies that come for you when the sun goes down. The most surprising element to this game that I found was that it actually has a story (it used to not have one, it started with finding your son but the game was so early access it didn't actually have that made yet! That is how long I have played this game since!) I actually enjoyed uncovering the story and thought that it was a  much better telling of a survivor story on an island than bigger productions like Lost achieved. 

In summary, its got a good story and provides many hours of compelling gameplay as either a singleplayer horror experience or a fun multiplayer tale of survival on an island that has some unique monsters and challenges for you to sink your teeth into. If you like open world surival, crafting and horror elements then this is for you.
