I am a 60-year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing The forest. I am a single father to my son, who is now 17. My son recently started playing The forest. In less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son because he was always out with his friends or watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account to play with my son. I started playing, but this was my first time playing a video game since the 90's, so I was quite lost. I asked my son for help, and together we spent hours playing The forest. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Steam has ever since brought me and my son closer again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. The forest reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.
It's a fun game to play alone but even better with friends.

What i love about this game is well.. the Cannibals themselves, I love how they interact with the player. They don't go head on like any npc, they would keep distance and attack at the right moment. They would also circle around you and attack you from behind. They run away if you kill their leader and wont attack you sometimes if you don't engage or if you just keep your distance. These mutants also climb and jump from tree to tree and would travel as a group belonging to different tribes. This is more than just a survival game as it has mutants, and you uncover their origins and the mysteries of the island while searching for your son. 

The game is beautiful, has day and night cycle, temperature, thirst, stamina, and hunger. There is a sanity level which i don't think has a purpose but i hope they update the game to give it purpose like don't Starve. As for building you can build anywhere and items don't break as they don't have durability. In terms of inventory items also don't slow you down and the inventory doesn't have a maximum cap it bases of the number of per item you can carry, unlike other games you can carry as much of an item so long as you have space like the same item filling an entire inventory but in The Forest you can carry all items but each item has a maximum cap like only 5 bottles.

Also lets talk about the tree cutting.. which is unique as a video game since you can actually see the tree being cut not just, hit hit hit then break into material, you have to circle a tree in order to cut it.. or at least hit it entirely since you might only cut the front so you have to move closer and hit the parts which are not cut.

Having played survival games such as Stranded Deep, The Long Dark, Subnautica, and BreathEdge, I thought that I'd enjoy one of the top rated survival games on Steam. I came into it very excited until around 6 hours in when I started to lose interest. The majority of your time will be spend in caves where you can barely see a foot in front of you at all times. I really wanted to like this game especially since Sons of The Forest is coming out this year; however, it was so hard to love it because everything felt way too repetitive. Base building is basically worthless since all you really need is a simple leaf tent to save your game. Next, the combat system is just utterly not good in the sense that all you need to do is to swing until they're down. Plus this swinging reuses the same animation over and over for pretty much every weapon (except the flintlock pistol and bows). Then comes food and water (or thirst). Food can be hard to come by and it spoils which is a nice touch but when it comes to thirst, you will find an abundance of soda which really negates the difficulty in finding clean liquids to quench your thirst. Lastly, the A.I. is just dumb.

TL;DR: I rate it a 6/10, the graphics are nice, you don't need a fast PC, the story is interesting, yet the gameplay and exploration is lacking.

I have not played single player, but played through on multiplayer and had a fun experience. There are some bugs and I had achievements that didn't unlock even though I did them (some unlocked randomly, or later on). But overall, it was a fun game to play with a team, especially if you aren't into scary games on your own. I don't play horror games, but because of the multiplayer option, I was able to play through with friends and experience a different type of game and story and I really enjoyed that. The story was well done and interesting, you are faced with emotional choices, there are things that make you laugh and things that make you feel uncomfortable/uneasy, and of course you run into things that make you jump. Definitely recommend!

I wanted to like this game, it's got quite a bit of what it takes to make a great survival crafting game, for sure. However... 

Item collection is jank. You can only carry small amounts of most things, even with the 'bag' upgrades. If they were trying to go for some form of realism with this game, I wouldn't bat an eye. However when you're fighting against giant mutant cannibal monsters in various colors, that rather goes out the window.

Crafting is basic and gets old fast. You ARE allowed 'custom' builds for houses, but in the end the expense of it isn't worth the effort. Crafting for weapons is few, crafting for random necessities like armor, food, etc. is also sparce (and many times, extremely obnoxious as you have to chase down and somehow hit everything that moves to get it). You need a LOT of supplies for singular things, and I mean a LOT. So plan out those multiple trips and LONG walks.

Plan to deal with a lot of issues with your character, from parasitic water (because good luck finding the pot to pan for the water to slap on the fire to boil the water to drink- and did I mention you can only get water from certain sources, and you need the water skin to pick up the water from the pot to drink?) To having to eat constantly (which isn't too horrendous, but any food other than the snack bars expires fast). Health (your HP bar) is an absolute pain to replenish, as only certain things will help you.

My absolute biggest beef with this game came in the difficulty level. Okay. I like a good hard survival game, for sure. But straight-up, when you throw me into a BRAND NEW GAME at the VERY START with NO tutorial-- and I immediately get attacked by a group of six to twelve cannibals at once? That's poor game design. And this didn't happen only once. i died, restarted, and this happened to me four more times. I nearly quit right then and there.

But I pushed on long enough to try and get a strong feel for this game. And let me tell you, I'm sorely freaking disappointed.

First ill start with the things I like, I love the wide open world! I cant get bored of walking through the white snowy mountains to dimly lit caves. The Lighting and shadows are just so pretty, I always find my self on boats sailing across the ocean, and all little details. Like when you go to the limits of the map, you pull out a picture of Timmy to remind the player what they're supposed to do. Probably The most immersive survival game's I've ever played. I have hundreds of hours of game time and I've enjoyed every last second, from the laughs, to the cry's. but they're some bugs that either were annoying or weird, For example. an armsy once hit me a single time with full creepy armor and I died. and once I was looking for the blueprints, and found a dead cannabal on the island.

Out of this experiences I would totally recomend it to people who are in to survival games

The Forest is pretty good. 7/10

I got about 80 hours of game play before I was ready to rush to the end and move on.
The game is complete but it feels like there's not much to do once you build a base - besides hunting for story items.
Most of my time in game was spent hauling logs, sticks, and rocks to build a base.
The base building is slow and clunky, but offers unique customization options to build in trees, cliffs, and over water.
The enemies have interesting AI. Their hostility is determined by your actions.
The graphics are decent in 2022, but not special.

I'm hoping the 2nd edition to this game will have more to do, more base building options, and more focus on replay-ability.
This edition is fine for the price, but buy it on sale if you can.

Multiple reasons:
1 ridiculous hitbox and melee attack are stupid and weird, feels like punching a piece of cotton. Dissecting and eating corpses are kinda interesting but somehow....
2 food and water. right now my understanding is that you have to spend your entire day hunting deers squirrels, turtles and other animals to prevent your "stomach" from hurting you, and you have to spend a lot of time looking for water, and that makes up my everyday.

It's one of my all-time favorites and the only game to every trigger my fight or flight response so much that I could physically feel the adrenaline being dumped into my bloodstream (even on a second playthrough when I know what to expect). Don't read anything about the lore or watch any videos, just dive right in, experience the world, and see what it's going to throw at you. This game is a wild ride, and the sequel can't come soon enough.

I am a 44 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 12 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Its a neat game when you first start playing it but the flaws start showing up very quickly. The building is probably the worst I've ever played in a survival game. To build a medium sized square house you'll be chopping down trees for several hours. God help you if you make a mistake somewhere and need to rebuild it because you don't get any of your resources back. Other than just surviving in the forest the only other thing to do to progress the story is to explore several caves that all look the same. The first few you get into are cool - dark, spooky, and maze like. Then you see the caves again. And again. And again. I finally gave up once I got to the bottom of the giant sinkhole - the coolest looking thing I had found at that point - and was rewarded with a weapon that was worse than the one I was using.

Overall the game has some good ideas. The atmosphere is done exceedingly well, hunting and surviving is fun, but there really isn't any depth to anything else in the game.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

Combat is very simplistic and has little to it. The game expects you to be able to find tiny caves all over the map that looks the same. Then when you enter a cave its made with absolutely no structure allowing you to get lost very quickly. The only way to combat this is to have a tab with youtube open 24/7. Later on when harder enemies appear the melee weapons one grows used to are immediately almost useless and you are forced to just only throw explosives at enemies. There is no actual difficulty to this game with the developers idea of difficulty being to add more enemies. The game's overall gameplay loop isn't that fun with you being forced to be stuck in a cave for a lot of your time and since the food expires so quickly you are near starving for all of your playtime in caves.

Admittedly, this game had one of the more interesting and compelling atmospheres out of the handful of games I've played recently- and it's a good concept, truly!! But that can't excuse the lackluster AI programming, downright terrible layout and map design, bland sound design, etc. Every cave in this game looks the exact same; and often the items needed to progress are in the weirdest spots, to the point if you miss a single turn, you can waste upwards of an hour. Great concept: terrible execution.

The Forest is a good game. It looks very nice even on very low graphics quality, also really love the building system. The only thing that I found hard was the aiming system, it took me a while to really grasp what was going on.

Finished the game in coop after 40 hours (still got some caves and things to explore) but holy moly

This game is my first survival game but it might just be my favorite forever or until the sequel arrives, the nature of enemies, the atmosphere, .. you don't know what 'darkness' is until you play this game and it becomes night, it really shows how other games don't try enough.

Never a moment I felt without tension, anxiety or fear, especially in the caves, it was an experience that I needed several breaks from at times but pushed on cause you wish to uncover what happened here.

In my playthrough I had pretty much no bugs so that was nice, I feel like this game is worth it completely at full price, even at higher price and I'll be getting Sons of the forest on release if it is even remotely positive.

My review doesn't have anything to do with the game itself. I've played it in the past, it was fun overall, and I moved on.

=======================================================================

The main reason I'm reviewing the game now and giving it a negative score has nothing to do with the game, but I am for a reason that will affect every Unity developer going forward. Unity is merging/partnering with ironSource, a company with an utterly terrible track record and a company who has actively created malware installers disguised as legit software for PC that backdoor installs adware, malware, etc.

Unity is making this "business move" because their s##tbag CEO (former EA, because of course...) wants to introduce built-in data tracking and monetization tools into all games that use the Unity engine, so that developers can use these tools to track players and enable them to gain a deep understanding of our psychology and effectively use that to influence us even harder to spend on micro-transactions. These practices are predatory and only growing more  and more by the day. We as consumers have to fight against the tide in any way we can.

I refuse to play/buy/install any Unity games going forward if this is the way they intend move forward. I'm sorry to the developer, but there's not much else we can really do to spread awareness and cause enough backlash. Developers are the ones who use engine products, they have more sway than anyone else to go against Unity right now. Please speak up.

It's surprisingly really in depth! I originally thought it was just a horror survival game, but it goes so much deeper than that. The lore you piece together by exploring campsites, caves and other structures are very detailed. There's a lot to see and do, and the world is large enough that we accidentally completed it before seeing it all. There are some truly unique mechanics. The endgame was also unexpected! All I wish is that the ending cutscenes were shared when in co-op. My partner got to see everything and it didn't end up making too much sense to me because of it. I would highly recommend if you enjoy horror, survival and exploration!

The Protagonists of The Forest and Fallout 4: a dissertation on excellence (or lack thereof) in character writing and motivation.


Fallout 4's Nathan:
- is named Nathan (100% chance of being a fan of tom macdonald)
- low paid soldier that commits war crimes and oppresses marginalized groups in other countries to make other people rich
- unoriginal story of man with deceased wife on a quest for vengeance to save patriarchal lineage (bechdel test? hello?)
- despite living in the future he cannot make cool tree houses
- needs a bunch of alt right fascist MilSim LARPers to fly him around
- requires nuclear weaponry to fend off rats and flies
- makes a cringe gang with civil war reenactors purely to impose authoritarian views on the population
- needs permission from land barons to build his shoddy, rusty, and tetanus-laden OSHA hazard/eye sore "structures" in areas with zoning laws and HOA fees/regulation
- does not sacrifice children to eldritch gods and/or aliens
- wastes valuable time solving other people's problems to find son because he's incompetent
+ has a dog

The Forest's Eric LeBlanc:
+ is named Eric LeBlanc (a proud name reminiscent of beloved icon Matthew LeBlanc, star of the documentary "the friends: a realistic portrayal of life in the big apple")
+ high paying career as an actor beloved by millions in a respected liberal arts field
+ very progressive story of man with deceased wife going on a quest for justice to save son (just like breath-taking keanu as johnathan wick)
+ can make cool tree houses
+ makes his own glider to fly around
+ can demolish wave after wave of enemies utilizing only his fists, rocks, and sticks with ease
+ lone wolf sigma male that needs no one else to survive
+ can build a beautiful home anywhere on the island with his own two hands without HOA violations
+ willing to ritually sacrifice children to eldritch god and/or aliens to save his son
+ kills a sea turtle and slides on its shell down into a sinkhole to save son mere moments after losing him
- does not have a dog

PROS:
Very fun and tense will keep you on edge and first 8 days will be terrifying as you discover more.
Satisfying chopping of trees.
Various difficulties if you don't like hardcore games.
Multiplayer that's solid and not choppy or laggy.
Will say the story is pretty good but haven't finished it myself. I hear its a pick the ending type.
Mobs aren't too hard to deal with, if it's your first game ever will be tough but with skills from other survival games like Conan or Minecraft, this one is really easy to pick up and play.
Has an ingame version of voice chat you cant use which helps.
CONS:
Personally, its way more fun with at least a friend or more, otherwise wouldnt be fun solo with the process of making a base
No real way to speed up grinds other than getting bigger pouches for smaller items.
If you wan't a big cool lookin base it will take a long time chopping trees especially solo.
Certain things a little buggy like the roof ends dont fill in, certain trees just don't chop, and mobs will get stuck on little rocks and stuff when coming at you.
Building very different from other games which I like to see, however wonky at times.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

>"PussyDestroyer69," and "xX_CuntMagnet_Xx" start squeaking in some unfathomable language.

Honestly felt incomplete with the amount of jank in the game. The lights suck, especially the flashlight. Repeated playthroughs of this game aren't fun as there is no randomization to locations so you know what's in them 100% of the time, thus making it a rush to grab modern axe, katana, keycard, and modern bow. There's no point in any exploration if you know the game already.

Genuinely feels abandoned by it's creators the second it got to 1.0 state, with minor fixes since then but the fact of the amount of glitches I've ran into in especially the barely tacked on MP is horrendous.
If you die in MP more than once, you will start in the plane with little HP, little to no stamina and nothing. You then need to get back to your gear with those stats or avoid running into cannibals. It's really tedious and overly punishing of a system.

This game took thirteen hours of my life and my sanity that I cant get back. The first two hours? Cool. Fun. The last hour? Also cool and fun. The middle 9 hours? Torture. 
The mechanics are busted and make no sense, the balancing is weird, and the story honestly couldve been done much better. My friends and I played together and just lamented about how bored we were. I dont ever leave reviews on games, but this warranted one.

Don't even buy this game on sale, they are making another and haven't even finished this one. 

The story is barely a concept. It plays out like a trying deep hardcore fanfiction that has no real satisfying ending. The pacing is terrible. The choice in the end has no real impact. 

The game finds a way to be buggy in most cases where bugs don't even seem possible yet it finds a way. I've seen more glitches in my few hours of playtime than I have every game combined. 

The game isn't scary or intense. The most impact it has is when bats fly at you in the caves. The AI isn't scary and none of the designs are really that creepy. 

The game has so many ideas and executes none of them in a compelling or interesting way.

Timmy isn't even a cute kid.

Really good survival game spilled with a huge map, crafting, horror and an okay story. I played with the Early Access version back when it first launched and I already liked it. The game is now finished, has a proper story and you can play trough it without any issues. Not gonna lie, when I started playing the game I got addicted to it so much, that I only put it down when I got all the Achievements, and finished the story itself. Since then, I never really touched it. So I completed it on normal and decided to give it another try on Hard difficulty with my dudes. It's a little bit hard for them, because they just started playing it and never knew anything about the game, but they're at least enjoying it. I don't exactly know if I would complete this game alone once again, it's more fun and faster with other players.

this game is very close to being perfect. Everything is perfect from graphics to crafting systems. Example to craft an axe instead of only needing a stick and a rock you'd need a stick, rock and rope. Crafting items can also be upgraded into lasting longer or just be better and stronger as a whole. For this game genre everything is perfect apart from 1 or 2 main things. The adventure aspect. I only have 7 hours on this game but I've noticed some of the clues found have no explanation and if there is you'd only get it at the very end of the game. Doesn't matter too much but the biggest issue that isn't even that big of a deal is the caves. The story is that your plane crashes, kid gets taken by tall naked men and you need to search for little Timmy, you explore in caves and kill the naked men you see before they kill you first. The issue is some caves look almost exactly the same and there's nothing special about them really, Caves consist up of around 6 main things. Darkness, rock, rope, water, loot and gore. (gore being bodies, guts and the naked men) Caves always have these 6 things and nothing else to them which can make it very underwhelming. Some areas also lead to places you've been before. The game is also very unclear on what you need to do and you honestly can't complete the game without google. You need to go in caves in a certain order. Some caves have doors that need a key card that you can find in cave 1, but if you don't know that then you'll be spending about 5-10 hours exploring landscapes and caves to look for this key card or other items needed to explore and complete the game. With that aside that's mainly the only flaw in this game. A tiny bit pricey for the game but not dramatically overpriced I'd probably pay a max of ¬£10.50 for it so only ¬£5 extra needed which doesn't hurt anyone really if you're going to even have a steam account. The amount of deals steam does this game is 100% worth it and recommend it to anyone. Its single player and multiplayer and you can make private servers too so it's perfect to play by yourself or with friends also. You could also make friends on this game, I personally haven't because i only play it with my cousin but its defiantly worth the money.

I am a 54 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 40 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching Faide montages on YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I don't watch horror movies. I don't like scary games. But that didn't stop me from playing and beating the Forest with my friends. After purchasing the game on sale for $5, my expectations were low. I'm happy to say I am utterly impressed at the scope of this game. The map was larger than I thought and had an even more expansive underground cave system. There are story item collectibles everywhere. There is a variety of mutant and cannibal designs and movesets. Various weapons to find and use. After getting over the initial tedium of farming for resources, this game becomes a fun survival ride that you can continue for as long as you want, sometimes so long that you forget your main objective. Once you get there, the end-game is a surprise, and the actual game ending was a very satisfying experience. Music is limited in this game, but the music you do hear feels very intentional and impactful. 

My main complaint about this game is that I would randomly get booted off of my friend's server once during each play session (usually after 45mins-1hr of playing), and if we hadn't saved in a while we would lose progress, which was really frustrating. We had to get used to periodically building shelters to save. Another thing is that the controls were wonky playing with a controller and it was a little hard to get used to the controls, camera, and combat. I feel like I never 100% got the hang of aiming and wielding each weapon. The camera movement would hurt my eyes after a 2-hour session, even after adjusting my settings. 

Nonetheless, I can see my friends and I continuing to hop on the Forest to build and mess around with cannibals as we anticipate the release of the Sons of the Forest. Even for the regular price of $19.99, I recommend this game if you are looking for a fun single or multiplayer survival game.

If you like having the odds stacked against you and constantly being afraid of the dark then this game is probably for you.

A fantastic survival game.  Enough in the game to keep you challenged, even more so when the cannibals and mutants come calling.  From the very first minute after crashing onto the island you feel the urgency to find food and liquid to feed your body.  Building some sort of defence and shelter is what you need to focus on from the onset.  Looting what you can find from the crash site is also a must, and some very helpful items can be found to help you stay alive long enough for the days and nights ahead.

Personally I have not delved much into the story line, just stumbling over and finding the items through exploration.  Night time makes the hair stand up on the back of your neck when the uninvited guests come calling and wailing.

Crafting and building is well thought out and put together.  However you need to refer to the wikipedia related to the game to find out more of what you can craft and build.  Lots and lots of information on how to craft and build items.

There is plenty of food to find in game and water if you know where and how to look for it.  This is a constant effort you must do to stay alive.

The cannibals add to the game and make it interesting, but the mutants could be removed as in my opinion mar the game slightly, however they are integral to the back story and story line.  Needless to say I am not keen on them in game, they are grotesque, brutish and absurd (they are mutants though, so I must accept that).

There are to my knowledge 140 items you can build physically, and a plethora of items you can craft.
It's a thumbs up from me to the developers, for such an enjoyable game which I rate 9/10.  1 less than 10 because of the mutants, but that is just my preference.

Buy this game you will not be disappointed.  Check out some of the video's and reviews on the Tube.
Have fun and enjoy the game I personally recommend it. :)

The worst fucking storyline, not that there is much of a story (not a bad thing), it's that if you do try to finish it, you'll wish you died in a real plane crash. HOLY SHIT, if google didn't exist it would be nearly impossible to actually finish the game; the number of times you go somewhere just to be told you have to go to a cave that you didn't know fucking existed to get an item you didn't know fucking existed is insane; the game doesn't tell you any of this! You'll just be trying to progress when you see something that you, for some reason, can't do/ make/ finish. Google it, and now you need to go back two caves and pick up a small item in an obscure place that you would've never known about. The story feels like a side part that they thought they needed to include but actually just ruins the game.

The game is brilliant, however, at being a fun sandbox where you build houses and try to survive cannibals. Though the building is horribly tedious, having 90% of it being hauling logs from one spot to another, gathering a little rope or some sticks, saving, and repeating. It takes hours just to build a simple wall or custom house and is honestly not worth more than a couple of days of playing.
Screw this game! I highly recommend this game! It sucks! This game is amazing with friends!

Great change of pace from my traditional time killers. I have played a few others in this genre, but this was the first that stuck and that I have completed. If you stay task oriented, the game on normal difficulty could easily be completed in a few weeks time as a casual.  This is the game you need if you are in a rut with a specific other game and need a break. 

Pros that might be confused for cons: The intro confusion and lack of information "is if as of you crash landed on an island." You kinda just have to figure it out. 

Actual Pros: The game is relatively simple to learn, and the ambiance is a bit creepy even scary at times.  Even after completion of the main story I feel that I am still on guard. The story line is decent, but given the cost and scope of the game I'd say it is more than adequate.

Cons: After having completed the game, there is little reason to continue.  However, this game now has me more oriented towards other titles in this specific drama and I will absolutely purchase the developers next title "Sons of the Forest" when available.

I am thoroughly convinced that my "friends" who recommended this game are either mentally deficient or on the payroll of the developers. I cannot begin to comprehend how it boasts such a volume of positive reviews. The map is about tenfold as large as it should be given the current density of content. You will spend the majority of your time chopping trees to constantly build new bases in pursuit of actual content, lest you have a single base and must repeatedly trek over vast empty swaths of this abysmally oversized hellscape. 

If the UI and controls don't constantly remind you that you're playing an indie game, the sheer volume of bugs and jank certainly will. Enjoy the first 5 minutes of the game, because the little area around the plane is as visually appealing as it gets. Then, if you're me, you will discover a duplication glitch during your 6th minute. With geography less interesting than the procedurally generated terrain of Valheim, The Forest feels about as hand-tailored as a Hostess donette. 

If you've heard that this game is scary, you have been lied to; any level of fear this game could have instilled is completely overshadowed by obtuse progression which steals your attention from the story as you attempt to figure out what the hell you're supposed to do to stay alive. You have two options‚Äîwander around aimlessly (dying repeatedly of hunger and thirst) until you find what you're looking for, or give up, Google it, and enjoy playing the entire game with an ad-covered walkthrough and laggy interactive map open on your browser.

[h1]Fantastic Survival Game[/h1]
I have not played that many survival games but I can already tell that this is gonna be one of the best ones I'll ever play. You embark on a quest to find your lost son on a mysterious island flooded with butt-naked 'humans' which seem a little too hungry to anyone's liking. After encountering some saggy cannibal tits you'll be frightened enough to fashion yourself some shelter to keep away from the freaks as far as possible. The game has a good amount of exploration. You're looking at around 30-40 hours of gameplay with surface and underground exploration. Good range of enemies and of course, what would be a survival game without crafting? - The crafting is incredibly convenient and satisfying, from crafting survival gear to walls to housing items this game has a very great variety on what to build. There is no survival meta and the possibilities on how to play the game is endless. I mean, if you want to torture yourself you can actually play through the whole game as a vegetarian and even get rewarded with an achievement for it! On a serious note amazing game absolutely recommend at any price point to be honest.

Bought reviews for sure as they are far from realistic. I simply don't see a possible scenario where I could give this game a positive review, even after following the game from release in all the way back in 2014. Bear in mind, I'm writing this review in light of the price tag which is, as of now, 16.79 Euros. I believe that the game is overpriced when compared to what it can deliver and here is why:

The bugs, the poor saving system, the abysmally goofy combat, the empty story line, the clueless progression, the occasional plummeting out of the map, the inability to commit sudoku when stuck downsides are so common place that it is hard to take this game 8 year game seriously. A complete clown fest. The USP of this game is what, atmosphere? Can't even stop laughing at the way player models have been made. Total automatons whose torsos are entirely immobile when arms flap about to imitate eating/fighting, legs - running jumping. But the torso and the head are just static objects. 

As mentioned the combat is mediocre at best. Either block or mash LMB. The cannibals are buggy, and overpowered at times. Buggy in a way that they would glitch through the environment and surround you. Overpowered in a way that they will gang bang you, because again, there is only two things you can do - block and hit. Cannot do both. The moment you stop blocking, you die. And the combat (swinging your weapon to fight) itself is so bloody goofy that there is only one thing that tops that. And its the bow. The bow is something a stoned first year game design student would make on unity as a bet. Animations are atrocious, aiming is garbage. Same with spears when I think about it. And for a 2014 game, god help the consumers. 

Also, perhaps it should be named The Cave System? Since the caves are huge, the player can easily get lost in them. And the caves are a place you'll find yourself spending most of your gameplay in. Navigating. But there's a silver lining - lots of loot in the caves. Quite attractive, right? Naw bruv. Loot anything in the caves, walk away for 20 meters, come back, the shit just respawns. Infinite loot. Balanced.

Inventory management- shit. Glitches with quest items. Crafting is goofy, difficult to manage - shit. The loops you have to jump just to set up quick select slots "1 2 3 4" is abysmal. All throughout the game, the devs have never decided on what keybindings do what. So forget familiarity with the controls. Because if you want to manage different items but in the same manner, then the controls change. For instance, to light a flare is LMB, to throw RMB. Molotov - light L, to throw LMB. 

Not going to delve into building, which is decent but far from perfect. Long story short, narrative is hollow and unclear. Game progression stalled by short term survival goals which can be tackled easily. Purposeless.

Overpromise, sell, underdeliver. Wish i could get a refund. Only buy the game when its 90% off.

I enjoy survival games and did a bit of a huint, after No Mans Sky and ARK, this was looking pretty good.  On first playing I was a little bit lost, the system of bulding where you have a pretty limited blue print manual (where if it's not in it, you can't build it) felt restrictive, many of the features of the manual aren't game "upgrades" just aesthetic tweaks to a base, which incidently you don't need as it only serves really as a save and rest point, and the twigs and leaves shelter do that - so there's no reason to go to all the trouble of chopping logs for a wood cabin.  So there was a lot a can question, but I've currently racked up 28 hours on this game so something much be working!

On the plus side, the cannibal enemies are "manageable".  You can hear them coming from a long way away and prepare yourself.  As long as you face them and arm yourself with a nice pointy stick, you should be fine.  The mutants are a little tougher, but still not impossible.  I do like the "direction" it gives you, sometimes survival games can feel a little aimless, where with this, you have your "to do" list, you know you've got to find "TIMMY!" your son, so explore, when you explore you find caves, your todo list updates and only gets crossed off when you've covered the whole area, so have an idea if you've collected everything, you have to explore these caves which slowly provide reasonable upgrades which make the game more fun (such as aqualung to breathe underwater, flashlight, chainsaw to chop trees etc.)

I've not tried in in VR yet, it might be good but for the moment I'm happy with what it is and am looking forward to completion.

This feels less like a horror survival game and more like a rage deleted game.

If you are looking to scratch that Subnautica itch, the Forest is a pretty good alternative. You start the game as a plane crash survivor in the middle of a forest. Your first several days, you explore your surroundings, hunt animals, find water and build a shelter. As you explore further, you realize you are not alone and you are actually sharing the forest with cannibalistic mutants.

There are two ways to play the Forest. You can focus on the survival aspect and build your own fortress, set creative traps and fight the cannibals. Or you can focus on the adventure, explore caves and find items to progress the main story of the game. The graphics and overall atmosphere are surprisingly good. It can really get scary at times, especially when it‚Äôs dark. Combat is a mixed bag. Enemy AI is pretty good, but I can‚Äôt say the same thing about the melee combat.

Similar to Subnautica, the game takes twists and turns as you progress and gives you a satisfying story, especially towards the end. 

Overall, I would not suggest the Forest is a must play. But especially with its co-op mode later added to it, you won‚Äôt regret your time with it and it could be one of the best alternatives available to the original Subnautica.

I have never been super into survival games - i got into Ark for a while. This one is a lot of fun and have played about 20 hours so far - bought it a couple weeks ago during the summer sale. I play single player, my son's not quite old enough to play with me, so that poses some challenges (like the first time i built a raft and realized I need two people to move it). It's scary enough to have me jump out of my seat during nighttime stone-gathering but not enough that it cheapens the game play IMO. The cannibal AI is probably some of the best I've experienced. They approach you from all angles, can dodge your arrows, and can recognize and change their behavior depending on whether you are covered in blood, mud, or paint which is cool. One thing though is that the deer AI is pretty stupid - I have tons of deer skin because they just stand there and take it.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

A wonderful game that offers aspects of survival, multiplayer and building aspects.
If you are looking for a game in which you like to build a base for hours with your friend, collect resources needed for construction, and then during the night defend yourself against hordes of monsters, I recommend it.

[B]Weapons:[/B]
A large number of combinations and construction of survival weapons, spears, bows, axes,ropes, rabbit traps, there's even a chainsaw to find ,a lot ....

[B]Base:[/B]
In short, the base can be built as you wish, made of wood or stone.A fort, a water base, a tower, a castle, a house, a treehouse, an entire village or just a shack.

[B]Survival:[/B]
The weather conditions give us nuts, eating and drinking is a problem at the beginning, the snowy part of the map will be cruel and the caves drain us from the water, breaks to the end, malnutrition or obesity, arthritis is the worst.
Make sure your friend has torches for the expedition, a sack of food and a water bag, make sure the water is clean.

[B]Feedback[/B]

This game is the perfect example why you shouldn't have kids. Apart from the fact that they're expensive, aren't dishwasher safe and brutally honest, they will also ending up downing your plane and getting kidnapped so as to ruin what would've been a great holiday. Welcome to The Forest...

The Story:

You play as Eric Leblanc (in theory) and while on a flight to an unspecified location with your son your plane is shot down. It ends up crash landing on a peninsula where you are the only survivors and little Timmy is kidnapped by a strange man. It then becomes your task to tame these lands and rescue your son, unravelling a horrifying story of abuse and experimentation. The Peninsula has a rich history that is enjoyable and refreshing to discover but as the picture becomes more and more clear, the natural beauty of the landscape starts to take on a more sinister tone.

The Gameplay:

This game is played from a first person perspective and has strong crafting and story elements. Enjoyed solo or in multiplayer of up to eight players, you're thrown head first into this harsh landscape.  You don't start with much and quickly you'll realise you have to set up camp as well as find ways to manage your hunger and thirst. The game separates the survival from the story in a brilliant way as you can craft and explore as much as you want without the game nudging you in the direction of the story. You never have to touch the story if you're only interested in surviving the difficult landscape and that's awesome.

The Forest has a deep crafting system that you could make many useful things from. The things you make aren't like Ark: Survival Evolved where you start off with a simple stone axe and progress to guns and machinery. Instead everything you craft remains simple but adds convenience to your storage, housing or defence. All the designs look very aesthetic as you want to make your space look good in a survival game, but never leaves the realm of realism.

The game's combat is primarily melee orientated and there's a decent range of enemies that fall into two categories. The more common being the cannibals, isolated from the developing world for years and remaining very primitive and feral. The second being the mutants that roam the island. Grotesque, creepy creatures that will attack without hesitation. Kind of like the in-laws.

The enemy A.I. in this game is phenomenal. They adapt to combat by dodging, retreating or calling in reinforcements. Even during the early game, instead of mindlessly attacking you, they will prefer to watch you from a distance and stalk you while you set up your first camp. They leave you alone if you leave them alone. Only after a few days does their aggression increase. It makes for a very ominous and tense arrival. The mutants only start spawning after certain days too, organically increasing the fear and tension. That cannibal who scared the sh*t out of you on day one seems like nothing compared to the horror that comes knocking on day ten. In other words, as you level up the game levels up with you so you don't remain comfortable for too long. It's very refreshing and impressive. The animal A.I. on the other hand is atrocious. They will run into walls, through fire and freeze when you hit them. Their entire budget went to the enemy brains apparently.

The Forest from a graphical standpoint is impressive too. Beautiful, lush environments, different biomes, water and weather effects, lighting, everything was designed with real effort. A friend of mine brought up a valid point about the game's map. It's big, but not so large that it becomes draining to travel over it. It isn't miles of nothingness and is instead medium sized with plenty of landmarks so you can have a rough idea of where you are at all times.

Lastly on the topic of gameplay and the open world, we have the caves. Within the game are several interlinking caves that contain numerous enemies and story items. To progress in the story the caves are essential as you need certain items from within and they're a whole different world compared to the surface. If you hate the forest, you'll love it after coming out of your first cave. They're dimly lit, often claustrophobic, filled with nightmare fuel and confusing to navigate without a reference of some kind. Very atmospheric and puts the "horror" in this survival horror title.

Some Pros:
- Great survival and story compared to similar titles.
- Online multiplayer so you cry with your friends.
- Fairly priced for the great amount of effort put into this title.
- Gorgeous world & clever A.I.
- Engaging gameplay and progression.
- Various developer cheats and game modes to try.

Some Cons:
- Gathering the required resources with fewer players or for bigger structures becomes tedious and repetitive.
- The carrying capacity can be a bit irritating. You can improve the base amount, but a bit more would've been nice.
- For achievement hunters, some achievements are insanely grindy.
- Cave order and story progression is often very unclear. If you're a casual player you'll likely need a guide.

Conclusion:

The Forest is up there in terms of survival games and in terms of quality for your money.  It's fun, it's scary, it has co-op, is fairly affordable and it has a sequel releasing in October. It is often on sale and it is living proof that smaller developers can do far more with the resources they work with than these triple "A" corporations that will release a game in pieces and claim "they had no idea it was in such a state." I can't recommend it enough though. Among a sea of awful survival games, The Forest stands out as one of the greats.

Before I begin, I would like to preface this review with a couple of footnotes:
1. I played through the game on Hard. In hindsight I think that was a mistake.
2. I played The Forest solo, and I think this is an experience best shared via co-op.
3. This review is just my experience, all reviews are subjective, and I'm going to try and criticize the game fairly.

Now that's out of the way...

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I did not like The Forest. There was a lot that I didn't like, and not much that I actually did. I'll go through my experience (albeit anecdotal) to highlight why I feel this way.

Day 1-2
The game opens with a cutscene of you, the protagonist, losing your son in a plane crash. It is immediately implied he's alive and it's your job to go and find him. My first night I rely on some supplies in the plane, make a shelter and a rabbit trap to try and begin my soiree into the forest. No issues so far as I begin to build a more permanent shelter near a water source nearby. On my second night, I have a fire going in the dark cooking some rabbit that I caught that day. Out of nowhere a strange man rushes the fire and scares the shit out of me. First big scare on night two. I end up killing this [spoiler]cannibal[/spoiler] and get some rest.

Day 3-4
On the dawn of the third day I kick things into high gear, it's clear that this island is hostile. During the day I get raided by more enemies. I have to fight 3v1 in a nerve-racking fight that had me panicking the entire time. After this it's almost dark. I can't finish my wall tonight. I'll pick it up tomorrow.

Day 5-10
By the 5th day I have a wall, a cabin, a permanent fire pit, and a source of fresh water. Things are really looking up, and I can resume the search for my boy. While I'm reading through my survival guide inside the walls of my compound, more enemies show up and start bashing on the walls, damaging them. I wasn't even moving a muscle and a squad of them are beating down my beautiful wall. I kill them by hitting them through the wall and cheesing the fight. Little did I know this was an early precursor of what's to come...

As the days go by, I keep exploring and returning to camp, similar to a cat. A little further in each direction and then back to the safety of my walls. And [b]all the time[/b] I keep getting harassed by the locals at my home base, almost every day. This forces me to stop what I'm doing, cheese them through the wall, often wasting precious daylight, and then having to sleep until morning just to find MORE enemies to deal with.

By day 10-15, I realize there is little point to having a camp. I just waste time defending, cheesing, repairing, eating, drinking, exploring for a few minutes, and resting. Repeat. It's time to go do some serious cave diving and see what's really going on here.

Day 15-25 is where I really make my progress. However, almost [b]Every. Single. Fight[/b] is me aggroing an enemy, kiting them to the edge of their traversable zone and then stun locking them with my axe one at a time. I am not exaggerating when I say this was the ENTIRE COMBAT LOOP for me. Block. Kite. Cheese. Stun lock. Each enemy takes 10+ hits even with the [spoiler]modern axe with speed+ upgrades[/spoiler]. Again, partly my own doing because I elected to play the game on Hard.

Day 25+ was mostly the late game story for me. I will say the final chapter was pretty cool. But getting [spoiler]down the sinkhole[/spoiler] was not pleasant. A gauntlet of tough enemies and a harrowing battle with hunger and thirst, just to find out I don't have enough MacGuffins to access the final area. So I had to go all the way out, find those MacGuffin(s) and return later.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

In generally, I know this game is a Open World Survival game. But I think some of the core game design is flawed or just bad:
1. The Sound.
The directional audio is extremely poor at close range. During combat I kept glancing to my left thinking there were more people attacking me, but there weren't. The directional audio when the sound originates within 2-3 meters of the player is extremely poor, misleading, and not fun.
2. The Cheese.
This was my biggest gripe. Every fight I could not take on enemies more than one at a time. This meant some element of cheese in about 75% of all my combat experiences. In addition, if you have to repel or climb down to enemies, they will just swarm the rope or wall at the bottom and attack ad infinitum. So you just get beat to shit before you can dismount the rope or rock wall and square up.
3. No Auto Save.
I know this is an intentional game design, so I'm going to try and not knock it too much. I'm all for old school or hardcore design choices. But when you are deep within a cave, no way out, running low on supplies, and you are 2 sticks short of building a shelter to save, this is very frustrating. I died in places I worked very hard to get to and you don't just "load checkpoint." Instead, you are [spoiler]carted off to a cave across the map and have to work your way back to where you fought so hard to get to[/spoiler].
4. The Pacing
This was another major gripe. I wanted to immerse myself in the world. I wanted to become the Tom Hanks of the island. The survivor with amenities, a home, and supplies. The constant unrelenting raids, even when sometimes I was standing still in my cabin, AFK. I realized the best thing to do is just be a nomad, travel and eat/drink as you go, and all the base building be damned.
5. The MacGuffins
Some of the items in the game are almost useless but the game makes you feel like you need them. For example: [spoiler]If you travel north you encounter a snow area, which needs a warm suit. Not an easy item to craft. I thought there would be huge progression gains and the next leg of the game would unfold[/spoiler]. But nope, the item in question added no value and the area that it unlocked was devoid of life or intrigue.
6. Sequencing Breaking and Traversal
This is my final gripe. Due to my frustrating experience into the final third of the game, I started going down cliff faces or "Skyrim-horsing" up cave walls out of frustration. This led to some sequence breaks that were frustrating to untangle. Again, my fault, but the game should not allow you to clip on walls/rocks so easily.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

To conclude, I would like to bring in one of my favorite Open World Survival games: Subnautica. This genre's strongest point is a great journey of discovery and wonder. Though sometimes frustrating. But the feeling you get when you re-surface in Subnautica or travel to a new depth for the first time is truly special. I didn't feel that way at all while playing The Forest. It was a frustrating experience and the cave diving all felt monotonous and not very special. It didn't feel like I had really earned this new cave like I did in Subnautica when you first dive below 100/200/500 meters. 

There were some things that I did like. This game truly turned me into an island savage. The aggression I felt cheesing and stun locking enemies was intense. I loved driving my axe into their corpses over and over out of sheer anger at having to earn each individual kill one at a time through unconventional gameplay. The game [b]is scary[/b]. Going through some of those caves and my first time finding a [spoiler]Virginia or Armsy[/spoiler] was truly terrifying.

This game has about 95% Overwhelmingly Positive on Steam at the time of writing this. Most of you will love it. I was just that 5% that didn't.

Imagine, if you will, that a modest-sized team with a modest budget decided to make a Far Cry game in Unity, emphasizing crafting and horror elements instead of virtual tourism and run-and-gun action. That's "The Forest" in a nutshell.

The protagonist is on a plane trip with his son when the plane suddenly goes down; when he recovers consciousness in the shattered plane, his son is missing, and there appear to be no other survivors. He begins to go about the task of gathering the essentials to ensure his own survival, and in time discovers that he is on an island (or possibly peninsula? The navigable play-area makes it unclear) populated by one or more tribes of unfriendly, cannibalistic humanoids.

The player, as the protagonist, will gather resources, craft tools, structures, weapons, and buildings, and explore the land and the caverns and tunnels beneath it on a mission to survive long enough to figure out what happened to your son. A successful player will likely do things such as crafting clothing and armor, making racks to stretch and dry meat from hunted animals, and learning the uses of poisonous and edible flora and fungi. The game tracks energy, hunger, thirst, and temperature, as well as the possibility of getting sick from blood-borne pathogens and toxins, and the player will have to put at least some effort into preserving the protagonist's health.

There is a mystery to be solved, and with persistence (not to say the use of game guides or FAQs), the player will gradually uncover it.

Personally, I found the game captivating. The graphics do a fine job of capturing the sense of a densely foliated forest and environs, and the cannibal tribes and other creatures are creepy and threatening. Crafting and building strikes a fine balance between realism and game-play, and there's a real sense of accomplishment in expanding one's base camp and expanding one's inventory of tools, resources, and weapons. Information about the place and its inhabitants is fed to the player at a slow and steady place, and as its nature becomes more apparent, the sense of dread begins to grow along with the discovery of new threats.

Be warned that while there are two "endings" to the game, none of the potential resolutions is exactly a happy-go-lucky "win".

There are places where the game's lower budget and level of polish become visible: the odd physics glitch, the interminable rope-climbing sessions as one explores the underground, the sheer number of times one has to "whack" an enemy or a prey animal before it finally succumbs. While the more primitive weapons available to the player are perfectly on point for the setting and theme, by the end I was occasionally wishing I just had a "real" gun to resolve a situation quickly; realistically, in many cases, the only quick resolution one can hope to get comes from running away. Combat becomes, "Sigh, one more battle to use up a bunch of stuff I'm going to have to re-harvest" some time before the game reaches its plot-conclusion, or at least did in my case.

Still, quibbles aside, I had a good time with "The Forest"; it's reasonably priced, and packs in a good amount of enjoyable, satisfying game play.

It's a GREAT game. I've known about this game since it was in development, I remember watching YouTubers playing this, and me begging my parents to get it because it looked so cool. But they wouldn't because they wouldn't allow me to play horror games so I looked up on the Play Store for a version of the game, and all I got was a really shitty version of this masterpiece. Imagine the Mona Lisa drawn by a toddler, that was what it was like to play on that bad version of The Forest. I was surprised to learn that this game was made with the Unity Engine. I remember watching people make games with this engine and you could always tell when a game was made with it. You just need to look at games like Who's Your Daddy or Crab Game to get my point. It's probably because they were made in a hurry and with the free version of the engine. This game how ever, it's really well made, the graphics are really great, the physics and sound are also really great. I have pretty low standards when it comes to those things but I think that for this price, The Forest is a game with pretty nice graphics. However, we can't have everything in life, so even this game has some drawback, at least for me... For starts, it can be really laggy. I don't know if it's my potato PC or some virus on it, but I have a GTX 1060 and three screens. And for a while, games that I play on this PC are really just turning bad with how laggy they get. I've tried to play with and without the three screens, it's stil laggy (maybe just a bit less, but still laggy some times). It's not like it's unplayable, but maybe every minute or so the game lags in some way or another. If you have a good PC and no viruses this should worry you.

I would give this game 4/5 stars. 

At first I really enjoyed the game cause there's a lot of things you can build and discover, but after playing it for many hours and finding clues, the game got a bit tedious. 

Some specific things I didn't like:

- I spent a lot of my time getting lost even with my map and for the love of god couldn't find some things at all (like the raccoon or crocodile), maybe i was just super unlucky, but I went through the map thousands of times and just didn¬®t see them. 
- The caves are awfully dark (duh), but it's not even scary dark, it's just annoyingly "where the fuck am I going" dark and the torch, lighter and flashlight don't give that much visibility...so if it was meant as a scary element, i was more annoyed by it really.
- The story and clues...I mean the overall story was good, the concept of it fine, but I mean when I think about it, the clues, the documents were not very important and I would much rather have less stuff to build in the beginning and find parts of the survival journal with more blueprints to build. And even after finding all of the documents and stuff I was still mildly confused by the end and felt that it was a bit rushed? Had some plotholes? I dunno, was a bit disappointed. 
- I felt that the weapons weren't very accurate when it came to "hand to hand" combat. I would expect that where i¬®m looking the weapon would come down, but it just went somewhere else or under a different angle, so I just stuck to a spear most of the time. 
- Also the rebreather...it could automatically come off of your face when you're on land.

Things I liked: 
- The base building was great! Spent hours on my base and loved watching the monsters get taken down by my traps.
- I liked the overall scenery and map
- I played on normal difficulty and felt that the strength of the enemies was fair and liked to battle with them.
- I liked exploring, just felt that some exploring was for nothing or just some piece of paper that meant nothing in the end
- I really liked that the amount of things you need, even in multiplayer was always displayed and that there were a lot of things to help you carry more things


Overall, I still liked the game, just was annoyed by some stuff that made me glad that I finished the game and could just build bases :D

I am a 49 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

First of all, this game is awesome.

That being said, I wanted to mention a few things that bug me, because The Forest does so many things right that it's a shame to find these relatively obvious issues. For example, the custom roofs have 2 holes on the sides, and there's no official way to fill them in. I also think there should be much less cannibal attacks, because even if you're well prepared, it still gets really annoying and slows down your progress when you're trying to, say, build your base. I think there should at least be an option to tune down the spawn rates of enemies. The building system could also do with a grid, so that if you want you can easily align your buildings, instead of eyeing it.

I have played this game through now and it's a good game, not a great game though. I say that cause I feel it could have been so much more. 

 A lot of the enemies in this game feel like they could have been refined more in the combat, I mean the human run and jump at you and to avoid them you just step to the side. The mutants are a little more tricky but not impossible to kill. 

 The base building feels good but again I feel they could have done more with it. 

That aside, it is a fun game and I did enjoy it, I may even play it through again the future

Being an avid solo backpacker irl some things about the Game really triggered me at first. Once you get the Old Pot SW corner of map, you can play the game.

That said it is really difficult and in its own way feels much like trying to survive in the wild. So far I've spent most my time just trying to survive, most often when I try to explore I end up barely surviving several nights away from my home base. I'm not sure what the %$#@ is going on here yet but I feel like I landed on the island of Dr Moreau or worse.

I am a 40 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Rules and Guidelines For Steam: Discussions, Reviews, and User Generated Content
These guidelines apply to all places in the Steam Store and Community where users can post content. This includes, but is not limited to, discussions, comments, guides, product reviews, screenshots, artwork, videos, tags, and Steam Workshop.

When providing feedback, posting information, or discussing a product in Steam, whether it‚Äôs negative or positive, please make sure you are being relevant, constructive and polite. Developers take feedback from all kinds of sources into account, even though they may not have the time to respond to every post or question.

Please note that Administrators/Moderators reserve the right to change/edit/delete/move/merge any content at any time if they feel it is inappropriate, abusive, or incorrectly categorized.

All users are subject to the Steam Subscriber Agreement and Steam Online Conduct.

General Rules
Do not do any of the following:

Flame or insult other members
Bypass any filters
Abuse or encourage abuse of the Post Reporting System
Post personally identifiable information (i.e. name, address, email, phone number, etc.)
Bump threads
Derail a thread's topic
Post links to phishing sites
Post spam (i.e. +1, 10char, rickrolls) or Re-post Closed, Modified, Deleted Content
Repetitively post in the incorrect forum (example: trade requests belong in trading forum)
Openly argue with a moderator
Manipulation of the User Review system or voting/rating systems
Content Rules
Do not post any content on Steam containing the following:

Porn, inappropriate or offensive content, warez or leaked content or anything else not safe for work
Discussion of piracy including, but not limited to:
Cracks
Key generators
Console emulators
Cheating, hacking, game exploits
Threats of violence or harassment, even as a joke
Posted copyright material such as magazine scans
Soliciting, begging, auctioning, raffling, selling, advertising, referrals
Racism, discrimination
Abusive language, including swearing
Drugs and alcohol
Religious, political, and other "prone to huge arguments" threads
No Backseat Moderating
Let the moderators do the moderating. Backseat moderating is when people who are not moderators try to enforce the forum rules. If you see a person breaking the rules, take advantage of the Report () button or simply ignore the offensive post(s), thread, or review.

Report Posts to Moderators
Should you observe a fellow Community member breaking these rules please report the post or item by clicking the Report () button located on every item, post, and review.

Repeated Offenders
Repeated offenders of the above rules and guidelines will be banned from the Steam Community. Any moderator has the ability to ban a user for violating the rules at their discretion.

The Forest is an excellent survival game that instills a constant feeling of dread within you. Almost no matter where you decide to settle, the cannibals(and other things...) can find you. And they hurt.

This game is a bit glitchy and the story absolutely comes second to the survival aspect, but I have to give it a pass since it was developed more by artists than coders. I love the little details in this game, like actually having to swing your axe at a tree from multiple directions in order to fell it, or having to boil your water before you drink it. The little sounds that play when you mouse over the materials in your bag. The fact that you can make armor from the bones of your attackers.

There aren't a lot of game breaking bugs, but building is still extremely annoying and finicky sometimes. You'll quickly find yourself with more food than you know what to do with, and the enemies can be very unforgiving. Even so, I've had a blast playing this game both alone and with friends, and though I don't have a lot of hours in the game yet, I definitely plan to play more.

Awesome Game, buy it you won't regret it. When I first bought the game, I thought of playing for a couple of hours but NO, I played for 10 hours straight with my friends and the day after 6 hours.

I played this game solo the other day. It was fun building, crafting, setting up traps, and getting good sleep. Everything was going well, Life was a good man until I found the cave. Not one cave, cave after another cave. I realized how scary this shit is when you're alone in a cave. Got pretty much some new items, killed cannibals, and most importantly came out alive.

After the cave, I found a deep hole that's where I remember what she used to say. xD

Loved it, can be finished quite quickly by accident but that's a good thing in my books. The Story, atmosphere and AI are all great, especially when it gets dark. Overall, it's definitely worth the money on sale or not. Can't wait for Sons of the Forest coming later this year.

im only 11 hours into this game and im loving it, im a huge survival game fan ive played them all, Rust, H1z1, Ark, Atlas, 7 days to die, subnautica, dayz and so on, so when it comes to playing new suvival games im usualy not impressed, but this game actually surprised me, is it the best? no, probably not but its got things in it that just make you go wow, 

the wildlife has got to be the best ive seen in a game, the way they move, the way they interact with you and your surroundings, i give them 10 out of 10 for that, 

the building is good, the traps are inventive and brutal , building walls is pretty darn good, your not limits to flat areas , you can build up steep inclines and it doesn't look odd,

The Combat is okay nothing really special about it, range weapons have no cross hairs so can be a bit difficult

The Enemies, but god the way they move, the AI is pretty good, but also quite dumb at times, sometimes they will dodge like a pro move like and pro when they are being defensive but if they are coming for you then they can be quite dumb at times but still one of the best when it comes to movement, its not generic like some games where there is just attack mode and defend mode, these will doge, rolls, jump attack, leap , even climb trees, enemies are pretty challenger and increase in number as the game goes on,  

It has a story! unlike alot of games it starts you off on a plane (wont say anymore of the story due to spoilers) but right from the start it hits your heart strings,

Be warned this is a pretty creepy and gruesome, im used to this sort of stuff but  sometimes ill sit there and go damn thats just nasty.

The Forest is a game for those seeking a thrill and a challenge. With each camp and area offering a brand new challenge and mystery to the player. Whether or not its Groups of blood thirsty cannibals or large mutant beasts, this game is always full of surprises. Discovering massive hidden caves with secret areas is a blast and after seeing the trailer for The Sons Of The Forest, this game and the next is in the hands of very talented Devs. I highly recommend checking this game out.

I am a 52 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

wow.. This game is crazy good. First of all, the lore is absolutely insane and also the items and customization. 

What it's about: 

You begin flying with your son in an airplane, but suddenly the plane catches on fire and crash-lands on a cannibal infested island. After the plane crashes you are greeted with a cut-scene where a mysterious red man carries your son away from the plane. For the next few horrifying days your goal is to get your son back.
 
Pros:

-Customization
-Tools
-Buildings
-Fighting system and game play
-Multiplayer
-Atmosphere
-2 Endings
-Health system (you can exercise and gain pounds and stuff)

Cons:

-Little buggy at times
-Grieving in public games
(not really many cons because its such a goated game)

All in all, this game has to be on my top 10 list also because it was much better playing with my friends. Sadly the whole experience was a little downgraded due to stupid old me spoiling the ending for myself. Good luck and choose your ending wisely...
