The Forest is one of those games that nearly everyone has heard of, but few have played, and even less have completed. This is perhaps thanks to its lengthy "early access" on-ramp and the 15 minutes of fame it experienced in the YouTuber circuit a little too far before its full release. While I was aware of this game and its premise, it got lost for me in the glut of 2010's early access survival craft-em-ups until I picked it up on sale recently and was blown away by its quality. 

Awakening in the fuselage of a crashed plane with nothing more than a hatchet and a survival book, the core gameplay has players sorting out how to supply themselves with clean water, shelter, and food in a remote forest while defending themselves from an increasingly hostile tribe of mutant cannibals and collecting clues as to what's going on and how to find the protagonist's missing son. The narrative is mostly communicated through notes, tapes, and other clues scattered across the titular forest.

Overall, the core mechanic of The Forest is discovery. Finding new points of interest on the map, experimenting with survival strategies, and picking up tidbits of a greater lore from assorted clues. None of the game's individual systems are particularly complex, and the real "progression" comes more so from growing your knowledge of the game and using it to your advantage. Having now beaten the game, it feels like one big puzzle that's immensely satisfying to solve piece by piece, but leaves me with little desire to replay since I feel I could easily meet the conditions to beat the game in a couple hours with the knowledge of what to do and where everything important is.

A major highlight is the AI for the cannibals, which is phenomenal and makes them feel like living, breathing people. Instead of just attacking you, they may stalk you from a distance, start charging you and then stop to watch your reaction, run away to bring intel about you back to their tribe, or even flee in fear or cower in reverence under the right conditions. They will always keep you on your toes and still manage to surprise me.

Very fun horror and survival game! I'm not that into survival games at all really but The Forest interested me because of its premise, its cool horror elements and that you can play it all in co-op! The Forest has you play as a father traveling with his son on a plane when it crashes and your son is kidnapped. You then have to find your son, survive day to day and deal with tribes of cannibals that can attack you at any given time. 

As someone who's not really that into survival games I found the gameplay to be a lot of fun actually. Building up a fort and various items to help you survive until you to the point where your in a groove and you can get by with ease. The amount of crafting options you have both from a building and supplies perspective is insane. The game also features a bigger selection of weapons then I was expecting with a couple of different axes, bows, a katana (my personal favorite), flare gun etc... You can find these in the various caves you have to explore to uncover items you need for the story. Exploring them reminded me so much one of my favorite horror films, The Descent, and the game even has a Easter egg for it you can find. The game is also quite the looker too with some gorgeous lighting effects and photo realistic graphics. 

The game also features quite a good amount of options both graphically and gameplay wise. You can choose whether buildings you make are breakable or not which was good since in the later half of the game you can have huge armies of cannibals attacking your camp at once, and it would just be impossible to rebuild everything back up before the next big attack. The enemy AI as well is really smart. While they attack you almost like how zombies do, they can be smart with how they overwhelm you. At the start of the game they won't attack you as much as they watch you from afar, but later they get more aggressive which makes the whole experience very tense. There is also a decent variety of enemy types as well. 

Lastly I like that the games map isn't too big. Its big enough to have interesting locations and landmarks for you to find but not too big that it becomes bloated like so many open world games fall into. 

In terms of what I didn't like there are a couple of things. Firstly I wish the story progression was made a bit more clear to the player as unless your checking a guide while playing, it can be very easy for you to wander around aimlessly or go into one of the later caves that your not really ready to take on just yet. A little more direction in the sequel would be nice but I get that they wanted the game to feel more open ended and for players to figure things out. Also at the end of the game you have to make a choice and you don't get the "complete the game" achievement if you make the choice your not supposed to, which really sucks. Might as well not given the player a choice at the end then. I also wish there was character creation as each time you die, you start back at the plane crash site and your appearance is completely randomized. Would have been cool if you could create and personalize your appearance, especially for a co-op game. They also use a Dark Souls like mechanic where if you die you have to run back to your corpse to collect all your equipment which can be frustrating if you were deep into one of the cave systems. Luckily enemies don't respawn in caves specifically after you kill them. 

Overall though, this is a solid game as it mixes survival gameplay, horror and cooperative play so well that's its very easy to lose a ton of hours in it. Highly recommend!

I'm going to give an honest critique of the game so that people like me know what they're getting themselves into. 

It starts off with promise. But pretty quickly you realize that it lacks the sophistication and attention that make worlds come alive and allows the player to feel truly immersed. Then, what the game lacks in options, it tries to make up for not necessarily in scale (because the map isn't that big), but in the quick turnover of days vs nights and the lack of stamina in your character forcing you to walk all. the. damn. time. Getting from one side of the map to the other takes forever. And along the way you have to fight off all kinds of savages, boars, even alligators. 

The movements are clunky and unnatural. The key-bindings are horrible. The field of view makes me feel sick. 

The worst part, though, is that there is no auto save, and you can't manually save your progress without first finding a "shelter" of some sort, or acquiring the resources for one and then building it. Warning: You'll need some of those resources and the time you spend getting and building them to make campfires, in order to cook meat and stay warm. At the end of the day this game feels much more like having one of those digital pets. It's far more work than it is play. And it's not as though it's even close to realistic. You can slide down a mountain face without getting hurt. You can eat poisonous berries and all it does is slightly reduce health. You can't run for more than 5 seconds without getting exhausted, but you can shotgun an orange soda and instantly have full recovery. 

This is very much an independent game. I honestly can't figure out why it has such a high rating. Maybe others have discovered something I haven't. 

In any case, the novelty wears off really fast. And there isn't much to discover. I already uninstalled it and I feel like an idiot waiting so long (less than 6 hours).

The Forest is a Singleplayer/Multiplayer survival horror game which you play as a father on an abandoned island searching for our son who is missing. The plane crash put us in this situation. 

For the first hours, this game was a boringfest. Literally, zero information and clues about where we are since the compass and the island map is hidden somewhere. When you learn the map layout OR randomly find the map and compass, game becomes excellent.

Crafting is really good at this game. Many things to figure out and craft. Graphics are good, optimisation isn't the best tho. Enemy and animal variety is alright, combat is really good. 

Overall, this game is great. Definitely worth to it's cost. Should try it out at least.

There are a lot of mobs in game like animals, zombies and some tribes.

I have a lot of fun playing this game and everyone should play this game especially with friends.

I know the game is not that cheap, but when it is on sale you should buy it definetly.

All in all once you learn how the game works, it's a lot of fun, even addicting.  You're not forced to do the main quest and you can go wherever you want, settle wherever you want and choose whichever methods you need to fight and survive.  There's lots of options the game offers from weapons to base building and gathering materials.  It can be quite the grind getting the things you need especially if you're building elaborately.  I would definitely give this one  a thumbs up because you're not stuck to some lame story and you're not bound to questing.  You just survive first then decide when and where you complete the main quest.  The enemies and bosses can be tough early on but the game gives you lots of options to get stronger and improve your equipment/armor.  The building system is a little quirky but once you get accustomed to how it works you do a lot with it.

Played for two hours. Felt like I was fighting the game more than playing the game. 

I don't feel like the game has proper scaling. On the first night of the game, (and I'm talking like--less than 5 minutes into actual game play) 4 guys show up at camp and all attack me at the same time. All I had equipped was a hatchet and nothing else.  

In this game, when you die, you start all the way over at the plane crash site as a "new guy" with absolutely nothing, and your "new guy" is cold, weak, and hungry with practically no stamina. And when you re-spawn as a new guy, the freaks that killed me are still hovering over the backpack of my previous guy, so now I have to stealthily get my backpack again without getting killed, only to have a new group of freaks attack me 5-10 minutes later and kill me. 

During the times my guy was alive, I would kill birds to make food. 1 cooked meat filled my stomach 1/2 full, but a 2nd cooked meat filled my stomach 0. At first I thought it was just a small glitch, but it did this every. single. time. And there didn't seem to be a way to store the cooked meat to eat for later.  

I wish there was a "cross-hair" mechanic to aim your weapon or to focus on collecting items like in other first-person games. 

After "dying" 12 times in two hours and making absolutely no progress, I was pretty fed up with the game. Planning on refunding.

I liked The Forest from the start for a couple of key reasons .. The environment you move through in the game actually gives way to you.

The saplings and bushes wont stop you dead in your tracks. A simple stiff arm from your character pushes them gently away and you move through the environment ergonomically, the way it is intended. This gives the user fluidity and a more realistic and natural feel.

Another reason is the looting and foraging and discovery of New things/items. 

There is an interesting Survival Booklet available for identification and reference with a Push of the D-Pad. All things crafty (and neatly illustrated) are easily accessed here.

Im just getting into The Forest .. but I can see already that this was a wise choice and a bargain for $4.99.

So from a surface perspective I see why this got so popular. Actually creepy horror and build things that feel like they'll never hold up.

At this point in time, I feel like the game might be seriously showing its age. I never bought it when it came out,  but you can't expect a game like this to hold up great for more than 5 years.

I'd love to actually explore and get creeped out a bit, but apparently getting rid of the creepy assholes that stalk you causes floods of them to come and try to kill you. Also, apparently trying to build and have a good time does the same?

So why even have the game at all? Why not just have a lighter, temporary shelters, and fire? If you were truly going to have to live in this place, why?

So in essence, the things that make the game fun are the things that just slow you down to keep the game from ending. It's pointless, and not in a groovy nihilist way.

Actually decent open world survival horror game with solid mechanics; The horror eventually wears out after you figure out enemy types and behavior, patrol routes, and learn which items block effectively and which attack better, but it is still pretty good for a first time experience, it sure as hell made me jump a few times back then. (Pro tip: use M131 color grading)

The map isn't a procedurally generated one either which I think is better, you can memorize it better and familiarize yourself with all the proper item, build, and resource locations.

Combat is meh, you attack and you block, then finish them off, with mutants you just attack and block, there are bows, and the throwing spears, but they have some very jank aiming that you have to truly master for  them to be any good, there is also the flintlock pistol and the flare gun but they're also meh.

Building in the world is relatively simple, you can't manipulate the terrain but there are countless structures that you can put down and connect and you can actually make a lot of creative stuff with it.

Story is non-existent, to be honest, I've played through all of this game without ever interacting with it besides picking up a few items from the caves.

Overall, pretty fun, I have like a decent 100 hours or so on this game on a pirated version, but I eventually ended up buying it for multiplayer shenanigans.

One of the best of the many, many survival games I have played. It focuses on survival, exploration and plot instead of getting bogged down in annoying micromanagement and needlessly over-complicated mechanics, which is a failing of many others in this genre.

Beyond that, the tension, creepiness and horror in this game are really well done. It is a dark title, so you should expect plenty of gore and death... but done in a way that serves the plot and the gameplay.

Definitely best if played with 1 or more friends, but also totally doable alone. Can be played pancake or in VR, and both versions can play on the same server. Note then when I played it in VR there were some specific bugs (like cutscenes not displaying), which may or may not have been fixed... but otherwise it was a solid VR experience and I was really happy I could still play with others even if they didn't have VR gear.

A good purchase at any time, highly recommended especially if on sale.

First of all I bought it on sale for less than 2$ and I did get my money's worth out of it. But It gets extremely boring and repetitive after a while. During the first 5-10 hours, you're super excited for all the items you get to discover and the challenges you face in your expeditions but After that, after you know most of what's to come, The game becomes quite tedious. 
You repeat the same tasks again and again, whether it be Hunting, Forestry, Base building or fighting off Cannibals at night. It all becomes a tedious task. Sure Base building is fun but only at the beginning when you've just started to discover things.

Bugs are there but it only crashed a few times for me and my friends. Not to mention that your Raft can penetrate any structure on water. 
Just by building a base on water, you become completely devoid of death by cannibals at night.
There is no real depth to the game, but for 132 Rs. or less than 2$, it's most definitely worth it. But never buy it at full price.

great game, fun to play with friends. The best part about it is that the developers have taken the time to look into aborginal australian history, really immersive and makes me feel like im captain cook in 1770. From the natives climbing trees, attacking you, stealing your stuff, its almost like the devs have just captured sounds and footage from WA, QLD and the NT for the natives sounds and movement, attacking in numbers trying to reclaim land. me and my friends are just humble settlers, cutting down forests and trying to get my son back, unfortunately, just like the in game aborginals, they don't like you doing stuff without their permission (which, like australia you'll never get). The growling and huffs and puffs are also, what i also assume to be australian aborginals, small brain monkeys unable to put together a sentence, so their body language and sounds they make from their mouths to be very surreal to me and almost frightiening with the similarites. Furthermore the face paints and body paints are very similar to aborunorginals and what i'll also assume is american indians. The only gripe I have with the game is that, they took my child, unlike the common story by aborginals that the white man stole their kids, seems like history have it wrong, it was the native population. Stolen Generation? no, stolen timmy, i guess thats what happens when you fly to the Northern Territory, WA or QLD and you end up crashing, overrun with small minded individuals who have been there for centuries but only made fire and stop progressing with their evolution. Speaking of the white man, it is assumed that the cause of the problems for the aborginial population, both in game and in real life is the over consumtion of strong liquor and petrol, just like the aborginials in real life, very well mimic with the in-game population, they have it stored in their huts that have been there for centuries. Centuries without progression, you would think that if they weren't monkey brained, they surely should be a global super power? no, the substance abuse is obviously rampant in game as well, with petrol can, poising the minds of the natives, just like real life. If they weren't drunks with 2 brains cells fighting for 3rd place, I could put these bludgers to use, but just like real life they will abuse the government system, getting money and benefits to sniff more fuel and drink more booze. Its quite sad how similar it is, unlike real life however, i have fun slaining these tree huggers, when i do it back in australia; they use the little communication skills they have to call the police, well, whatever police they can that isn't wrapped up dealing with their own people. But, how do they have alcohol and petrol you may be asking? the Aborginal populus will want you to believe it was humble white men like myself and my friends, but the denial and the lies make them angry, perhaps another reason why they attack you like in Townsville and Darwin. Currently semi-enjoying this game, but there are some bugs and A LOT of QOL improvements to be done.

Some examples. 

When you die you always spawn at the same start point as when you first started the game? Why not give us spawn at base?

When you finally find your body after dying and if you are carrying the axe you gain from spawn, you will get the message "too many axes" or something like that. The result is that you keep your default spawn axe, and the one that you have upgraded to max disappears..... 

Bug: When using weapon, character will sit down instead of using spear/axe or bow??? 

Building is weird, especially your own custom cabin. Walls/roof simply won't construct where you intend to.

Will give a negative review now, soley because you can't loot your upgraded gear from your dead body if same category of item already exists in your inventory. I don't think you can drop it from your inventory either, so there's no workaround.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Not sure how to start or say, but it will be a review from someone who enjoys doing mindless tasks in survival crafting games and building.

[list]
    [*]No tutorials ( figure out like in minecraft or google youtube how to assign hotkeys to weapons )
    [*]You need too many prompts to craft/build anything in this game. Often issues to highlight E on campfires/water sources.
    [*]Limited inventory for sticks yet you can carry entire axe arsenal and oxygen diving bottles . . .?
    [*]No in game map, you can't draw one either.
    [*]Building system does not snaps properly, its not very intuitive
    [*]You can't disassemble build structures, you loose all materials. Even if enemy destroys them.
    [*]Crafting requires way too much resources. Come on grinding for wood logs or sticks is not fun at all.
    [*]Can't free place decorations or items. Just on Wooden Cabin with limited space/pre-placed zones.
    [*]Lackluster in terms of decorative buildable items.
    [*]Gathering resources does not feel fun, not any items make it easier or reduce the "grind" aspect.
    [*]Torches in this game apparently only highlight 50 centimeters in front of you.
    [*]You can't equip torch or flashlight to replace Lighter. Can't even equip 2 torches at once to dual wield.
    [*]A bald cannibal can destroy your log house that requires 89 logs in few hits
    [*]Corpse running, ie die and go back retrieve your loot. If you log out you loose your items completely and start over.
    [*]Can't save your character in multiplayer, it always resets.
    [*]No additional configs for server to alter enemy difficulty or hunger/thirst ratios
    [*]Combat is very stiff with no melee feedback. Feels like you jerk off with your own feet.
    [*]You can't block with spears?
    [*]Hitboxes in this game are terrible i often ended up hurting my friends or removing part of my household.
    [*]Visited 2 caves and already got 2 mutants and 5-8 canibals attacking us every night.
    [*]All nights was us sitting at campfire waiting. We could skip the night with bed but i call this immersive gameplay experience 
    [*]Birds landing in your house windows are kinda cute, but they tend to ignore everything elsewhere and just noclip thru everything.
[/list]

Give me multiple systems to enjoy your game, then penalize me for even attempting. Good god the time wasted gathering 5 rocks or loading up sleds with logs. Fight off mutants 1x in the morning, be attacked by a patrol while gathering material to fix what the first wave broke. Now that everything is back in order and your base is set back up ( traps/ rock walls/ engineering at its finest) be prepared to wake up the next morning to see 2 spider mutants one way and 2 rhinos the other. So begins again the loop of garbage that does not respect my time whatsoever. I explored everywhere that wasn't cold, spelunk[ed] until my eyes bled, had immense amounts of materials/ weapons/ and a very impressive setup only to realize about 9ish hours too late for a refund that these devs just wanted to be jerks and try to stretch out their unrewarding experience. Don't worry, if you haven't reached the level of 'respect my time or I won't play your game', you will at some point in life.

Edit: Game is a lot more fun if you simply abandon the idea of a base. Believe me, if you live on the move you WILL enjoy it. Changed thumbs down to up after making a personal decision.

it had great beginning, not very obvious but not very bad tutorial, cannibals are sick! nice lil change from the "zombie games" style, special cannibals? almost feels like l4d2, loved it! building anywhere u like whatever you desire? Awesome! 
so why didnt i like it? well you see...
combat mechanics are awful... it has good potential if they improve it tho! enemies can kill you in about 3 hits now i understand it should be challenging but still, not fair. armor is suprisingly weak, very weak. easiest (kinda)  to craft is the bone armor which takes alot of effort to get just so it get destroyed in like 3 hits? 4? in a  1v1 fight against a cannibal. its ridiclous, sure you can dup but thats not an excuse. as for the  combat, its awful.. i struggle to kill anything with melee idk it feels like they need a lil tweak both the player and the cannibal, especially the cannibals they sometimes sprint thru objects or run like a super sonic! (same goes to some animals.. maybe all of them ) their attacks are bs, i tried but it feels so glitchy it need some improvements. especially when my player tries to finish off the enemy on ground. story is cool but i wish my character said somethin about the situation... he does moans in pain or when jogging so why not speaking? the cutsene towards the end was a lil not that bad but it felt like they shouldve polish it a lil (around when you meet the final boss baby)
i only replayed the game 2 times just to see the ending. there was no point to continue afterwards survival due to nothing interesting really happening afters and the cannibals become tougher and harder to kill after a while which didnt motivate me to stick around longer, you know.. the combat issue and health system.
the multiplayer part was bad, so bad in my experince.. if you have no friends with this game dont bother play with strangers... it happened to me many times i spawn in airplane with a wall and a door locked. unbreakable one too! either i wait til i get their permission or just starve in there... other times i keep meeting new servers, new peoples its not bad but i hate i must start from the beginning with 0 stuff in me, i got tired of it.

MY REVIEW:

Combat mechanics: 4/10 reason: It is very clunky, enemies phase through objects sometimes and start flying even


Scare factor: 10/10.  Only 17% of players have completed the game. That should say something.

Sound design: 10/10. The games sound design is immaculate and adds very well to the scare factor of the game

Music: 10/10. Very well designed and exciting music

Grind: Quite a lot of grinding. I beat the game in just over 24 hours straight with a friend and most of it was just grinding.


Ending: 10/10 ending left me discombobulated and wanting to know more



Graphics: Really good for a game released in 2014


Computer: Potato, nearly any computer can run it 



Should you get it? Yes, if it's on sale or just for full price.

Overall rating- 9.5/10

I finished the Forest on the Ps5 console Version, and I gotta say, I loved this game, There isn't much of a Story, it being told through Pages of Art, Posters, and titbits here and there throughout the caves. The Story requires Exploration of all the caves to be told properly. Best Recommendation, Put Markers at the exits and Entrances to each Cave, each with a colour. It will help you keep track of each location and where you end up. Especially if you forget something, The combat is fluid, interesting and requires some practise to be actually good at. You will however die if your not careful, smart and well equipped in the caves. Should you make it to the end of the Game, you'll be provided with a choice, Leave the World and Experience the Ending, or Go back and live out the rest of the game trying to survive against increasingly harder enemies. Choice is yours. However I have seen heaps of Bases built to handle all the elements and foes you meet, I would recommend Picking this Up when its on Sale though as the Price on Steam is horrendous.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
This game is an absolute blast to play with friends, a little buggy at times but nothing damaging mostly just good fun. Highly recommend.

I've been playing this since it was so early access you couldn't even make spears, you had to find them on the map. My biggest and onlyest complaint about this game is that is has essentially ruined co-op survival games for me and my friends. This is best we've found. You spawn together, you work together, you build  together, you survive together. The survival is great, especially in the hardest difficulty, the enemies are interesting without going to far into Left 4 Dead territory, and the building is fantastic. We've tried to find other games like this one, but they all fall short. Or spawn so far away from each other that we have to spend the first 2 hours finding each other on the map, which is just 2 hours we've could have been using to play something else.

This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

Pretty solid survival-craft game. Leans more horror than others. Early game feels like you're mostly chopping trees and hauling logs, but once you get a decent setup you get to focus on exploring the island. 

Unlike some other survival games, you know how to build everything you can build out of the gate, so you just have to figure out the best way to acquire said resources and hunt animals while also fending off the occasional cannibal. While its not listed out like your survival book, mousing over the gear icon in your craft mat will show you a list of things you can make with what you put on the mat. You book is for all placed structures; your mat is for tools, armor, weapons and herbs.

Good survival fix overall, better with friends, looking forward to the sequel.

Incredible game, full of atmosphere, quite spooky in places and I did jump a few times when lost in a cave. Completed the 'story' but I'm continuing to have fun due to the excellent survival aspect of the game.

Crafting is never a chore, its not overblown and is relatively straight forward. There is definitely an aspect of 'put in the effort and you get the rewards' when it comes to base building though, which I loved. 

On the whole, an amazing game for an amazing price, I'm now looking forward to see what this studio has coming next. EDIT: I've just seen what this studio has coming next and it looks awesome!

Don't buy this game.

Let's start with what I like: 
-great atmosphere
-sound design
-theme
-enemy design

What I dislike:
-everything else.

Building in this game is utterly atrocious, I've never seen a building system worse than this. To start with - any building is incredibly grindy. Most take 10-30 minutes of chopping and hauling logs to your base in order to build. I'm not opposed to grind in my survival games, but this is a horrible problem when...

You have no way to move buildings or adjust them after placement. Want to "dismantle" your new log cabin because the door is bugged and won't open? Your zipline is remotely near the ground and kicks you off if you ever try to use it? Placed a locked door backwards accidentally and just need to flip it? Sorry, no, you have to destroy it. The final punchline is that you get back NONE of the materials used to build it. It's incredibly easy to accidentally break parts of your base.

Let's say you want to put up with the grind and the tedium of building. Sure, build a zipline to more easily ferry logs to your base. The problem is that whenever you try to send more than 2 logs down a zipline, the physics engine breaks and they all explode into literal oblivion.

Okay, so this is rough you say, surely it's better with mods. Yeah, it can be, however, most mods do not work in multiplayer. There are mods to reduce building costs, to make placing buildings better, to make transporting logs easier, but none of these work on dedicated servers.

Speaking of multiplayer. Heaven forbid you want to actually play with other people, because this game really does not want you to. Want to give an item to another player? There is only one way to "trade" items. You need to combine the item in your crafting menu with a metal tray. Then you need to hold out the tray for the other player to interact with. This metal tray, by the way, is in the back of the plane when you start and is easily missed. Nowhere in the game tells you this. For some unfathomable reason there is no way to "drop" items (unless you count useless ones like rotten food).

The game is just filled with all of these half-baked half-assed workarounds and concepts that just go nowhere. For example, there's a sanity system that drops over time. Sounds scary, right? Well, it does nothing, except unlock some crafted furniture.

"So just play singleplayer," you say. Sure. Today I logged into my personal save and discovered all of my progress is somehow gone - my character's inventory remains, but the base that I took about 10 hours building is just gone for 0 reason.

Seriously, screw this game. It's an Early Access game that has never been finished, and now they're making a sequel. I've played half a dozen survival games that were way more polished at their Early Access/Alpha launch than this game has with years of "polish". I could go on and on about the baffling design decisions these people made. i am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

This is by far the worst "mainstream" open world survival crafting game on the market currently.  ARK has a reputation for being broken and glitchy but this is even worse.  Me and my friend absolutely love this genre but we couldn't play more than 6 hours before we gave up.  I kept getting randomly booted back to the title screen while we were playing, with none of my progress saved.  This game had so many things that bugged us but we kept going because this genre is typically pretty clunky, but that was the final straw.  

I noticed that a lot of what this game has was implemented in another Open World Survival Crafting game, Grounded.  Except EVERYTHING this game brought to the genre, Grounded did a thousand times better.  Typically I don't like comparing two games just because they're similar, but grounded really is the better version of The Forest. The only thing this game has that grounded doesn't is a "horror" setting.  But really, this game isn't scary at all so it fails at even that.

Free-form survival horror with some surprising dynamic systems.

Aside from gripes about a general lack of support over the life cycle of this game, it's a worthwhile game in the genre with an ample building and crafting system, reasonable survival needs, and a dynamic but ever present threat.  The aspect of exploring the island to gather specific components/tools as a form of progression makes it akin to an old adventure game.  The actual base building elements are arguably a little pointless but this depends on how you want to play the game.

Co-op and VR capability especially make it stand out.  Not many VR games are nearly as fleshed out as actual games, so this title working well in VR makes it particularly a major title in the VR market despite being an older game.

A boring survival game whose horror and stress relies on not being able to see in the caves, making it so you cannot tell if there are threats out there. Once the threats appear and you are able to fight them off, the game loses all scares. The combat is janky and poorly balanced due to relying on mechanics designed around survival (axe swings meant for chopping down trees, not fighting). Story is uninteresting, final boss is a poorly designed joke unless you have one of two long ranged weapons, at which point it becomes a boring slog.

The Forest starts off like the first episode of Lost, where you crash-land on an airplane in an uncharted setting with no technology. I have to admit, for as brief a cinematic as it was, the plane crash is a thrill and reminiscent of how Bioshock kicked off. Once you come to, you and your friends have free reign to navigate the island and do everything it takes to survive. You‚Äôll immediately find this is easier said than done, as you encounter your first batch of other humans.

The enemies in The Forest are tribal warriors that will demolish you if you‚Äôre not careful. They vary from intelligent survivalists to frantic savages, to abhorrent monstrosities. Other than the ax you are given from the plane, you can also craft spears for fast attacks, bows for enemies far away, and even set your foes ablaze with a combination of your lighter and a can of hairspray. Enemies tend to fight in packs, so it‚Äôs paramount that you and your friends work together to dispatch them.

The main attraction of The Forest is ironically not the areas within the trees but instead, the massive caves spread across the island. You‚Äôll find key items in these dark, expansive areas, like flashlights, chainsaws, and climbing tools for cragged rock. Past this, you‚Äôll need to manage your hunger, thirst, and body temperature. Sometimes the best food available is the tribal warrior you just killed, making cannibalism seem like a normality for survival. Morality is truly out the window in this game.

For sanctuary, you can build a nice shelter with the resources scattered about your surroundings. Chopping down trees feels great, watching them fall with great physics and a subtle creaking sound as it plummets to the ground. Once your housing is built, you can save your progress. Unfortunately, I did encounter a universal crash and lost 30+ minutes of progress at one point, so an autosave feature upon entering/exiting caves would be welcome instead of the ear-splitting bats.

In the survival game landscape, I‚Äôd still put The Forest very high on the list of quality, as the game clearly benefitted from its long development time and player input. It‚Äôs always great to see a game emerge from Early Access and earn Overwhelmingly Positive reviews on Steam. If you have a group to play with, it‚Äôs easy to recommend The Forest at this point, even several years after its initial popularity, as it‚Äôs been a blast for me so far!

This is a survival game for people who like a scary atmosphere, an interesting story, and to build stuff. The entire game could be blitzed through in one sitting, but you'll definitely enjoy it the most if you take it slow and invite along a group of friends. There are caves to explore, a handful of notable enemies to encounter, and lots of ways to die. You choose the difficulty as you see fit. 

Overall, I was impressed by how non-obtrusive yet intriguing the story was. I'm the type who almost always ignores the story in the games I play. (I generally want to get straight to the action.) But the subtle ways it was incorporated into the game play in The Forest had me interested, and when I finally decided to pursue the ending, I found myself pretty happy with the way it played out. It was nothing groundbreaking, but I enjoyed it.

I would say, though, that the main draw of this game is definitely the building. It's pretty neat to see your base gradually take shape, and to go from being the one hunted to being the hunter as enemies run straight into your traps. (At which point you generally proceed to burn their bodies and use their bones for furniture or armor, but I digress.)
its very interesting,wouldnt say its fun for just singleplayer unless u know,ur like that, but its extrmely fun with co-op

While the game is fun for the first few hours of learning the crafting and survival basics, the map is too big for objectives that are too vague on location. Once I learned all the things I would be going around with my group of friends who bought it with me to find, we all just uninstalled and moved on. It's hard enough to go a hundred feet from your safety area let alone cross the size of this map and stay alive when you're just wandering hoping to find the right object or poi.

The building and survival mechanics would be great for 100+ player online survival servers though. Something that has base raiding and maybe even vehicles. You could even keep the mutants in the game for fun but maybe they don't destroy hard earned bases.. leave that for the players to dispute.

Though very fun, it's hard to create a structurally sound base (at least it was for me) mostly due to the fact that everything is made of wood and the boss tanks it down. Though I haven't played for long but I hope to see some other form of construction to use. :) Overall a well made game, 8/10 would recommend if your into people hunting you.

This game was gifted to me by a friend who didn't know I don't enjoy games like [i]Rust[/i] or [i]Conan: Exiles[/i]. Even though I love the game mechanics in those open world games, the multiplayer game play devolves into a lulz fest.  That's fun for about hour but then I need something more satisfying than crushing your enemies, driving them before you, and hearing the lamentations of the women. Heresy. I know.

I played multiplayer only with 2 friends. We chose not to read anything on the game (unless stuck) and agreed to the shared experience of the unfolding story. The game play became stronger as we cooperated more. Sharing deeply satisfying triumphs of survival. Genuine "wtf holy hell" moments at some of the environments especially when played on a late model graphics card. We just finished it last night and...we were speechless.

The thing this game does differently than the other open world games I played is that [i]The Forest[/i] gives you a engaging narrative. A long story arc that gives you reasons to push the game mechanics in creative ways. It's not just a singular story arc either. What defines your favored experience within an open world game system end up being a foil to the story arc of [i]The Forest[/i].

Highly recommended. Arguably one of the best gaming experiences this old gamer has ever had.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Unnecessary and annoying mix of game mechanics that is clearly not dial in. Awful field of view, terrible weapon reach, ridiculous differences in game mode, pathetic illumination and artificial noise with no surround sound! Immersion breaking glitches, objects loading mid-air down to the ground, shadows move incrementally, birds fly at night, birds will flock to you and aggressive wildlife will attack no one else but you. Right hand wielding bow like with your other weapons because your magical BIC lighter, torch light and compass can only be held with your left and one at a time too, which means a constant switching to see what you are heading to or where you are heading to, and turning off and on the lights when loading your gun or when drawing your bow.

Abandonware in the bargain bin that belongs in the garbage bin! Get ready for Sons of the Forest to be even worse!

[b]The Forest Review:[/b] I'm reviewing this from a VR perspective as its's how I mainly play the game with friends. We've been hooked on the game all over again, played it before and it was an awesome game. Now I finally have it in VR thanks to my friend gifting me the game & I have to say that it's super scary. We've been working on our base for days and built over a large area and began journeying further out for resources and caves. I tell you that there is no scarier feeling than having cannibals scout your base only to return at night in large numbers to attack you and your friends, several days later we started hearing roars around the base outside our walls and that's when we realized that mutants were waiting for us outside so we started setting traps outside our base in order to fend them off. 

I tell you that the feeling of dread hits you as soon as you're surrounded. It's really a survival game, you have to drink, eat,  build & scavenge in order to obtain materials. The bigger things are the caves, that's where the main story stuff is at but going into caves is risky business if you go under equipped. We literally were chased out of a cave by mutants and skinny cannibals with our backs to the walls swinging our clubs like maniacs. Very much worth the purchase and even more if you're playing it in VR.

I didn't like this as much as similar survival games.  The problem is when you build a base, the cannibals constantly attack you.  It's not super challenging to fight them off, just annoying.  I don't mind getting raided every now and then, but getting attacked 2-3 times a day and then again at night just gets tedious.  You spend ALL your time fighting cannibals not building or exploring.  Additionally, your base defensive options are somewhat limited to a few traps and walls so you can't really automate your defenses much.  Effigies meant to ward off cannibals actually attract them!  I've read that there are ways to get around this like not building a large base (why make this an option in your game if you penalize it?), avoiding having fires at night (you know, when you need them because it's dark), avoiding their patrol routes (how would you even know where those routes are?), or moving your base, but that's pretty tedious and there's no real in game way to determine where your base will get attacked frequently.  Compare to, say, Valheim which had limited base raids, and far superior building mechanics, this is inferior in every way.  Or Subnautica with solid base building and amazing exploration.  It's too bad too, because the core gampelay actually is pretty decent.  As the devs left it (and they left it long ago), it's not a survival game it's a base defense game with very limited base defense options.

No doubt.

playing on your own is boring and stressful, and if your sense of direction is bad like mine then you'll never want to go exploring to find the caves you need to complete to get to any ending in the story.

playing with friends is one of the best experiences in existence. making a cute little house with your friends, hearing a friend saying theyre going to grab more sticks before they start screaming, followed by "so. you'll never guess what just happened." as they run back to camp from the airplane. ganging up on cannibals together and telling them to "fight back, fight back!" only to retreat when 6 more show up and outnumber you 2:1. holding the head of a squirrel around camp and telling everyone to look at what you've got. this games multiplayer is impossibly fun- in fact, it's so fun that when the game was too much for some of my friends computers to run, we spent a year without playing despite spending every month going "man i wish we could play the forest again." it is even so fun that my friend actually said "im saving money so i can get a new laptop to play the forest." not a new laptop so they could do more work or play more games in general, but get a new laptop so they can play the forest specifically. it is that fun. 

friends and i currently have built in the perfect place, close enough to the plane to make it there with enough daylight to spare. backed up to a cliff and surrounded by water on the other 3 sides so cannibals almost never cross into our area. far enough from the cannibal patrols to avoid detection normally, close enough to patrols to have a never-ending supply of cannibal bones. have we explored any caves whatsoever? no, my friends are all babies and are too scared to explore them with me, but i'm a bad fighter on my own and too impulsive so i cant be trusted to go on my own. are we still having fun while we figure out what we're best at in the game? yes- even our friend who is best at dying almost every in-game day is having fun. this is the best multiplayer survival horror game ever.

A solid horror survival game. The natives of the island can be a nuisance at times but generally speaking the game has decent enemy progression and at night time the sounds of the forest are up to the task of putting you on edge. Multiplayer is generally a good place to hang out with friends or with complete strangers if you'd prefer, griefers are a thing as with most games but they are a rarity and in most cases will be handled by the owner of the server. The atmosphere of the game is good and the flickering of the lighter is a nice touch especially when it goes out on you for a few seconds and you are left alone in the dark with only your thoughts and the distant footsteps swiftly approaching. Overall its a solid survival game that can be played by both horror game enthusiasts and Survivalists alike.

The Forest is a survival horror/crafting game set on an island with a bunch of mutant cannibals.

The reason why I am giving this a negative review is that I feel like the crafting the side of the game is under developed and the survival horror gameplay of the game wasn't really for me. In the end I quit about halfway through and don't really see myself picking it back up. Combine this with a couple of bad or at least unfun decisions and this game won't get a recommend from me.

The crafting and inventory system is very basic. You carry all resources you need (literally have a slot for each) and you never need workbenches or anything like that. You are encouraged to be a nomad. There are no rare resources or recipes to unlock, so there is no crafting progression. Basically the crafting system is there for you to figure out and then you are mostly done with it, only using it to quickly cobble together whatever you need at the moment. Your certainly CAN base build but there is no reward for it and most of the time it just hampers you.

The rest of the gameplay feels similarly basic. There are no RPG mechanics to buff skills or different abilities or a large variety of weapons, no, its just click to hit with either spear or club. Sure you dodge and block, but within 5 minutes you have figured out combat. Yes the late game enemies are more interesting to fight, so credit there, but I never felt that it rose to the level of engaging.

Really most of the game is spent in the very, very dark caves looking for items. That is how the game is progressed. And when I say dark, I mean obscenely dark. While I get the horror vibe they were going for and it does build a nice atmosphere, I had to turn up the brightness to max and change the color settings just so I wouldn't miss turns and get lost as much. Again, lost in the dark with cannibal monsters around is kind of good horror, but man was it not fun as it quickly got frustrating as I just wanted to know where to go. Not to mention that I was constantly afraid I was missing key items that I missed in the darkness, which is not the horror I think they were going for.

Speaking of the horror itself, that is the one good aspect of the game and what kept me going. The cannibals are monstrous sub-human freaks. They adorn themselves and their villages with severed and mutilated body parts. You will find grotesque totems of bound and contorted humans. And some of the late game enemies? Revolting. And great. They really instill a sense of dread in you, as you can really imagine that dying is much, much preferable to being captured by them. And even better, you can start resorting to cannibalism yourself becoming the very thing you are fighting against. Good, horrifying stuff.

There is no story here, not really, you are trying to find your son, so go kill cannibals till you do. There is SOME environmental story telling with notes and pictures around but it didn't really seem to add up to anything. The sound design and graphics are fine in my opinion, no complaints.

Last thing I do want to mention is that the colonialism optics here are not good. The cannibals are clearly sub-human, living in wooden huts, and doing things like cooking up missionaries to eat, and of course they kidnapped your son which justifies you, a white man, to slaughter them wholesale. That would be a yikes . Its basically the worst sterotypes that the colonial powers had about people they considered 'uncivilized'. Of course the distinction is that in this case the sterotypes are actually true, the island natives are not actually human (no genitals, able to run fast on all fours, seem to be incapable of complex speech, they really are needlessly violent). But the fact that this game plays into and gets so much mileage out of the 'jungle cannibal' trope is a bit gross. 

What this all adds up to is, that aside from the horror, there was almost nothing I liked about the game. I am clearly in the minority here, so I think other people got more out of the mechanics than I did, but for me, I would give this game a pass.

Another horrible adventure-craft with bad pacing and no clue what to do, expecting you to "google everything" like that's a great way to build software...no.   

Game starts, plane crash....immediately you have no water, and there's no way to find any, but of course it's gonna punish you for it.  So you have to google, why?  There's literally TWO way in the universe to get water (that is drinkable and not potentially harmful) when you start.  One is the find a "pot" which I've never found in multiple playthroughs, I'm not sure how far into the game you have to get to find it, but its' I guess RNG and nonsense to expect the player to have.  So...your best bet is....wait for it...a rain collector?  Yea, it works about as well as it sounds like it would.  I built it, and in 2 days I was ALREADY attacked several times but never got any water.  Fun.
Wanna build a base?   Yea, chop trees...that's cool, pretty standard right?  Oh, btw...it literally takes like 2 minutes to chop a tree.  By the time you get 7 logs for your "first bed/sleep thingie" you've wasted the whole first day, are tired, hungry, and thirsty.  Yea...I REALLY wanna play a base-builder when it's gonna take hours to chop down the trees for like, a couple foundations.

So, sticks and rocks, cool...other stuff you can build things with.  How many sticks can you carry? 10...how many rocks?  5....nope, not joking, like umm ok.  

Ok, killed a few animals, let's cook the meat!  Oh, you have to eat it all now?  You can't take it off the fire when its' done? Nope, eat it all now or it's gonna burn!  So, you'll waste all that unless you cook EXACTLY what you needed to eat in the moment.   

things harassing you around the base?  Less than 2 days?  you don't have walls, or traps, or any kind of protection by this point (see: how long it takes to chop trees above)...so uhh yea, the solution is "find a body of water and run in it because the mobs can't swim"...yea, fun....I'll just sit here and do nothing while I wait for them to leave.  Oh, rain collector, still nothing?  cool...

Horrible, horrible building UI....yea limme dig through this book and click on tabs to find basic things like "a firepit" or "a stone wall" ....so slow.  Then you build something and it's never on a grid, so it'll never look "neat"...yea, because people who place base-building games HATE neat and are NEVER OCD, right?  /s

Also, you don't even know what it'll cost until after you lay the ghost down....it just says "infinity" and then you build to an arbitrary length (no grid, snapping, anything...just a "stretchy" wall/platform/etc) and then it's like,oh btw that's 50 logs!    Oh, for this one platform?  You mean the things that take like 5 minutes to get a couple of?   And how long (real time) does the night last?  LONG....like, REALLY long.   

Oh, and trying to kill TINY animals with a clunky axe...yea, that's fun and not at all flakey.  Not that it matters, because water is the issue that'll stop you anyway.  Oh but don't worry, all the forest "experts" that know exactly where to go for pot spawns will tell you how silly you are for not immediately going to some random place and picking one up...

bleh...typical from devs that don't really understand how to make games, they just know how to throw a bunch of survival mechanics that have been done to death in a piece of software and sell it.  Making an actual GAME, fun, playable GAME is more than that!  

Also it's got all the typical "scripted" mechanics that survival/horror games have that feel so unnatural and punishing...like "the bigger your base is, the bigger the randomly (unavoidable) spawns that will attack you are"...umm, why?  Are the cannibals breeding?   Do they go from baby to killer-beast in 3 days?  Why?  

In the end, it's the same with all these survival/horror games...and I mean LITERALLY the same game....you either say "this is dumb" or, you slug through a bunch of non-fun stuff, for hours or maybe days, just to get to a point (most of which will be spent googling) where you can do a playthrough and then bash people for not liking the beginning.   

Waste...looks fun from the YT videos, but those guys already did their suffering.  I refuse, and I won't recommend it to anyone else (also the UI feels like it's from 1997, why?)

So... The Forest eh? Ain't gonna lie, the game is pretty bad and boring beyond belief. A friend bought it for me as a gift and honestly, I'm sorry for his wasted money on this than anything else. I would drop this game if I wasn't playing it with my friend and atleast getting to talk to him while playing this below average, overrated game.

TLDR:
Story 3/10
Graphics 6,5/10 (bit dated)
Sound 9/10
Character design 8/10 (not the cutscenes, they looked horrible)
Survival 5/10
Gameplay 8/10 (no major complaints, apart from the bugs it was playable and understandable)
Fun 2/10
Pick this up if it's on sale for a really low price or don't bother, but if it does seem like the type of game you'd enjoy, go ahead.

[b] Lengthy review below: [/b]
So, to me, the reason you'd buy this game is mainly the survival and horror-like genre and the exploration of the island, mainly the caves. Was it scary at times? Maybe, but not really? I mostly laughed rather than got scared, because the enemies getting stuck on terrain, flying up in the air and weird animations were hilarious. Survival is ok, I guess? You really don't meet any significant challenges other than the mutants and massive amounts of cannibals in later stages of the game. But you can just hide in the caves, it's safe and rich in resources there anyways. And not to forget, the caves. Ohhhh my f- god. How fast I grew bored of them. They almost don't change, are not particularly stunning and apart from the Chasm and Sinkhole cave don't pose any significant threat to you.

The basebuilding is fine, but it wasn't the most fun basebuilding I've ever seen. I for once didn't much care for it, even if I usually do enjoy it. The stuff you find doesn't really mean anything, I used the lighter 99% of the time instead of the torch, it just worked better. There are so many options for weapons, but apart from the bow, none stand out particularly in overall useability. They were more or less reskins. The other tools were fine, apart from maybe the pedometer, like fr, why is that even in the game??? 

The bugs were pretty funny but sometimes a hinderance. Like when you ride across a branch or stone with a log sled and you go flying 20 meters into the air, and this happened multiple times to me and my friend. The occasional cannibal or animal flying into the air was more funny than annoying, but it ruined the atmosphere. I did burst out laughing when a crocodile I just killed flew like 100 meters if not more in it's ragdoll pose. The most annoying bug/crash was when I tabbed out the window to play some songs, join a call on discord, etc. and the game crashed. This happened few too many times to be overlooked, and just to be safe, I didn't tab out of the game at all after experiencing this for the first few times.

The sound and art design of the enemies on the other hand, was the only thing I did actually like. It had it's minor hiccups but overall it suited the game and enhanced the experience. The mutants looked kinda scary and the cannibals were well designed. The caves are a different matter and a matter that I didn't really enjoy gameplay wise and looks wise.

Some spoilers for the crap story ahead.
[spoiler] The end game location was the second best thing in the game. I'm not talking about the Sinkhole (that one was pretty dissapointing and felt like they forgot what they even wanted to do there), I'm talking about the labs. They were genuinely fun to explore after the hours spent in the monotone caves. Shame you only spend a few minutes in them. 

The bossfight was fun, though it didn't really fill the void inside me from playing this game. It was challenging though, atleast one thing was.

The story itself? I would describe it like this: "There's a story, yeah..." The story wasn't present during the "main" game at all and the endgame felt like an almost different game from the early survival filled adventure. Saving Timmy didn't feel rewarding or gratifying, mainly because you only see him for like 2 minutes in the whole game. (Not including the cutscenes at the end) The whole story is more or less okay (a solid 3/10 for the effort), but it doesn't explain much, the random drawings and papers you find don't help it either, much less when you can't see what's on them half the time. The cutscenes at the end left even more confusion than they cleared. [/spoiler]

I for once don't really care for a second installment of the game and the story (If it should ever come out), because the first one left me really dissapointed and bored throughout apart from few (very few) shining moments of average gameplay.

The crafting menu was pretty fire tho.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

The Forest is a great game, especially when you play in the normal modes. It can be fun with friends, terrifying, and a great sense of accomplishment all at the same time. If there are two things I HATE in video games, it's survival and crafting. This game has both, but I could not stop playing. Both systems are unobtrusive enough to allow you to play the game while providing some urgency to your actions. The story is very engaging and presented in a brilliant way that keeps you coming back to uncover more until the final conclusion. You need to play this game if you haven't.

This is a fun game to play, either alone or with friends. However, I highly recommend playing this game with friends instead of by yourself. This is because, in my opinion, it is more fun to mess around while deadly mutant cannibal people are trying to kill you. Plus, I loved to hear my friends scream and curse like crazy when those mutant people came near them or when the cannibals did those weird calls in the trees (Get the game to find out). 
If you are playing for the achievements it may take you awhile to get them all because of one achievement in particular. Which is "Step Master". There are tips you can do to get it faster, but you are still going to be walking for a long LONG time. Other than that achievement the others are fairly somewhat quick to obtain.
Its a lil scary but thats what makes it fun

Brilliant game. Me and a friend played for 80 in game days before even entering the end game area, there is tons to do and plenty of exploration if you want to, but it is also able to be completed in a relatively short amount of time. The level of story is really quite dependant on you, if you explore and find all the little pieces of lore scattered around I personally found it to be quite entertaining and some interesting discoveries. Of course, if you skip the extra pieces or don't care too much then it probably isn't as good, as a lot of the story is based on player discovery. 

The building aspect is not the absolute best, but pretty good all things considered. Survival side of things is quite easy after you get the hang of things and find some of the buggy areas (such as stun-locking larger animals with a melee weapon), but it is good enough at catching you off guard that even 44 hours in with many tools we were running around cold, starving and afraid.

In terms of horror, this game does it brilliantly. The atmosphere especially in caves or deep in the forest is terrifying, and single player is, of course, significantly scarier than co-op or group servers. Some of the discoveries you will make are highly disturbing or creepy, and the enemies while not being perfect AI-wise are pretty scary, and will probably kill you. Especially on your first discovery. 

Overall this game has me very excited for the sequel, I absolutely love playing through it and considering this was created in 2014 I am looking forward to the mechanics, graphics and atmosphere of the next game. This game is very well worth the money and will not let you down.

One thing could have been great if we could have some materials back when our buildings get destroyed. I only faced one bug, half of my leg was underground. Other than that No bugs at all.
There is enough crafting materials and crafting option in the game. But again one can never say when is enough. Any cool weapons(katana, chainsaw...) or items(flashlight) can only be found in caves or unique places.

Overall I had a tremendous amount of fun playing this game. This game deserves all the praises it is getting. I just hope the next game can improve from this and still keep the fun parts.

I definitely enjoy survival games, but survival horror was a new genre for me. I'm glad I tried this game out, because I actually genuinely enjoyed playing this game. It's absolutely brutal, and filled with a ton of body horror and gore, so fair warning to that. While none of the imagery in this game bothers me personally, I have a family member whom I've played with who has a trigger regarding some imagery depicted in the game, so definitely make sure anyone you play with is comfortable with the following, and content warning for the following list:


- Hanging, nooses, etc.
- Human remain piles, both bones and flesh
- Loud, unsettling audio from cannibals screaming in distance
- Plenty of blood, including screen effects
- Uncanny amalgamations with human limbs and features


I definitely recommend giving this game a try if survival horror interests you, but definitely be aware that some imagery is not suitable for all ages, and can be disturbing to some.

My husband and I purchased the game early access and it was a lot of fun to play co-op!

(I've put in quite a few hours solo as well, but did not complete the game solo.)

The building system is fairly robust. If you are building a very large base, the resource gathering can be a bit grind-y, especially playing solo. But the time investment does pay off because you can build a pretty cool base!

The mutants can be a good level of challenging playing solo mode. Playing co-op the threat significantly declines, so I felt the "horror" element wasn't really there, but still a little bit of a challenge. 

I really enjoyed the story... we played back when the ending was first released and I believe there was only one ending at the time - but saw on YouTube there are now at least a couple endings. 

Since we purchased the game Early Access I think it was around $10 and amazing value... even full price (currently $19.99) I would still highly recommend this game if you're a fan of this genre.  I will definitely be purchasing Endnight's next game, Sons of the Forest!

I want to start out by saying I'm terrible at this game and I'm also playing solo when I'm fairly sure this game is not designed to be played solo, because of these two things I don't think I've really got too far into the nooks and crannies of the game yet. I figure 30 hours though, might be time to make an initial review. 

When I first played this I decided "it's too hard I don't like it" and stopped for ages, now I'm getting back into it I kind of like the challenge because it feels like an actual survival game. This isn't a game where you're the main character so fighting off a gang of ten attackers is as simple as hitting a button, you will have to out-think you enemies or outrun them. There's a good little adrenaline boost when it's been multiple hours since you last saved and it's pitch black and you hear those tell-tale footsteps of multiple enemies encircling you while you stumble through the trees back to your camp. 
Huddling by the fire while the rain pelts down, the air is freezing and the locals are beating on your walls is immersive af. Exploring the map is fun and while it isn't huge there's plenty to see, I've spent a good portion of time seeing the sights and that's without even having delved too deep into the caves yet. Watching the locals go about their daily lives is interesting, seeing how they interact with the world around them and what they make of your effect on their environment (they are NOT pleased about me making a big fort right on one of their patrol routes, for instance) is, for me, just as much fun as fighting them or escaping from them. 

There ARE some issues with the game, things that seem unfinished and bugs and glitches that will annoy the crap out of you but so far I've not found anything gamebreaking and have been able to adapt to every issue. 

If you're looking at this game and thinking "I dunno if I should buy it, I don't think my friends will play it, it looks too difficult to me" I'm gonna say you know what, just try it. Just dive on in. You'll most likely find yourself tired, hungry and dehydrated irl because you've spent the last 6 hours making your base look pretty and that's a sign of a good game.
