I've never experienced a game that leaves you afraid of what lies behind the trees in the dark, This game does a fantastic job at playing with tension and creating the sense of a real world situations and leaving the journey in the player's grasp. Beginning with a plane crash on a naked cannibal island it gives bioshock meets minecraft throwing you in an open sandbox with enemies all over. Allowing you to feel alien in your new yet familiar setting, fighting for your life whether creeping your way through the woods alone at night or forgetting your son's existence. I haven't been able to find another game that I've had this much fun with. It's one of the best survival games I've played in recent memory. I cannot wait for the forest 2

So me and my friends picked this game up for 5-8 dollars (can't remember exactly but cheap) and played it expecting a couple of days of a goodish survival game with some weird cannibal sub-plot, we ultimately got way more then we were expecting. None of us don't really enjoy playing survival games and we especially don't play more for than 2 or 3 sessions, The Forest was different. We ended up coming back to discover what lore was tucked away in this forest every other day (way more then we usually find time for). We also were quite often concerned for each others safety even near then end when were more or less decked out, constantly working to survive and constantly keeping aware of our surroundings (we played on hard mode).
 It also was the first time the 3 of us reached an ending to a story where we all wanted different paths or were torn on which result we wanted from the game (we normally just quickly settle on want suits us as a group) we were invested in different ways. 
Do I think this is the most polished or the best game to be released? Was it the best survival or the best story we have ever played... probably not but damn does this game surprise you in all of those categories, it really does, honestly it is really good at that. If you find this game at a price you are satisfied with please play it all the way through, it is worth it.

One of the best survival and open world games I have played, can easily be run on my Surface Pro 7+ on the highest graphics, gorgeous game. It has the full experience for those who just want to build and have a casual play through, and people who want some challenge. Even their normal mode can be a little difficult, but in a positive way. It progressively gets more difficult as you play on and build more structures. And without revealing too much, you are not alone on the island, so build up some defenses! YouTube videos might be required for a few things here and there, or you can challenge yourself, but overall a well-made game with fantastic AI and progressive difficulty. Seriously, well done to the development team. Could not applaud more.

The Forest is a fun game but it isn't without its problems. 

I feel there isn't much I can say for gameplay that sets itself apart from other survival games from the time but I'll admit that while other have stayed in Early-Access limbo, the developers of this one did see it through to the end and are working on a sequel which looks vastly better.

BUT... There some issues. Firstly, it was clearly made in Unity. The caves and massive sinkhole in the centre of the map are rather janky and the most dangerous parts of the map or caves don't tend to yield the best loot. For e.g. there is just 5 cannibals between the entrance of the cave and the modern axe which has the best block in the game while [spoiler] the keycard to reach the end of the game is protected by just one mutant [/spoiler]. Meanwhile, the modern bow, which is not that good of an upgrade from the bow you craft in protected by 2 massive enemies. 

Worth the purchase still if you have friends to play with!

There's glaring issues from the first minute of gameplay. Picking up items often requires surgical accuracy. Chopping trees bugs out and you lose stamina for nothing. I got FPS drops pretty frequently no matter the graphical settings. AI sucks ass. Enemies run in circles and birds fly straight into your mouth. You can't drink water from a spring, but sometimes can drink from a still pond, which gives you diarrhea. Plastic, metal and booze bottles everywhere but you can only hold water in a waterskin made of deer skin. The brightness and contrast options do absolutely nothing, and I had to squint my eyes 10 cm from the monitor every time I was in a cave or it was night. Also sometimes you have to wait for like 5 minutes in absolute darkness before you can sleep through the night. The character can't survive 2 seconds in snow, and once you get a warmsuit and explore the snowtop, there's absolutely nothing there. You need a raccoon skin for the warmsuit, but I didn't see one raccoon for the 30 days I was on the island, and had no idea I needed a raccoon skin before I googled it. Those are most of the problems I had.

So I completed the game and I got no achievement for it, which seemed odd. So I checked and indeed, there is an achievement for completing the game. So I googled more, and when there are 2 options on how to end the game [spoiler](one is that you let past be past and the other is that you kill a plane full of people)[/spoiler], the good guy option doesn't grant you the achievement. So I reloaded a save from 1 hour past and did the final boss and completed the ending again, [spoiler]this time making sure I murder all those people[/spoiler], just to get the achievement. Jesus. Oh and you can't skip cutscenes or the credits.

Poor UI choices, missing quality of life settings, especially for VR. 
We ended up losing all our progression even though we saved because of a bug. Server started spamming null ref exceptions.

Experience playing multiplayer for about an hour and a half. Ran into some game breaking bugs, loss of progress, and buggy server-side code causing clients to be kicked spontaneously.

The game feels a bit too janky, unintuitive, and confusing system to really want to bother trying to look past the loss of save data. That's something a released game should -never- have, not to mention 3-4 years after it's release date. 

Combat with a co-op part has poor feedback as well, trying to help friends kill enemies I had no idea I was also cleaving them with attacks. 0 feedback to me that I was actually hitting friends. 

Inventory and crafting system seems cool and unique, it's kind of annoying once you overlook the gimmick. I'd rather a list of possible crafts that I have available to me than slapping 1 item in at a time and checking the available options are then guessing what the icons mean. 

Carry limit is weird and doesn't follow convention of what other survival games do. You can carry every item in the game at once, but only up to a certain limit for each one. But if you ONLY want to carry stone, you can only ever hold up to to 5. I'd rather a weight system or some other form of inventory management than whatever logic this is.

[h1]What is this :  Survival crafting / basebuilding with cannibals.[/h1]
[b]85/100 [/b] 
[b]Playtime [/b] : 27h37 (1 normal campaign playthrough)
[b]Death [/b] :  5
[b]Crash [/b] : 0

[b]Perfected [/b] : working on it, hardest achievements are done üòÑ
[b]Recommended [/b] : Yes
[b]Controller support [/b] : Yes
[b]Replayable [/b] : yes
[b]Price [/b] : 22.79$ often goes down 60% for 9.11$
[b]Worth to me [/b] : 20$

[h1]PROS :[/h1]
* Crafting possibility : like Subnautica, stranded Deep, etc. you get quite a few premade building you can make, but you also have "expandable" structure like walls and zipline that you can extend to your heart's contempt's.
* Not easy combat, you will have to exploit what is at your disposal and keep escape route open.  The enemies AI is well crafted, with enemies sometimes circling you before attacking, not necessarily attacking one at a time.
* Enemies have a hierarchy which makes for interesting things.  If you paint yourself they think you are a god and will possibly momentarily leave you alone and/or kneel before you.  Some cannibals are leaders and killing them can make the others scatter for some time.  Some cannibals were seen crying their dead which is an interesting addition, making it all so much more immersive.
* Pretty much everything is hidden in caves, forcing you into narrow corridors and unfamiliar terrain to fight the cannibals.
* Big mutants are definitely changing the beat of the game. as you get used to fighting cannibals, you are faced with these things that have the upper hand and you have to develop different fighting tactics.
* The map is varied with different biomes, different terrain, different resources spawning in different places. 
*Story is a bit confusing at first, but everything unfolds nicely near the end.

[h1]CONS :[/h1]
* Item crafting is weird and there is no efficient crafting recipe log where you can search what you can possibility build and look for the resources. (Except the internet of course)
* Night and caves are SOOO dark, unless you use alternate graphic options. (Texas color grading helps a lot) Can craft a torch, can't hold it in your left hand for light while using the axe.  Lighter and torch don't send light far enough, making it impossible to navigate at night.  This can really bring the spooky vibes, but if you are trying to play on youtube and/or stream, you're viewers won't see a thing and progress will be very slow as you'll need to craft tiki torch as you progress which will require you going back and forth to get resources to advance a little bit.  Water is also completely blurry, making it impossible to see anything.  To prevent you going into the water with fear of shark, that is perfect.  If you are however trying to find something underwater, it is very hard.  Try playing with ocean quality set to "flat". This last bit is much easier once [spoiler]you get the rebreather (it has a light on it!)[/spoiler]
* Many mechanics are very obscures.  Ex : when sneaking, when the eye is lit, does it mean very visible or very hidden?  Took a bit to figure out as I seemed to sometimes be completly hidden yet the eye was full.  Aiming with spear/bow. Upgrading weapons.  Strength, athleticism, sanity, and calories (hard survival mode only) also required me googling how they work. Once you get used to them however, it makes a really nice game with a unique style.  Never has throwing a spear been so realistic...in the sense that i miss 90% of my targets...
* Sleeping mechanics? You can't sleep until the circle is filled at the bed, but it doesn't represent time of the day?  Had to wait 3/4 of the night to sleep once.  WTF is it?!  From reading online, I understand the goal is to force you to not simply sleep all nights away and have to endure the darkness and fear. With normal settings where night is too dark, that often means standing around and doing nothing for a while.  Kills the beat of the game.
* Massive mutants are cool to vary the game. However, when they spawn near your base, they can cause damage that represents a massive amount of work before you even know it.  Especially if they spawn in group of 3...  This can get annoying as it feels like whatever you build has to be temporary.  Alternatively, you need to select a base location before starting, knowing where mutants don't spawn.

I've been playing since the times of trees falling on your base and exploding on impact, the log sled shooting you up into the sky and insta-killing all enemies by touching them with the tip of a fire arrow. Holding a lizard by it's tail and showing the head of a shark to my friends really made me the man I am today, thanks The Forest for all these years of fun. 

You won't regret this purchase.

I recommend this game both for casual and veteran gamers for the following reasons:

1. Its atmosphere is very welcoming, but can also be scary in certain places. That's why the multiplayer option is there.
2. The concept is fresh and unique. A must experience game for any video game enthusiast.
3. Exploration is fun. There is no dull moment in this game. The thrill of exploring unknown territory, along with the fact that you're risking your life to look for your son, is addicting.
4. The AI here actually feels alive. Combined with the graphics, it makes you feel like you're actually in the game yourself. The environment, the cannibals, and the animals are just so immersive in its own right.
5. The inventory and crafting mechanic is realistic and interesting. Personally, I just wow'd at every new item that I crafted for the first time.
6. Not to mention the building mechanics are also fun. It's not hard to learn, and it's interesting to experiment with the building materials. Although there will be bugs and some minor issues associated, I don't find them that big of a deal.
7. Even if this is a game, your survival skills will be challenged. Incompetence in preparation before setting out can make a difference.
8. The combat mechanics is okay. If you're not creative with how you fight the enemies, you'll end up using a lot of resources, and unnecessarily lose HP. Basically, be smart with how you use your weapons!

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Great ambience, inventory management is a bit quirky at first but super nice once you get used to it. Playing solo gives you one of the best actual survival feels in the genre. Is it completely perfect? no, but it's definately  worth the price.

Overall it's an excellent survival horror game and the base building is fantastic. Enemies react to how you behave and they are heavily influenced by how you play and set up camps: playing a more hidden approach with several small tree houses will result in less night time attacks, and a more defensive approach with advanced traps and big walls in one spot will result in more night time attacks. The atmosphere is dripping, for example, when you crawl through a dark cave and you hear a low clicking growl akin to a giant spider bear... then you spot a glimpse of something large and fleshy moving in the dark... It's so good.

There are things I don't like, which are all kind of minor in the grand scheme of things, such as: [list]
[*] The longer you survive, the bigger base you build and the more enemies you kill... the more the enemies will attack and up their game in terms of strength, which results in large enemies that can one-shot your camps. It feels counter-productive to set up bases, survive and kill off attackers because you know that it'll only make things worse and it could all be deleted in one attack. 
[*] The combat is also janky with bad hit reg, clunky movements and bad shooting where arrows bounce off of invisible walls all the time. 
[*] It's either too dark or too bright, unless you change settings back and fourth between outside day time and night time / cave exploring. Even with the seperate setting for cave brightness set to max you won't see far in a cave. I see this design choice as good in thought, but poor in practice. 
[*] The story is really messed up and kind of poor (I'm guessing its the canon one, since it has the most content and is the most obvious path). [/list]

The Forest is, at its heart, a very simple game: you‚Äôre stranded after a plane crash and must survive the unwelcome cannibals and mutants that populate the land and want to pulverise you into delicious man-burgers. To avoid becoming someone‚Äôs dinner, you can forage, build and scavenge.

Perhaps the key draw of the game is the base-building. This is a rather clunky affair, with logs, stones and sticks being the main building elements. There is no realism involved here beyond the basics: no turning a log into planks to make it go further, no cementing stones together, no harvesting sticks from the trees you cut down. However, you can construct ziplines, a variety of bizarrely huge and complex traps and weird things like skull chandeliers. Frankly, there hasn‚Äôt been much logical thought put into the building side of things but, despite this, it is a lot of fun, and dodging enemy patrols to go and grab some materials from a nearby spooky copse so you can finish off a roof and avoid a downpour can be terrifyingly exciting.

Injury physics don‚Äôt exist: a head-shot will kill a cannibal outright but shoot one several times in a leg and it will still run around as normal. The AI is much-vaunted and is commendable and interesting but it didn‚Äôt really impress me: cannibals either see you and attack; or they see you and don‚Äôt attack, essentially. Really interesting AI would have allowed me to very slowly gain trust with some of them, perhaps even achieving simple trading. Fauna AI is almost non-existent: a deer will commonly stand there while you beat it to death.

The gore level is very high and to the point where it becomes a bit silly and ineffective.
 
The graphics are still acceptable with the basic textures in some places being offset by the gorgeous floral ensembles in others.

Regardless of all of the above, my experience has been absolutely plagued by bugs and crashes and, while some of those might be due to the variables of PC gaming, there were so many crashes (of different types) that I‚Äôm sure some are due to the game itself. Searching online for solutions shows that others endure the same problems.

If I could save my game whenever I wanted to in order to mitigate lost progress (you can only save at certain points) then I would be recommending The Forest.

If it‚Äôs cheap or you‚Äôre on the fence, or you‚Äôre good at ironing out the bugs then I say go for it. Just don't expect a deep, realistic survival game.

At first glance, the game may seem to have a weak storyline that can be completed in less than 1 hour, a small list of buildings, a joystick with a bad adaptation, etc.  

But despite all the disadvantages, a week after the end of the game, you are drawn to return back.  And when you accidentally saw that a sequel to the game is coming out in 2022, you begin to look forward to it.

The story telling is vivid and the experience is amazing. The crafting system is the best I have seen and the building system is very enjoyable. You can hunker down in a nice log cabin or you can enjoy a life at sea. There is nothing wrong with this game and is a must for any survival enthusiast!

Overall, this is a good game. I would highly recommend playing it with friends.

Graphics are decent, physics - very good and game isn't "glitchy" as you might think. Story of this game and your quests/tasks are interesting. Playing it on solo mode is okay, but it's much more grindy and terrifying. The fact that game is horror genre and a survival, makes it anti-fun when played solo. Roaming over map at nights, at solo mode - forget about it, unless you want hearth attack.

Multiplayer mode in this game is whole different story. Makes this type of game (horror survival) actually fun and less scary at the same time. Just by knowing you are not alone and that you can build/craft things way faster. 

This is usual for horror games, but it's worth mentioning - the more you play the less scary it is. For example, when you stumble upon some cannibal or monster for the first time, yeah - you pretty much run away. But later on, you will be farming those for breakfast - literally :)

The only cons I could mention are:

- Fight mechanics --- not that good. Fighting doesn't feel real. It's more like swinging and expecting to hit. Same way on the other hand, sometimes you think enemy won't hit you but it does and vice versa.
- Visibility when using lights, torches etc. --- Sometimes it doesn't 'light your path' at all. You can light up a torch and almost never is 'better/brighter'. Multiplayer mode perfectly explains this 'issue'. By lighting a torch or turning the lamp on, it's way brighter on your friends screen then on yours and vice versa. 

To sum thins up - yeah, buy this game, play it with your friends, have fun/laugh a lot. Then uninstall it and leave it in your steam inventory till' your younger brother or cousin says "Hey, do you have some game that I can play?" then reinstall it, grab popcorn and watch them freak out :)

This is such an interesting game, and it's put some hypnotic trance on me. An obsession would phrase it lightly, but i dream about this game haha. I guess I enjoy that there is multiplayer and it makes it a whole different world. I am definitely going to sink a sh*t ton of hours into this and lose my mind. Can't recommend this game enough, grab your chainsaw and get ready to destroy naked cannibals.

played this with a lot of friends, and the story is driving even in multiplayer. unique weapons are interesting, but not abundant. combat is a mix of easy and hard varying from enemy to enemy. while building can create impressive structures, there are much too many limitations to have it be described as good. reviewing this game now is pointless, but the sequel will hopefully improve on it all. the survival elements are not particularly hard, especially with infinite fish, and breeding rabbits. with an improvement to building and possibly travelling, this game would be quite possibly one of the better survival games of all time. sons of the forest should hopefully fill all the holes this game left, with the addition of electricity and more complex crafting. i enjoyed playing this game with my friends, although some things do become rinse and repeat.

This is a game with a lot of good ideas and a lot of problems. Overall it's pretty fun, but I won't recommend it because I can not condone selling an unfinished bugged mess like this. I played it multiplayer exclusively. The review would probably get too long if I were to write my thoughts about it randomly, so I'll just list and summarize all my points.

The good:
-large and beautiful world to explore
-can craft a base, decent level of customization
-interesting survival mechanics

The bad:
-one of the most buggy games I have ever played, honestly feels like playing an alpha. Nothing seems to work properly. Lots of item duplication, game crashes, flying items due to poor collision/physics interactions, persistent graphical bugs, the strength mechanic simply doesn't work in multiplayer for the non-hosts (you can only gain 2 strength by session even though it should be 2 by ingame days), sometimes when you start building something it will bug out so that you can feed it items but those items won't count towards the completion of the project
-lots of things can just despawn right in front of your eyes
-the base building is 100% optional. There's basically nothing to gain from building a base as far as the main objective of the game, cave exploration, is concerned.
-when playing solo the game gives you the map key item, but in multiplayer you have to stumble upon it
-the map is a mess. The simplistic outlines to make it appear as if it was hand-drawn is alright. The cursor representing your position being imprecise both in time and space is not, the weird and incomprehensible way map segments are drawn upon discovery is not, and inversely, the way you can somehow map things that are in adjacent inaccessible tunnels without ever seeing them is not. You can't even get to properly map the entrance of most caves. Was this ever tested? I don't think so.
-the inventory is a monstrosity. It is so bad that it could even be used as an example of what not to do for future developers.
-building a base takes eons and a lot of utility buildings like the ziplines barely work
-the "can't sleep now" timer is abhorrent and works inconsistently when restarting the server. I don't even really get why they bothered to implement this. Wasted time that should have been spent fixing bugs.
-the story and setting aren't worth mentioning
-most of the game settings (graphical, sound etc) just don't work. As in, they literally do nothing.
-I have never been much of a fan of games that use darkness to prevent you from seeing stuff. I just find the mechanic unfun.
-contextual actions on a button are a terrible idea most of the time, and here the gameplay difference between attacking down or horizontally is a huge problem in my opinion
-enemy AI is silly, lots of enemies stuck running in circle, running towards a wall etc
-losing your stats and upgrades with death in multiplayer is ok, but losing map completion isn't

The game feels simple but refined. There are some gimmicky quirks but overall I found the experience to be unique in its own. The ominous presence of unpredictable enemies makes for an enjoyable challenge. Sometimes you might feel like your base's defence and your overall strategy are on point until a rhino-mutant  strolls along and knocks your walls down like toothpicks and slamfists you in a corner until you have no armor. The constant need to re-think defence and the way enemy types gather or respond to DIY mazes or trap-paths you have carefully engineered drives the connection you have to the game. The flunky online map only compliments the randomness of enemy pathways. I only played for ~80hours with a significant portion of menu time since pressing Esc pauses the game. This is a great novelty if your used to multiplayer. The game's biggest caveat is that it is simple. I couldn't imagine playing for any longer without having to change my location and difficulty. Not being able to modify structures and manually destroying them to delete is also a drag. 

I straight up chose a difficult campsite which only became apparent when playing with some friends and seeing how quiet the map can be in other parts. MP could increase overall game time for a few more hours with team play usually requiring the need for more constructables/consumables/storage etc. Also sailing around is pretty cool. The scary elements of the game are done well and that's why you never feel completely safe with crocs, sharks, all types of mutants and cannibals that chase you down. 

Well rounded single-player game that deserves a couple of weekends. Looking forward to the sequel in September.

So I want to start off by saying that the game is fun but the no I don't recommend this game is for the crafting system the other part of this game. things to note is the broken zip line for moving logs over long distances and the sudden explosion at the end when you come into the load range if you send over too many, the fact that this game is both single-player and multiplayer yet the large raft is useless in single-player due too needing 2 people to move it. The large raft should have just one oar in the middle of the two it already has right under the platform and ditch the two it already has. The building system for buildings is so broken it's not even laughable. Floors should be 8' X 8' squares that you place and then build and they should snap together rather then the one click and drag that you can't even put a hole in for stairs inside your house...... STUPID!. The day/night cycle is way to short. The chainsaw's fuel consumption is worse the a semi truck. There needs to be more storage options for other things in your inventory like more baskets for dynamite or other explosives, furs, ropes and so-on.

PS. Forgot to mention that the house boat's oar is backwards. you can't see where your going to the left side and the load/unload ramp is in the back in it's current configuration. Turn the oar around so that the back becomes the front and you will be able to see where your going much better and dock alot easier. Also the basic log holder 7 logs while the upgraded one holds 12 and not 14 even though there's room enough for two more logs.

The island is pretty nice looking despite the games age. The enemy AI is interesting and feels somewhat lifelike, often just moving about the island and scouting the world until they find players. They communicate with each other, growl and size up the player, climb trees and perch on rocks. The enemies are simple but reactive enough that they still feel like a challenge and interesting to fight. Those are just the regular ones too.

Great decisions were made to give players options to play in creative mode and disable building destruction.

But...

[h1]
How am I playing in a dark room with gamma and my monitors brightness maximized and I still can't see shit in this game
[/h1]

The sleep cooldown doesn't even line up with nighttime, so I have to wait like 5 minutes in the dark before I can skip back to day. Why is there even a cooldown on sleeping? if you simply must restrict the ability to sleep, why not just allow the player to sleep at night like minecraft?

This game is full of frustrating mechanics that seem to lack polish. Holding shift while standing still drains stamina. Sitting on a bench prevents you from crafting or using menus. Items sometimes can't be picked up. I can't pick up a story item because the item doesn't react to anything.
Cave jumpscares (bats usually) are louder than any other sound in the game for no reason. They play every time you reenter the cave or get near the entrance, and even though I know they're coming they're so loud that they still make me flinch. 
Building mechanics sometimes just don't work for no reason. I can only build regular campfires in my treehouse, but I can't build standing fires (torches). I can't align stairs on the same height as my a platform, and even trying to line it up manually is impossible because the game doesn't let you orient objects on the Z axis separately from the X/Y axis.

This game is cool but every aspect of the game has some kind of problem attached to it. They all add up to make an aggravating experience. Hopefully the sequel is more polished after the release date has been delayed

Dangers of Cocaine
Young people are surrounded by pro-drug messages in the media and on the Internet. They may try cocaine for the excitement or the experience without realizing the very real risks and consequences that come with cocaine use.

As a parent, you are your child's first and best protection against drug use. The following is information from the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) about cocaine and how to help your child say "No" to drug use. (Child refers to child or teen)

Cocaine use affects health and well-being
Cocaine stimulates the nervous system, causing brief euphoric feelings, increased alertness, talkativeness, and a sense of empowerment. People high on cocaine can also be sweaty, restless, and dizzy, and have nausea and vomiting. People coming down from cocaine effects may feel sad, have delusions or paranoia, and even think about suicide.

Acute effects
Cocaine use increases heart rate and blood pressure, and can lead to abnormal heart rhythms and lethal heart attacks‚Äîeven in young people who are healthy. Cocaine use can also cause seizures and strokes.

Cocaine is a very addictive drug
Cocaine is highly addictive. Cocaine use, even soon after starting, leads to loss of control over use, and strong cravings to use more and more cocaine more often. Drug use must continue regularly or else the user will have withdrawal symptoms, including lethargy, muscle weakness, irritability, slowed comprehension, and depression. Drug addiction does not have a quick and easy cure, but medical care is a very important part of addressing addiction and recovering health.

How is cocaine used?
Cocaine is sold as a powder and is usually inhaled, or snorted, through the nose. The powder also can be melted into a liquid and injected directly into a vein.

Crack is a smokable form of cocaine that is prepared from powder cocaine. Crack is relatively inexpensive. Smoking crack increases not only the rapidity and intensity of the cocaine high, but also the risk of addiction.

Signs of cocaine use
Recognizing the signs of drug use is the first step in getting help for your child, but some signs are vague. Consider cocaine or other drug use if your child

Spends less time with family and friends and more time alone or away from home
Loses contact with friends or changes friends
Is frequently irritable and argumentative, and often loses control of his behavior
Begins to skip classes, shows up late for school, or has a drop in grades
Loses interest in hobbies
Stays out all night or runs away
Develops sleep or appetite problems
Has a big change in weight or appearance
Shoplifts or steals money
Possesses drugs or drug paraphernalia, such as mirrors, razor blades, spoons, or lighters

I've never felt so actively on edge and anxious playing a game. The way that it triggers my fight or flight instincts so perfectly is absolutely insane. It's not your typical horror at all, there's this pinch of realism to it that just makes you feel in the moment, as if you're actually there, and I'm honestly finding that I love it.

If you have friends, I highly suggest that you play this together. If you solo, I wouldn't suggest any difficulty higher than easy. Normal is not impossible, but two or three hits from an average enemy can take you completely out and most of them travel in packs of 3 to 8 so, solo at your own risk bro

Purchased this in 2019. Played through and beat it with my partner, but continued on to build an elaborate base and fight all sorts of specials for weeks thereafter.
It's 2022 now and I still come back to it every few months. Even if you don't play the campaign again once you've finished it, it's such a thoroughly enjoyable, well-executed, and well-conceived experience.

As a British Columbian, I'm super impressed by how accurately Endnight have recreated the beauty and moody ambience of their native British Columbia's temperate rainforests, 

I've been a gamer my whole life and an archer since 2008. This means I tend to gravitate towards any game that has a bow as a weapon... and this game still has by far the most natural, most intuitive and realistic archery I've ever played. I can't quite express how difficult that is to achieve. 7 Days, Rust, Scum, a number of other survival games I've had the pleasure of playing‚Äînone have managed to come close to The Forest in terms of accuracy in their experience of archery.

Would love to see the next iteration include some kind of community-building, similar to that in Rust.
From the moment I started my adventures in The Forest, this game has continued to be one of my top 3 favourite games of all time, and I've bought it for several friends over the years purely out of love for this game, and my compulsion to share it with as many people as I can.

Truly brilliant work, Endnight!

I was minding my own business with my son Timmy, enjoying our plane flight and considering a nap because the in-flight entertainment options were kind of limited. Suddenly, our plane encountered turbulence and as is usual for such times, we went through some explosive decompression issues and ended up in one third of a plane. Good thing I pre-purchased seats in the tail section.

I woke up in my seat sometime later - alone, hungry, thirsty and with only the dead body of a flight attendant to keep me company. As is usual for such times, I immediately stole her clothing and everything I could find that wasn't nailed down. 

I then consulted my handy survival guide and built myself a hunting shelter, a fire pit and explored my immediate surroundings. Let's just say the locale was weird and apparently hostile to the other foreigners who had gone exploring before me.

On my way back to my camp / the plane wreckage, I met some emaciated locals who did not understand English. As is usual for such times, I chased them down and brutally slaughtered them with my improvised hunting implements. Harvesting their naked bodies for bones, teeth, nutritious carbohydrates, protein and fats, and heads to keep me company, I congratulated myself on a job well done. I had survived my first day in the forest!

That was some time ago. These days I'm somewhat of a local celebrity, distinguishing myself from the common rabble here by painting my body red and mashing my rivals into piles of bloody pulp with my trusty "mace"; a large skull on a stick covered with human teeth (and the remains of those who have irked me). This impromptu vacation has really put me in touch with my best self and I sincerely hope that Timmy has found similar success in his exploits, wherever he may be.

Now, having improvised a respectable gaming computer from materials sourced here, I am preparing to play this game called The Forest. I'm not sure what it's about but as is usual for such times, I am anticipating a wholesome entertainment experience to distract me from my life of violence, subjugation and cannibalism.

This is a crappy game and not at all what I thought it would be after seeing the vids on it.  I'm actually mad I wasted 6 bucks on it (guess that should have told me)  Building in the game is very awkward - time consuming - and just plain confusing.  I feel like I'm playing a game from back in the 80's . . . swinging your meager axe against the antagonists is spotty - you click and don't swing or sometimes you do - still can't figure it out how you defend yourself.  You get a bic lighter that your character will automatically try to light when it's dark or you're in a cave.  Problem is he's still trying to light it when it's daylight and you can't stop him . . . glitchy.  Everything in this game is micromanaged - for example if you want to drink clean water you have to find a pot and boil it. . . you can't get a pot until after you've dispatched cannibals - dispatching cannibals is a cluster****

Your char. is constantly hungry and thristy - you spend more time trying to locate food items which rapidly spoil on you and you can't keep it on your inventory until you get a drying rack - good luck getting to make that before they find you and you're in some cave trying to get back to camp which has a cannibal in hiding waiting to take you out.

You die - game over - no respawning - have to go back to a prev saved file.  (again just like 80's games)  Overall, the game was a good idea ruined by poor execution and horrible game play.  Wouldn't buy this for a dollar.   Truth be told - I've only played the game for roughly 5 hours.  (4 of which were in peaceful mode) I don't know if I can get my money back as I've never felt the need to do so (but I'm gonna try)

Don't buy - just look at it and move on.

[h1]This game has ADHD[/h1]
It's got great aspirations, but it tries to do too many things at once, but doesn't complete any of them, so the whole product suffers. I have no idea why this has "Overwhelmingly Positive" reviews (at the time of my purchase and of this review).  Here are a few of the reasons I wouldn't recommend this to anyone.
[hr][/hr]
[b]Crafting [/b]- The crafting system is unclear and difficult/frustrating to navigate. Half of the things you can build or create are in your guidebook, and the other half are cryptically available as you put items into your crafting area. [i]Is that a Chicory, Coneflower, or a Marigold icon? Where the heck do I find Aloe Vera?[/i]

[b]Harvesting[/b] - It takes 89 logs to make a cabin, 4-5 logs per tree, 15-20 chops with your tiny axe each, (about 300 chops to get only the logs. Need Sticks? You can find them on the ground, and saplings give you 2, you need 21 to do this one small thing. And no, [i] you can't break logs down into sticks.[/i] Need Food? Just go kill and chop up a cannibal, then eat them. It lowers your sanity, but sanity [i] literally means [u]nothing[/u][/i]. So the bad guys are literally just food with zero consequences. They're way easier to find, and they deliver themselves!

[b]Enemy/Combat System[/b]  - The enemy difficulty curve goes really high, very quickly. There's very little in the way of time to learn how the mechanics work, before you get called to dinner by the locals,  tonight's special could be you, or them.

7 Days to die does all of these so much better, and so much more on top of that. Honestly, don't waste your time or money on this one.

I am 42.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.
Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

I bought this game while it was discounted by 70% (less than ¬£5) which seemed a good deal and was little to lose if it didn't live up to my expectations. Generally I am not a fan of survival games as they bore me or have toxic MP environments however this one I have monitored for quite some time so thought it worth trying out.

So far I am in the early stages of this game having racked up a trivial 1 hour and still trying to get  familiar with the controls, building, hunting, exploring and staying alive. Those cannibals, the human type, have given me a rough time but not deterred me from venturing out. I read that around the 7 day mark I will eventually meet more aggressive, violent, mutant cannibals which I'll have to deal with. Here's hoping I can survive that.

I managed to find the yacht quite by accident which has become my temporary base to save games and rest till I explore further and decide on where I want to locate and build my home base. Having read a couple of guides, it matters where you build it, so will take than into consideration before I do anything.

The graphics are pretty good. Being stared down by a cannibal or a group of them can be unsettling as you're left thinking if they will attack or run away. Night brings its own problems as you're limited on how far you can see with your lighter plus you're vulnerable to being attacked before you can react.

I have not yet tried co-op, just single player so far. I look forward to joining with a friend later to see how this goes.

In all, I am quite impressed with the game and would recommend it.

I like the game itself, the theme is very cool. But there are a couple of issues game-play wise. For a starters, the location where you crashed your plane randomises every time you start a new game. Also there is a very big immersion killer, the location where the rear of the plane crashes (the starting point) dose not in any way shape or form look like a plane smashed into the ground, all the trees, bushes or even the ground itself look intact, the rear half of the plane looks like it was teleported there. That's a strong dislike. The second issue i have encountered with the gameplay is even under "normal" difficulty the enemy NPCs are extremely overpowering still, you as a normal human take swings with the axe quite slowly so you end up beaten up and dragged into their lair very easy. The enemy NPCs should technically die from a blow to the head or have a high chance of a limb cut off or severely injured but they somehow take many hits and you simply get beaten up. I'm talking about the human looking creatures, nothing else. I had to literally switch to peaceful mode just to get some sort of game play going on. There is not a very good balance between the beasts and you. 

There is certainly a big thumbs up for creepy and scary AF, very detailed body parts and gore is present, the character looks and feels realistic especially when you are covered in blood. I am not sure what the plans are with this game but i shared my concerns, you may consider it on sale which means you only loose about 10 dollars. I do suggest the concerns to be addressed to make it more enjoyable

This game has a lot of potential, but fails utterly to meet its mark and is NOT WORTH 20 something dollars. The resource cost for buildings and the damage enemies do to your buildings needs a major rework. Structures/shelter take too many resources to build and is too easily destroyed by late-game enemies. Another issue is the building damage function. When an enemy hits a building unit to the point it breaks, usually your entire structure collapses, making the game extremely frustrating because the cost to build protection (a feature I really like about the game) far outweighs your actual protection from danger and leads too enemies destroying your fortifications with ease (one enemy destroyed an entire Alpine Tree-Fort with one hit). However, the quest line is entertaining and your enemies are always keeping you on your toes.

If you like exploration this game is pretty cool. There are a lot of secrets in the game. Building is a bit wonky at times, but you have a lot of options and items for crafting. The story is quite nice, you have to sort of piece things together yourself based on things you find on the island - other plane members, photos and drawings that give you hints to other places or pieces of the story. Also, you'll find various caves - some are simple, some are complicated and big, there's an interesting twist to some of the caves and places you see. Overall good game. If you appreciate survaval and exploration games I think this one is definitely worth a try.

Underwhelming.

Rather than make it a gradual buildup, they throw you into the game with a complete blueprint set for setting up a base, but the UI was so confusing I didn't realize that fact until it was already getting dark. Had enough time to set up a fire and shelter, tried using the drying rack but found out small meat cannot go on the drying rack, resorted to eating snacks and soda. Now I'm just huddling around my camp unable to sleep until morning, while I fight off endless number of annoying cannibals that are spawning at the beach I'm on. It's been night time for what feels like half an hour now, just swinging my axe and taking damage. It feels pointless. Can't even build walls because the cannibals don't leave you alone.

Did I do something wrong? Is this how the game is meant to go or am I being punished by The Forest??

Edit: After wasting some more time trying to play this game I have requested a refund. This game is just frustration from the cannibals making dumb noises to the slow af building mechanics, it's just not fun. I'd rather start a new Minecraft Survival world. That's essentially what it is really, minecraft with realistic graphics, and terrible UI. Spent the hole time convinced that the game wanted me to learn how to play, but every time I asked the door was closed in my face. 2/10

Sometimes I miss the various beautiful polycules I've had in this game throughout my past.  All of us bereaved fathers desperately searching for our baby boy Timmy while building a new life slaughtering cannibals for effigy parts.  Our ultimate goal to not only find our dear son, but to build the epitome of trap mazes that turns a survival horror game into a tower defense game.

The Forest is one of the funnest games I've ever played and I keep going back to it, with friends and solo.  I can't wait for the sequel and I hope the devs take all the time they need before releasing it, although I'm also looking forward to a little of the same jankiness this game has to help keep me on my toes.

Extremely fun and exciting game. My friends and I played for hours a day every day because you can focus on different genres of the game. If you like discovery, explore the caves. if you like combat, find cannibal camps. If you like crafting and design, build walls and keep the enemies out while you relax. Not only that but you can play by yourself, with friends, and with strangers. It's not only a survival game, the plot is immensely deep and interesting. Not to mention smaller things like sliding down the sinkhole and little exploits that make the game way more fun, like making infinite bullets so that you can have much more fun with friends.

Really fun start so far. Only complaint is that it's hard to remember what's bound to my hotkeys without a little action bar on the bottom of my screen.

Update 2022-05-18
--------------------------
Still super fun, especially with friends to take the edge off! Definitely my favorite take on the survival-crafting genre so far. The enemies are terrifying and challenging, especially when the action economy gets tilted. Resource gathering is often simultaneously intense and disconcerting, beautiful and relaxing. Base-building is so exciting! Planning out fortifications and traps, incorporating new weapons we've learned to make into how we plan our defensive structures. And omg, discovering new enemies. Devs are super creative, and each enemy feels worthy of considering when planning a build. Seriously love the game.
Some notes:
- Some sounds are too loud relative to other sounds (defensive wall gates opening, build complete, structure repaired, maaaybe water splashing too). The rest of the foley is amazing! Especially the wind!
- Controls feel a little inconsistent, e.g. sometimes putting something down is done with G & other times with C. Eating meat is done with right-click, but eating a snack or drinking something uses left-click.
- Can't easily reorder quick-slotted items. E.g. if I want to move my axe to slot 4 (where, say, my meds are) from slot 1, I can't just combine the axe and backpack to re-slot it. I first have to replace the axe with a different item, then put it where the meds currently are, then put the meds where the axe used to be.
- I tried to boil water when it was raining and my pot duplicated itself. Was frustrating 'cause my water meter was flashing red, but the water couldn't boil due to the glitch. Thought this might be caused either by the pot trying to fill itself with rainwater while already being full of fresh water, or by the meat cooking on the fire; basically something causing the fire state to update & trigger some sort of refresh.
- Would love to see some light RPG stat elements, OR perk trees. Ideally things that just marginally improve QOL - faster movement, slower metabolism, improved stamina... just tiny things to help the passage of time and improvement of skills sink in

I absolutely love The Forest, great atmosphere, amazing mix of survival and horror, with no scripted jumpscares. 10/10, it's a 50/10 when you play with friends, but the VR support is not very good, My main problem with the VR support is that is has a set height, which you then are forced to stay at, and if you attempt to crouch down in real life, it just makes you permanently taller, which makes it even harder to reach the ground, and it has no strength stat or weapon speed stat, it also takes no stamina to swing a weapon.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

The Forest is my favorite take on the survival craft genre. While you have options in game to play forever, it does have an actual ending you strive for. I am a bit boring and like these kind of games to have some form of closure. The story telling from the corpses, pictures and documents you find create some amazing lore and make exploring the little nooks extra worth it. The game is kind of separated into two different layers.  Base building, hunting, gathering and stocking up on items for the caves is all done on the surface. The meat of the game will be surviving the caves, which is where most of the story items and lore are presented. It was a good balance of survival craft and exploration, and even more fun with friends. I did find the game to be too visibly dark for my liking, and changed the color scheme later on (there are quite a few options). I recommend the game for anyone enthusiastic about crafting while simultaneously craving the horror elements that the game presents.

I love the horror genre- movies, videogames, books, etc. I don't get scared easy but my god I can't play this game more than 30 minutes at a time. As of this review, I'm 18 hours in and have barely accomplished anything. I went on one long expedition around the island and haven't left again. Every time I chop trees, build a fire, or even think about exploring, the nightmare cannibal acrobats swarm through the trees or I see a chieftan strolling nearby. I'm constantly retreating back to my minimalist hunting lodge stuck between 2 boulders at the base of a cliff on a lake. One time when I was checking on my rabbits then heard a horrible screeching echoing through the field. I never noped so fast. I can't wait for the sequel so I can never finish that one either.

I want to start this review saying that I have not yet beat the game because it does have a story but its not completely required to do unless you're in to completing stuff like that. I have 51 hours on record as of right now at the time of my typing up my review of this game there will be no spoilers so don't worry about that when reading my review. I want to say first and for most that this is a great entry level survival game for new comers or people that have little time playing the survival genre although this game is very big it on its survival side of game play its also a survival horror you will be facing up against cannibals on a forest type island after the plane that you and you're kid is on crashes. This game has some great survival elements for newcomers of the genre you will be doing things like keeping yourself fed and hydrated there are a few different ways to to do this you can find soda, or find clean water streams to drink from or make rain catchers and get your water that way as for food you can hunt for it after obtaining or crafting a weapon that you could use to hunt you can also sometimes find energy bars and other types of food left behind by people that has came to island and encountered the cannibals, the cannibals seem to horde peoples stuff that they kill. The other survival elements that are present in the game is being able to build pre made or custom log cabins with building the custom way you have the option to make huge home bases with defense's and loads of traps and other forms or home protection if you're not into making huge detailed bases then there are three sets of pre built cabins you can place and all you need is to cut down trees and find the other materials to build it it shows you how much of each thing you need to complete it. There is also temporary shelters you can build and save at if you like moving around you can also make garden plots and grow you're own food and herbs that help you heal and have more stamina etc. there is also meat drying racks to where you can basically make you're own jerky that don't spoil and go bad there are loads of decorations you can put up in and outside of you're house there are a few different types of fires you can make to stay warm, rock walls you can use to wall off your land there are also lots of useful items you can craft for your house that you can use like fireplaces that's built out of stone, tables, chairs, couches if you play with friends there is armor racks and weapon displays among other things. The next thing that i want to talk about is the map and different biomes there are a few different in the game as far as terrains there is a snow area, a woods area, deep forest areas, islands, and a more vegetated and floral area each with the own uniqueness to them. There are also caves on the island but i would not recommend trying to live in them they are a part of the story and there will be lots of hostile encounters in them. Each biome has plenty to explore and lots of different things to find  and see the graphics are not bad I use a 3070 and that's way over the recommended specs to run the game i use to run the game on my non gaming laptop at low graphics and it was just fine so that should give you some context it don't take much to run this game at the highest settings I also played this game when i had my 2070 super in my rig and it ran it at the highest graphics the graphics on a visual level is very good they aren't like some super crazy graphics but they are visually pleasing at high to very high settings. The story is very mysterious and compelling there are no cut scenes or anything like that but its more of figure it out yourself type of game you get and find clues along the way and you have to put it together which there is a end game to story which I'm still trying to figure out its not hard you just get distracted by other things to do in the game but so far the story is good and interesting.  I would recommend this game to people looking for a open world survival horror or a person that is just now getting into survival games that have actual survival elements and game play in the game even if you're a seasoned vet at survival games you will enjoy this game  and its also a affordable game as well. my overall thoughts on the game is that its a great open world survival game with lots of things to do all the while having a horror vibe to it which i really enjoy and that the new Sons of the forest follow up game is going to be amazing after playing this. Thank you for reading my review i post reviews on games that i really enjoy only so be on the look out for me in other review sections.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

If I could put a maybe on this I would. The Forest makes me feel good and bad. It‚Äôs a good game with friends and has great story telling moments like how some people went insane and formed their own groups. Whilst letting the player discover hidden secrets of the island without shoving it in their face. And tidbits of info for the player so they don‚Äôt get lost. But I‚Äôd be lying if I said it was a 10/10. The game feels very dull and there‚Äôs not much to do on the building side of things. One thing I love about survival games is build but this game doesn't give me a reason to. Sure, I'll build a storage box and maybe a house. But walls, tree houses, and traps? That‚Äôs not needed. Honestly even the enemies in the game don‚Äôt pose a challenge. Especially when you find the katana or chainsaw. The most difficult thing I‚Äôve had was the boss fight and that‚Äôs it. So if you're looking for a strong story with grim moments and a great atmosphere then this is it. But if you're going for building, then keep looking.

Only 109 minutes and I feel like I've been through a game that has no building limits; the reason why everyone loves minecraft! It gives you a great feeling to be limitless, with a true challenge. There is actual story, enemy progression, and my personal favorite, the reason why this game was made for an adult audience; Dismembering and Cannibalism (I have not gotten far in the game, that's all I know.) The horror factor of this game is quite satisfying- for me, its perfect. The night is pitch black, there is voice chat, and the fact that you starve so quickly is nice, practically being constantly on edge for what you will catch next. Great game in general.

This game is amazing, simply put. I absolutely love the crafting and building aspect., which is pretty extensive, but not so much as to be overwhelming. The game is indeed playable solo, but be prepared to suffer through monotonous tasks, such as gathering lumber and rocks for hours on end, its much more enjoyable with a party.  You can set out to complete the story as quickly as possible, or build up a main base to add comfort and security on those long, dark nights. The intricate cave systems are actually pretty scary at times. It took a little while to get used to hacking up bodies, but the bones are worth the mental instability that you will surely suffer. This is the epitome of a survival horror game and I strongly recommend this to anyone who also enjoys crafting and building.

The Forest is a reasonable length survival horror game.  If you've played Green Hell, it's similar to that but with a lot less micromanagement and a stronger emphasis on exploration, combat, and horror.  They are similar enough that if you enjoy Green Hell, it's fairly safe to say you'll enjoy the forest - the forest is the less hardcore of the two (and my favorite between the two).

Co-op is fun (though often tense when caving) - I usually just host from my game rather than running a dedicated server.  Only thing that took us a bit to get was that we assumed only the host had to save their game - EVERYBODY has to save.

It also plays well in VR - and you can play mixed VR/non-VR when playing co-op.  Like many games, there isn't exact parity between VR and non-VR players.  VR players can attack faster and more accurately, timing a strike to interrupt an enemy is way easier when you're swinging your arm, and there's no glare in a VR headset so generally VR players have better nightvision.  On the other hand, inventory management and crafting is way easier with mouse and keyboard.

On to some of the details...

If base building is your thing and you're just looking for a game to build a fantastic palace in, few things you need to know that might be a hangup for you.  Settling down in one place permanently means at some point the island's cannibals will figure out where you hang your hat and start trying to take you out.  They don't patrol entirely randomly.  They are fairly organized - and once you start a war with them and they're beating on your wall ever other night, moving out is the only way to end it.  They can definitely damage any structure you put up.  On the other hand, building structures is fairly free-form - it'll be some variety of log cabin probably, but you'll be able to define the shape and get moderately creative.

Up to the player if the cannibals being able to zero in on you means you live on the run, or you build and maintain defenses, or you build multiple small bases scattered in relatively out of the way locations and just swap to another if you get discovered near one.  Construction is optional, but drying racks, rainwater collectors, storage - they're convenient.  At the very least you won't get through the game without the occasional campfire.

There's also a slow escalation of violence - your first few run-ins with the locals might just be them shouting and making threatening gestures.  Even when they get violent you can often drive them off by hitting them with a stick once or twice.  You'll kill some soon enough though (pretty much need to when caving), and they'll know, and try to respond in kind.  They mourn their dead when they find them, and form up hunting parties when they do, which is alarming and noisy when the corpse is anywhere near your camp (though you can carry bodies elsewhere to throw them off your scent!).  

The enemies on the island patrol dynamically, and remember where they've encountered you or seen your structures, and adjust accordingly.  Standing your ground and killing patrols make them less likely to attack you when they don't massively outnumber you (e.g. lone scouts), but more likely to patrol or outright attack where they think you are in and in bigger numbers.  If you like to fight, the NPCs will oblige by getting more fighty.  Playing it stealthy and refraining from murder, you'll still get into the occasional fight (or flight) but there will be fewer NPCs out looking for you (and less likely to follow you if you try to give them the slip).

The Forest is not for everybody - but it's a good fun-sized survival game.  Finishing it is far from a daunting prospect - most of the challenge in finishing it comes from figuring out where you can and can't go - finding the caves, and delving into them.  Then maybe revisiting old caves when you get new tools (e.g. SCUBA gear).  If you know where everything is and just go straight to it and live off knowing where all the candy bars and soda are stashed, you will skip a ton of exploration time and the game could be finished in a day probably.  But if you just play it and don't know all that, it'll take a while to finish - pretty much down to how much you dawdle.

This game saved my life.

I am 28.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.
After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

This game was incredible.. but some things really got to me.
Disclaimer: minor gameplay spoilers, nothing from story

In short: After completeing my home, and completeing the story. I feel fulfilled yet wanting more. This game rewards you immensely for going off the beaten track, if you can see one that is haha. I hear this game is great with friends but I played solo. Lumberjack simulator with fair amounts of hints of danger. Don't forget to save at a bed or shelter you've made frequently. Always prepare for the worst, no such thing as being too prepared in this wilderness.

In full:
When I first woke up from the beginning of the story.. you were literally thrown into this beautiful wilderness we know as 'The Forest', and my Subnautica mind kicked in almost immediately: Make a shelter, do I need tools?, get some food somehow, hows my water, can I do this before night? Alot of things flooded into the cranium and I was hooked into this game immediately. As night came, they arrived.. I wasn't ready for them and ended up running along a coast line until I dipped into a big pond and lost them as I stayed under the water as long as my breathe would allow. Day came and I made some progress on something resembling a place I can at least hide for the night. I learned you can sleep in this game but it goes off of when you did it last over if it's night or day. Fast forward to having this small cabin made with a defensive wall around it, bordering a deep pond so my foes can't get in my base but I have access to water I can boil, my ambitions get bigger... fast forward till about 3 or 4 days of gameplay from the times of this review, I finished my log cabin, log for log, rock for rock, it's a masterpiece imo that took alot of finesse with the building mechanics of this game (it has a very elaborate custom log building system, probably the best building system in any game I've ever played! Impressive 11/10). I knew it was time to proceed with the story... 

I should add in between all of those happenings I mentioned above, I cave dived to explore and got quite rewarded for my efforts.. I'll let you figure out the rest but in conclusion with this remark: Save at a bed or tent/shelter before you go down. Be sure spare underwear is available irl lol.

I completed The Forest a while back and I held off writing a review because at the time I had real mixed feelings about "the end" (no real spoilers, I promise!)

The Forest is a game of 3 main parts: the surface, simple caves and the [spoiler]sinkhole[/spoiler]. The first few hundred hours I poured into this game was on the surface and the simple caves. Exploration was fun with a sensible level of survival and progression ... and that's where this game shines: base building.

Bases start as simple, well hidden, with small fires and basic comforts. You can spend ages finding nice little spots, just far enough from regular patrols, but near enough to essential resources, building essential outposts you'll need for exploring further and deeper. Now, you could complete The Forest with just these simple bases, but actually, this is where the game really shines! Once you know your way around the island you'll find yourself drawn to spots where you think "hey, this would be a really nice spot to put down some roots - look at that view!".  Soon, your simple camp grows and the base building mechanics of the game really kick in. You'll soon have walls, rooms, heat and light! It's here where The Forest lets loose in a way that few other games do. It's not pefect, it has niggles, but base building is a real joy and the freedom a player has is only tempered by their ability to create whilst under attack by the islands denizens.

Multi-player takes base building to a whole new level and is where the game really shines and where I spent many happy hours, creating, tweaking, experimenting.

I'd played most of my hours in Alpha and took a break from the game until it was fully released. My return focused more on the story line rather then base building. I stuck to smaller, agile camps which provided sufficient shelter whilst not attracting too much attention. The game doesn't penalise you for this at all, in fact, staying on the move often proves less dangerous, albeit you need sharp eyes and ears with an ability to get stealty really quick.

Solo, and agile I started to really enjoy the flow of the game ... until I hit the end part of the game. From being very open, very player-led, the game takes a far more linear path. The closer to "the end" the more this was true. Rather than exploring and chosing how I was approaching not getting eaten I found myself on a narrow path with enemies I simply had to go through, rather than choose if i wanted to fight or stealthily avoid. And the nearer I got to the end the less fun I was having ......... and that's why I didn't review the game right away. Because, right then I felt all those hours had been spent in the wonderful sandbox to suddenly going through a narrow tunnel.

Now, don't get me wrong, the story is good, and there are important (albeit often vague and unexplained) player choices, but the end of the game felt very, very different. I couldn't just bail temporarily and enjoy the top side for a while longer, or pop back for supplies, I was on a path I couldn't control to a great degree.

Overall though the game is amazing! The graphics are beautiful, the setting and almost silence of The Forest are so appealing, as is the sudden pace change when you walk into a group of the islands inhabitants. The above-ground section of the game is amazing and my only real gripe there was the AI of the enemies which could have been so much better.

If you're looking for a survival game and not so concerned with the actual stroy line so much then you will love The Forest.
