One of my favorite games. 

The graphics are more than good enough and make the open-world (island) very pleasant to explore. The world offers a lot of different landforms and terrain for the player to evaluate and decide on the kind of base they want to build. Minding my business chopping trees and spearing fish is an enjoyable and relaxing experience. At least until I hear the distant shrieking of cannibals and have to decide to flee or fight. Players have a variety of weapons they can make or find, as well as defensive items to be built, allowing us a lot of freedom in play style and strategy. 

There is a main plot that is almost entirely made up of environmental story-telling and exploration. Should the player choose to explore the caves below the island they will come across various items that offer insight into what the hell is going on as well as direct them towards the goal of finding the protagonists son. The plot is interesting enough, but it's not really where the game shines.

This isn't one of the scarier games I have played. Most of the fear is in the tension of knowing that the enemies are out there watching but having no idea where. The player needs to keep their eyes peeled for movement in the tree tops, ears attuned to notice the snap of a twig or rustling of leaves that could just be the wind or a rabbit but might be something waiting to attack. The scariest part about cannibals is their speed and ability to jump from tree to tree, hunting you from above. The island also contains mutants who are luckily slower and make a fair bit of noise. I love the mutant designs. Virginia is easily one of my favorite enemy designs in a game. 

A decent amount of space combined with the crafting system and fun combat mean that even after over one hundred hours my experience playing the game is still unique and enjoyable each time.

Review of VR version: So close to being amazing, but in the end, it's just another janky half-a**ed VR port of a flat game. Correction: I see it's actually a flat game with a VR "mode". Good lord, I should have known better. VR isn't just a gimmick anymore. Make a VR game or don't.

My biggest complaint is that the physical crouch option is broken. Every time I squat down or even bend over to try to reach something on the ground, suddenly I'm levitating three feet in the air, and whatever I was reaching for is now out of reach. And this bug apparently appeared in 2019. So I guess the game is abandoned or they just never cared that much about making it an actual VR game in the first place.

Possibly both, judging from the weird cuts to a third person view, which is unexpected and jarring in VR. And then I get to a part where I have to get through a whole cave system full of enemies with no saves or checkpoints, in a game where throwing molotovs is really weird and hard to aim and more likely to set me on fire, where there's one spot you have to walk through but there seems to be an invisible wall, where sometimes I get launched into the air for no reason...at which point I think I've decided I've had enough.

There are good native built-for-VR-from-the-ground-up games now and more on the way, including at least one survival game, and another that is technically a VR port, but I hear is so well done it might as well be a native VR game. VR games are not just flat games in 3D. I don't care how good the flat version of a game is; if they're not going to take the time and effort to actually make a good VR game out of it, I'd rather they just didn't even bother.

This game is meant to be played together and that's very clear in the game's systems. I tested it out with a friend for about 2h and we had a blast but he refunded the game so I was left to play alone. Now, I'm not going to argue the game needs and "easy mode", it doesn't but the scaling of difficulty between playing solo and coop is like night and day. When playing coop you can easily deal with 6 normal enemies rushing at you but for some reason I don't think the game does any scaling of this when playing solo. I get absolutely destroyed if 3 of em rush at me at once, 4 hits and I'm dead. All the other mechanics like building, crafting and such are great but the game feels like a pain to play when you're alone because it's not balanced. Normal difficulty (easiest in the game if you exclude peaceful) shouldn't be to much of a struggle to get through, you should get close to dying and face a challenge but it should be able to be overcome by trying a few times. So in summary, if you want to play it together with friends definitely buy this game, otherwise I can only recommend it if you like grinding and dying a good few times before you survive  your first nights.

The best spooky game. I really love this game. It's excellent at being a horror game, it's a survival simulator too, you can build as much as you want (or not), and all the little details, such as game mechanics, crafting, and the makeup/design of the [i] literal forest [/i] are really what truly makes this one of the greatest games of all time. 

Sometimes I just like to stand in the forests during the daytime. When the wind is blowing, and the sounds of the trees and the animals are all around you, it's just beyond magical. It could nearly rival the real thing. Ethereal.

This game and Green Hell are the holy grail of survival games. I recommend playing singeplayer at first to get the horror and loneliness feel of the game. Once that wears off, I recommend playing with a friend or two. By far, my favorite qualities are the tree chopping mechanic, the graphics, and the cannibals with their AI. My least favorite qualities are that building is long and tedious and can be destroyed quickly by cannibals and instantly by mutants, and the zipline will not work in certain angles- and if you want to rebuild it, you have to destroy it and rebuild it with new resources, including the valuable resource ,rope. Overall, it it is my favorite survival game alongside Green Hell and I 100% recommend.

Great game; very fun to play as a group with friends. There is some plot to the game but it's very subtle? Finding plot points is essential to BEATING the game but not necessary to survive in the game. Private servers/worlds are easy to manage, and there are options included to personalize your game with relative ease (resources being replenished, enemy difficulty, etc). 
It also seems that there is a creative mode, which I have not tried but seems very interesting as well. 

Overall I would give the game a 7/10 for intuitive gameplay, replayability, and just general fun.

The best part about the game is being absolutely scared in the dark and imagining voices around you when you're just cutting down a tree. Playing it with friends is much better because then you can scream into the mic asking for their help while running towards your base and being chased by 6 cannibals. The chaos that comes when 3 mutants raid your base is also the most fun part

8/10 would recommend

As far as my impressions of The Forest, I have to confess that, unlike other survival games I have played, I do not find myself sitting alone thinking, "I really want to play The Forest for a while." On the contrary, I get a 'butterfly stomach' when I think about playing alone.  Rather then being drawn to the game and then scared while playing, I find myself scared of playing and yet drawn to it (to some degree) because of that apprehension. That said, I am enjoying The Forest, but like most games I play, I enjoy it more with others rather than solo.

[h1]The Forrest is a great game.[/h1] It has good graphics and is a lot of fun to play alone/or with friends. The downsides are that if you die, you lose weapon upgrades, your clothes fall out of your inventory and you have to collect them separately, and you can also experience some bugs with getting through textures and other things. On the positive side, some of these bugs are even fun. [b]Nevertheless, I recommend this game.[/b]

i've beat this game far too many times, made so many friends while playing and i must say this has to got to be one of the best and scariest gaming experiences i ever had. the randomization of the game is great, as you either spawn in and see literally 0 cannibals or the whole village rolls up on you. it may also make your life of finding food and water easy or extremely difficult because the damn deer have weird hitboxes and run annoyingly fast. the darkness in this game is incredible, as it is genuinely impossible to see if you don't have any light sources. the caves are genuinely horrifying, as they are extremely dark and the cannibals scream at you from the darkness. the way you and your friends begin screaming when an armsy charges you in a cave or a group of cannibals rushes at you is something you never experience in other games. while the game can be non-serious at times, i believe it is a great horror experience and everyone should give it a shot.
7/10 experience alone, 100/10 experience with friends (especially when its all your first time playing).
genuinely the most relaxing experience ive ever had on normal mode for singleplayer and is very fun on multiplayer

This is a fun game, and there's plenty to do, but honestly it's underdeveloped. There are a large number of bugs that were never fixed, and it sends the fans in my brand new, high spec gaming PC crazy. I've still played 52 hours, and I'm not finished yet (having too much fun) but I wish this game had been given a bit more love. Hopefully the sequel (Sons of the Forest, due October 2022) will be a lot more polished.

This game is a masterpiece. From the lack of music to fill the voids, to the desperation of the music in the main menu screen. The visuals are great and amazing for when the game was released. The cannibals chasing you around the peninsula feel almost human as they take attacks in turns and roll to dodge attacks. The building aspect adds a lot to the game's ambiance, as even the smallest amount of protection from the unknown and feared can add a sense of security and some horror at the same time. All in all, The Forest is one of the best video games I have ever played. I'm personally very excited about Sons of the Forest.

A group of my pals (me included ofcourse) decided to Deforest the entire forest to make way for our lord and savior Jesus Christ. During this time, i have completely forgotten about my son Timmy who has been lost since we crashed. I am faithful to Timmy's mother, but the naked female cannibals running around my camp are starting to make me question that loyalty. If you think that it would be easy to keep said loyalty, you have not been on this island for 7 years with nothing resembling pleasure except for this dirty tree stump, which has just started to grow things and i believe that Timmy is now officially a big brother, so if i find him, i will tell him this wonderful news.

This game is a blast. I don't know what it is about it, but it's just so fun (both with friends and without, though I highly recommend playing with friends for a full hilarious experience).

The building mechanics are a bit janky sometimes, but there's just something satisfying about spending hours chopping down trees to make nice log cabins and fences that will inevitably get torn down by mutated beings from hell. In fact, most of my hours are probably just from chopping down trees and struggling to find sticks.

The combat is very simple, but you can upgrade your weapons to an extent which is nice. The spears take some used to aiming with if you want to throw them. The bows are a little easier to get used to.

It doesn't matter how long you've played or what you do, there's always a dread-filled, creeping feeling when you hear the cannibals' screams at night when all you have for comfort is the torchlight. The worst are the caves, which are deep, dark, and terrifying. They did an amazing job with the tension and creepiness factor. I still haven't gotten the courage to go into a cave alone.

I'm very excited for the new Forest game in the works.

This is a very well done survival horror crafting game. The art and sound design is spectacular and really scared me at times (especially inside caves or at night). The combat is decent but you should definitely try your best to fight from range as the enemies can mess you up easily if given the chance. The building portion of the game is pretty fun but the amount of wood / stone necessary can be a bit too much for some structures (such as the gazebo) which makes it a bit tedious. There are some minor bugs but nothing too game breaking. Overall I highly recommend this game and am looking forward to the sequel.

My very first survival game when stepping on Steam. I have played it several times, and I could say it's quicker, easier, and stronger with more people around. Collecting materials and building will surely take less time when you do it together. When I played it duo, it feels more challenging that I can explore, craft and learn everything from scratch. By the time I play it again, it's for accompanying friends who haven't completed the main story. Overall, The Forest offers a generous amount of adventure and thrill when played with friends, but a bit gore for me.

I just finished the game with my girlfriend doing coop from the very start to finish. I highly recommend this for survival fans.
The base building mechanic is great and your defenses keep you mostly safe as long as you keep up with the maintenance. The game has a grind to it but no where near as much as a game like Ark. The Traps you build to stop the cannibals are hilarious for such a seriously toned survival game. 
Diving in the caves always feels intense and you don't get a full feel for their complexity to until you reveal most of the map for them. 
The tools you earn along the way keep the pace moving forward and let you go from barley surviving to thriving.
The ending was also A+,  I can't wait for the sequel.
The game looks great but it is the sound for me, It is immersive and so dynamic. Just take the time to stand still and you'll see what I mean.

the first day goes by fine, you say to yourself "this game isn't that scary," then night comes. it's pitch black, you can only see about three feet in front of you using your lighter, "did i see something in the top of that tree," you ask yourself. "was that laughing," you say turning around. "did i hear breathing" you say looking around you, squinting. then you see him, about 50 feet from you stands a seven foot tall humanoid creature, hunched over, breathing heavily. he charges at you and you defeat him, but the noises continue, "i have a bad feeling about this," you say to yourself before three of them surround you.

Being chased by cannibals at every moment is definitely not calming, and shows the kind of atmosphere that you‚Äôd be getting yourself into. The base building mechanics are very easy to use and allow you to really personalise your camp. Whether you‚Äôre playing on the hardest difficulty or the easiest, the game‚Äôs story is compelling and creepy - Two qualities I think a horror game should have. Therefore, I would recommend the game to those who are looking for a creepy cannibalistic experience.

Fun survival game. Played with friends and it 200% made it better. 

This game does have one major downside though, and that is that it feels unfinished. It really feels like an early access game and since it's finished it really shouldn't. Some of the menu's need some work, and I find myself going to the wiki to look up crafting recipes quite frequently. I also think that there should be more advanced tools for mass collecting of resources. If I need to make a wall that needs several hundred rocks which in my opinion is not unreasonable then there should be something that allows me to get those faster than just picking them up one by one. 

I hear they are making a sequel, and while I am looking forward to it I do hope they actually finish it and give it some good polish this time.

This game. This one right here. This is the GOLDEN STANDARD for survival games in my opinion. Every other survival game I've ever played has always at some point made me think "man, I wish this game had this one cool feature like in the forest." It is fucking INSANE how much you can build in this game despite there being a lack of large servers of people. It almost feels like Rust if the game wasn't nearly as brutal and the player base had very little toxicity. On top of the in depth building mechanics, the story for the game is truly riveting. I could replay this game several times and I would still enjoy the story and the gameplay as a whole. Survival game makers should take note, this one fucking NAILED it. 10/10, would DEFINITELY play again.

This is one of my favorite games up with Garry's Mod I highly recommend this for horror fans.  I like almost every thing about this game, the weapons, game play, enemies, and the atmosphere. My only complaints would be those pain in the ass worms (and boss when near my buildings) breaking my buildings. I rarely fight these things, instead I just reload an old save ( especially the worms).  I also don't see why they censored the cannibals genitals when, A: this game is not for children, B: the female cannibals breast are not censored. I also find it strange how none of the dear are bucks. But I am nit-picking I was so excited to play this game once I saw the trailer and it did more than deliver. If this review seemed like I was just shitting on this game, it just because I thought this review would become a novel if I listed all the positives.

The forest in "The Forest" often looks and feels as close to real as I've seen, and that's rad. The AI is extremely impressive, as I'm sure you've heard, but it is breakable. That's not a bad thing. Especially with how smart enemies feel and how helpless you are as an early-game solo player. That said, your experience with this game can go three ways: 

Play "The Forest" alone if you want a heavily immersive disaster survival crafting sim. 

Play "The Forest" with a friend if you want to somewhat break the immersion in favor of capital "F" Fun. 

Play "The Forest" with a friend using a third-party voice chat program if you want to get absolutely buckwild, build a treehouse or two, and cut a swath through the enemies you once feared. 

It's a good game, I'm a day one for the next installment.

Note: I will edit this review once I complete the main story/quest to find "Timmy." At 23 hours at time of typing the following: 

This game is f-ting incredible. It is slightly janky at 8 years out from its initial release. This is very much an "indie" game. That said, the level of freedom in terms of what you can create, how much you can explore, and the level of depth in both literal, virtually physical/geological terms, as well as in terms of how deep the AI systems and mysterious story elements make the forested island seem, come together to create a survival-horrific co-op experience (lucky and cowardly enough to not have played alone yet) that is absolutely unparalleled and still graphically beautiful by current standards. You can slide downhill on a sea-turtle's shell and beat a cannibal to death with its own club after devouring its BFF's arms and legs, then turn the newly dead cannibal's skull and bones into arrows and light fixtures. You can build a raft next to the scene of this grizzly encounter and paddle it to a little island from which to view the larger island in all its terrifying grandiosity, toss some dynamite at a subtly marked bit of stone, and watch as the explosion uncovers a cache of hidden supplies. The achievements are goofy fun, too. Little Timmy be damned! I built a Gazebo!

The Forest is a really intriguing concept and fun to play, except it is also buggy and has a lot of bad design decisions that kill the game's enjoyment off.

For example, rejoining a multiplayer game gives you two options: "Continue" and "Join."  If you absentmindedly click "Join" it erases your progress and starts you over.  Why is this even an option?

Also, time apparently does not stop on a dedicated server when all players are logged out - We had played for something like 12 hours, got a really decent base going, and then logged out.  Real life prevented us from getting together to play again for a couple weeks, and when we finally did, our base was completely gone and a dozen cannibals were standing around where it used to be - the only reason I know it didn't reset the map or anything was because the lumber sleds we built to haul logs around in that area were still there.  Apparently it also killed us off while we were logged out, because even clicking "continue" to get back on to the server started us over from the plane crash with empty inventories.

All in all, this could have been a great game.  But the developer stopped before it was done, and it's one of gaming's biggest dropped balls ever.

So i've played this game somewhat more on different accounts, and i have to say it is one of the most fun survival games because of how non-functional it is, this isn't any new groundbreaking information. Basically, what i'm trying to say is that so many aspects of this game are fucked beyond belief that it comes full circle and is more fun than if it were 100% patched. Games were the fun comes through bugs are notoriously frustrating in some parts, and this is no exception, the combat system needs a serious re-work and so does the AI of the enemies, however, if you can put aside all of that, you still have an incoherent mess of gameplay. 8/10

I thought this game was great! I played through the entire thing in VR which scared the crap out of me. Dropping into a cave full of monsters was certainly an experience that I would recommend everyone have in VR. Even beyond the scares, there is an element to the forest that keeps drawing you back in. Whether that be the crafting or the exploration, it creates an itch that must be scratched. I'm not going to give any spoilers but, I personally didn't enjoy the final moments of game play prior to the ending. It just felt like the juxtaposition between the 97% of the game play that came prior to it was too great. Overall it was a 9/10 VR experience.

I like this game. It has an expansive map that is enjoyable to explore, you don‚Äôt feel bored as you walk through the forest and continue to look over your shoulder and behind trees‚Ä¶.waiting for any threats to present themselves. The sudden attack from those forest fellers are actually really realistic and align with my experiences. Funny little creatures they are. The building aspect is a lot more polished than one would expect. The player is able to cut down trees and construct buildings, defences, traps ‚Äì leading to a cohesive flow of the game. 

Just writing this is actually making me reflect on my own life and experiences a little bit. Some of the games accuracies have invoked some vivid memories within me. Usually I have a memory like a sieve, so games like this really help me to reflect (smiley face). 

I grew up in the lush forests of Ohio. Deep greens and beautiful browns as far as the eye can see. I lived with my father in a small clearing of the forest, close to a view of the ocean ‚Äì it was beautiful. I am a son of a preacher man, he would go to the local town and read the bible for those who came to listen. Delivering sermons, giving last rites, those sort of things. It was never really for me and I‚Äôm not sure if it was for him, but he liked carrying around the old bible and the attention it brought. He even would accept donations for his efforts, something I‚Äôd often tell him off for. But he‚Äôd just look at me and say ‚Äòson! If it smells, it sells!‚Äô I quite genuinely never understood what that could have meant, but I guess looking back that he meant that it didn‚Äôt matter that he wasn‚Äôt religious. Sure, the act of faking it was bad, but people enjoyed it anyway and got something from it ‚Äì so maybe he was right all along. One day when he was making his way down to the town, I called out to him from our humble home to remind him to take his Luncheon. That old coot would always forget his spam sandwich, more for me I guess. But I knew on that particular day that he‚Äôd be out late so I wanted to ensure he took the sandwich and his 2L bottle of full cream milk. My father was a simple man, and as I reflect on my life, I guess I am too.

Before we departed for the day we‚Äôd often shout out to each other: ‚ÄúLook out for the forest fellers!‚Äù as a laugh. We‚Äôd chuckle and go about our day, it was a fun little ritual that made us feel close. The forest fellers are the fabled creatures of the Ohio forests. No one has ever truly seen them and yet they are mentioned in the town almost daily over concerns about the threat they may pose. I never understood those town fools, I‚Äôd spent my whole life exploring those forests and had never seen such a creature. One day, once my father had left, I set out in the forest to hunt for dinner. It was a warm day, the sun trickled down through the lush trees above me and a distinct smell of pine hung in the air. It was still, quiet even, and the only sound heard was my boots against the slightly damp leaves which coated the ground below. It didn‚Äôt take long for me to find a rabbit stuck in one of my traps. Seeing the rabbits struggling in the bonds always made me feel strange. I was happy to know I‚Äôd caught dinner and would be able to cook us up a hot meal. However, I couldn‚Äôt help but feel sympathy to the creature. It‚Äôs death would allow me to eat and yet I could never shake the feeling that as I was staring at this struggling prey, I was looking at a reflection of myself. Almost as if in the middle of a food chain I couldn‚Äôt understand. I‚Äôd escape a glance at the eyes of the rabbit as it would peer at me. I could have sworn that those animals I hunted would gain some form of sentience before I would finish the kill. Their black eyes would peer at me, into the chasms of my emotions ‚Äì where conflict would stir. The way they stared at me always felt the same. A distinct feeling that their eyes were saying ‚Äúyou‚Äôre next‚Äù   
--------------------
That same night I had prepared the rabbit into a stew, and had it slowly reducing over a fire as my father arrived home. He was in a hurry and huffed into a chair by our dining table.

‚ÄúThose fools in the town, always playing silly buggers‚Äù. He muttered as he took a swig from his water flask. 

It was always the same. He‚Äôd sit down and complain about the town‚Äôs folk making fun of him, well, the non-religious ones ‚Äì ironic.

Father slumped further into his chair, his chin against his chest as he muttered. ‚ÄúA bunch of divs they are. Skinny, that bald fool, sat in his hightower all day thinking he‚Äôs above us all. Little does he know that his town folk wouldn‚Äôt be as content as they are without my sermons.‚Äù

‚ÄúSorry to hear they‚Äôre giving you grief again‚Äù

‚ÄúSorrys won‚Äôt cut the mustard, I need to show them how vital I am to that retched town‚Äù

‚ÄúFather, we‚Äôve never been of their kind. We‚Äôre proud forest people‚Äù

Father looked angry after I said that, but not at me. ‚ÄúOh, are we? That‚Äôs another issue, those idiots think we‚Äôre in cahoots with their big bad forest fellers‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù I stammered angrily

Father grunted out ‚Äúmmhmm‚Äù

I couldn‚Äôt believe it. Just because we prefer to live in the forest, they think we‚Äôre somehow friends with a bunch of mythical creatures? Those town folk can‚Äôt look past their own noses! 

I poured the stew out into two bowls messily, my coordination a little affected by my heightened mood. ‚ÄúLets not worry ourselves with them, we need to be above their foolishness‚Äù

‚Äúmmm‚Ä¶..maybe you‚Äôre right‚Äù father said as he swallowed a bite. ‚ÄúNot a bad stew, son‚Äù

-------------------

The next morning father went about his usual routine, grabbed his bible, and set out. ‚ÄúLook out for the forest fellers!‚Äù we cheered, as usual. I didn‚Äôt have much to do that day. I just tended to the gardens a bit, using some compost full of banana peels and other food scraps to keep the crops healthy. 

Once I washed up from the gardens I decided to venture into the forest for a walk. I was still fuming from the conversation the night before, and I was hoping I could clear my head from the walk. I‚Äôve heard the townsfolk have a remedy called Sudafed. However I had forgotten to ask father to collect some for me and thus the walk would have to do. I came upon a clearing not long into my walk.  A small area where the sun struck the ground and the trees had almost parted to allow it do so. It was a magical place, a natural marvel. I would come here often to relax. This time, however, the clearing felt different. It was like the ground had sucked up the sunlight and left me in a dark void. The trees around my almost felt to close me in. It was dark, solemn, and yet the light still poured in. I felt panic rise in my chest and my legs feel numb. A slight buzzing sound began to sound in my ears, soon growing louder and drowning out my own thoughts and even heartbeat. My head felt light, my body almost airy, and my mouth dry. I struggled to understand the feelings as I looked around hurriedly and attempted to grasp at the knife on my belt.

When I saw my favourite content creators, such as Captain Sauce and Smi77y amongst many others, play this game and have a blast with it I figured it had to have a lot of good things going on for it to garner that praise. As someone who thoroughly enjoys survival games, I was sold pretty much straight away with the setting and premise. So why am I not recommending this game to you? Because it's absolutely abysmal.

For starters, the combat is an absolute mess. I can barely, if at all, defend myself from the onslaughts of cannibals that can literally combo-stunlock me into death and lose my 30 minute save TWICE. I try everything the game tells me, and yet I get punished for following the guide. HELL, I get punished for NOT following the guide and crafting new gear and armour that does literally nothing to help me. I spent 20 minutes hitting trees to make a shelter or a sick house, which is fine since it's a forest and obviously you have to incorporate that somehow. But at the end of the day, I think the crafting system for structures is so unbearably tedious that making a simple FIRE is expensive.

Overall, this game is just a massive letdown from what I had my expectations set out to be. I was expecting to be met with a fun yet challenging experience, especially with the horror elements, but I was met with bullshit combat and survival mechanics that REALLY hindered my enjoyment for this game. Get it on a discount instead.

The one thing that is regrettable about this game is, I did not get it during it's release. It was on my wishlist literally for years.

This game is a blast with other people. If your group is well organized, some can hunt for food, while others are building.

The main story does not overwhelm the game making it priority. More like it is running in the background waiting for whenever you are ready. I find this good, as with story dominant games can feel like you are on a railroad track to completion.

Overall the graphics are great, but they are a few things I like to point out. The deer looks cartoonish, the player model is really atrocious. Which is weird because the cannibals  look fairly good in comparison. Lastly  since we on are the topic of cannibals. Why didn't they give the males naughty bits or a grass skirt like the females? Kinda immersion breaking seeing a bunch of "Ken Dolls".

Final tip before I bring this review to a close. Play your game on multi-player host. That way you can invite friends to participate in the world of your creation.

[h1]Overhyped[/h1]

It was great back in 2018 for what it was, it's still ok now in 2022. 

But it being 'ok' and having overwhelmingly positive reviews is just bs, regardless of other people being entitled to an opinion. There are far, far better games on the market. This one just happens to be a streamer's fan-favorite so naturally a lot of blind followers will jump on the hype train that it's something spectacular. 

Is the horror unique and terrifying? Yeah it is
Are the graphics good? Yeah they are 
Is the animation good? Yeah it is
Is the atmosphere there? Initially yeah it is
is the crafting a chore? Yeah, it is
Is it worth $30? No way, maybe for $10 and even then that's for the added fun of co-op

I think The Forest was unique back in 2018, but now it's not. Maybe the hype got to the developers when it came to developing the game? In 2018 you would have thought by 2022 it would have been a borderline AAA title, as it looked like an ambitious title with good graphics and animations, just lacking the funding for polish and content. It's not a flop but it's not great.

this one kinda came outta left field for me. i originally bought it just because it was available in VR, played it a few hours and kinda forgot about it til some friends got me into it again, but the game play and mechanics are well tuned on both VR and flat screen. my only complaint really is for parts in VR that are immersion breaking like the opening cut scene looks really cool being front and center for a place crash but the scaling is off and when it takes you out of first person perspective when you climb ropes or get knocked down is a bit off-putting. but that pales in comparison to all the rest that this game has to offer. the crafting in VR is especially fun. and using the modern bow as well. makes headshots feel extra rewarding being able to actually aim down sight with your hands. and the chainsaw makes me feel like a lumberjack. map traversal can be difficult but never frustrating, although ive yet to play the harder difficulties. but there is always plenty to find so it makes exploring worth it

I enjoy the game somewhat, but the bevy of quality of life issues make it hard to recommend. This game came out in 2018 and the controller support is minimal at best. The default layout is not great, and there is no in-game way to modify it; this is unacceptable for a modern game IMO.

Also, the actions in game can be incredibly finicky. Picking up an item can sometimes require a good 10-15 seconds of slightly moving your character to be in the exact position necessary for the command prompt to appear. Additionally, it's often difficult to even see what button they want you to press because the color blends with the environment.

Combat is boring and shitty. You have an attack button and a block button, that's it. Hit the bad guy a couple times, then hold block until it attacks you, wash rinse repeat. When using ranged weapons, there is no reticle. Sometimes it's not a big deal, like with the slingshot. Other weapons, there is absolutely no fucking visual point of reference at all, so you just have to waste ammunition and probably die in the process.

Graphics are good, theme is good, it's fun to play multiplayer, but the previously mentioned issues bring it down considerably.

If you want the hair on neck to stand on end, play this game.... [i][b] in the dark!![/b] [/i] .  I bought it on a whim and was not disappointed.
The graphics are pretty good, but I got the game (after watching a couple of videos on it) because I like these sandbox type games that allow for free roam of where you are at.  
There is a number of storylines to follow in the game, which I'm having a hard time doing.  I'll probably have to resort to watching videos on what I have to do to actually "complete" the game.  I'm 25+ hours into it & don't think I've accomplished much in the ways of the storyline.  I'm having quite a bit of fun just with the "base building" aspect of the game.  I'm just glad there is no timer on the story line. 

It is a bit on the "gory" side on what you have to do at times and it's a little disturbing on the types of cannibals you'll find so beware of that if you plan on having kids watch or even play it.  

Mats for construction are quite abundant so no hunting around for them.   That's a plus in my book.

I give it a 8.5 out of 10.  For ME that's high.  

And remember....play it in the dark.  [i] [b] Trust me!!  [/b][/i]

I am intrigued by the survival scenario, but I ended up playing on peaceful mode most of the time. Even the easiest mode with monsters was very difficult to build up defense before a hair-raising encounter. There are too many things to do to ensure survival and not enough time, energy, or safety available at first. When I tried to escape from them I found it near impossible and frustrating. I suppose this may be realistic to the scenario, but this is a game. It killed my desire to continue playing.
For gamers who like a challenge it's a decent game, but I think there should be a reasonable period of time at the beginning where there are zero monster encounters; a player could get better set up that way and focus on objectives better. The story is frankly not that appealing to me either. Too generic and makes me think of Fallout 3 & 4.

The Forest is so perfect, the lore is amazing, and i really enjoyed the way the game worked. Let's get one thing straight. Other than the monsters and their designs, this game, is dog shit. The graphics suck, the map is small and bland, and you bug into a wall every 5 minutes. And while the sequel does seem to be improving on almost everything, including the monster designs which were already fantastic, that doesn't excuse the original "The Forest" to suck monkey balls. With that being said, this game fucking slaps. Now I've never played this game alone before and I don't plan to because I bet I'd be pretty miserable. But the three times I've went out of my way to suggest starting a new world to a group of friends boggles my mind. Because conceptually, all my previous critiques still hold up. But for some reason, something about T-bagging a poorly rendered zombie with your friends while we're all starving and dehydrated just never gets old. It's such a bad game but it can be so fun with the right group of people. 10/10

Definitely enjoyed the game on single player.
Has a variety of spooky things to come across, slightly challenging, and interesting and decent-made crafting mechanics.
The story-line is interesting, feeding you bits and pieces of lore through exploring caves, camps, and villages.
The best game play is when you're with friends.

The main downsides:
Armor in the game depletes REALLY fast and it takes quite a bit to get enough bones for a full set of bone armor.
Depending on where the game puts you in the start, without any knowledge, you can very easily run into a cave that has very difficult enemies, a lot of enemies, or a combination of both.
The thing that pulled me out of the game was going into multiplayer hosting my own game without cheats enable and a bunch of kids with loud mics somehow used cheats to destroy my buildings while hovering in the sky, laughed when I came to the camp and saw it, and then proceeded to kill me when I ran away.

I'd give it a solid 6.5/10.

My plane crashed. Someone took my son. I seem the only survivor. I pick up an axe from the dead stewardess's chest and run to a safe location with my nifty survival book and my lighter which NEVER EVER gets empty! the book has blueprints for a fire and a shelter. I cut trees, more trees and even more trees. I slaughter birds with my axe and throw them in the fire. I eat birds and drink poluted water until I find a pot. I cook water in the pot yummi. I cook birds in the pot. I catch rabbits, I eat reabbits. Then I need to build more buildings, chop more trees, build a neat cabin and a bigger fire. I need to build traps and a wall so I cut more trees, chop chop. O no, there are the cannibals and my wall isn't finished yet HELP! The cannibals surround me and attack. I dance around them. One steps into my fire the dumbass, haha that teaches him! I slaughter a cannibal with my axe, take his club and smash the others with this club. I cut off their heads and put them on a stick. That will teach them! I cut off their arms and legs and hang them to dry so I can eat it later. I burn what's left of their bodies so I get bones. I make armor from their bones and a spear. I go hunt fish with the spear but what is that? A naked woman trying to kill me? Can't we talk about it? "You woman, me man, I got this nice cabin there... no?" She doesn't fall for my charms and attacks so I chop off her head and burn her body, more bones. Her screams alerted more cannibals. I hide in my cabin. They look through the window, I shoot an arrow through their head with my just self made bow and bone arrows. My wall is almost finished, just a few more trees. I must have chopped a thousand already. I got ambushed by more cannibals and mutants, I pass out. They drag me to this cave and hang me to dry. I wake up and they were foolish enough to: 1. leave me alive and 2. leave my belongings with me so I lit my never emptying lighter and see my axe. I chop myself loose and fall on the cave floor. I find meds, soda cans, a compass and a map. I see a rope, I climb up to find myself in a cannibal village. As I sneak away, another naked woman jumps on me. I forgot to take the damn meds and my health is really low. She knocks me out and eats me. Best next thing to sex.

Score 11/10 - would get eaten by naked women again.

This has to be one of the best made survival games on the market. However the difference between "The Forest" and other survival games is the story. Yes, many other survival games have a story all their own, but with "The Forest", to me, the story is more of a main focal point of the game itself. I love playing with my friends and jokingly start yelling, "Timmy! Timmy! Where's my son?!" (If you haven't played this game before, you play the role of a plane crash survivor and have your son (Timmy) taken the first few moments you're on the island). Apart from the story line, this game is a wealth of fun, especially if you are with friends. The experience of "The Forest" is drastically changed when played in a multiplayer setting and the horror aspect is turned from terrifying, to scary with a dash of laughs and smiles. Weird to say, but I feel that's how most horror games are and "The Forest" is no exception. Overall, "The Forest" is an amazing game and I highly recommend it to those looking for a fun (and what can be challenging) survival game! 9/10 all around!

I watched a trailer of "Sons of the Forest" not so long ago and realised that I already own the first game in my library for ages. Finally decided to give it a try and man, this damn forest just sucked me in. It's fascinating. I could not even imagine that cutting trees can be so addictive. 

The first impression was indescribable: first meeting with cannibals, first fallen tree on your log house, first meeting with mutants (with all 3 at once in my case - unforgettable experience), first visit to the caves... It was created just by four people? - unbelievable. So many things are done on such a great level in this game, that it can easily put to shame numerous losers from AAA industry. 

I'd like to mention stylish and ergonomic inventory, fantastic sound design, thrilling atmosphere, overall attention to details 
and of course - great enemy AI. I have not seen such a good AI probably since F.E.A.R. These "primitive" cannibals are 100 times smarter than all those super soldiers from CoDs and BFs.  They learn. And you have to learn how to deal with them. 

You can pacify them or make them even more agressive. You can trick or scare them. They can run away in fear and call for help. Some of them are so deranged that can start eating their own fallen brothers and sisters. Others - show compassion and try to drag away wounded tribesman. Great work.

What worth special mentioning - the way developers limited the world. You have a huge island, surrounded by boundless ocean. What could stop you from leaving the island? Try and see. It was such a simple decision but at the same time so emotionally strong.

The game tells me to find some Timmy... Who is this Timmy? Ah, da hell with Timmy! I already spent more than 100 days on this island, established my own religion, building my private village and of course - practicing healthy cannibalism!
I LOVE THIS GAME ITS SO F*UCKING GOOD <3

I have some really strong opinions on this game, this might be the best survival horror game I have ever played. The experience is also elevated by presence of CO-OP. This is a masterpiece, simply put. From the story to game-play to the shivers you feel while playing, the game grips you from beginning till the end. You might not realise what the game has in store in terms to the storytelling. Some think this game is an ordinary survival horror game that relies on jump-scares but the really is harshly contradicting. The story takes you somewhere you might not even dream, let alone expect. Its an absolute must play game for someone who likes a good story that will stay with you forever, just like some of the best thriller movies. In terms of game-play the game offers all you can ask for in a survival game, like crafting, making shelters, gathering resources, discovering new regions, etc. The main focus of the game is in the caves, as you would find hints to the story and more importantly tools to progress in the game. Also the cave experience is phenomenal as the caves are pitch black and you don't have any light source other than your trusty lighter. Moreover there are plenty of cannibals in the caves which further elevates the spooky setting of the caves. 
It takes an exceptional game-play and fitting story to gather overwhelmingly positive reviews which just shows the capabilities of this title. Also this is the first game made by Endnight Games, who are small team with just 4 people(while The Forest was made). It pains me to think that big developers like Ubisoft are launching Far Cry sequels which are completely identical to previous ones and people still choose to play those rather than trying new and fresh games like these. I hope that with a debut game like this, Endnight Games grows and give us more stunning titles like these and would not deviate into more generic game making.
Second part of The Forest is also coming out in 2022 named Sons of the Forest and to say that I am excited is an understatement. <3

I would recommend buying this game on sale not that there is anything wrong with it. I think the game runs great and has a fantastic story to run either solo or with friends which always adds more to the game when it allows you to run a story while having fun with friends. If you want to put time into making a base or trying to craft or kit up your items it does become slightly boring having to chop down trees or try to get stick but it does help and allows you to get more in depth into your story. But getting this game on sale i feel is just better just in case the interest drops better to pay 8-10 dollars for a game you play all the time then 20 for a game you won't touch after 2 or 3 times of playing but that being said buying it full price and finding out you don't like it you always have the option to refund your game for I believe up to 1-2 weeks either way if it wasn't what you wanted or expected you have some time to get your money back.

While this game took me a little bit to get started, I fully recommend this to any form of survival horror fan. I thoroughly enjoyed playing this game, and I still play this to this day. However, I do recommend playing with friends. It's a bit more grindy when you play single player.

It has a very obvious story line, the interface is manageable (after you figure out how to do things, that is) and inventory limits are based on numbers of items rather than weight.  The AIs are very intelligent too - which makes game-play interesting because they don't simply run up on you and attack, but can rather attack in a pack and kill you with back-stabs.  Not a game for beginning survival/crafting gamers, but very enjoyable for those who like a challenge.

Don‚Äôt even know where to begin with this game. Survival horror, but not your average horror. More like when you have a really weird disturbing fever dream about your son being abducted by cannibals that come in many shapes and sizes but are always naked and angry. Building was a lot of fun, the survival aspect is just right to keep you entertained throughout the day and give you an incentive to grab materials to advance further into the story and world exploration. Combat isn‚Äôt that bad at all, actually quite fun to try and figure out what‚Äôs the best combination of weapons to take a heavy-hitting cannibal down fast. Lots of funny moments and good memories ahead but I would recommend playing with atleast 1 extra friend because I could see the single-player becoming difficult and the solo work being demotivating towards progression.

Day 38... Exploring the caves with the boys... stumbled across the holy grail of the island... "The One Who Hums"... a small fragile naked cannibal who hummed with the power of a dying sun. Hums that made time itself stand still. He did not attack us. He was at peace knowing the power he withheld inside himself. At first we stood at a distance observing this creature of beauty... soon we were sitting side by side. He stopped humming at one point and at that very moment life seemed to have no meaning... no purpose... then he broke out in a symphony of hum. We danced and we pranced and circled him. Then the level 4 noob appeared and lit him a flame... the Forest went silent for years to come... much love.

Hi, I'm writing this for both the game developer and the players: What's good about the game? Quality, enjoyment with friends in this big world, simple construction almost flawless and many other things that you may know better than me.

But the negative points of the game: (which I want the manufacturer to fix) ... Lack of fabric and lack of alternatives in nature is a big problem that can cause:
1- You will not have a rope
2- You will not have bone armor
These are the greatest applications of fabric that can protect you in construction and resistance to the enemy.
Leaf-covered armor may be an alternative, but it is not effective.

Lack of cooking tips (for cooking food with a pot) in the survival booklet.

* Excessive attack on the enemy during construction, even normally, there is no safe place to build on the map! Except in the water, which makes it impossible for us to build a house in the forest.

Lack of other wildlife such as bears, tigers, bees (which can be used for medicine or food or even poison for weapons), snakes and insects that can be a challenge to treat.

And .... not having a torch to search in the cave or at night, so that we only have to find our way with a lighter!
Why is there no option to make a torch using wood, a little tree sap and fabric or tree leaves?

But with all this, it is a good game. I hope the basic problems of the game are solved with a little creativity.
Good luck.

If you are a fan of the open world survival craft horror genre, then this is undoubtedly THE game to play. Solid 10/10. This is a must play for so many reasons.

Excellent balance between survival, crafting, combat and "creep factor". The cannibal AI is awesome. They are intelligent and unpredictable which is one of the best and most terrifying parts of this game. The survival aspects are simple and effective. The core survival mechanics of hunger/thirst/sanity/warmth are enough to keep you busy without becoming cumbersome. The game strikes a fantastic balance between moments of pure beauty as you explore this incredible island landscape contrasted against the horrors of the cannibals. The sound design is extremely effective at both informing the player and at creeping you out. The story is solid and between surviving, defending your base and progressing the story, you will have plenty of quality gameplay.

The base building is a beast all its own. You can setup a simple effective base with just the essentials. Or you can build a towering fortress to exert your dominance over the local population. It is easy to spend hours upon hours tweaking your defense, perfecting and stocking your base with all manner of resources. It's extremely rewarding and addicting. The building mechanics are simple and intuitive. Alternatively you can go with the minimalist approach and build everything you need to survive on a simple small raft (bed, drying racks, water collectors and fire pit). This makes you immune to all enemy attacks as they can't reach you on the water. The small raft is the easiest and safest 1st base which you can put together within 5 minutes. From here you can build a bigger houseboat or start constructing a land base while having a safe place to run to if/when SHTF.

I've had this game in my library forever and I finally had time to start playing it recently. I am so glad I did. This game is a masterpiece and I am really looking forward to the sequel (Sons of the Forest).

TIP: If you are struggling with visibility at night or in the caves change the color grading to M131 in the display/graphics menu. For a truly terrifying experience leave the color grading on "Original" and don't adjust the night/cave brightness slider.

Easily one of my favourite Survival games and one I go back to time and again, alone and with friends.

While I couldn't care less about the main goal of the game (besides escaping) it's fine in general, the real beauty to this game though is the small details, things like the way you cut a tree that gives it a realistic feel or the rabbits that breed when penned, and something that seems to blow everyone's mind is the enemy NPCs, I don't know how but the way the developers designed the NPC AI makes it seem like they have infinite possibilities in terms of the way they behave and react to your actions. 
I've tried to replicate certain things in the hopes of getting similar behaviours from them and failed multiple times, but that gives the game such a refreshing long term playability. 
The crafting and building in the game is very free, a lot of trial and error, and gives you a sense of accomplishment when you've built a camp or filled your backpack with interesting and useful items you've created.
There are some small gripes I have about how many of certain resources it takes to build certain things, or how long it can take to build a substantial base, but honestly it's not important. 
The VR implementation is absolutely magical too, so even long after you've figured out this game you can jump into the VR version and become truly immersed in it like it's brand new.

Overall this game is incredible, I highly recommend it for survival fans and for multiplayer fans, and I should add, it has given myself and one other of my friends and actual, real-life panic attack on separate occasions, because of an unintended jump scare (by us not paying attention), if that doesn't entice you into playing I don't know what will.

The Forest is a survival game with good combat, a large map, and an incentive to *actually explore and beat the game* (unlike other games I have reviewed).
The story is that you were going on a plane somewhere with your son named "Timmy"
The plane crashes and you (or a few other people if you're playing multiplayer) are the only survivor(s) of the crash. You look around and see a flight attendant with a hatchet lodged into her chest. You pull it out and you use it to collect resources and to fight the nearby cannibals and, a little later into the game, mutants. These guys will attack you and unless you set up a fort you're going to be doing a lot of dying. I would recommend building a base overtop a cave entrance due to the fact that if your base ends up being overrun you could escape into the cave and stock up on supplies that you can find down there, and go through and alternate entrance to escape any mutants or cannibals at your base. I won't be touching the storyline all that much to avoid spoilers but the final boss was a little underwealming. Just a little more health and damage than a regular mutant. It would die to about 7 flare gun shots. The fact that you were basically givin free medicine and food and water made me expect a lot more than what there was. In conclusion, this is a pretty good survival game with a lot of insensitive to beat the game and a good story.

Overhyped, extremely buggy. Here is a short list of my complaints

1. A friend and I built several rafts that kept getting glitched onto land and stuck on tiny obstructions in the water. Also rafts are pointless as far as I can tell because the inner waterways are almost impossible to navigate with a medium sized raft and there is no benefit to building a raft in the ocean as there are no islands.
2. The game doesn't distinguish between dried food and raw food which makes drying racks a pain
3. The hit registration from certain enemies is atrocious and the physics is even worse. Ever been punted into the skybox by a monster that is facing away from you?
4.Flashlights taped to any tool or weapon are invariably useless as it points at the top right of your screen
5. Tropical salt water fish living in fresh water ponds. Giant Monitors and Rabbits living in harmony. Seriously?
6. Controls revert to default every time you open the game
7. Lighting molotovs, dynamite and fire arrows is insanely tedious. Throwing the two former weapons is also janky as it uses a floor reticle, which would be acceptable if it didn't scroll at a weird angle and if it were actually accurate.
8. The developers decided this game was finished and have decided to work on a sequel rather than make this game good.
9. The developers quit working on this clearly unfinished game in order to make a sequel.
10. The developers are satisfied with this and think it deserves a sequel.


The game gets crafting right though, and it gives you a lot of freedom in placement which is very good in my opinion. Gathering resources and exploring is a lot fun in this game, but after 18 hours and 4 raft bases that literally beached themselves and several deaths to projectile drop kicks from that fat zombie bastard, I have a hard time seeing myself ever playing more.

The Hog Rider card is unlocked from the Spell Valley (Arena 5). He is a very fast building-targeting, melee troop with moderately high hitpoints and damage. He appears just like his Clash of Clans counterpart; a man with brown eyebrows, a beard, a mohawk, and a golden body piercing in his left ear who is riding a hog. A Hog Rider card costs 4 Elixir to deploy.

Strategy

His fast move speed can boost forward mini tanks like an Ice Golem in a push. At the same time, he can also function as a tank for lower hitpoint troops such as Goblins as he still has a fair amount of health. Most cheap swarms complement the Hog Rider well, as they are nearly as fast as him and usually force more than one card out of the opponent's hand.

The Hog Rider struggles with swarms, as they can damage him down and defeat him quickly while obstructing his path. Barbarians in particular can fully counter him without very strict timing on the defender's part, though be wary of spells.

A Hunter can kill the Hog Rider in 2 hits if placed right on top of it. However, if you place something in front of the Hog Rider, the Hunter's splash will damage the Hog Rider and hit the card in front of it more.

The Hog Rider in conjunction with the Freeze can surprise the opponent and allow the Hog Rider to deal much more damage than anticipated, especially if the opponent's go-to counter is a swarm, or swarms are their only effective counter to him. Skeletons and Bats will immediately be defeated by the spell, while Spear Goblins, Goblins, and Minions will be at low enough health to be defeated by a follow up Zap or Giant Snowball.

However, this strategy isn't very effective against buildings as the Hog Rider will take a while to destroy the building, giving the opponent ample time to articulate another counter.

Against non-swarm troops, it can deal a lot of damage during the freeze time, but this can allow the opponent to set up a massive counterpush. For this reason, players should either only go for a Hog Rider + Freeze when they have other units backing it up from a counterattack, or if the match is about to end and they need to deal as much damage as possible.

It is not a good idea to send in a Hog Rider simply to destroy a building, especially if it is the only building targeting unit available, as defeating Crown Towers becomes substantially more difficult. Spells or simply waiting out the lifetime of the building are more effective. The exception to this is an Elixir Collector placed in front of the King's Tower. If a Hog Rider placed at the bridge, he can destroy the Collector for a positive Elixir trade, though the damage from both Princess Towers will usually mean he does not survive to deal any damage to them. However, if the opponent sends in defending troops, it can be an opportunity to gain spell damage value.

In a deck with several low-cost cards, it might be worth it to simply send the Hog Rider against one building. These decks shuffle their card rotation quick enough, that they will arrive to their next Hog Rider before the next building arrives in the opponent's card rotation.

Long-ranged troops like Musketeer and Flying Machine can snipe those buildings, preserving some of the Hog Rider's health, possibly allowing it to get some Tower damage.

When there are buildings placed in the middle to counter the Hog Rider, understanding the placement of the Hog Rider and the type of building placed can help the Hog Rider to bypass certain buildings.

Passive buildings such as spawners and Elixir Collector have a larger hitbox than defensive buildings; which means that if a passive building was placed 3 tiles away from the river in the middle of the opponent's side, then it is impossible for the Hog Rider to bypass that placement as the Hog Rider will get pulled to that building.

Defensive buildings have a smaller hitbox than a passive building, which means if that if a defensive building was placed three tiles away from the river in the middle of the opponent's side, a Hog Rider placed at the very left or right side of the Arena may be able to bypass it due to its smaller hitbox.

If the player has a building already placed down in the center of the arena, and the opponent tries to bypass it with a Hog Rider at the edge of the arena, they can use certain air troops to push the Hog Rider towards the building as it jumps over the river, effectively denying the bypass attempt. They must be already hovering over the correct placement, as very quick reflexes are required to correctly perform this technique.

For Bats, Skeleton Dragons, and Minion Horde, they should be placed right in front of the Hog Rider as soon as it is deployed.

For Minions, Skeleton Barrel, Mega Minion, Flying Machine, Electro Dragon, Baby Dragon, Inferno Dragon, Balloon, and Lava Hound, stagger the above placement one tile to the right if the Hog Rider is placed on the left side of the arena, and vice versa.

They can also use ground troops to achieve the same result. Something like an Ice Golem deployed at the Hog Rider‚Äôs landing spot will obstruct his path and force him to go around the unit, which causes him to be closer to the building instead of the Crown Tower.

The Hog Rider can kite Very Fast non-building targeting troops due to his own Very Fast speed and building only targeting if he is placed on the fourth tile from the bridge, slightly into the opposite lane. He can also stall grounded units when placed right at the bridge. He will pull them towards him while deploying, and then be untargetable by them when he jumps over the bridge. After landing, he will pull them back. This can be useful when the player needs to deal damage in the same lane they are defending. It will also help separate troops behind a tank in a large push.

A Tornado placed on the second tile front of the player's King's Tower and staggered two tiles towards the Princess Tower will activate it without any damage dealt to the Princess Tower, helping them in defending future pushes. This can also be a method of mitigating all damage dealt to a Princess Tower, but doing this more than three times may result in the King's Tower's health being low enough to be targeted directly, opening up the possible threat of a back door three crown. A better alternative is to pull the Hog away from the Princess Tower into the attacking range of all three Crown Towers, which will negate all damage as long as none of them are already distracted

A very powerful combo is the Hog Rider, the Musketeer, and the Valkyrie, typically referred to as the Trifecta. The Musketeer will defend against most troops, while the Valkyrie can protect her and the Hog Rider from swarms or high damage units. The Hog Rider is used to deal damage to the tower.

This can be effectively countered by Lightning, one-shotting the Musketeer and severely damaging both the Valkyrie and Hog Rider. The Minion Horde is also effective, but the enemy can Zap them and the Musketeer will one-shot them all. Even if the Musketeer is defeated, the Hog Rider and Valkyrie will have enough time to severely damage the Tower.

The Hog Rider should be placed behind the Valkyrie to give it a boost so that it stays in front of the Hog Rider, protecting it.

A Hog Rider combined with a Goblin Barrel can be awkward for the opponent to defend against. Timing it so that the Hog Rider is tanking the tower shots for the Goblins is the most effective way to deal damage. However, a Barbarian Barrel can shut this down with minimal Tower damage for a positive Elixir trade, as long as the Goblin Barrel was placed directly on the Tower.

Le for√™t. Der Wald. El Bosque. The Forest. No matter which language you speak, where you live on this planet, or what a forest looks like for you, it often suggests the same universal concept: a separation from society. It is this universal trait which the developers of The Forest are well aware of and have made palpable through their harrowing survival horror.
	To begin, every element of the game is a product of the setting. While this may be true in some respects for many games and media, few titles use the setting with as much versatility and application, squeezing from the setting: the mood, the tone, the atmosphere, the conflict, and even the plot arc. The forest alone demands the player‚Äôs respect. One must forage for food and water to maintain their energy levels in order to keep their endurance levels up for completing work as well as for surviving interactions with the brutal, cannibalistic denizens of the island on which the protagonist has been marooned. 
	Pause. Cannibals? Yes, cannibals, and no, certainly not zombies. And how terrifyingly refreshing these horrible people are as antagonists, and antagonize they do. Part of the setting, the cannibals are a tribal people riddling the island in groups, even families. There are hierarchies to their order, which you will occasionally be able to identify based on their dress, but more impressively‚Äìconsidering a programming standpoint‚Äìby their behavior. I must break the immersion here to laud the incredible AI of the enemy throughout this game. From the few things I heard about this game before playing, I figured you built a fort and survived waves of cannibalistic monster-zombie things as long as you could. That is not what this game is and to debase it to such an idea would be to vastly undermine what the developers have achieved. There is a great variety to the enemy, they have different strengths and tendencies: some aggressive, some more observant and standoffish, some hauntingly complacent. Let it be said that when it finally does come to fighting them, it is a primal challenge. They are strong and can kill you with a few hits, especially if they are armed. And launching into a melee with more than one is a gamble, especially as they will retreat and regroup with incredible speed. I could say so much more, but you should find it out for yourself; interacting with them is absolutely intense and a wonder to behold from a psychological standpoint.
	Back to the setting and progress of the game. Much of the gameplay has the player fighting to survive the landscape. If one can last long enough, they will find themselves gathering resources: primarily sticks, rocks, logs, and food. If successful, the player can build a fire, cook a meal, and with persistence, even build a respectable shelter, of which there are many varieties, and considerable freedom for a totally custom cabin of any size and shape the architect (the player) decides.
	A player could probably survive in the world while building a minimal shelter from location to location and living a more nomadic lifestyle, but that is not how I wanted to play. I greatly enjoyed building a cabin complete with defensive walls and traps all around, customizing it to my needs and wants, so that in the interior of my walls was a nearly completely self-sufficient compound. It took me many hours, but it never felt like a grind, as gathering resources takes time, but only enough to keep one from being careless.
	And this is where, again, I must stress the power of the setting in this game. I have never played a game that so literally gave me the sense of being home. This game defines what a home is. Is it where the heart is? I suppose it can be (especially if you decide to become a cannibal yourself) but to me, it was about security and respite. Mind you, none of this was scripted by developers, it simply happens through your own interaction and decisions in the world. For example, I chose where to build my cabin, and I chose it strategically. After completing my compound, I felt a true sense of accomplishment, not only that, I felt like I had separated myself from the incessant dangers of the island. Starting a fire in the black nights granted the respite I mentioned. Beyond the walls, I would hear cannibal‚Äôs footsteps in the grasses nearby, or their howls, or barks, or shrieks. And while I felt such respite in my cabin‚Äìmy home!‚ÄìI knew my safety was never absolute. I had to defend my walls many times and many nights from raids. After surviving, it showed me where I needed to bolster my defenses. This is a major part of the beauty of The Forest: nothing but the setting and your own tribulations tell you what to do or how to do it, and as time goes on, you learn more, and become much more effective at surviving. As this happens, you get braver.
	You will eventually push into the forest. And you will eventually step into the caves. Not because it is scripted, but because the setting will drive you to do so when you feel you must. Where the forest itself is beautiful yet unnervingly tense, the caves are black and timorous.
	The caves are dwellings of nightmare. Your progress through them is dim, slow, and myopic. You‚Äôll hear sneers and rustling in the impenetrable dark, only to see a face and muscled body breach the light of your flickering lighter. Filled with gore and evidence something misanthropic lives there, the caves are always desperate, and you will want it to end the entire time, making the moment you see daylight true relief. Upon reaching the surface once more, you will walk much lighter as you return to your cabin, which by this point will solidly be defined as home. If you reach home, you will want a drink‚Äìperhaps both in-game and in real life.
	It is in this way that the setting also creates the narrative. I could write so much more on this, but I do not want to spoil it for you, and to do so might dampen your experience. I will say, though, that the narrative I experienced while playing this game is the most profound I have had in about two years (ask me which game made me feel as strongly). However, where that game had a beautiful, literary, rich script, thousands upon thousands of lines long, The Forest must have a script of fewer than even a hundred lines. Yet through the introductory sequence and the ending sequence, you realize that this game embraces the videogame medium so beautifully, so artfully, and that realization will elevate the entire experience for you. Without spoiling anything, I realized that, again, the setting is the narrative; the programmers created an introductory sequence and a conclusion, and all the decisions, actions, and events you decided to make create the unscripted plot arc of your story. This, to me, is embracing the medium. In a movie, you observe snapshots of wondrously staged realities, where what happens will always happen to those characters with imagery that is crafted for you, but granting unique interpretations. In a book, you read otherwise impossibly detailed perspectives of events and characters with beautiful language, which spark a unique image and connection in every reader. Videogames are about choice and interaction; they are about controlling and affecting another reality; whether or not deeper meaning is made from it is up to the player, but made more present by the developer. The Forest perfectly demonstrates this in a way that is universal. Through such a minimalistic script, the developer somehow weaves incredibly profound themes of loss and possession; survival and morality; to have and have not. 
	I cannot recommend this game enough, and I will not forget the fifty-hour experience I had with my first play through.
        Hell, I didn‚Äôt even touch the multiplayer. I bet that‚Äôs good.
        Overall, I give this game a sublime rating on my patented reverie-scale of ‚ÄúThree weeks of pre-sleep ceiling-stares with frequent, innumerable, future ceiling-stares to come.‚Äù

Survival game that has just enough survival aspects to not be overly annoying and inconvenient. Keeping up with hunger and thirst is actually not hard. You can even build a rabbit farm for infinite food and build rain catchers with turtle shells for fresh water whenever it rains. Really fun to play with friends. Without spoiling the fun and the mystery of it, the caves are where the interesting stuff is at.

Pros:
+  Interesting story with a lot of mystery. You can look up the wiki which I recommend unless you want to figure stuff out for yourself. This would take a LONG time to do so... I recommend using theforestmap.com for finding any tools, weapons, hunting sites, etc. that you may need. It's very buggy in the steam browser though so take care.
+ Combat is fun. Lot of choices for offense like, bow and arrow, katana, clubs, molotovs, handmade bombs, spears, a flintlock pistol (if you have the will to find and assemble all of the parts. A bomb are needed for each part), etc.
+ Lore is interesting
+ Mundane additions like the music player, and birds landing on your hand, show attention to detail and make you feel immersed
+ Derpy physics can be extremely funny with friends
+ Things get easier as you progress and find tools and build

Cons
- Although the physics can be derpy and funny, it also leads to things being unpredictable. During combat, or low-health situations, you will find a slight to moderate loss of control.
- Hit boxes are a bit weird for ranged attacks. You can get used to it but even I still have trouble landing arrow shots
- Sometimes the enemies glitch as if experiencing high-ping in Call of Duty
- Free building in this game has no way of measuring and is completely eyeball reliant
- Without a wiki/map a player would find it extremely difficult to play the story

Not going to lie, this game took me a little while to get into.  I played it for about 5 or 6 hours and put it down, not touching it for about 6 or 7 months.  But then I saw it popping up again on reddit, so I decided to give it another try.

Boy am I glad I did!!  It turned out I was approaching the game the wrong way (as in more of a base building game, much less of an exploration/survival style game... which as we know doesn't work out too well if you're a newbie). After watching a 15 minute video on Youtube about the different styles in playing the game, as well as a few do's and don'ts, I jumped back in.  And I played non-stop until I beat it.  I never played with a friend, only solo, so I can't imagine how much more fun this could be if you had a buddy to play with.

This game is fun, scary, exciting, and rewarding.  Definitely work every penny! 9/10

If you haven't played it yet, there's still time to before the sequel, Sons Of The Forest is released. I consider this game exemplary of everything a good survival game should have--base building that will itch that creative urge, some heart pounding suspense moments, a beautiful open world to roam, and--perhaps most importantly--a good story driving the whole thing. You'll uncover the mystery of the island as you play, which gives players that much more motivation to continue exploring and discovering up until the point you begin to piece things together--at which point you'll realize the story is perfectly set up for a sequel. Luckily, one is coming.

Two complaints up front.  Darkness is a problem, and unfortunately none of the fixes are completely adequate; I found myself sitting by a save point just waiting to go to sleep so I could have some light to work with.  Second issue is that I spent a whole lot of times my first playthrough cutting down trees and gathering materials, and when I started the game over, doing all of that work again felt like a slog.

Other than those, I think this is a fantastic game.  Enemies are pretty interesting (although, there isn't a huge variety of them), once you get used to how combat works it gets fun.  The crafting is cool.  Some of the more obscure items will require some research to locate (you'll never find them all on your own).  All in all, it's a lot of fun, and it has emotional content.  Great graphics and sound.
