About five years ago I lived downtown in a major city in the US. I've always been a night person, so I would often find myself bored after my roommate, who was decidedly not a night person, went to sleep. To pass the time, I used to go for long walks and spend the time thinking.

I spent four years like that, walking alone at night, and never once had a reason to feel afraid. I always used to joke with my roommate that even the drug dealers in the city were polite. But all of that changed in just a few minutes of one evening.

It was a Wednesday, somewhere between one and two in the morning, and I was walking near a police patrolled park quite a ways from my apartment. It was a quiet night, even for a week night, with very little traffic and almost no one on foot. The park, as it was most nights, was completely empty.

I turned down a short side street in order to loop back to my apartment when I first noticed him. At the far end of the street, on my side, was the silhouette of a man, dancing. It was a strange dance, similar to a waltz, but he finished each "box" with an odd forward stride. I guess you could say he was dance-walking, headed straight for me.

Deciding he was probably drunk, I stepped as close as I could to the road to give him the majority of the sidewalk to pass me by. The closer he got, the more I realized how gracefully he was moving. He was very tall and lanky, and wearing an old suit. He danced closer still, until I could make out his face. His eyes were open wide and wild, head tilted back slightly, looking off at the sky. His mouth was formed in a painfully wide cartoon of a smile. Between the eyes and the smile, I decided to cross the street before he danced any closer.

I took my eyes off of him to cross the empty street. As I reached the other side, I glanced back... and then stopped dead in my tracks. He had stopped dancing and was standing with one foot in the street, perfectly parallel to me. He was facing me but still looking skyward. Smile still wide on his lips.

I was completely and utterly unnerved by this. I started walking again, but kept my eyes on the man. He didn't move.

Once I had put about half a block between us, I turned away from him for a moment to watch the sidewalk in front of me. The street and sidewalk ahead of me were completely empty. Still unnerved, I looked back to where he had been standing to find him gone. For the briefest of moments I felt relieved, until I noticed him. He had crossed the street, and was now slightly crouched down. I couldn't tell for sure due to the distance and the shadows, but I was certain he was facing me. I had looked away from him for no more than 10 seconds, so it was clear that he had moved fast.

I was so shocked that I stood there for some time, staring at him. And then he started moving toward me again. He took giant, exaggerated tip toed steps, as if he were a cartoon character sneaking up on someone. Except he was moving very, very quickly.

I'd like to say at this point I ran away or pulled out my pepper spray or my cellphone or anything at all, but I didn't. I just stood there, completely frozen as the smiling man crept toward me.

And then he stopped again, about a car length away from me. Still smiling his smile, still looking to the sky.

When I finally found my voice, I blurted out the first thing that came to mind. What I meant to ask was, "What the fuck do you want?!" in an angry, commanding tone. What came out was a whimper, "What the fuu‚Ä¶?"

Regardless of whether or not humans can smell fear, they can certainly hear it. I heard it in my own voice, and that only made me more afraid. But he didn't react to it at all. He just stood there, smiling.

And then, after what felt like forever, he turned around, very slowly, and started dance-walking away. Just like that. Not wanting to turn my back to him again, I just watched him go, until he was far enough away to almost be out of sight. And then I realized something. He wasn't moving away anymore, nor was he dancing. I watched in horror as the distant shape of him grew larger and larger. He was coming back my way. And this time he was running.

I ran too.

I ran until I was off of the side road and back onto a better lit road with sparse traffic. Looking behind me then, he was nowhere to be found. The rest of the way home, I kept glancing over my shoulder, always expecting to see his stupid smile, but he was never there.

I lived in that city for six months after that night, and I never went out for another walk. There was something about his face that always haunted me. He didn't look drunk, he didn't look high. He looked completely and utterly insane. And that's a very, very scary thing to see.

This game is perfect for those who like open world, survival, horror, and massive freedom to build. If you're lazy and do not want to collect resources there's a way to get unlimited resources and if you're too scared of the enemies in-game there is a peaceful mode.

I may have small play time, but this game is incredible. I have over 300 hours on playstation.

 First off, the game is relatively easy to pick up, the controls are simple and easy to understand. beginning off is exiting and thrilling. First few in game days you will have likely done some exploring and ran into a few cannibals - Even at this point the game is enjoyable, simple base building and survival right? Not really.

The storyline in this game is one of the best out there. even to this date (2022 Feb) the exploration is incredible, large wide landscape and a huge mess of cave systems. LOADS to explore. even myself after playing over 4 years haven't seen every inch of the map. Even the miniature side story's are very immersive, knowing other people have crashed there and you aren't alone. Through exploring the cave's - for the first time - you will find stronger enemies and mini bosses. Terrifying and thrilling. Along with exploration, new items, new things to craft - one time only item drops and loot drops if you die. Difficult but fun.

The story plays along a character looking for their kid. The more you explore the map the more you find out about the story, how sinister this island is and whats on it. Solo or multiplayer the story is enjoyable, role play possibilities. Going into the endgame is so thrilling. The story so in depth you feel like if you die its over. It no longer is a game it's a mission you have to complete.

Even after you defeat the final boss there's more options for you. End the game and leave the island, or stay. Leaving will mean you lose the world but unlock a creative mode - even more possibilities. Staying on the island means new over powered items are able to be unlocked, questions answered that you have asked through playing. The longer you are on the island stronger enemies appear on the surface aware of you. Secret caves you might find.

This game is limitless, its also beautiful. Outstanding Graphics for it's age. I would HIGHLY recommend this game. ALSO a sequel is due May of 2022. There is so much more i can say about this game, but in short - It is one of the best survival games out there. Alongside it's top quality storyline and in depth gameplay and enjoyable replayability its 1000000% worth investing the small amount of money for this masterpeice.

[h1]"Bugs, bugs and once again glitches"[/h1]
And that quote accompanied me the entire game. It is broken in almost every inch. The list of bugs I encountered throughout the 40 hours of gameplay is almost endless:
- Disappearing items
- Duplicated items
- Problem with logbook entries in caves
- Items that cannot be picked up
- Disappearing armor
- A falling tree will not destroy a rabbit cage made of a few sticks, but it will destroy a gazebo.
- Disappearing injured animals
- No water in turtle shells despite the rain
- The immobilized rafts
- Practically all sounds
- Being thrown to the desktop
- And many others

Playing alone is pointless. Two of us on normal difficulty find it difficult to go through the caves - I dread to think how you can do it alone.

I have to say that I'm sad and disappointed because this game, without all the annoying bugs, would deserve at least 8/10 for its interesting and unique story and atmosphere. Unfortunately, until the developer fixes his game (which is unlikely to happen), the rating remains in the low range.

[h1]Tips:[/h1]
- Respect every tape you get and make bombs out of them immediately - you'll need them, and you can never have too many tapes!
- Build birdcages - a very quick way to get feathers and thus arrows
- Logbook entries often pop up [b]ON TOP[/b] of cave entrances
- Mutant heads count towards the "Trophy Hunter" achievement (easier to get than geese heads)
- The "Longest wall" achievement is not about a palisade, but about the wall of a building

It's almost alarming how quickly this game pulled me in. The setting is a worst case scenario primitive survival response, and the fear is made real by the constant threat of whatever is making those strange sounds near you... This game is amazing. I can't stress this enough. It tells a story in such an open-ended and non-invasive way that many games never seem to have done before. While cut-scenes exist, they are few far and between and most of the story is told directly with how you interact with the world. The island that you find yourself marooned on contains so many secrets and it is your responsibility to find them as you are given no exterior story telling that can tell you how. And when you do find the pieces of the puzzle, it is up to you to put them together and interpret them. If you like games where you can build, but you also like horror games, this game is for you. I appreciate just how realistic the survival aspects to this game feel.

I did not play this game on release, I didn't even think I would like it. To be perfectly clear I didn't give it a chance until I saw it had VR support. All of my gameplay has been in VR.

What this game does well:
Creepy sometimes scary aesthetic for a large amount of the game. Base building and survivalcraft with SOME tower defense mechanisms. Exploration is a must for better equipment and learning the secrets of this island. Narrative and story are not cutscenes and long books but instead found as subtle hints or drawings in the game world. Says the game has been around since 2014 (alpha) and I don't see a mod community making the game look graphically better. Even still, the game looks and plays like a relevant 2022 game.

What it could do better:
VR floating hands leave something to be desired, even if the best game of all time in VR does the same thing. Using both of my hands to do things would be amazing but my right arm is the only one getting a workout LOL. 3rd person movement is a bit quirky and weird on ropes and such. It could have a sequel out with VR capabilities right now. Honestly these are all minor gripes, they've done a great job here.

Conclusion:
This is a whole game. A whole game with a better than decent VR port. IMO SkyrimVR (not modded) doesn't even compare to this in terms of playability. If you enjoy survivalcraft games and need a VR experience...please consider this one.

Shortly, your Plane crashed on an island, your Son was kidnapped after the Crash, survive and find him.

First real survival game I've played, in addition to it being my first semi-horror game.  I went in rather timid, but managed to find my way.  The Forest is incredibly well done, with suspense, paranoia, and a little bit of horror.  For anyone out there who shares the same fears of running through the unknown, I urge you to try out The Forest.  Learning curve isn't too steep, but the game won't be holding your hand either.  The game is very enjoyable alone, or with up to 8 other people.  I would recommend playing either alone, or with a single friend, as anymore then that can possibly break some of the immersion you will experience.  All things considered, incredibly beautiful game.  I would give it a solid 8/10 for the overall experience.

This is probably one of the greatest survival games to ever grace this Earth, and there's a multitude of reasons for that.

First of all, very few survival games manage to deliver such an enticing story with an absolutely mindblowing ending, and even fewer manage to do it solely through clues and events instead of the usual mixture of dialogue, notes and so on. The Forest not only manages that, but it manages to balance it well with the survival aspects of the game. It's like there are two layers of gameplay here; The Forest - the survival game, and The Forest - the mystery/investigation game. Puzzling together the pieces of what happened while you try to survive through hordes of cannibals and mutants is an amazing addition to this game.

And let's talk about those mutants for a bit. They are properly terrifying. Beyond just being a survival game, The Forest is also a full fledged horror experience. While learning to fight off single mutants doesn't take a particularly long amount of time (they are quite dumb and you can easily cheese them, especially if they come at you one by one) that doesn't stop them from feeling like a constant threat to you and your encampment, as you can get easily overrun. A couple of Armsies and some cannibals barging through the woods can easily turn a nice morning where you went out fishing into an intense battle, while hearing their approaching roars in the caves can chill you to the core.

Finally, there's the building aspect of the game. While the building system isn't as impressive as it is in some other games (the building mostly consisting of preset objects, with quite few custom options available) there are still enough options to satisfy most people who enjoy building in survival games. The custom foundation and custom walls will be your best friends when trying to build your house in your own unique way, while being able to run platforms and bridges along trees is a nice touch as well. The building can sometimes get tedious, as you have to bring each and every log that's needed for the construction over to the building side either manually or with a cart - you can't just magically shove them into your inventory - but I do feel that this more realistic approach to building feels right at home in The Forest, and I don't think a more "advanced" system would've worked qute as well. You're a crash survivor after all, not a builder and architect!

Overall, this game is an incredible experience, and definitely among my favorite games of all time.

It's a good survival game but flawed in many regards:
[list]
[*] Clipping, oh man it gets annoying to see myself or someone I play with just levitate or clip through objects. Especially during preset animations, they never seem to match from other person's perspective;
[*] There seems to be [spoiler]an invisible wall midway down the hole if you decide to build a rope and go down that way. Glider works, from what I've seen jumping from a zip line into the puddle works so why can't I rope down?[/spoiler]
[*] The alternate ending does not give you the Survive the Forest achievement (finish the game). If it's considered an "alternate ending" why not? It would've been cool if I actually had to do something [spoiler]after I decide to crash another plane, not just watch it go down and bam, black screen, one year later whatever. The same way alternate ending let's you continue playing, the "right" ending should let you too, at least to some extent.[/spoiler]
[*] Getting [spoiler]the artifact[/spoiler] feels worthless. Not because the zombies (I know it's cannibals but I couldn't be f*cked to differentiate) are too easy on normal difficulty but because [spoiler]it literally has no God d*mn story significance. The cave collapses if you chose to emergency shutdown so you either end the game by creating another 9/11 or play in your little "creative mode" with a spike-ball that either repels or attracts zombies.[/spoiler]
[*] What does the S.O.S. sign do again?
[*] Why can't I use a flare as a torch? You know, weapon in one hand, flare in another.
[*] Some caves feel... empty. For example [spoiler]there was some underwater cave which we couldn't go in because we had no scuba gear. After getting the gear from another cave, we went back and lord and behold, there were f*cking coins all over the floor. That's it, just a deep dive for some coins which I can't even use because you get way too d*mn many to ever have the other components for explosives and I'd die of old age before I use them all on vending machines in the laboratory.[/spoiler]
[*] [spoiler]I don't feel like Indiana Jones going through the whole map to assemble a gun that takes ages to reload.[/spoiler]
[*] [spoiler]Why is the kid bass boosted at the end there? During the live show tree cutting cutscene, the kid looks like he has several strokes at the same time. You'll find that either disturbing or the funniest sh*t you've ever seen. Is it intentional? Or is just the animation that f*cked lol.[/spoiler]
[*] The combat is.... eh? It goes back to the clipping issue.

But, overall I believe this game excels at things other survival games don't: crafting, base building, exploring. You know, the very thing a survival game is based upon. Considering it's 16,79‚Ç¨ full price, I'd say it's a pretty good d*mn game.

Both great and bad at same time. It has great graphics. The layout is solid. But it has a unfinished feel to it. Like when you build if your not exact you get caught up on things getting you stuck. There are some things you need a lot of, but no way to store any off them except by cheating like skulls. Sure you can store skulls in a catapult but then you need to launch them to collect them. Things that you need up front like a map need to be found. Once you know the area no prob but before you learn you will spend hours wandering around aimlessly with only just a few reference point super easy by look. You will have to change your video settings to play it. There is no light in a cave. And what they give you for light only lights up two foot in front of you on normal settings. So you need to play with the brightness and gamma to be able to see at all what your doing and thats with still adding lights. Things like fire dont last long, its easier to keep them lit more then most games as you use leaves to keep them lit, but i'd rather have a fire i had to put wood on that lasted more then 5 min tops. The night cycle is so weird. If you dont sleep on time exactly you will eventually be moving the time at which you can sleep resulting in you playing at night and sleeping in day. Is it fun Yes but it feels unfinished in alot of areas, and worse yet the devs havent put out a update in over a year so i doubt there still fixing it. Oh sometimes you will be fighting while standing on something it gets bumped or something and send you and it flying 20 foot in the air to land and die. Ive played 20 hours and got 100 kills and it says less then 25% that purchase this game get that. So it makes me think people give up from all the quirks to quick.

All around, a very good survival/horror game. Definitely worth the money for it.

Gaming
Have you ever wondered about the history of gaming, or why people play games in general? And why gaming can be useful? Well, I‚Äôm here to tell you, even if you don‚Äôt care! First of all, Have you ever heard of gaming? Well, of course you have. It‚Äôs been all over the world, for multiple years, almost a century now! Now, for those of you that don‚Äôt know, Gaming is the act of playing a game on your console or your computer, it‚Äôs the activity of playing games. Now, did you know that the first game was made in 1958 by the Physicist William Higinbotham? Yes, It was a very simple tennis game. The game was called Pong, and it was very popular back then, and little bit now. But now, you might be asking, ‚Äú how many people play games? ‚Äú Well, there are currently around 3.07 billion people in the world that play video games! 
Let‚Äôs now talk about why people play video games, and why it can be good in your life. First of all, gaming helps people around the world. It can help cope with people's stress , and some games can just make you really calm, and help you get a better attitude/mood. You can also make money by playing video games, PROFESSIONALLY. You make a lot of money by streaming or winning tournaments/championships. It‚Äôs a win-win because while you are making money, you‚Äôre also having fun. But, you have to get lucky to start making money in games, so it‚Äôs not something easy and it also requires skill, which is why there aren‚Äôt many people that go for playing video games as their main job. For me, playing video games is a hobby, and it‚Äôs really fun with friends. So that‚Äôs why I play video games, as well as it helps me cope with the stress I might have sometimes, or it puts me in a better mood. Now, there are multiple reasons why people play them, but I believe that those are the main reasons.
Now that you know all of that information, you basically know almost everything about gaming, so I‚Äôll just be telling you fun/interesting facts. There are approximately over 5 MILLION video games in the world! That just shows how many games or options there are for you to play.. Did you know that there are 10 main types of video game genres? There is Sandbox Real-time strategy, Shooters (FPS and TPS), Multiplayer online battle arena, Role-playing (RPG, ARPG, and More), Simulation and sports, puzzlers and party games, Action-adventure, Survival and horror, and lastly, Platformer. There are so many genres you can pick to play, which is why gaming is SO popular! Did you know that  Games provide a 23 percent gain over traditional learning? 2013 research shows that games can increase learning outcomes by two grade levels. Playing action video games trains people to make right decisions faster. How, you might ask? Players develop a heightened sense of their surroundings and that helps them multitask. And surgeons that regularly play video games make 37% fewer errors and perform their tasks 27% faster than peers. There are so many benefits of playing video games!
I hope you learned something new from this, and I hope you enjoyed my speech! I just have one last question for you.. What is your favorite video game? Personally my favourite video game is fortnite, I play it all day, and I am champions league!

If you enjoy games based in building things, fending off enemies that vary in difficulty, and collecting materials and items, then this game is definitely one you should at least try, for $20 it's fairly entertaining, enough so that I have over 100 hours in it and still find it fun to play. 

Story wise, this game is pretty good. I like the lore, and I am saving my pennies for the second one coming out soon. 

The online has potential for griefers, but with a decently large map, it is not too difficult to just move away from them or just even remove them from the server altogether. 

Other than that,
 my only complaints are the low enemy volume, as after a while, I'd really, really love to see groups of like 20-30 cannibals attack my base,
and the boats, because the largest raft with two oars on each side is basically impossible to use by yourself, something it does NOT tell you when crafting it. 

And for some reason, they removed heavier boat building. Which, while I understand, is just disappointing to me. I really enjoyed having a hilarious tiny raft with 5 floors and flights of stairs causing it to lean heavily to the side, while staying row-able. That was a hilariously fun glitch.

Otherwise, this is a good game to play to pass time, and is even funner with friends or even strangers, and I'd recommend grabbing it, if you can on sale, even when the second comes out.

Pros:
-Gameplay is pretty fun from the start.
-Enemies are not that dumb.
-Visuals are ok. Can be better. It doesn't look like on screenshots in the steam store. (yep i have all on ultra)
-Audio
-Coop
-Crafting is fun?

Cons:
-Building in the game is sort of terrible. There are lots of limitations and odd rotations. Some parts of buildings cannot be repared after enemy destroys it.
-Feels like they added a lot to the game and tried to throw it all together.
-No random generated maps. Kills the idea of replaying.
-Can be a bit buggy and higher difficulties are stupid. Can't really build anything when enemies come every 5 min or less.
-Combat is sort of awkward. Hitboxes are a little odd as well.
-Lag when you enter cave or some part of cave. It looks like the game is loading the location you have entered.

Solo and cooperative gameplay feel very different. 

In the former, you're scared, alone, and constantly threatened. Caves, once cleared, are your only true safe zone. You pray that your camp, if you have one, isn't demolished by weird mutants, and that your traps can ensure a safe escape from groups that wander the island. Camouflage is a must.

In cooperative gameplay, you have other people to help build fantastic walls, set traps, build a farm, stock shelves, and revive you in a fight. The game quickly becomes an exciting splunking expedition where your previous dangers have become a resource of bones and skin. The surface is yours to sew and reap. Grab your chainsaws, and have fun!

AWESOME survival game. I know it says I've only played for 1 hour but that's because I have almost 100 hours logged on my PlayStation and I enjoyed it so much I bought it AGAIN almost immediately after getting my PC to experience it with even better visuals and with other friends! The crafting element is really cool and easy to use once you do it a couple times and the base building offers a lot of variety. The overall story is fantastic and I was blown away by where the story takes you if you follow it. But it's equally as fun just as a sandbox survival game, no following story nmecessary. I'm STILL discovering new things to do. Morbid and wild enemies/environment constantly giving me scares and jumps that evolve as you play. Imagine a truly terrifying horror Minecraft with real world graphics and an actual story. Single player or multiplayer, if that sounds like you're thing, you're missing out if you haven't played this.

Amazing !

Seriously half the people including myself initially don't understand this game. Anyone who claims there isn't enough crafting is wrong , as after 55 days in im still finding cool stuff from a secret evil church to a full on glider. It's not minecraft but once you finish it you'll get that mode which is cool. Or the horde mode that's crazy. Because its not Ark it actually works and works well which means it's a scary horror story which has two endgames based on choices.

The optimisation isn't great and there's a few glitches but nothing bad considering how much is going on.
The music is none existent outside of musical tapes but the sound is terrifying ..truly scary.
The gameplay is high mearning curve and finickity at times bur plenty of options.
Lastability is months or years as every time you play its different with random starts and locations and new updates. No microtransactions at all.

The combat isnt destiny but its brutal and fast with awesome weapons.
Overall the attention to detail is spectacular with many stories told through the environment as much as the lore through collectibles.
The multiplayer is a little buggy but amazing fun and an entirely different experience.
So i'd say buy it as it's cheap and play it and dont give up.
Use your second device as a game support tool as there are interactive map apps. And the wiki is cool though don't spoil many of the brilliant secrets and surprises.

I've played games for 20 plus years on all formats and across every genre and i was amazed to find it is one of the best game experiences i've every played and beyond value for money. Give it a chance and you won't be disappointed.

It's the most real-feeling survival game I have ever played.  Very tense.  It is also the scariest game I have ever played.  If you are going to play it single player, I recommend doing a play-through on Peaceful mode first, to learn the game mechanics because it is not very intuitive.  The tutorials are not very helpful.  You will most likely be Googling a lot, at first.  Also, it involves a LOT of caving, and the caves are so dark you  can barely see your hand in front of your face.  They are also like mazes.  You will most likely get lost a lot and finish up highly frustrated.  Learning HOW to craft items, what items can be crafted, and what they do is very important to your survival, and it is a lot easier to learn on Peaceful mode.  Then you can also learn HOW to build, and a bit about the map because the map provided is not very helpful, plus you can learn many other things such as how to build.  Once you know the game mechanics, this game is highly addictive because it is a lot of fun.  Really a blast on multi-player.

Loading in for the first time with a friend, this game had a lot of potential. Encountering the enemies for the first time was exciting. Discovering our first cave. Building our first base. After about 3 hours or so, however, the game very quickly loses all of its charm. The jank of this game becomes extremely apparent.

Combat, for example, is incredibly shallow. Bows deal little damage, and take an absurd amount of arrows to kill the simplest of enemies. Clubs and axes simply boil down to mashing attack and stun-locking your enemies.

Zero replayability. Everything on the map is the same every playthrough with the exception of the spawn point. Once you've experienced all the caves and the ending, that's it.

A majority of the buildable things in-game are pointless. You can survive with a basic fire and shelter and that's it. The rest is a waste of time, especially since enemies can destroy them anyways. My friend and I took  roughly 30 minutes to build a log cabin, only for it to be destroyed a couple nights later. 60+ logs worth of time and effort just gone.

Unfortunately I had lost substantial progress on a character playing w/ friends, not knowing that the save function was mandatory in MP. Kind of ridiculous that the host saving doesn't save for everybody... and sleeping doesn't save either? Specifically making a manual save is required regardless of SP or MP. You can chalk that up to being a mistake on my part, but still...

And finally, once you reach a certain point it feels like a guide or walkthrough is mandatory to complete the game. There are a about 10 or so caves scattered throughout the island and multiple points of interest, some of which are incredibly hidden and unlikely to be found by natural means. If you don't look up the necessary caves and items you will wastes tens of hours looking for things you don't even necessarily know about.

Overall kind of a generic survival/crafting game with little replayability and an endless ocean of jankiness and obtuseness. I would suggest not wasting your time.

Even though there is a sequel coming out very soon called "Sons of The Forest", this game is still a classic and fun. It would be more fun if you had a group of friends to play with, the game is beatable even with friends by your side. The horror factor is still there, sometimes you get jumped by mutants or by cannibals. The fear is unwavering even at night, because you'll never know what's behind you. The thing I like about this game is cave exploration, so many lore to uncover. I've recently beaten the game with friends, and I'll tell you: It was so fun and satisfying, but there is no replay factor unfortunately. After you beat the game, you're left with nothing but to fuck around with developer mode. Still, get this game on sale.
This game is a lot of fun when you have people to play with!

Cheesecake recipe

Ingredients
Ingredient Checklist
Crust:
1‚Äâ¬Ω cups graham cracker crumbs
¬º teaspoon ground cinnamon
‚Öì cup unsalted butter or margarine, melted
FILLING:
4 (8 oz.) packages cream cheese, softened
1‚Äâ¬º cups sugar
¬Ω cup sour cream
2 teaspoons vanilla extract
5 large eggs
TOPPING:
¬Ω cup sour cream
2 teaspoons sugar

DirectionsInstructions Checklist
Step 1
Preheat oven to 475¬∞F. Place a large pan filled with 1/2 inch water in oven.

Step 2
Make crust: Mix graham cracker crumbs and cinnamon; add butter or margarine. Press crust onto bottom and 2/3 of the way up a 9-inch springform pan lined with parchment. Wrap a large piece of foil around bottom of pan. Freeze until filling is prepared.

Step 3
Make filling: Use an electric mixer to mix cream cheese, sugar, sour cream and vanilla. Blend until smooth and creamy. Scrape down sides of bowl. Whisk eggs in a bowl; add to cream cheese mixture. Blend just until eggs are incorporated.

Step 4
Remove crust from freezer and pour in filling. Carefully place cheesecake into preheated water bath. Bake for 12 minutes; turn oven to 350¬∞F and bake until top of cheesecake turns golden, 50 to 60 minutes. Remove cake to a wire rack to cool.

Step 5
Make topping: Combine sour cream and sugar; spread over cake. Cover and refrigerate at least 4 hours.

This game is absurd. On normal mode, which is the EASIEST of the 3 difficulties, is unbalanced and overly difficult. It spawned DIRECTLY IN FRONT OF ME, TWO ARMSY'S. Not to mention, the enemies are overpowered! It takes 10 spear stabs to kill Regular Cannibals, and they hit me WITH BARE HANDS, and in THREE HITS, I'm dead??? Also, they can DODGE and I CAN'T?! RIDICULOUS! The weak spear, which has half the damage of the upgraded spear takes TWO THROWS to kill a Cannibal. But the upgraded spear? TEN STABS?! I tested it and the weak spear being thrown does as much damage as DYNAMITE!!! The game is still bugged too! A deer SLID off of a mountain and got stuck SIDEWAYS on the side of it! A bird was just sitting in mid-air! Not on a tree branch, mind you. IN THE MIDDLE OF THE AIR. A bench fell through the wall of a building. Just went straight through it. Then, despawned, respawning back up inside the building, proceeding to fall again. Rabbit was just in the water, running around on the bottom of the pond. I threw my spear, and it left the dimension. I could not find it, it completely despawned. Pulling up the crafting screen lets the world audio keep playing even though the world is paused. Suitcases and objects FLY in the air without even being touched! I ate a blueberry and it HURT ME?! Passengers bring powered tools, but NO WATER?! Only alcohol?! This game needs SO MUCH fixing and the normal difficulty NEEDS DESPERATELY to be decreased before this becomes #1 on the Rage Games list!

This game is great with some friends. A survival "horror" game that isn't actually that scary, a game that is casual and enjoyable for some of my friends who never play survival games. Some of the mechanics in the game, such as athleticism for your character, are pretty much useless as well as some of the weapon "upgrades." Combat can be comedic at times, and it's certainly not super polished. Hopefully the sequel fleshes stuff out more, but for $7 I had a ton of fun and enjoyed a surprisingly interesting story. I would highly recommend this game when on sale for a group of 2 or more friends to play through.

This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself super turned on and moist. I was fapping like a maniac. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I fisted my rear end in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my master baiting hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my box of tissues and soap to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to satisfy myself. 

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted fisting damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fisting of rage, or been one to break down a butt and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while my butt's recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "fisting". I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to fisting. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the butt fister I needed to be in that moment, not the weak ioncel boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and fisting friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others rear end unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

It starts off great me and a single friend, with a plan for this large screw off base. We're running out of trees in walking distance to cut, so it's a must to create a wooden cart to haul wood in. Well cart #1 ends up capsized in the river, never to be touched again. Then comes along cart #2, it did its job for a while. That was until it hits a stump, sending it into the 9 circles of Hell. As you watched cart #2 travel to the center of the Earth it's suddenly shot into sky, and was now falling from the sky like something out of Chicken Little. This stayed like this for the entirety of the game play, you'd watch the cart fall from the sky, through the ground, to the center of the Earth and repeat. This is where the fun begins as two more friends join the server. One a goofball, not wanting to actually build a base, but instead creates a raft. A raft that would keep him away from the cannibals but also make him "the captain". But this is not just any old raft, he puts a shack on it. From the cliff of our base you see this floating shack, which was glitchy as all hell. He was on a mission to sail around the island on his new raft, but little did he know, that he would give himself a plethora of new name tags. So when you did a 360, you'd see at least 7 copies of his usernames. But what makes it more fun, is that you'd also randomly find multiple shacks around the ocean as it glitched more into the game.
It's like realistic Minecraft, pretty fun even when you turn off enemies.
One of the best survival games I've played so far.
I am Glad I wore My Brown Pants.

I'm a big chicken when it comes to horror games.

...But this one's got a spot for people like me too. You can turn all the baddies off for a purely survival gameplay experience, which I thought was great. My online friends and I discovered how well this game does with the scares. By far, the most brilliant trick this game did is some optical illusions with lighting and level of detail that keeps you on your toes. The story arc is great, and it really feels like a discovery the whole time.

What I'd change: I don't like killing sea turtles or sharks, neither creature deserves it. I wish survival wasn't so easy to brush off, mid-game survival gear makes it trivial. A few more survival mechanics (more intense cold, sanity maybe, illness), and I feel like the local, um... residents... obliterate your structures without much thought, a log wall seems to only slightly slow them down.

Worth the play, but this game could definitely benefit from a little more depth and tuning.

My curiosity piqued I decided to make my way to the tree and see the view. While up there I noticed a ship wreck just off the coast and before heading down the hill to explore it, I took a moment to appreciate the tranquility and peace I found being out of the forest of cannibals and various other dangers lurking among the trees, only to turn around to leave and see three of them absolutely sprinting full speed towards me from 20 feet away. I screamed, panic quit the game, and have been too scared to go back. 10/10

I also had a major problem trying to connect and play with my friends in VR. When we're on computer, no issue, but VR seems to be a hassle whether it be not actually joining the game, or lag thats unfathomable. Just a rough experience all around. 

Recommended for PC not for VR.

One of the best survival games out there!

- Boring. 

Despite having random spawn points, the game is too linear and you'll end up going to the same caves in the same order each save/world.

- Building is lack luster and time consuming, for example a log cabin takes 80+ logs. Want to build a castle? Good luck.

- Easy to cheat, takes the fun out of it.
You can dupe arrows accidentally just by trying give them away! or dupe logs just by your friend picking them up too fast while using a log sled.

- Hackers. And hacks are easy to get!

- Short story; no lore. Which leaves the game being a day and night simulator.

There are in-game structures which are indestructible; this makes using them a no brainer, after awhile cannibals are no longer a threat or much less of a threat. Your base regardless is ONLY used for: extra storage, cooking and sleeping. So... if your base does get overrun, it doesn't matter anyway. Who cares? Not me.

I have had 'The Forest' in my library for a good two years now. When i first got it, I jumped in, got scared by the caves and didn't understand what to do. 

I just got Covid and saw that The Sons of The Forest was coming out and it looked really good so I thought "Why not beat the first one before TSOTF comes out".

Boy did I have a diamond of a game just sitting for years. 

The forest is a hardcore mutant like survival where you're stranded on an island and have to freely explore to unlock the story. It is challenging enough to make you think, but not hard to where its no fun or you feel like you're not making progress. There are useful items scattered throughout the map and throughout caves that will definitely help you. I cannot lie I did have to take to youtube at some points to find items/ make sure I'm going the right way through the final cave, but I was able to do so without spoiling anything major. The ENTIRE ending is absolutely phenomenal. You go through a certain door and its like the entire game changed and it gives an amazing wow factor and feeling. You are left with 2 choices, two different endings. I personally activated the button and really enjoyed that ending. (trying not to spoil anything but also share my thoughts on the ending I chose) it is a very good twist and leaves you ready for the next game. 

Took me a good 5 days of playing to beat it, maybe 5-8 hours everyday. 

Definitely worth my time and money and I will be counting the days till the next game!

Well optimized, atmospheric, mysterious, and immersive AF. Definitely pretty scary too. Suffers from some design flaws, oversights, and poor choices, though, but nothing game-breaking, more like just frustrating and tedious. Only being able to get water from specific ponds, for example, is pretty dumb. The game excels in its single-player story mode. While co-op is certainly fun, it often feels like an afterthought, which is a damn shame. The client-side synchronization for the players is pretty abysmal and there are some DUHH co-op features missing, like being able to give important items to your bros or trade between inventories. Overall, the game punches well above its price category and I highly recommend it, especially on sale. As I'm writing this, the game costs less than 6 euros, which is simply amazing.

Perhaps what I love the most about this game is that it has that arc where you can go from a weakling to your enemy's worst nightmare. The fact that you can become a worse cannibal and monster than the cannibals and monsters stalking you is quite the gruesome power trip. Decorating your fortress with the impaled heads and skulls of the savages is the very essence of this game's soul.

This review will contain minor spoilers.

Like many Early Access games of its type, The Forest had a tremendous amount of potential.
It's very clear that the developers had a ton of ideas just as it's equally clear that they lacked the time or manpower to execute on many of them.
In a word, The Forest feels unfinished. It's genuinely impressive for the first couple of hours, but its many issues become glaringly obvious the longer you play.

The game is filled with half-baked systems which are at best baffling and at worst a waste of time. A few of these include:
-Sanity
-Weapon upgrades
-Sleep
-Weight
-Crafting in general (many items have only a single use)

Even basebuilding, which obviously had a lot of work poured into it, is ultimately pointless since the optimal way to play the game is running around the island and building temporary shelters every night. There's no crafting bench which grants access to more recipes and there's no reason to have stationary storage since materials are so plentiful and your character can already carry around so many. The game features a slew of traps which can be used to defend your base, but in my 11-hour playthrough, I never once even considered building them as there's just no point.

The story, for all the praise people give it, feels shoehorned in. A lot of what you encounter makes no sense in-universe. As an example, towards the end of the game you are required to have a keycard to progress. Right before the checkpoint to use said keycard, there's a photo on the ground of a dead body with the keycard in its hand. The photo has the word "keycard" written on it with an arrow pointing to the corpse's hand. The game is FILLED with moments like this.

Beyond that, the game feels generally unpolished.
-The level design is extremely amateurish and immersion-breaking.
-Once you get the katana, combat becomes trivial.
-The animal AI is hilariously bad.
-There are a number of bugs, one of which forced me to reset to an earlier save.
-Inventory management is UNBELIEVABLY clunky. I cannot stress this enough.
-General menu navigation is a chore (at least when playing with a controller)
-Audio balancing issues throughout the game (especially noticeable in the final cutscene)

I could go on but I think the above should give you an idea of what the game is like. The fact that the reviews are Overwhelmingly Positive is baffling to me. The Forest feels very much like an Early Access game which needed way more work to be considered complete.

The game is not all bad. The mutants are well executed, the cannibal AI is very impressive, and some moments genuinely spooked me, but the luster wears off quickly.

Never in my life has my opinion of a game gone from extremely positive to abjectly negative so quickly.
In short, give this game a pass.

To start with the strong point: Ambience is really good. Few games are unsettling even after you see the monsters a few times but this one manages to be creepy for as long as I played. 

That's where it ends. I started playing blind on hard with a friend. Here's what I found by the time we decided to drop the game.

The food/thirst system is basically meaningless. You can overcome those issues within a day or two in game. Find a few sea turtles or tortoises and you've got water for the rest of the game. Birds are literally everywhere and make getting food absurdly easy. Every area you explore is full of literal snacks which restore plenty of hunger even if you go in ill-equipped.

The combat ranges from decent at best to boring and gimmicky most of the time. Facing every powerful enemy in the game is like "Let's pick them apart from range with ranged weapons that feel terrible to aim and run until they retreat to shoot them again"

Worse there is no tech-tree. There are a few crappy items you can make, and then a handful of other items you can find in caves. The game doesn't really feel like you progress at all. It just felt so pointless. 

The only thing you can do is go around and explore caves to find some decent loot, cheese OP abominations and repeat. 

No XP system. No tech progression. An extremely basic stats system, and the ability to occasionally glitch through the floor and fall forever. (which was the last straw for us.)

I have never played this game by myself and don't think I'd ever be able to; it's way too scary loll. Instead I played with 3 other friends and we all had a blast, making fun of the gremlins and even starting a band?!?!!! The survivalist aspect was pretty difficult but the grind was fun, knowing that at any moment you could die from thirst or hunger while also trying to fend off the gremlins.

The storyline was unique and interesting, and the game had fun ways of pushing you into wildly horrific circumstances which could easily chill you to the bone and make you want to crawl into a corner and pass away, even with friends to help eachother, which is what really sells this game for me. The stress and fear may difficult to live with in the moment, but the absolute GREATEST part about this game is when you're done killing gremlins, done with a cave or done with swimming and you have that awkward & chilling moment of peace before jumping back into the game.

The graphics were amazing for a game that runs really well on my less than adequate PC, with the wildlife always bringing you joy even when you had to kill animals to drink water and slide down mountains (which was easily one of the most fun parts of the game).
funny make me go lol and boo

I am currently playing and enjoying the game for the most part. A lot of details were added and I can see room for future growth. From the moment the plane crashed I found it next to impossible to believe that there was no one else nearby that survived. Unless it was similar to Cast Away and you made a Soccer Ball into a friend, someone else should have been with the playable character or at least an option to be completely solo or not would have been amazing. I found playing with completely no friendly NPCs made the game hopeless giving no inspiration to carry-on seeking others.  Besides some of the things I listed below I still want to complete the game and see what else is in store. I know I have less Pros than Cons listed but the game is still good overall.

Pros:
Nice open world.
Enemies were scary and unpredictable. 
Teaches good critical thinking in regards to survival skills.


Cons:
The build options would benefit greatly if it had more to offer. (Unless it does overtime and I have not progressed enough) 
VR made it impossible to complete certain tasks. (I died trying to light a fire after 15 minutes because it would not light for nothing)
Ability to save in game would have been helpful to save even while in a cave in case you needed to fins a stopping point for the day/night.
I was stuck in a cave with absolutely no way of understanding how to exit and came close to stop playing altogether.
More detailed guide of what to do and or where to go.
No ability to climb small rocks that was right by my base that the enemies could scale with no effort.
Another thing that I was most sad by was that no other passengers or NPCs were able to help me build a stable, secure place to build a base and gather food, water and other things like wood. That would have made for a really enjoyment, causing players to play solo while also being tasked with keeping the found NPCs alive and working together to complete the game. 

(Don't want to spoil anything and my sincerest apologies if I have already)

In my opinion, the game is great but there is a lot of annoying features that makes the game unbearable.
- Inventory system is the worst, can't even find what I'm looking at and can't even change their places. There is no need for such a complicated system, it should have been more simple. Imagine you are crafting something new and you cant find it.
- When you want to build a building or such things, you have to use a book that contains them. The book has a lot of pages and when you want to build a specific thing, you have to look for it through the pages or memorize the page. Page tabs are not clear so you have to look at pages for a while.
- You will find the map ahead of the game and it's possible that you may never find it. Even if you find the map it's just a piece of blank paper that draw on it as you travel around. It's ridiculous and unnecessary, you could have just given the blank paper at the start of the game. Absolutely bad choice.
Overall the game is actually fun and scary, even more fun when you play with your friends. You get used to these annoying features but I do not recommend the game.

An FPS solo/multiplayer survival game with an interesting and simple story. You and your friends have to survive on an island full of cannibals, with a goal to rescue your son who has been stolen by one of them.

A great game for survival fans with a faint touch of horror game, the game has 5 different difficulties (creative, peaceful, normal, hard, and hard survival), I personally find the normal difficulty is good enough. 

The game doesn't have a lot of explanation/hints telling you how to craft weapons, armor, medicines, etc. You just have to figure it out, and you will get a hang of it, as soon you understand their mechanics. A few flaws and glitches in the game but it's not too bothering. I'll might as well say, the glitches can make the game still enjoyable and fun.

Okay, I usually am not one to write reviews but this game was SO good. I played it with a friend and the story line was really fun to figure out and follow along with as well as just playing a survival game in general was super fun. I really enjoyed periods where you just focused building your base, hunting, etc. and then you go to caves and really dive into the story line and the eeriness of the game. The ending also had me super surprised and after reading up on it, the amount of Easter eggs and depth that goes into the story is super impressive.

Building/Crafting. Exploring/Looting. Hunting/Scavenging. While not having a very diverse building/crafting system and only a handful of different enemies it's still great fun. The story whilst not completely engaging isn't entirely forgettable and the tasks tied to it will keep you entertained for a couple of hours, great fun and hours of playability with friends. Unlike most other "Survival" games this one isn't limited to above ground and features cave systems with rewards for those willing to explore, there are even secrets in the ocean! Decently balanced combat for the mechanics of the game with options to cater to most combat type preferences. 7/10 could have done with some crafting tweaks and additions.

There are Improvements to be had to this game, but i'd say its worth its price tag, specially if you got some friends to play with, 

>Pro's
It's cheap
Fun to play, and satisfying when you kill tons of Cannibals and mutants!
Tons of variations to base building, decent amount of different crafts of weapons and utility.
A pretty good sized map to explore, including a quite extensive underground area.
Enemies feel alien and foreign in every sense of the word, they may look somewhat human, but by god they are anything but.
Combat especially inside the caves can be quite challenging and fun.
The Environment feels alive, and is visually pleasing for the most part.
The Story is actually kinda interesting once you get into it and collect pictures, find missing passengers from the plane etc

>Cons
Can get stale if you play by yourself
Building a base, is a real time sink(getting an efficient method of transportation is vital, like zip-lines and log carts)
Combat is pretty repetitive n basic, and extremely clunky, like the Spear is long, but it feels more like its melee range is sat to the same as any other melee weapon.
I can't seem to remember the music in the game
Big grind fest, limited inventory
The Katana is somehow not the best melee weapon in the game, even tho it's an actual proper weapon, compared to these makeshift clubs and wood cutting axes.
Feel like they missed out on the opportunity to make metal forging a thing(could have just used metal scraps or even mined some, i mean there's plenty of rock formations, especially down inside the Caverns)
No Crafting animations, or animation when you wear armour(bone, hide etc) only a small effect that your char acknowledges that you put it on.

Overall, cheap fun game with friends, not a great game to play by yourself unless your really bored and forgo all the base building. Because building one yourself without cheats or mods is a super long endeavour. Decent story, freaky enemies, and a overall fun experience if ur into these kinda games

Semi-fleshed out cannibals, however they could use a little more work to establish their religion, and whatnot. But you can even teach them, that you're peaceful. By using a stick with some cloth on it, to block all their attacks, without hurting them. Walking slowly, and never turning your back to them... etc. But you can sort of "tame" them, which i really like.
The graphics are alright.
Can be genuinely terrifying on singleplayer.

Cons:
Incredibly difficult, which some players may not like.
Nudity, which makes it hard to stream this game on sites like YouTube and Twitch.
It can get REALLY dark. And i mean, the "you can barely even see your hands" kind of dark. And that's difficult to deal with. But a very minor con, nonetheless.
It doesn't really do much of a good job at making you care about TImmy. But saving him, is not really the point of the game, nowadays. Used to be though.
Very bad memory management. Can easily crash some computers.
Can't set character as left handed. But not really an RPG, anyways.

But overall, it's one of my top 10 favorite games.

Pros:
Exceptional exploration with no hand holding.
Caves that are better dungeons than those in most RPG games.
Ambient audio.
The forest can really look gorgeous.
Unpredictable A.I. makes the natives look and feel threatening
Simple but functional crafting system.
Original and fun inventory design.

Cons:
Impolished/buggy.
Could use more hotkeys.
Enemies in the caves should respawn.
Enemies in the middle of my base should not.
Items respawning in the same place are easily exploitable and kind of silly.


What you're probably thinking is that The Forest is a survival focused game where you're supposed to build a fort and simply persist. Cant blame you for I was under the same impression until I got my hands on the game.
While survival can be the name of the game, me and my friends led mostly nomadic lives, building only what was necessary to spend the night while catering only to the most basic needs and staying constantly on the move throughout the peninsula and its network of underground caves in pursuit of our goals.
It is up to you to choose how you want to play and set your own pace for exploration as The Forest's gameplay is flexible and free-form. I'd say it was more of an adventure than a survival game for most of us but, that does not have to apply to you and your band of brothers.

Personally, I enjoyed the exploration the most and can't even remember all of the times that The Forest left me gasping in amazement. Successfully navigating through and surviving the perils of the cave systems felt like a rewards of it's own to which the frequent ‚Äúlore chunks‚Äù and occasional gear upgrades were more of a cherry on top.
The lack of hand holding greatly amplified the reward and the experience for me as everything we did, every cave that we successfully navigated and went through felt like it was 100% our doing as there were no ‚Äúarrows‚Äù guiding our way to take the credit, and the moderate consumption and distribution of previously prepared rations encouraged us to embark on another expedition and conquer the peninsula and all of it's nook's and cranny's, one by one.


Other than exploration, there's also a simple yet sufficient base building aspect to The Forest.
Cutting down trees to make walls and huts, getting familiar with, harvesting and eventually cultivating local flora (and even some fauna) comes with advantages of their own ‚Äì as well as the consequences.
Sure, it's great to have a place called home but should you stay in it for too long and make a ruckus while doing it, be prepared to deal with your new and openly unhappy neighbors.

The natives will take actions proportionate to yours (or so it seemed to us) so if you desecrate their hunting groves or over-expand into their territory, be prepared for more than a couple of sleepless nights. Also keep in mind that violence breeds violence so, if it's not necessary or in self-defense, try not to cast the first stone. Cowering in the nearby bushes or simply running away is probably the best option - unless you crave bloodshed.

One last thing to mention is that, unlike most games dabbling in the survival genre, The Forest actually has the beginning and the ending. It even provides the player with optional activity that will encourage exploration and investigation which I highly recommend doing as it will shed some light on the history of the the land and events that took place there.
Whether it's a good story or a mediocre one, well, that's up for you to decide but I can say that I really liked it and that it definitely wasn't a bad one. Those of you who liked 


Still having doubts? I say pick it up!
Support the small, creative team and help them make a sequel worthy of The Forest. I personally can't recommend it enough.

Having backed this game since the start, I'll say it's been journey. Lots have changed during it's development, but I have to say that the crew behind The Forest have made a near perfect survival game that can be enjoyed alone or even more so with friends! It's incredibly scary and horrifying but at the same time the most serine relaxing game I've come across in a survival.
if you're into straight up survival, this game can challenge you just against it's nature, but if you include the indigenous you'll be in for quite the hellish experience. Be aware, you can treat this as a sandbox game, or a story driven scare game guaranteed to keep you  on your toes be that in the deepest of caves or dark forests.

I would always recommend this to anyone, because Steam allows you to play for a few hours and should you find you hate it; get a refund! - I doubt even the most picky of players will request a refund tho, as this game has been with me for years, and for years I've played it alone and with friends over and over... Each time finding different things to do and different ways to play. Who doesn't love making giant Tarzan-land covered Forests or Castles to fend off foes...

Anyhow, do try it! You won't regret it!

The Forest is a buggy mess that failed to grasp my interest from a gameplay standpoint. If I didn't have friends to play it with, I likely would have never bought the game entirely because of the poor polish and my own personal difficulty with getting into survival games. But, the game came on sale, prompting my friends and I to get the game. 

We had a group of four. One friend who had completed the game prior on PS4, one friend who had watched a playthrough on YouTube, and two noobs (I was a noob). My time in The Forest featured many bugs (some entertaining, others deterring), an addicting gameplay loop and lots and lots of deforestation. We setup camp near the yacht per our leader's recommendation and began our playthrough. Our gameplay boils down to two categories; Base building & piss-farting around, and exploring. We all contributed a little to our eyesore of a base, but the other noob in our group spent the most time building. In one instance, he spent about 2 hours at the base building up a large custom house that we barely ended up using. During this time, the rest of us were deep underground stood in a circle messing with the [i] awful [/i] in-game voice chat making each other laugh in any way we could. As for the other half of our playthrough, we'd always go cave exploring the moment we get bored of base building. I did a lot of "follow the guy who has his map out" so I didn't have to lead the pack, meaning I didn't get the full experience of the exploration aspect of this game, but it worked out for me. We'd explore the caves and always emerge satisfied with the loot we'd find, and go back to base building. This gameplay loop was enough for us to jump back and forth between the two sides of the game without getting bored. Overall, the gameplay was good. 

However, this gameplay would not have kept me hooked personally. Without nostalgic value, a fresh survival game is like trying to do nofap. I'm willing to give it a go, but I'd likely give up after a couple hours. What kept me going was my friends engagement in the experience. Since most of them seemed to be immersed in the adventure, it was a lot of fun to play and mess about with them. Now that we've finished our playthough, I likely won't touch this game again unless its with other friends. 

TLDR: The game is awfully made, but fun to play. If you have friends to play it with, your positive experience is guaranteed. I look forward to the sequel.

If you're interested in a survival game about being trapped in an uninhabited part of the world, surrounded by native cannibals, with the ability to build up your own base from scratch in any way so you please; avoid The Forest at all costs and go buy Green Hell instead. 

The Forest is a collection of half-baked ideas slapped together and brimming with frustrating controls and gameplay. If you decide to just use of the of the pre-built structures for saving and sleeping and spend the rest of the game just speedrunning through the main quest, then maybe you'll get a few hours of distraction from it. But if you try to engage with any of the game's base building aspects (aka: the main feature of the game), you're going to be left disappointing at best and furious at worst. 

First of all, none of your build-able items have descriptions so if you want to know what a thing does or how to best use it, you'll be going to a wiki constantly. Furthermore, very few items actually snap together, forcing you to do your best to eyeball structures as you cobble them together. And as far as I can tell, when you try to place the blueprint of an item, there's no way to 'scroll' that blueprint closer or father from you. So you have to move your character first to line it up, which can cause a ton of problems if you're trying to build in a tight space or in a precarious position. And by the way, don't make the mistake I did and waste all the time and resources building a fireplace thinking you could use the FIREPLACE to make fires or cook food. Nope. It's a decoration only. 

It's that kind of baffling gameplay choices that you'll find everywhere in The Forest. Food you put on fires has no cook time indicator, so you might not even notice you put down something small like bird or rabbit meat and leaving you to guess at how long it will take to finish. Also, you are unable to take cooked food and put it in your inventory. Once you put it in a fire, your only option is to eat it. But if you leave it in too long, it burns, lowering its value. You're only able to sleep at specific times, so if you're low on energy and have no food to keep it up, you're kinda just screwed. Also, I hope you enjoy being attacked by natives. A lot. Because no matter where you go to try and build on the map, you're going to be fending off cannibals several times a day, every single day to the point where you can barely even get through cutting down a tree. And this isn't late game mobs, either. No, you're dealing with this annoyance day one.  Not that failing combat even matters. As long as you lose all your HP outside, all the cannibals do is drag you into the same cave and string you up, forcing you to cut yourself down and trek back home. You don't even lose any your things, or even much time, so there's no thrill to combat; its just this annoying thing you have to do all the time.

Overall, everything The Forest does can be found better in other survival games. If the concept of this game still seems interesting to you, I would HIGHLY suggest getting Green Hell instead as it has everything this game has to offer with none of its problems. As for The Forest? I bought this game for $8 and I still feel ripped off.

It was a beautiful start of 2022. We played this game together, he and I. While there are thousands of miles between us in real life, in game it felt like we were really close to each other. We built a base together, - it wasn't anything fancy but it was nice sharing a living space with him. We went against cannibals and mutants together. I would lie if I said it wasn't challenging. Not just for the fighting part; I got to see how hot - tempered he is when things got messy. It even led to an argument between us but it was nice getting to know the other side of him and overcoming struggles together. Like in real life.

We went to hunt animals together. He was the one who taught me the art of hunting and, let me tell you, I've never felt more confident about my skills than I did back then. Finally I was able to provide meat food for both of us, not just berries. Surviving in the forest together really brought us close. I remember that delicate moment he approached me to have a suck on my peen for the first time. It was unforgettable. And it's become a thing we treated each other to on a regular basis ever since. I've never felt being so close to him. So intimate. We even had a threesome once. It was a stranger that we stumbled upon during our journey. We parted our ways soon after but he kept thinking about that person and the experience we had as a trio for quite a while.

Looking after our home base, cutting trees, crafting stuff, exploring caves, stalking animals, dismembering and eating people, experiencing countless bugs, looking for trouble and regretting it after, having arguments and sorting them out, creating a space to live and survive together, teaching and learning from each other, speaking la langue de l'amour... It was nice sharing a life with him. Far from the civilization. Just the two of us. Living together. Getting close. In game. Beautiful start of 2022.

Ratatouille is a 2007 American computer-animated comedy film produced by Pixar Animation Studios and released by Walt Disney Pictures. The eighth film produced by Pixar, it was written and directed by Brad Bird, who took over from Jan Pinkava in 2005, and produced by Brad Lewis, from an original idea from Bird, Pinkava and Jim Capobianco. The title refers to the French dish ratatouille, which is served at the end of the film, and also references the species of the main character, a rat. Set in Paris, the plot follows the rat named Remy, who dreams of becoming a chef and tries to achieve his goal by forming an alliance with a Parisian restaurant's garbage boy.

Decent game, but it has a ton of   [b]j a n k[/b]. Read through at your own peril but I'm gonna go over every single point I can remember off the top of my head:

+ Combat has a steep learning curve, but is fun
+ Aesthetic for the enemies, especially the mutants is great
+ Definitely gives me horror vibes, but not more than I can handle
+ Inventory UI is unique, and quite nice to look at
+ The story of the game is short and interesting
+ Base building is quite fun and customizable, love the House Boat
+ You can upgrade a rock with flammable cloth and set it on fire in your hands for a flaming rock weapon

+- This is the first game I've played where having 400 ping is actually an advantage. Animals do not even react fast enough to you sprinting up to them and stabbing them with a spear. It's nice but I'm not sure how I feel about it. Playing in my friend's lobby I was downright unkillable

- The game is honestly too dark. I know lighting is a mechanic but sometimes it's straight up unplayable for me. How can cave interiors be brighter than the open forest under the moonlight?
- Some obvious features don't exist, for example choosing which arrows to retrieve/deposit into an arrow basket
- The crafted bow feels like hot garbage, and I hear it was made this way because they added the modern bow. Doesn't make sense in my opinion, if it sucks so hard you wouldn't use it in the first place
- 4 hotkeys maximum? Really?
- You can't turn on/off flashlights on bows. Replacing the battery requires dismantling the modified bow, crafting batteries into the flashlight, then crafting it back into the bow. Makes 0 sense
- Lighter and handheld flashlight share the same keybind, meaning you can't choose which you pull out without going into the inventory. Lazy move on the dev's part
- You cannot disable the auto-equip of the Rebreather, meaning that once you acquire it, any submerge will start draining your air canisters
- Aiming for spears is atrocious. You cannot aim below a certain angle, so if a critter is too close to you, you gotta find some other ranged weapon to use on it
- Most weapons are redundant in this game. Weapons you get at the end of the game (Machete) are downright useless compared to weapons you get at the start (Modern Axe). The pistol is garbage considering how long it takes to assemble it
- *Permanent* weapon upgrades go away when you die. Doesn't make sense to me, unless the cannibals/mutants are stealing the glass shards right off your weapon after you're dead
- The gazebo isn't sheltered for some reason. Seems easy enough to just put a covering of leaves over it, but I guess that was too much developer time and money to implement
- It makes no sense that you can store 10 boulders, a chainsaw, 2 bows, 7 spears, 50 arrows and 4 axes in your bag, [b]but not a single animal head trophy[/b]
- Inventory management system being restricted by item quantities rather than max weight kinda sucks. Makes no sense that I can load up with all the above mentioned items, but can't drop 5 boulders to make way for 10 more lizard skins
- Lots of stuff falls through floors. Had several primed dynamite sticks fall through the floor before they could explode
- Bow/Crossbow aiming changes perspective when you crouch. I don't know about you but I wouldn't hip fire my bow just cause I was crouching down. It should keep its perspective no matter what position you are in, as it would in real life
- Plenty of outfits in the game that you'll never get to see cause you can't see yourself. Unless your outfits are only made of pants and sleeves
- Cold damage makes no sense. Rabbit fur boots exist that give 20 cold armour, along with the Warmsuit which gives 100. However cold damage cannot be prevented unless you have 100. Ergo, rabbit fur boots have no use in the game and are just a noob trap
- Baby damage is wayy overtuned in this game. How does a baby hit for like 120 damage on Hard, but a Cowman does no damage on charge knockdown
- Several arrow types exist in this game, including Bone and Modern arrows. However, Bone arrows are retrieved as wood arrows, and modern arrows convert to wood arrows after having fire/poison applied to them. So basically only wood arrows matter
- You can store raw, bloody meat and severed cannibal limbs in your bag. But you cannot store berries without a fur pouch
- For some reason, thrown cannibal molotovs cause my game to stutter every few seconds. I like that they exist, they just have crap performance
- Sharing system is crap. You can only trade 1 quantity of 1 item on the sharing tray at a time. It also makes no sense that the ONLY way to pass something to someone else is to put it on a tray instead of like... Dropping it on the ground maybe?
- I just remembered, you can't drop most stuff on the ground. This is a flaw of their weird inventory management system
- I can wear 10 pieces of creepy armour but the armour rack will only hold 9..?
- You can only carry 10 crossbow bolts, but the flare gun can be loaded with 10'000 flare ammo, ironically making it a better and more convenient ranged weapon than the crossbow
- Flintlock pistol parts in multiplayer are not shared, so you'll have to kill your friends to see who gets the one pistol, which ends up being a crap weapon compared to the modern bow/crossbow so you end up with no DPS and no friends
- You cannot pick up and discard burnt food from a fire pit. You literally have to force yourself to eat coal to get rid of it. If you accidentally loaded up your fire pit with spoiled meat, you can't get rid of it either. You have to wait until it becomes coal, then force yourself to eat all of it, or else your fire pit becomes unusable
- Forcing you to use turtle shells to craft water collectors seems unrealistic. I'm fairly certain people use like banana leaves and stuff IRL to do that. Also cause the dead flesh stuck to the shell might poison your water over time
- Breaking buildings doesn't return any materials to you. Not even partially
- I've never heard of a log holder before. I'm pretty sure it's easier to just pile logs on the floor rather than build a log cage out of sticks
- It isn't obvious ANYWHERE that you can upgrade storage buildings to a higher tier. I finished the game twice before figuring that part out because the icon for it looks like it would mean "Reverse orientation" or "Flip". A plus sign would've been sufficient but apparently that wasn't intuitive enough
- I can put 10 sticks in my bag, but to store 5 spears which are made of 2 sticks each, I need a separate bag made of boar leather. 2head move by the devs

At this point you probably think I'm being nitpicky. That's because I am. A lot of these were obvious QoL or common sense things, that a game priding itself on [b]REALISM[/b] should have thought about long ago. If this game was in beta/early access, I would be recommending it. Unfortunately we're way past that and some parts of the game still feel like garbage. 4 hotkeys in a game where you get pants pockets and a backpack feels like an archaic design and is not fun at all, considering how many hoops the devs make you go through to do simple things - like picking berries. I definitely have more criticism to throw at the game but this is just what I thought of off the top of my head. Game needs work
