I love this game so much! That being said, there are still some pros and cons to it.
Pros: Almost always in some threat that keeps gameplay fast moving, Fun and intuitive crafting interface, intriguing story, good progression from early-game to late-game items and gear, multiplayer is always a blast with friends! Enemies are cool, scary, and just difficult enough to keep things really interesting. You really do earn everything you have.

Cons: The custom structure building mechanics are very difficult to get used to, and even then, building custom stuff is a chore. Buildings can get demolished by falling trees and even just one wave of enough enemies. Rebuilding is a constant struggle until late-game. It is very possible to lose all your hard earned itmes and be forced to start over from scratch. Any bugs you encounter will not be fixed as it is not priority at all since a new sequel is coming out soon. Hard to run on less powerful computers

If you are able to look passed the cons and really immerse yourself in the game, I can not suggest this enough. I've played this for so long because even with its flaws, it's a fantastic game with a great community and lots of online help if you get stuck. Have fun!

Played through this game over the course of a week with a couple of friends. While crafters and survival horror games aren't usually my taste, I really enjoyed The Forest. It's genuinely spooky, and the crafting mechanics are intuitive and fun. Jump-scares and gross-outs happen organically. You can really get lost in the atmosphere. Playing solo was too freaky for me. Chopping down a tree while cannibals stare at you from the woods, breathing heavy? Ugh. No thanks. Playing with a group was still tense, but in a fun way. You know you're going to wind up going down the big pit in the middle of the map, eventually - How you get there, though - that's the story.

[h1]The Forest Game Review [/h1]
[h2]TL:DR[/h2]
I've never been so fun playing survival game that look similarly to Minecraft, except it gives Horror environment with the island inhabited by intelligent cannibals looking for cannibalizing you. You are to survive by making shelter and gathering resource while also looking for Timmy and other missing passengers.
This game is just so worth, It also provides Multiplayer mode where the story wise you also have other passenger surviving with you(of course it would be CO-OP Quest story although it would reduce Horror atmosphere in the game).

[b]The Forest Terrain and Environment[/b]
The environment, Graphic of Terrain in the game are so HD is fancy. the game has fixed terrain and places, means making multiple world will have the same terrain and location of caves(only plane which would be your spawn are different) atleast the map is not too big than other Similar Open world games, which mean you will likely less watching clue or walkthrough from internet to progress your story.

[b]The Forest Gameplay Mechanic[/b]
By explanation as simple as possible, this game is an open world survival game played in first person perspective, where you have the decision of how do you want to survive(whether be it making shelter guided by basic surviving knowledge book and marking place as your home, or attacking the other Tribe and cannibalizing them).
The game provides basic knowledge that can be used for real life surviving in the forest such as making fire, shelter, how to find water, SOS signal, etc.

As for Creatures, are designed with well controlled movement. Take an example of deer or rabbit, it can smell you right away when you want to hunt them. You can have this problem solved by disguised with nature which will reduce their awareness of you(this work for Cannibals as well).
The first time you meet Cannibal would be your best experience, they often move in a group and not attacking carelessly unlike mobs in other game. they are designed so well that it has nearly sapient intelligent level, capable of surrounding you, attacking you from behind, and even stalk and scout you from away.

[b]The Forest Story Review Warning Contain spoiler[/b]
The game provides the scene where you and your son named Timmy were on the plane. The plane went turbulence and crashed on an unknown island, where you son is taken to somewhere unknown. while surviving you are also besought to find clues about where your son is taken off, finding whether are there any other passenger survivor, and clues about man made things which is abandoned.
While Progressing the story, I found it enjoyable and giving Horror atmospheric feeling. it's wiser to explore the side caves before you exploring the main cave because it require some item to be fulfilled in order to progress which lead to the explanation of how cannibal exist, what caused your plane to crash, and many more.

[b]Weakness and things you should considerate [/b]
the game also has weaknesses, which I thought would be:
[olist]
[*]lacking of late game weapons since you need to progress the story in order to obtain more stronger weapon and the more you progress the story, somewhat the tougher they become.
[*]lack of late game building ideas since the book only provide basic knowledge of survival.
[*]the game actually demand you to find other missing passenger and Timmy rather than enjoying survival because the cannibal does attack you occasionally whether you're on your shelter in the morning, or trying to sleep and woke up being surrounded, etc.
[*] I only played this CO-OP, I did singleplayer but didn't progress the story since CO-OP feels merrier and more fun. but I found out that even we did CO-OP the Mutant(I haven't mention this, they're different than cannibal) is quite tough, strong and require tactic to kill it. [spoiler] let alone the final boss [/spoiler], i can't Imagine how hard it would be if i played it singleplayer.
[/olist]
That's all my Opinion I can give, my verdict has been given on top of my comment.

If you really want to feel the meaning of loneliness and surviving on your own among scary cannibals and awful freaky monsters , going through hell and back to fine every item that is useful , to build a little camp that would keep you alive for at least the first week and above all , to fell the stress of running as fast as you can just to stay alive during the mid-night rain storms , I recommend you to play the Single-player campaign.

Btw, Try to get the KATANA Sword on the first day , Trust me you gonna need it :)

This can be a fun game, but I think you have to play with friends. It's worth noting that I played as a guest with others and had no idea this game had an actual story. 
Potential Spoiler- As a guest, you get a slightly different intro, so I had no idea why I should find this Timmy kid on my objective list, it wasn't until I played some solo that I saw an alternative perspective and realized. I think this is a neat dynamic, but the lack of awareness for the game made it difficult to follow and I just thought it was a "Rust" like game.
This lack of story created an environment where we spent most of our play time cutting down forests and building bases, zip-lines, and other intricacies before one of my party started reading online... Then it all changed. We went from trying to manage our village to exploring and achieving goals. These goals and my companions understanding of the game gave us purpose and this is when I started to enjoy the game...
Until we ran into several glitches and issues (destroyed points for one do not mean everyone sees it destroyed or your location may not match up with some locations of items- reloading fixed many issues by resetting values. Another issue was achievement tracking in the system didn't register so for some doing this, you may have to host a separate game to get those that don't register correctly). We worked through them, but these issues can severely disrupt the enjoyable nature of the game.
One key takeaway for those willing to brave the game- guest saves are separate from the host... so if the guest saves and the host reverts their save, the guest maintains everything. This is nice for guests.
If it weren't for the multiple bugs, I would definitely rate this more favorably, but it's still an enjoyable game with a good group.

This game saved my life.

I am 38.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.
After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.
Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

I loved this game. The story felt original and can be interpreted in whatever way you want. It seems to be one of those survival games where you start off with very little information but a clear goal in mind. Your plane has crashed and you must find your now missing son in a vast Forest. As you proceed, the game unravels a twisted (and tbh thoroughly enjoyed) story about it's inhabitants.

Without giving much more away than that, The Forest is a solid game. Genuinely scary, with stressful survival moments make this game both intense and worthy of a lengthy playthrough. So often for games in the survival horror category seem to not end, or have no goal beyond just surviving as long as you can until something kills you, but this game has an ending I really enjoyed.

Singleplayer or multiplayer with friends, doesn't matter this game is really fun either way. If you're more horror-oriented, I would recommend singleplayer because obviously playing with friends makes it less scary.

I probably finished the game about 3 times and played 6 or 7 times with different people. As you can see, it's a good game, the crafting features of the game are pretty good compared to the game's release date! The story of the game is very beautiful and ends with different endings depending on your different choices and the materials you collect. One day you will not be able to find anything wise to eat, you will eat mutant human legs, the next day you will make stew from the islanders, in some days you will cut freshwater turtles into pieces and then slide on the hills with their shells.

NOTE: flying, sliding down the slide is extremely fun. After finishing the game, it is highly recommended to turn on the cheat mode and make a water slide!
it's great it's like Turkey simulator.
Love it!!! I love every aspect to the survival of it

Gameplay is pretty fun but gets kinda tedious at a point having to kill cannibals over and over again for armour or having to farm certain materials for armor. Though building in the game is really good, it still feels kinda limiting to how much creativity the player can use in building structures. Multiplayer opens up a whole new world of fun for this game, making it go from a horror game in singleplayer to a fun experience with friends in multiplayer. Had a ton of fun with friends in multiplayer even there were some annoying bugs sometimes. Overall, I'd give it an 8.5/10.

I had just finished it tonight as I am writing my review and I can say this was one of if not the best survival horror games I've played in quite a long time. While i still really recommend this game, it does have a lot of issues.
Quite a few bugs

all items are always in the same spot leading to very easy game play and a lot less replayability

Bad balancing and optimization for some weapons and buildings, Crossbow shoots way too high past aiming, the gun is way to underpowered for a weapon that is the hardest to obtain in the game and you cannot place most items in the church obtained through the blueprints.
You cannot change the flag on the log cart and the cart is indestructable leading to multiple flags all over the map. 
And many many more issues.
The game is great but i feel like it was far from being fully developed and required a bit more development
Some cool things they could've added to the game would be.
Skill points and perks.. The ability to level up stamina, speed and health and have certain perks like carry more logs or better bow accuracy.
More than just the 5 mutants.
a nest cave where you could fight a load ton of cannibals at once
more animals like bears or wolves.
I still very much think everyone should give this game a go. however the devs should have done more with it, Especially because its such an amazing game. i just hope the second one is a lot more developed.

I encountered The Forest often on the Steam front page. Not even once was I interested in buying this game. I never even clicked on it. Until somehow my friends and I decided to play it. I had no idea what to expect, and the game was all the better for it.


We went in fresh, eager to see what the game was about. Had I played this solo, I would likely have built a small base and gone through the game slowly and, frankly, nervously. Instead, we ran all over the island like maniacs. Maniacs who were even worse than the cannibalistic locals.


Wherever we encountered the natives we cut them down. As if that wasn't enough, we invaded their subterranean homes and slaughtered their women and children too. The mutants struggled, but their resistance was futile. No enemy could withstand the might of coordinated molotov cocktails.


We found other passengers and strange clues on these expeditions that eventually led us to the story's finish. A revelation and ending that were as freaky as the entire game up until that point. I enjoyed the entire wild ride from start to finish, but it was frankly quite horrifying.

Super fun to play and mess around in, especially if you have a friend to play it with. It can be a it frustrating at the start, with being killed by the cannibals and whatnot. Make sure your making armor for yourself so you wont be as easy to kill. The lighting and sounds of the game are pretty good, and i can definitely tell there's a story going on, but i admit i have not been paying attention to it. Fun game!

The Forest is a single player or co-op survival game where you seek to endure after your plane crashes on a mysterious island inhabited by tribes of cannibals. Not only that, but one of them has taken your son, and it falls to you to get him back. If you like survival/crafting gameplay, atmospheric wilderness, fast, deadly, brutal combat, uncovering mysteries with a breadcrumb trail of meticulously placed clues, and soiling your britches in a cave with one to seven of your buddies, then this game very well might be for you.

[b]The Good[/b]
[list]
  [*] The foundation upon which The Forest builds everything else good about the game is unquestionably it's atmosphere. For a low budget game originally released in 2014, the environments look really good - the surface areas are beautiful, isolated, mysterious, and wild, while the caves are dark, cavernous depths, menacing and enticing at the same time. Incredibly good ambient sound design adds to this - in the forest, wind blows and leaves rustle, while in the caves, water droplets echo through the empty spaces and unseen things scurry in the darkness beyond your vision. It is all delightlyfully immersive (until of course you spot a deer running into a tree).
  [*] Weirdly, despite AI for certain things like animals being dreadful, The Forest really nails the enemy AI. The cannibal enemies are very immersive - they stalk you, they surround you, they run when they lose the advantage and wait for you to turn your back, or come back later at night with reinforcements. I swear to God that I've even seen one pretend to be grieving a fallen companion, only to immediately come attack me when I got too close. Combined with the combat, which is simple but nicely impactful, your encounters with the enemy are really good and tense. The cannibals feel intelligent and threatening, especially early in the game. In a lot of survival games, the enemies are just an annoying hassle there to inconvenience you, and don't really create much interest aside from the objective danger they pose (i.e. you might lose some health and items) - even the venerable Minecraft has this problem. In The Forest, though, the encounters by themself are engaging and immersive.
  [*] Despite having a pretty minimal approach to storytelling, The Forest manages to present an intriguing mystery to unravel. Within the first couple hours of the game you find yourself with a lot of questions. Where is this island? Who are these tribes of cannibals? What is this weird gigantic quarry/sinkhole? As time goes on, more questions get added. Why [spoiler]are there a bunch of horrifying mutants on the island[/spoiler]? Why did the plane crash in the first place? How freaking deep does this cave system go? What the hell is this [spoiler]modern industrial facility at the bottom of the pit[/spoiler]? Now, this is where a lot of games fall short - they present intrigue, and get you to ask a bunch of questions, but never get around to answering them properly. The Forest actually manages to stick the landing - if you continue to play, you will slowly uncover the answers to more and more of these questions, eventually building to a very cool and climactic ending sequence that offers something different from the rest of the game. For an open world survival sandbox game, The Forest does story surprisingly well.
  [*] Survival mechanics are solid and not overbearing - survival systems like hunger, thirst, and energy are definitely present in the gameplay and are something you need to manage, but the systems are simplified enough that it doesn't become tedious or distract from the meat of the game which is the spelunking and exploration. They strike that nice balance of adding something without materially reducing the enjoyment of something else.
  [*] I think it is well understood now that 'good with friends' is not a very meaningful reason to recommend something since almost anything is fun if done with people you like spending time with, but I think in the case of The Forest it is justifiable, and I'll tell you why - the emotions and experiences you get while playing The Forest are in particular feelings that thrive off of a group dynamic. On the one hand, The Forest can be terrifying, and this feeling of anxiety can easily be fed and intensified by a group of people. If you are already jittery crawling around this cave in the dark, imagine how you are going to feel when your buddy ahead of you rounds a corner and starts screaming for everyone to run. On the other hand, The Forest can be busted in hilarious fashion, and it is less annoying when you have some people to laugh with. My friends and I spent several minutes after one of our log sleds began clipping through the earth and repeatedly falling from hundreds of meters in the sky back to earth trying to catch it, and fun was had by all - if that had happened to me in single player, I would have seen it as an irritating setback and likely tried to just ignore it. Friends make the good parts of this game better, and minimize the impact of the bad parts, so I highly recommend finding people to play with, even though the single player experience is solid on its own.
[/list]


[b]The Bad[/b]
[list]
  [*] This game, despite coming out of Early Access in April of 2018, is blatantly unfinished. It can still be very janky, things clip through geometry, wild animal AI is completely busted, easily reproducible bugs that have been in the game for years (like the pot duplication glitch) are still present, areas that seem like they should serve some purpose or have something in them are empty, and so forth. The company is working on a sequel now, though, so these things will likely never get fixed. As I said above, the game is fun, I recommend it, and it is in an acceptable state for the price point, particularly if you get it on sale, but I want to temper expectations - despite what it may say on the store page, this is still very much an 'early access' game and it will be forever. This is hopefully something the developers can improve upon in the sequel since they are presumably going into development with a lot of experience and resources than they had when they made this game.
[/list]

Just enough sickening possibilities, just difficult enough to keep you playing without wanting to rage quit. This game satisfies adventurers, builders, solo fighters, team players, and horror fanatics. I love/hate the ambient sounds of each area. I love/hate the reality check on precious resources. This was one of the few survival horror games I managed to finish. Playing alone tends to get slightly boring, but industrious minded folk who find joy in creating structures and have the patience to build it over hours of their playthrough might enjoy that alone.

The real fun started when I began playing multiplayer though. With more people, and playing on the hardest difficulty for the lulz, we suffered through many days and nights of terror when fighting enemies, exploration through environment and caves, as well as having fun with constructing base building, long af ziplines, and dense fortifications laden with traps against mutants and cannibals. 

The story element is a slow burn as you find pieces and pieces of clues that you put together to understand wtf is happening with the island and it was a blast to get most of the big picture and realise how messed up everything is. 

The cannibal AI is highly intruiging (sometimes janky yes, but it makes them unpredictable at times), and the design choice of making enemies climb trees, sneak, lunge, and generally act like a sneaking murder demon in the darkness led to plenty of screams from me personally. The paranoia hits when you hear noises in the distance and have frantically figure out how much of your resources you want to save and waste in confronting or running away.

Not all is peachy though. Some mechanics such as the sanity meter just seems unfinished, and other design choices (such as hidden structures) are so well hidden that the average player would never find it in their runs which is a shame. Even though most of the game is worth the exerience and polished in most aspects, it's clear to see where the gaps in their polishing were.

Overall, an amazing game and highly recommended a playthrough with friends.

Amazing game that's infinitely playable; I've come back to this game after finishing it time and time again - and it's even better multiplayer. Even after replaying it so many times, it's still just as scary as when you run through the first time.
The AI is deliberately confusing, which makes the game so frustrating but so enjoyable, and the snippets of story you pick up from photos and experiences are incredible. The 'campaign' as it were, is frankly both terrifying and addictive.
There are definitely some aspects of this game I would change, and things I think will be rectified in the new game Sons of the Forest, but as it is, it's a wonderful game and I cannot recommend it enough.

An incredibly janky and finicky survival game and a nightmare to try to build in, The Forest is unashamedly a single-minded vehicle for it's incredibly well executed AI and jump-at-every-noise atmosphere. Everything else rides in the back. While I'm frequently frustrated by bugs or UI decisions, that feeling is outweighed by the things this game does best. If the sequel's a more polished, well rounded survival experience I could easily see myself sinking a lot of time into it.

The Forest is a beautifully immersive survival game that expertly lures you into a false sense of security, executing the Lovecraftian horror elements with perfect timing and precision. Under the base survival mechanic lies a cryptic, thought provoking story line that consistently plays on mystery, and ends on morally macabre decisions.

The world has been presented in such a way, that you WANT to explore. You WANT to venture to the deep, dark morbidness because the game rewards you for doing so.

If you love horror - this game is for you!.
If you don't love horror - Play multiplayer - Much less scary when you're with friends.
Go for it. Don't think, just buy.

There is like two parts to this game, there is dealing with the tribes of cannibals and mutants.  Part of dealing with that involves building a base, protecting it, and even furnishing it.  The second part is exploring the caves and trying to solve the mystery of what happened to the little boy that was taken after your plane crashed.  I'm doing well on the base building and setting it up.  Having a little bit of trouble with the other part.
I guess I should mention that the cannibals are unpredictable, except when they have far superior numbers, 
then you will be attacked.  The Mutants can be avoided but will attack if you get close to them.  It's also good to have more then one base to fall back to.  It's an enjoyable game though.

Games map is very big with so many different caves and camps and what not to explore. And not to mention the amount of things you can tinker with and craft is limitless. Playing with friends is also a must because you guys can build a base together and it makes it a lot more fun fighting the monsters.

To put it simply. This game is amazing. I remember when it first released and how choppy it was but the gameplay was there and made it fun. The story is completed along with multiple endings which is worth playing both sides. The horror aspect of it is perfect, especially if you know anything about the AI which is something I could write a book on because this game has probably the best AI in any game I have ever played.

My friends and I always find ourselves coming back despite if its been weeks, months, or even a year. We always come back to play and when we do, its either we beat the game again or we just binge-play for hours among hours. I cannot wait for the sequel to release and to play that for many more hours to come.

The game is fun to mess around in, but a lot of  mechanics are clunky. Stamina runs out way too easily. For such a large map, with big caves, traversing is a chore when even descending a rope drains your stamina. The enemy AI is not great. They get stuck on rocks, run around in circles, walk into water and die way too often. This ruins immersion and downplays the horror aspect a lot. Building anything requires way too many logs where I couldn't care to build anything cool due to the time needed to farm logs. The in-game map lacks any detail, and the cave map is quite useless beyond a rough idea of where the caves are.

There is a story, but you have to piece it together based on items you find, walking sim style, which doesn't do justice to the story at all.

The game doesn't tell you what items you require for the endgame. The path to the endgame cave is super long, and takes forever to get out if you realize you are missing something or need to stock up on resources before the final boss. 

Once the novelty wears off, the game is just unpolished. It still does a lot of stuff right and is a fun time if you keep your expectations tempered.

very fun and scary game. i love the theme of the game and how you need to save Timmy. love how the cannibals get stronger and stronger after each day. the only thing i always get scared of is the bats in and outside the caves.

Setting up a dedicated server can be a headache but after several hours of troubleshooting I got mine working. There are some bugs in the game that are quite strange, such as the Old Pot duplication glitch that happens if you let the fire go out while you have a pot on it. Do not play this game expecting a flawless experience. That said, it's a nice take on survive 'em ups; I appreciate the environment, the little objectives, the nice surprises in the game world (no spoilers), the crafting system/interface, and so forth. I would recommend this game to fans of the genre who have the patience for less polished titles.

A ton of fun with a friend or 2, but very difficult especially solo. No hand holding which makes it a fun and wild challenge. Looking forward to the release of number 2!
got the game on sale and was waiting for it, starts out like you would think, but the more you play the better it gets and honestly i would recommend to anyone who likes horror survival craft games.

Pros:
-Gameplay is pretty damn fun from the start. It is challenging and enjoyable to learn things as you go along.
-Enemies are interesting and relentless
-Game has come a long way since launch. Gotta respect the work.
-Visuals are nice. All environments are interesting to explore.
-Obviously, one of those games that need people to play with
-Crafting is fun and nice to try out

Cons:
-Building in the game is sort of terrible. There are lots of limitations and odd rotations. 
-Feels like they added a lot to the game and tried to throw it all together. 
-Only one kind of map. No random generated maps. Kinda just kills the idea of replaying.
-Can be a bit buggy and higher difficulties are stupid. Can't really build anything when enemies come every 5 min or less. 
-Combat is sort of awkward. Hitboxes are a little odd as well.
-Unfortunately, I have to compare something like this to Valheim since it seems sort of similar in ideas. Valheim is much better in content and gameplay.

I love playing this game. The survival, concepts and story are very neat and have a realistic feel to them. The quality and sounds aspect of the game make the game even better as they give the feel of actually being on the island.

The only thing that could be improved is the VR support. There is no controls section for you to check the key bindings, which can make some things hard to figure out. For example: I had to google how to jump not knowing that you would have to push the right joystick up. Personally I don't really like that because its the same joystick as looking around which makes jumping in VR difficult without your character turning around.

The best survival game I've ever played.  9/10

Being a big fan of horror and a casual fan of survival games this game exceeded my expectations. There being a story had most of my interest but the aspect of survival into the discovery of the story kept me pushing forward towards a goal rather than just becoming over powered. Constant discovery of game play enhancing items and lore items with an end game truly make this game stand out from the rest. I consider this more of a story game with survival game play. 
 
That being said, one of the big perks of this game is it can be played as just a survival game alone or with 8 other people but in my opinion it would have been nice to have other hostile forces such as bears, cougars or snakes and a fishing pole mechanic would have been nice as well, basically deeper survival mechanics. If this were just a survival game without its story, it could still hold its ground due to the great crafting options, craftable item placements and dynamic AI but could also come across as limiting to those with minor nitpicks. still as stated before, the best survival game I've ever played.

10/10 would play again, amazing story, mixed with the survival aspect made this one hard to top, worth every penny i payed for this game.

This game saved my life.

I am 38.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.
After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.
Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

This game is very entertaining and caters very well to people who like complex survival games. This game pretty much has it all from melee and ranged combat, to cutting down trees and building survival shelters or a fortress on the mountain. There are many elements in the game that make it impossible to experience boredom in any play through and similarly to Minecraft there is an optional ending. This means you can continue to build your Island and survive, or you can speedrun to the end in an hour. Overall I believe this game is great considering it also offers coop gameplay which makes base building a lot easier and taking on caves a little more interesting.

Pros-
The Story- This is a huge element that Minecraft is really missing. There is little to no lore in Minecraft or Rust for that matter. The Ender Dragon only has the meaning the player applies to it. While this is fine it doesn‚Äôt keep the imagination and causes the game to become kind of stale because it doesn‚Äôt create a need to explore map areas for special items. The Forest does not fall into this trap. The story starts the gameplay and helps provide a reason to explore the whole area. 
The game begins with a plane crash which sets up a survival situation. The main character was traveling with his son who has wandered off with other survivors from the crash site before the protagonist awakes in the wreckage. This missing child is what drives the story in The Forest. Another big advantage to the story of The Forest is that it is not forced upon the player. Only the beginning is mandatory. After this the only things compelling you to follow the story is your own morbid curiosity and/or your empathy for your son and survivors as well as some snide achievements from the developer. However, you‚Äôre going to want to follow the story. It is exceptionally entertaining, and the atmosphere really helps sell a decent narrative experience. While exploring the vast wilderness you soon learn that you are not the first visitor to the Peninsula. As you gather the remnants of other inhabitants you slowly learn the story behind the fleshy abominations that stalk the wilderness. 

The gameplay- Beyond the story the gameplay is excellent. There are many games in this genre which try to go for ultra-realism in response to the fantasy worlds of Minecraft, Terarria or No Man‚Äôs Sky. The Forest hits right smack dab in the middle of these two takes on the genre. The graphics are not cartoonish. Most of the game is sensible. There are no magic tomes or spaceships to gather an endless amount of resources for. You do not have to travel to another dimension or planet to get some new, undiscovered resource. On the other end you are not trying to gather 12 different things just to make a container that will hold your water. There is little in the way of creating an economically functional homestead because cannibals do not care for trade. You are not building a campsite for your survival. 
Skill in base building is not necessarily an architectural trial where you are trying to get every little detail perfect. It is not an exercise in creating an automated production facility to trade large amounts of items with NPCs or other players. Your base‚Äôs quality is mostly measured in its ability to defend your homestead and the effectiveness of your organizational structure for storing your resources. The base building mechanics are fluid. You are given several basic premade structures and options for custom buildings. This allows for you to choose how you want to approach the story. Are you going to hold up in an intricately designed fortress and slowly gather a good number of resources to tackle the story in a few large excursions into the interior of the Peninsula or are you going to traverse the island and build a series of small bases at key locations on the map tackle the story area by area? Are you going to do a little bit of both? All of these are considerations to be addressed as you are beginning playing. 

The Enemy A.I.- The Forest has a stellar AI system. The enemies on the map evolve as you do. They have a collective personality, and this creates very compelling combat. Initially many of the cannibalistic inhabitants of the island are neutral towards you. Your actions with the functionally sane Cannibals dictates how they respond to you. If you are aggressive, they will become aggressive earlier in the game. If you are stealthy or diplomatic, they will leave you alone for a while. In addition, the natives frequently run patrol routes from their camps to specific geographical areas on the map.  If you are discovered in an area by the aboriginals, they will send out raids against you if they are hostile. There is also a hierarchy to the forces arrayed against you as well. Cowmen and Armseys act as tanks or assault vehicles for the cannibals. Virginias are a kind of personnel carrier for the freakish abominations. The Cannibals are a kind of foot soldier. They use tactics against you. They will try to surround you then rush you. They may engage in a kind of one-on-one honor combat to test you. 
I would like to note that there are strategy games that would wish to have an AI this advanced. The A.I. adapts and evolves and it can make the game immensely entertaining. You are not handicapped in any way. The cannibals in this game do not get more resources. They do not get attack of defense buffs or any special units like they do in strategy game. The AI gets no special privileges. It makes the combat a true test of wills where you feel a legitimate sense of accomplishment for successful raids, ambushes, or intelligently engineered defense perimeters. I would highly recommend the developers of Total War, AOE, Starcraft or even Paradox games to get into contact with The Forest‚Äôs developers and ask them how they created such a dynamic and challenging A.I.

Cons
Lack of resources- As stated above I think one of the best parts of this game is the pacing and the gameplay. It‚Äôs not a huge grind to build the perfect base. All this being said I think there were some missed opportunities. In most survival situations clay is a commonly used resource for shelter building and storage creation. I think this game really missed an opportunity to make clay storage containers and structures. Currently there is only one or two storage options for clean water in the game and clap pots would be a welcome addition. I would have also liked to have created clay house by a river junction. There is also a lack of options when it comes to building with pelts of hunted animals. Most of the animal pelts are only really used to create storage pouches. I think there was a miss opportunity to create a yurt in the plains area of the island with animal hides. 
Limited weapons and combat options for the player- While the AI is stellar and leads to many unique combat experiences the options for defending yourself are limited. There are few one-handed weapons. Most of the melee weapons are two handed. There is no shield even though you can collect turtle shells as an item. Currently the turtle shell only has two uses. A turtle shield could have easily and sensibly been implemented into the combat. I would have also liked a crafted blade option. A stone knife could have been added to the game and would have been a welcome addition to crafting and combat. There is also only one firearm in the game. A few firearms would not hurt the game play. I think a bolt action and a revolver would be a welcome addition and would not give the player too much power especially if ammo was rare on the map. 
The game includes too many impractical traps. Many of these traps are only useful in a handful of situations. There are a few useful ones such as the leaf trap. I think a rock or boulder trap would have been a better option than some of the other traps due to the dynamic and elevated terrain of The Peninsula. Lastly, I would have liked combat opportunities to clear certain areas on the map of natives. You can kind of do this by placing out totems and effigies but it‚Äôs not an exact science and they are not guarantees what you won‚Äôt be raided on your territory during a midnight resource run. An option to clear out a few select areas of natives would also add to the multiplayer experience because it focuses the more combat oriented players on a server on the common enemy and not onto other base building focused players. The players on a server could organize little 3-man war parties to go raid the natives and freaks and take control of territory and resources.

The feelings that you get when you find yourself barely alive after the airplane crash are priceless. Vulnerability and fear force you to explore, craft, and defend yourself against the unknown. Then, once you get to know the unknown, you feel yourself even more vulnerable and desperate, and yet eager to resist and survive. And this is why I want to recommend this game.

However, it has its flaws that will make your journey quite bumpy:
- I expected to have more plot hints that will make my exploration more determined and connected
- at times, the AI acted in an unpredictable and glitchy way which also ruined the moment

P.S. Looking forward to seeing Sons of the Forest.

The nameless and silent hero is what you are. The ruthless, cold and determined survivor. Watch to see if you can escape the Forest's clutches. The cannibalistic beasts that look into you from the darkness of each passing night. A land outstretching over jagged stone, complimenting the softness and gentle nature of deep lakes and rushing rivers. Over rock, dirt, branch and tree, the plethora of all the creeps and crawls and runs through the trees awaits you, the sole survivor of a devastating plane crash. 

Will you survive? 
The choice is yours, silent hero.

The Forest Is a great open world survival with fun features such as in depth caves with a story line and items inside to help you. What I find really cool is that you do not NEED to go into the caves or pay any interest to the story line and you can just explore, build or just kill. 

I will say there are still bugs in the game that I wish were fixed such as the item called "old pot" Whenever trying to heat up water 50% of the time it wouldn't work and it would just duplicate the pot. This isn't actually useful as you can only hold one pot and that it doesn't boil your water making me die of thirst. Another issue is some of the multiplayer. I played with a friend and found a few bugs such as all the old parts did not spawn for me but spawned for my friend. I could not hunt fish if my friend was not with me otherwise they would not spawn and that's it to be honest.

But that's just small bugs and does not really effect much of the gameplay. I still really enjoyed the game and really recommend it. I must say the story was really interesting and cannot wait for the second game.

I should not have put this off for as long as I did. But some part of me is glad to wait until about a week ago when I picked this game up. Now I cant wait until May 2022 to snag the 2nd game coming out. This was one hell of a ride.

Had to near the end cause we got stuck and instead of spending the next several hours looking through every single thing we just took a peak at the overworld map and one of the caves along with an odd bug with the end boss but otherwise this game was great to play. 8/10 (-2 just bugs and some issues finding key elements)

Go and get this game if you haven't already , you wont regret it.

One Piece takes place in an alternate world where pirates rule the seas and anything can happen. Gold Roger was the Pirate King who had fame, fortune, and power. But when he was captured he was sentenced to be executed. On the day he was executed he revealed his One Piece treasure is hidden somewhere at The Grand Line.

This made people set sail and try to hunt down the One Piece treasure. Many have failed and never found the location of it. But over the years it's drawn attention and formations on hundreds of Pirate groups who seek the title of Pirate King. The whole world has entered the Golden Era of Pirates.

On one island lived a boy named Luffy, who is friends with a pirate named Captain Shanks. He looks up to Shanks as a hero. And would do anything to be part of his crew. But he was too young to become a pirate or part of any crew. One day Luffy encountered the Devil Fruit. He ate it and obtain the power the fruit hold. It gave him the ability to stretch with a body made of rubber. But once you eat the Devil's Fruit, you're cursed with the powers forever. And can never be able to swim again. After almost drowning in the water, his friend Shanks saved his life. As Shanks departs with his crew, he gave Luffy his prized straw hat. He told him to keep it with him, until they meet again. While Luffy was left feeling sad but honored at the same time. And his new destiny in life, will be to start up his own pirate crew, go to the Grand Line, find the One Piece treasure, to become the new Pirate King.

A few years later, Luffy starts his quest to find him some friends for his pirate crew. Throughout the series, he'll find new lands, new allies, treasure, danger, and plenty of villains to face off. But with some faith and the powers of the Devil's Fruit. Luffy will sure to succeed his goal in becoming the Greatest Pirate that ever lived.

Comic made back in the late 90s, and the anime series has been around since the earlier days of SpongeBob. I first heard of it when it came on the FoxBox back in late 2004. I wasn't entirely into many anime back then. And I never saw the English Dub of the series, as I found it to be an OK series. After reading on the internet that the dub is heavily edited and nothing like the original. I grew interest on how good it is. I read the first volume of the Manga series. And liked how the story was going.

Wasn't until January 2007, when I finally start to check out the Anime. Only I viewed the episodes that are subtitled, uncut, and uncensored. And I grew to love it. The animation is very well done, it's funny, it's action packed, and it's dramatic sometimes. I don't even consider it a kid's cartoon, when it's more aimed to teenagers. But with an interesting cast of characters, and over a hundred secondary/miscellaneous characters. One Piece is indeed a great Anime next to Case Closed, Naurto, & other ongoing series.

The reason why it's very underrated was because of 4Kids being the first company to distribute the anime. Which they edited and censored a lot. And many flaws in the dubbing. Such as voices that don't suit the characters' personalities. Too many pirate accents and catch-phrases that get old instantly. All the violence, blood, alchol, drugs, and nudity were altered and removed. All the weapons were altered to look harmless. 4Kids spent more time edditting than spending time on the scripts. Plus a lot of filler and small episodes were removed. And most of them were too important to take out in the series.

The good thing is 4kids no longer owns rights to One Piece. I knew they would drop it, because they did a poor job in introducing the series to English speaking countries.

With over 300 episodes, I can tell that One Piece is really big in Japan. I've seen all the current episodes. And can't get enough of it.

So those who like their Anime uncut, should highly recommend seeing One Piece uncut by fan subs or Funimation's release on the series.

As a survival game, this one misses the mark, as a building game, this one leaves something to be desired, and as a horror game, its far too disjointed. This game could have been great, if the story line was done in a better manner, instead the only way to "beat the game" is by searching every corner of the cave system to find the items needed. It was long, boring and finally required looking up from other gamers what I was missing.  I spent lots of time with this game, but not because it was particularly fun or entertaining - it was due to a lack of information on gameplay, a terrible save-game system that potentially makes you re-do tons of work, and because I was determined to "beat it". The gameplay and combat system was pretty bad as well. You never really grow as a character and run around hulking on enemies, you just kind of learn some better tactics. Despite the huge effort and time with this game, the pay-off was far from worth it with the crappy and confusing ending.

I remember playing this game for the first time on my PS4 years ago, and the fun me and a friend had by just screaming and running thru the caves and this game. A lot of indie games that come out nowadays aren't usually that great, but this is just one of those games with an amazing plot, that they executed very well. The soundtrack is amazing, the enemies are very interesting and unique, the story is very riveting, there's a few side missions you can do, base building, just a lot to do in the game. There's nothing scarier than going into the caves with just the plane axe and a lighter, especially since the lighter decides to mess around and go out every single time you're about to do something important. Although there are exploits and glitches in the game to beat it or make it easier, playing the game legit for fun is awesome, and it really is a great co-op game to run with any of your friends, or even alone if you wish. There definitely is some replay value in this game, which is awesome as well. I remember getting the plat achievement on PS4 for this game, and I usually only do that for great games. If you're looking for a new game to play with some friends, this is definitely a good little horror survival you can all play.

Awesome game.

Got it on a discount but to keep it short, this game brings exactly what I've always wanted. A survival game, with a damn story. And a good one at that.

It's what I always wanted from Don't Starve. Took me about 80 hours to finish, but to be fair I spend more than half just surviving and building my base.

Graphics are really good and the FPS is both high and stable.

Solid game!

I suggest to play with friends as it's more fun to throw all your morals out of the window and chop down naked women in the forest together. 

The Story is interesting and the game does a great job holding that balance between having the right amount of story clues (with its collectibles) and leaving you to explore everything at your own paste. 

Considering how the game used to be in its early stages (not the first acc I play it on) it has come a far way and while it's not perfect (you sometimes still can see through certain walls, achievements are buggy in multiplayer, ...) it certainly has improved a ton. 
Especially the multiplayer function I have to address; something that used to be so damn bad I quit the game with my friend is actually a ton of fun now. The few cut-scenes the game has, while they can't be entered together, look well made in the perspective of the second person too. Sound would be cool for them too but at least you get to experience them about as good as the other player. 

The Forest is a game you deffo can play once every half a year/year (just story, building never gets boring if you are into that stuff) and still have fun going through collecting everything over and over again. 
Hyped for the next game, will definitely buy

This game is schizophrenic. It tries to be a horror game, a CO-OP survival game and an open world builder game and fails on all accounts due to poor implementation. The crafting system is unnecessarily complex and the inventory system makes no sense. Serveral basic functions(such as cooking, swapping equipped weapon/item or simply saving a multiplayer game) are extremely unintuitive and will sometimes screw you over. I'm a big fan of survival/builder games like Subnautica, Raft, Valheim etc but this one just doesn't cut it. It's shoddy workmanship all over that leaves you frustrated. I played this with a friend for about twelve hours and then we just stopped because there is too much wrong with the game to keep it enjoyable.

While I can't say that the game is amazing, I think it is a fine game. I played the game with my friend on hard survival. We ended up dying a few times, before we picked the safest spot in the game, and got to work on setting up defenses. The parts we hated the most about this game was caving. It was very tedious and boring to do. The horror element of the game is kinda taken out when you are with a friend, so it was just me and my friend wandering aimlessly. About 15 hours into game play I discovered we had a cave map. That would've been useful for a long fucking time. We ended up packing supplies, getting to the bottom of the sinkhole, and I killed the final boss. I say "I" because my friend ended up getting glitched into the ground after trying to kill the final boss with a chainsaw. We ended up building a drip car, and sledding down into the sinkhole. This game really told us nothing, and I had to watch a few hours of farket to understand what the hell we were supposed to do. I love the cannibals in this game. Their behavior that doesn't make any sense really puts you on nerve. Finding a creeepy mutant or two out in the wild is always a scary sight. Lastly, the mouse sensitivity slider doesn't work properly. At its lowest setting, which is 0, i would expect my mouse to do nothing. But it still moves my camera and it's still too high of a sensitivity (for me).

My whole life I've been waiting for this game. Right out of the womb I told my mother this would come out in approximately 15 years. When it released I was so joyous I threw a party  at my parents little duplex and all my nerdy friends showed up to have a LAN and play it for the first time. We played for 8 hours and took a fun little bathroom break and continued our journey for happiness in the gaming world. At first the game wasn't bad, but slowly the shivers came in. After around the eight hours I was shivering timbers and my friends had to 911. But it was too late. I passed away from a major brain stroke. I think it was the lack of gameplay and it reminds me to much of minecraft. Especially the pesky zombies and the building mechanics. This is not me but this my mother speaking on behalf of me. Currently I am paralyzed from the neck down and will be a forever vegetable in this realm of shitty ass. I would nopt recommend this game for anyone lest you will meet the same fate as I did. This is classic  YouTube Hype. The game is buggy and should not be considered as a finished product. 
1> combat is virtually impossible when dealing with 8 or more enemies at the same time.
2> Defensive builds are weak to the point that it is pointless to build and use them.
3> Food gets destroyed way to easily. 
4> Mobs are OP to the point that the i just build save points because i die ALL the time. 
5> When the game glitch player loses everything. 

In conclusion: This game hates the player to the point that the game isn't fun. The player can't enjoy the build aspect, can't enjoy the survival aspect and it becomes endless frustration with the combat glitches that enable mobs to insta-kill because the player becomes frozen. Mobs also destroy food so recovery becomes impossible and again more frustration.  Maybe my PC can't handle the game as well as it should but i cannot recommend this game to anyone because the game is simply not finished.

[h1]TLDR[/h1]
 So far, it's very promising. 

[h1]Cons [/h1]

[list]
    [*] There's a glitch where you will occasionally do a charged / heavy attack even though you are no longer giving input on keyboard or mouse. 
    [*] Steep Learning Curve (although, not as steep as some other games)
    [*] Multiplayer bugs are few, but when they happen, being attacked by invisible enemies sucks. 
    [*] There are occasional sound glitches where there are no cannibals, but you can hear a cannibal, which make you panic a bit, thinking you're about to get attacked. 
[/list]

[h1] Pros [/h1]
[list]
    [*] Excellent Survival Sim
    [*] Challenging Enemies / Fights
    [*] Beautiful Visuals
    [*] Extensive Crafting System w/ Unique Interface
[/list]

SPOILERS!!!
[spoiler] So first up, there's a fair amount of cringe culture in this game. The cringe starts as soon as you run into any females. This game has boobies, and probably other jiggly bits, but I haven't gotten far enough or glimpsed them. 

What I have seen are mutant cannibal babies that blob along the ground and make the most disgusting and nightmarish sounds.

The worst parts of the game (so far) are the best parts of the game. Be prepared for disappointment with your first bow. Killshots are not a thing with early arrows. Maybe upgrades will yield better results. 

Loot, survive, stay alive. 

Will update upon game completion.
  [/spoiler]

I took a chance on this game, as you don't always know with early access games (at that time) whether or not they will end up finished or even what they promised to be. Thankfully, 260+ odd hours later, it turns out I found a hidden gem in this game.

The story is decent, although if you are like me, you might forget about your son for a loooong time (like in fallout) as you focus on surviving and building up a decent base or bases.

The game has decent survival elements, and the enemies are just as interesting. The more days you survive, the harder it becomes (which is a nice change, as usually, once established in a survival game, it can become too easy) as different enemies begin to appear and the AI seems to, at times, try and work out ways into your camp/base/settlement.

I don't want to give too much a way, so IMO. this game is worth a shot - plus, the incoming second game looks even better, so this franchise is really looking like something to get behind. Enjoy!

If you like multiplayer open world survival crafters with spooky atmosphere (think 7 Days, H1Z1/Just Survive, etc.), you'll really enjoy this.

The gathering and building systems are okay, and in line with basic expectations for the genre. Cut trees, gather sticks and other assorted bits, build things. The building is flexible enough that you can make some cool creations (check the community screenshots), but it's never going to rival something like Conan Exiles. There also isn't much in the way of decoration available, though this fits well with the theme of the game.

The inventory and crafting systems are unique, immersive, and intuitive. Everything you carry around is represented by the item itself on a big tarp -- an actual big pile of stuff rather than the typical icon/number in a bag slot that most inventory systems default to. You combine those items in the middle of the tarp to make new items, and while it isn't the deepest, most tiered crafting system I've ever seen, it also doesn't feel skimpy. Everything has purpose.

The combat is excellent, and the enemy animations are spot-on. The hitboxes and enemy strike range feel perfectly tuned. The encounters with these things are sometimes genuinely horrifying (especially that first playthrough -- all those sounds in all those caves WILL make you feel things). I don't really want to say anything about the individual enemy types, because some things are better left for players to discover on their own. It'll be quite a discovery, though, I assure you.

Speaking of caves, there are a lot of them to explore, with a ton of items/equipment to find (lots of stuff in the overworld, too). The world is static, so once you get the island memorized you'll know just where to go for everything in subsequent playthroughs, but getting to that point takes quite a bit of time (provided that you don't use an online map to assist, but even then sometimes it's difficult to orient when underground).

The cherry on top of an already fun game is the surprisingly engaging story. It's told in a way that starts off by piecing together subtle, disturbing clues but eventually snowballs into something much more goal-oriented and linear and clear. You don't have to mess with the story at all if you don't want to -- the game functions just fine as a pure survival builder. But I'd highly recommend it.

While the cannibals are a bit tricky to deal with, this game is very fun, and although it can get a little repetitive, there is so much to do, including follow the story line or just build an empire of a base.

While not a perfect game, it was still an excellent experience to play through. 

At times it feels like it's two games at odds with each other (the more standard Survival stuff in the Forest, and the creepier cave-diving), and it'd probably be an even better game had the devs focused on one of the halves, but it's still great overall. 

Highly recommend it! If you're into creepy, scary stuff, solo play is for you, if you just want the story and experience, co-op is a fun, albeit occasionally buggy experience.

I had an absolute blast playing this game with a friend. At first glance, I thought it was going to be a mindless survival game but I was totally wrong. The cave systems were massive and extremely well designed, the story was well-written, and the crafting was so fun that we spent 5 hours building a lift to access a hilltop for our base... also, don't even get me started on the cannibal AI. They're so damn smart that they will literally watch you from afar, not engage you, and observe your every move so they can plan their attack accordingly. I was blown away by the level of detail the developers put into this game. I bought the game on sale but would have 10000% paid full price. I cannot wait to play Sons of the Forest in May :)

Realmente no se que decir. Estoy enojado por varios aspectos del juego. Lo termine tanto en ps4 como en Pc 2 veces y mate a todos los bosses, Whorm y Megan 3 en total. La idea del juego es excelente, de hecho el gameplay en si es excelente y la historia esta ahi para acompa√±arlo a este, haciendo a "The Forest" una experiencia survival horror muy vivida y de las mas turbias que uno podria jugar. Imagino que se preguntaran que es lo que me enoja respecto al juego, si todo lo que mencione fueron alagos. La cuestion es que todo lo que me enoja del juego son en aspectos tecnicos. El juego esta LLENOOO, y digo REPLETO de bugs. Algunos son graciosos, otros son perdonables y otros incluso arruinan el rol y la experiencia, rompiendo el juego completamente. Y no solo los bugs, sino que tambien la mala optimizacion del juego. The Forest parece que fue optimizado por 4 monos y medio. Tengo una rtx 2060, jugue el juego en medium/low y me iba de 60 a 35 fps, lo que me parece completamente injugable. Por momentos parecia que estaba jugando en ps4 pero con teclado. Horrible. El juego es bueno, muy bueno y lo recomiendo, solo advierto respecto a los bugs que van a encontrar jugando y recomiendo que jueguen en low a 720p o menos por que ya te digo que ni una Rtx 3090 va a poder correr bien el juego. 


Edit: Estuve investigando un poco mas y lo que mas baja fps es hostear un server de multiplayer (q evidentemente es la forma mas divertida de experimentar el juego, jugando con amigos). Si jugas singleplayer o multiplayer sin hostear, el juego deberia ir bien depende que gpu tengas. Ahora respecto a los bugs, xD ta bastante bugeado el juego, no hay mucho que decir.

I thought this game looked like a good survival game similar to other survival games I'd played, but even though it starts out promising, eventually I found the survival element to be extremely basic and superficial.  The game has plenty of different animals for you to hunt and plants to collect but they are all so abundant (and loot too) that there's never any threat of starving or dying of thirst. There are plenty of things to craft and that creates an incentive to look for particular animals and plants, but once you've crafted them all there's no real pressure to gather food or hunt. I thought things would get more difficult as I went along but in reality the only thing that threatens your survival is attacks from the mutants. 

The other major problem I have with the game is that base building is essentially unnecessary. It's purely cosmetic, as the mutants basically never attack it unless you build somewhere close to their villages or patrol routes. Basically all you need to do is build the most basic hut in the game and it will serve the same purpose as a huge base with palisades and guard towers all around. Also, building even a medium sized base requires A LOT of grind, from collecting timber or stones you need and bringing them back.

Another thing I didn't like with the game is that exploring the caves, which is necessary to "progress" whatever semblance of a story there is in the game, is mostly just tedious and pretty much impossible to do properly - unless you know how (you need to plant lots of skull lamps around each cave to let you see what you're doing).

My last major gripe with the game is the "snow area" (I don't know what else to call it), which is a large area in the map that's covered with snow leading to up to a mountain. Firstly, this area starts about 50 meters above sea level, despite the fact the rest of the island seems to have a tropical or sub-tropical climate. Then in order to explore this area you need to craft a "warmsuit", which requires more components than any other craft item, but after exploring it pretty thoroughly it seems there's basically nothing in it, just a few abandoned tents and nothing particularly interesting. So it's essentially just a waste of time bothering with it.

To be fair to the game I thought it did do some things quite well. The graphics are pretty nice and I think the horror elements of the game are pretty unnerving, like the weird appearance and behaviour of the mutants and the strange style of buildings they use. There is also plenty of building options for base building too, if you have the patience.

To me the Forest would be better described as an "open world horror" game rather than a "survival" game, as the survival element is largely superficial, while exploring dark caves and battling strange creatures is actually what the game is mainly about.

18 hours, no searching things up until we absolutely had to in order to paw our way through the tiring and difficult journey of this game, and I say this in a positive manner. I mean that this game does everything it can to throw you into the shits when you think you're safe and everything is fine. Unexpected things will happen. 

This game is actually very well made, solid frame rate at all times during game play albeit loading screens. The story is actually fairly easy to follow if you pay attention to the files you've found and pictures and what not. We had not known there was multiple endings to the game and we happened to get a darker one. I won't spoil anything for those yet to play it, but I will say that the implications this game leaves you with on that ending are wild. I have not played a game that isn't afraid to go all in on their story like this in a good while, they don't pull their punches with this one. 

All in all, I would give this game around a 85/100 because I had found much joy in this game, from learning to do the crafting without realizing you can hover over the gear to see what you need to make specific items, finding out which weapons worked best for me and having my loved one with me through all of this. I recommend playing this game with one other person at least, it is much more fun when you're not alone, however if you're into it for a true horror survivalcraft experience. This is a VERY good game for it!

[UPDATED REVIEW] I have put in around 23 hours now into the game and have progressed through the story quite a bit, but sadly throughout that process, I have decided that I can no longer recommend this game. The game just feels way too incomplete and it only gets worse the longer I play it. I've ran into countless bugs and have reached a point where I am no longer enjoying the game like I once was, trying to complete this game has become a burden. Overall this game is very fun but there are so many things holding it back from being a good game. 


[FINAL UPDATE] I just finished the game and honestly, I'm speechless with how great the ending was and how refreshing it felt to see the entire story link up and build up to the ending. I have decided to change my review to recommend the game again just based off the story itself. Although the gameplay and buggy mechanics frustrated us often, the story made up for it, glad to say that I can recommend this game once again.

The game should not be called THE FOREST, it should be called THE CAVES. 

CONTENT:
- There is no content on the surface at all, that you are encouraged to do.
- To complete the game you need to go into THE CAVES and hope to find the cave that has the items you need.

SURVIVAL:
- There is no survival aspect, I could survive the game only on chocolate bars and sodas found in caves.

BUILDING:
- Building in this game is pointless, there is no point in having a base as caved are split across the map and monster attacks are large and its just a waste of time to fight them.

COMBAT:
- There is no variety of monsters in this game, like 4 types of monsters with variants of each other.
- Combat system/attacks are overall clunky and slow

This game saved my life.

I am 41.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.
After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

TLDR: The game is a worthwhile play, it is enjoyable.
However the game can be quite slow and boring at times.
Progression through the story is optional but pretty much required.
The game is worthwhile with a discount.

I personally think this game is quite a bit of fun. It's very engaging and the concept of this gamestyle is really interesting.

The game is centred around the survival aspect of 'The Forest'. Similar to other games such as Rust, Raft, Dayz, Minecraft. Your aim is to survive for as long as possible, on both natural resources and resources gathered from surrounding establishments. 

Where this game differs from the afore mentioned games, is that there is a strong emphasis on the plot and story of the game, in which you must locate your son Timmy, who was taken by a cannibal not long after the plane crashed.

Although the story is technically optional, it is pretty much necessary to have any fun and to progress in equipment. As the majority of supplies such as food and water, as well as upgraded tools are acquired by engaging in the story.

The story in particular is quite interesting, there is definitely a lot that could be delved into regarding lore, and the story unfolds itself very nicely.

My only criticism with the game would be that it can be quite difficult initially, due to the lack of instructions. However this is also a good thing as the game teaches you the mechanics through failure.

One thing to note however; the game is able to be completed within 1 hour. It is usually done much longer within the 15 - 30hr mark from other reviews and mentions. 
I personally found the game far to slow paced for my likings. It is far too difficult to locate the items and is very redundant. So through the use of a walkthrough or two  - to guide me in the right direction (after doing the same thing for an hour). I was able to comfortably complete the game in 11hrs feeling very satisfied with the story.
