Play through The Forest in 2020-2021, and I had an absolutely immersive blast. This is an easily digestible entry into survival for someone like me who's inexperienced with the genre. It is captivating, horrifying, and builds a perfect road of rising tension and mystery as you discover terrible clues of the peninsula. Highly recommend for a heart-pumping single player terror-ride.

The ecosystem on this fictional planet makes no sense. The 'cannibals' (who weren't actually that canaballising anything, and should've died long ago had the digestive system even remotely occurred in the developers minds, as no humans graced the face of the small barren 'island') are poor excuses for enemies, and even the baddest bitches in the whole of the planet were big ass babies who got their ass smashed in by my small ass coin bomb. At the end, the endings were, well, disappointing to say the least, but i'll leave that to you losers who would love to discover this full game. The ecosystem would've been thrown into full disarray had any simple research been completed before hand, however it was clear there was no pre-development phase. The 'cannibals' (whom i have mentioned were completely upsetting and pitiful) should've ate everything and anything shown by their nature and juicy phat bazooga bums, and send the environment into havoc. But nope, the trees still grew like hormonal petty bitches and the rabbits kept on running their dumb asses into my little dumb fuckin traps which made me visibly upset. I hauled my stupid ass around for almost an hour to build a scrubby little hut which could not fit me and my 7 other friends who all seemed to love this game also. The alternate ending the game had in store for us was also disappointing. Our child had a huge spasm which was completely normalised and everyone was gasping as if theresa may death-dropped on stage. Can't find a pro for this game. Enjoy <3

Quite well made.  I used to dream of making a game very similar to this myself.  Visuals are very good.  Crafting is rewarding.   Being a very experienced camper, survivalist and having lived for a short time by bushcraft myself, I appreciate it.  If the developers are still adding to this game, I'll add a wishlist...

Proper fire building technique: stone ring, then leaves, then sticks then, later a large log to burn in half.  This is how fires are done and it would be cool to see it represented in a bit more detail.  The fire is the heart of a camp.
Garbage on the seashores.  It really is everywhere.  Just a few odd pieces and a useful item now and again.
Add plastic bottles.  They can hold one water.  Cannot be used to boil.  
Make it cost slightly more endurance to cut trees down.  You should have to rest for a moment after each tree.
I like how the tree cut animation chips wedges out of the tree!  Nice touch.  It made me wonder if you could work out a way that causes the tree to fall realistically to the way it is being cut.  I have felled a few trees and its not that hard in a basic way.  Front wedge, back cut, etc.
One last thing... I get that there is a list of plants found, but if there are notes on what they do I dont see it.

Thanks for the game experience.  You rock and I hope you make a good buck!

The Forest is an excellent game with a compelling story line and the gameplay to back the story up. The visuals are stunning, with the lighting being very well done. The attention to detail in this game is meticulous, such as the precise sound design, the animations, and some other completely random things that just enhance the experience such as the chance for a bird to fly onto your hand if you're standing outside. Most of the things and items found on the peninsula have some connection to the lore. The AI of the mutants in this game is where this game really shines, this isn't some AI pathfinding thing where it just constantly looks for you to kill you. You can remain friendly with the mutants, you can be hostile, the mutants respond to your actions accordingly. There are patrol lines of the mutants, there are multiple tribes and they clash. Now, the cave system is really the bread and butter of The Forest, and this is where it really gets interesting. By delving deep into the complex cave systems of The Forest, you will encounter new enemies, find new and better weapons and find items crucial to the lore. Without spoiling anything, I can say that this game exactly follows a linear circular narrative with the ending, the ending isn't cliche, and will probably surprise you (unless you've paid very good attention to the lore throughout the game). I personally find The Forest much more enjoyable with friends, however, the single-player experience is also excellent.

All-in-all, if you're a fan of survival/horror games, there is no game I would recommend more than The Forest.

I am a 69 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 16 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 30 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Like creepy cannibal beings in caves with multiple arms and legs that throw babies at you? Well, this game is for you then! The first time I ever saw this game I knew I'd like it, this is my favorite genre after all, Open world survival crafting. I know it seems like this game just keeps going, but there is an end, a very strange one at that, and it's pretty much in line with the rest of this creepy storied game. VR makes the creepy factor of having babies thrown at you in a cave even more creepy and generally adds new life to the game even if you've beaten it in non VR.

This game saved my life.

I am 41.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.
After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

Pro-tip from a local, you can light a tennis ball and be a human torch. 
- This game is so in the grey...not because of the tennis ball trick. The initial five hours were so bland, everything seemed as generic as it can get and the game wasn‚Äôt expecting anything from me, it was as if the game was pretty much expecting me to know it all. Survival, the first two days it was berries and mushrooms with an occasional warning from the locals to stop plundering their stuff seemed normal. But it soon got tedious when I tried to progress, the first rabbit trap was 31 sticks - the game for some reason mostly spawns a few dozen sticks in a particular area rather than spanning to a larger space so there were times either you stumble upon dozens of them or there is nothing. Same for a Cabin, had to chop down 20 trees. By the time I was done with the two, it felt like a part of the forest is gone. Survival Guide checklist was useless, it asked me to build a shelter and now it wants me to defend it‚Ä¶but from what?
- Bugs, just like with the sticks birds do the same and they are so abundant you can see 4-5 of them occupying a single spot with some choppy AI, same with animals. 5 hours in-game walking around and I was still unsure of the objective, my guy won‚Äôt say or write down anything about the geology. The local population kill count according to steam achievement has gone up to 25 though I haven‚Äôt killed a soul yet. One of the worst about the game was the hostile animal spawn, they just spawn right under your butt or somewhere behind with the occasional despawn. This caused my first knockout, an alligator spawned right behind and attacked, there was a fight and it retreads then re-spawned behind me again. I know it‚Äôs the same alligator because of the blood splashes and it happened twice with the same alligator. 
- The locals were kind enough to rescue my butt from the beast and secure it in a cave‚Ä¶now the game decides to give me a map and a compass‚Ä¶why now? And the map is empty so the previous 5 hours were for nothing. In fact, this game should call itself - "The Abysmally Dark Caves", because everything the game has to offer for the plot is in the caves. I say abysmally dark because you can‚Äôt see sh!t, most of the time I was spooked by my own hands. Of course, the game has options to craft any and everything from the start including torches and I was stupid to think there will be craft progression/blueprints to collect so ended up face to face with a baby-maker humping my guy to death. Start again, this run doesn‚Äôt count.

The second run was way better since I understand the game elements a bit more, inventory management/crafting system was excellent. Cave exploration is now better with spears and arrows, and more bugs. Molotov just passes through the floor and at random fire arrow will not have a prompt to light it. Lighter has more range than torches or any light source,  and enemies can spot your lighter from half a mile away‚Ä¶once alerted they start running back and forth in a circle between their initial spawn spot and a little bit short from where you stand indefinitely. Enemies are so easy to exploit and kill, but they do offer quite a bit of challenge when combat works. Day and Night cycles don‚Äôt matter anymore, sleeping is bad since it immediately makes us thirsty and hungry. So the game is mostly about going above to get resupplied and making progress in the caves, there is no way to switch between the two maps so you‚Äôll have to just remember the geology. There is no UI to keep you up on anything, I totally missed so many items and lost at times because of the chase, for almost 10 hours there was nothing but backtracking since the game does a terrible job at aiding you to progress - as I said before, it expects you to know things and it doesn‚Äôt want to end by helping you find anything, everything has to be memorised. 

Is it a bad game? No, so is it good? Almost. My take on it is if you have a lot of time to spare with friends it is a great game. It did a terrible job at keeping me engaged, everything is there but you‚Äôll have to find the meat of it yourself which takes a lot of time. The story content of the game is around 30 minutes, but it took me 20+ hours to find it without help. As an overview, the land above is for base building and fun, while the caves underneath are for the story. For the price these can even be two separate games, so the game deserves the asking price. Personally, it falls down where certain aspects of the game feel underdeveloped. Eating and drinking could have done more than just filling up a meter, sleeping is not worth it, sanity‚Ä¶got no clue. Stats improvements seem to require cutting down trees‚Ä¶hundreds of them, not sure if it does anything. There is no NPC to interact with, no dialogues, no notes, the only sense of progression is when finding unique gears. The game doesn‚Äôt even let you know when it ends so you can roam around the desolate place for all your life. It was fun but most of the time I just wanted it to end.

Edit: Changing to Positive. While the game does lack at explaining itself, it was mostly fun after understanding the core mechanics and of course less tedious since I know what was going on.

The Forest is a good game. To put it shortly, I think that this game is worth the money, especially with a group of friends to play with to mask the flaws of the game.

THE ISSUES:

The biggest problem for me in the forest was the lack of surprise factor when playing the game. Over the first few hours of gameplay, everything seemed new and completely unexpected. See that huge-ass monster? What is that thing? Over time though, that feeling seemed to fade away and nothing was left to replace what was previously so surprising and evoked the feeling of, "What the hell is that?" The cannibals were never really scary or anything, they just kinda watch you and if you smack them in the face they run away and don't fight. The cannibal villages were also very lazily made in my opinion, no beds, just a tent and dirt, sometimes there wouldn't even be anything in them. Only really the main cannibal village was interesting in my opinion, but it still needed a lot of work. The animal enemies were really bad, like the crocodile, who was nothing more than just a blind and deaf old lady who walks into your house sometimes. Aside from that. the game overall seemed to have a large emphasis on the building aspects of the game, but I didn't really care too much about building something cool or interesting, me and my friends just built what we wanted to and left it at that. The amount of content available post-game is also something that needs a bit of work. Like yeah, you can spend hours of your time scrounging for the hidden pistol, wait a bunch of time to fight the worm fella (24 real-life hours, btw), build a huge house, but the problem with all of those is that they are tasks that are meant to take a while inherently, like a goal that is being worked towards just by playing the game. The problem comes when you beat the game with your friends on like day 20, have already done all of the caves, beaten the main story, and there just seems like nothing else to do. There is no reason for to try to make a better house than I already have, because there is nothing that even threatens my house. There is nothing left to explore, nothing left to collect, nothing left to see, and therefore achieve. Those are the biggest problems in my opinion.

THE GOODS:

The Forest is not a bad game, even though I might seem critical of it. I really like the atmosphere, outside, in the caves, everywhere pretty much. The combat felt pretty nice too, even though the bow felt kinda odd and I never bothered to get the gun because ammo is so limited for it (also annoying to get). The final area was really nice too, the contrast between it and the rest of the game was cool. The enemies were also really cool, too, I really enjoyed discovering a bunch of wacky creatures that really made me back up and go, "The hell was that?" I think that this game is best played with friends, because a lot of things in this game would be a lot less interesting if there wasn't someone else with you. Searching for caves, which is pretty much the goal of the game, is also a pain in ass if you don't have a few grunts (friends) helping you along the way. The Forest is a very on-your-toes kinda game, you don't know when something might jump you out in the woods, or what that thing might be. I think that really summarized my experience.

Updated review from recommended to not recommended. Glitchy af.

I loved the game at first. I'm new to the crafting/survival genre but sadly the game is riddled with glitches making it unplayable.

I spent a lot of time crafting and building out the map, which was fun, found some glitches but nothing that impacted too much.

That all changed today. Basically after spending days of my real life building out the map, my structures are just falling apart for no reason. I will load a save and half a structure will be gone.

Because this is the main appeal of the game... it's extremely frustrating and makes it feel pointless. It's unintentionally become the Dark Souls glitch that makes the game way more difficult.

I have only had one other game that I loved and stopped playing--Dead Island--and I stopped because randomly my save reverted back to a week or two previous, and I didn't feel motivated to redo everything on the chance it might not glitch out again.

There are full lists of glitches out there for this game, and you kind of put up with most of them if they don't impact the game. For example:
1)Arrows, spears and other weapons disappearing when you try to pick them up
2)Fire not being able to be lit when you have just built it
3)Building things in places where they don't work (e.g. a climbing rope goes lower than the ground, therefore you can't climb up it)
4)Corpses and trees disappearing early

Most of these you can kinda push through or workaround. The bigger ones were
1)Can't raise your weapon to block in some circumstances
2)You can jump or fall into parts of the image that you can't get out of, meaning you have to reload from a save. I guess they call this clipping.
2)By design, you may switch weapons when you don't want to--for example, while holding your weapon to block
3)By design you die quickly from fire--however enemies don't die after being burned multiple times
4)By design, your armor doesn't last at all very long in normal mode
5)By design, if you start building something and cancel it, you lose all materials that went into it.

All in all, I would have given the game and 8/10, but now I'm thinking 5/10 would be pretty generous. I got it on sale too I think, but at this point I feel like I've wasted my life on a game that doesn't play by its own rules.

Hope the devs can make a stable build of this sometime.

if you have free time in your hands and you're looking for a decent survival craft game then the forest is a game that you should really dive into. 
I had so much fun playing it in both solo and with friends, so after having enough hours on it, I finally decided to give it a review
[b]Gameplay:[/b]
as you may expect, you will be collecting food, drinks and going for alternative ways like hunting and saving water to maintain your energy while exploring around and spending a fair amount of time cutting down trees, also finding and crafting equipment that could make your life kinda easier and also weapons to protect you against cannibals attacks¬† 
[b]Enemies and difficulty:[/b]
the more days you survive the harder it goes and the more creatures and cannibals appears to attack you or try to destroy your base and at times you will be forced to defend it or move on and explore the map  
speaking of it, I really love how smart and unpredictable the behaviour of cannibals here, it really feels realistic so kudos to the devs :) 
[b]Graphics and atmosphere:[/b]
for a crafting game it looks very good I must say, and I really loved the environment, when I finished building a cabin and sit in front of the fire at night it felt like I was really there haha
(you may still want to adjust the graphics and filters to your preference)
[b]Story and replyability:[/b]
the story was added later and it can be or can't be long depending on how you play the game, I found it decently good but once I finished I felt like I lost a purpose of playing the game, so my advice is to not focus much on it
as for replyability I wouldn't mind replaying it with friends, some people will stick around especially if they are having fun with building and getting creative so it varies from a person to another. ‚Äã
[b]conclusion:[/b]
when I first got it I didn't expect much but I was really impressed uh well except for the cheaters who joined and tried to ruin everything when I set the lobby to public, but anyway if you feel like you're in the mood to give it a go then do not hesitate on picking it up!

The Forest is an enjoyable co-op experience, but isn't polished at all.
We've encountered many bugs and problems during our playthrough.

[h1]1. Story[/h1]
The Forest won't offer a narrated story. You need to find tiny bits of information hidden within the world. As much as I like game like these, it's a needle in a haystack. Even if you find every tiny piece of story, it‚Äôs confusing. Nothing is really explained. You can vaguely guess, but ultimately everything is a mystery, which I find rather disappointing.

[h1]2. Gameplay[/h1]
[h2]2.1 Fights[/h2]
Fighting enemies is more or less fun at first, but get very tedious in the long run.
While shooting arrows with bows work fine, melee weapons feel weird in the beginning. It took time to compensate woolly attack patterns. Once you learned how to kill enemies it‚Äôs rather hard to die.
[h2]2.2 Building[/h2]
The tree chopping mechanic is enjoyable. Gathering resources is easy and slightly tedious, but no big deal. Building anything works good most of the time, but I dislike the "building menu" as much as I dislike the inventory. It's hard to find anything within it.
Any bigger structure needs logs from trees. The bigger the structure, the more you need. But enemies will just destroy anything they see, so you will likely lose parts of your base. Buildings have almost no purpose, which makes it really sad to see your decoration and enormous amount of time you put into it just go -poof-.
[h2]2.3 Exploring[/h2]
As good as the game looks, whether it is overground or underground, the island you‚Äôre on will only offer a few things to see. Especially, caves look almost all the same.

[h1]3. Conclusion[/h1]
The forest is a massive time sink with too many small and medium-sized problems.
In all objectivity, the game does not deserve a positiv nor negative review.
But my disappointment weighs it down to a negativ review.

I highly recommend this game if you want to try out a survival game, or if already love the genre. This is the best I've played so far. The value of getting this in 2021 is sketchy since the sequel is set to arrive in June 2022.

The great:
- Multiple and appropriate difficulty levels (including sandbox)
- Animations are outstanding
- Full player agency
- Some areas and sounds literally give me goosebumps
- Building and crafting is fully immersive and well designed

The good:
- Good realism
- Engaging multiplayer
- Decently large map
- Low price in 2021

The bad:
- The sequel "Sons of the Forest" comes out in mid 2022, making this game less of a value as time goes on.
- Combat is janky and not that fun
- Game minimizes when tabbing to another window

Great survival/horror game. Good mechanics, multiplayer functionality, and story. Crafting mechanics in this game are different, and good in my opinion, as you can place items to be crafted and then start to build them without any materials on hand. This allows a player to piece-mill building as one might do in a true survival situation. I received this game as a gift from friend to play with. I have not been compensated for my review.

One of the best survival games out there.

Has a few bugs and some items are plain bad or useless (for example the upgraded rock, which lights YOURSELF on fire whenever you hit something[!?], or the bomp, which has an exploding radius of an Inch), and most of the caves you need to do to get special items, like the Chainsaw or Katana are a bit too easy while some, like the cave of the modern recurve bow is a fairly big cave with acceptable difficulty. 
Exept for that the game is a really fun one to play with friends -I dont like playing it by myself, because I get scared by mutants easily- and it has some interesting features. The graphics are extremely good even on bad PCs, but the game has some trouble with handeling 2 Monitors, at least for me, because it tabbes out sometimes even though I am in the game. There are also a few cute details, like a birb landing on the arm of the Character or spiders crawling away after picking up a rock. 
Over all this game is very good and fun to play. I highly recommend playing it and I look forward to the release of Sons of the Forest.

This game is one of the only horror games I've played that has actually made me feel scared at times. The feeling of always being watched is creepy and in my first playthrough I was on edge the whole time. The gameplay is fun and the story (if you even pay attention to it) is somewhat interesting. Each cave felt unique and I felt a sense of accomplishment whenever I made it through and got a cool new tool or weapon.

I think that some people get a feeling of being mislead by the game's presentation as a basic survival game and then get bored because they run out of stuff to build, but in my eyes the limitation on that kind of stuff is more of a signal that you should go actually try to beat the game. And even then, there's so much that you can build with the different custom buildings and the hidden blueprints that are underwater.

One thing that bugged me was that there's no autosave and you have to individually save characters at a bed for each person playing in multiplayer. This was a big problem because one of my friends that I played with would randomly disconnect because of his internet connection and then lose all of his progress since we were last at our base. It was very annoying and something that I hope will be improved on or even removed altogether in the sequel.

Overall, I think this is my favorite survival game of all time and I would recommend to anyone that is looking for something to do.
One of the best coop survival games I have played.  The game play, building, and story are all amazing.  I have been searching for a game that delivers this well, but have yet to find one.

Wonderful graphics, plenty big and interesting world, plenty of hunting, danger and cannibals to kill, good structure building and object making tools once you learn how to do it. And challenging quests. Character control works good. Fun in both single and multiplayer mode. One thing I don't like is the save game feature. You must build a shelter or find the right tent to do a save. So, if you spend an hour exploring a cave or forest  then die, you've lost an hour or more of game time. The sleep feature is a nice touch. If it is night and you are in a shelter you can sleep the night away in a few seconds. I say it's worth buying.

Not for the faint of heart.

[h1]The pros :[/h1]

- Probably the best building system I've ever played. So much freedom !
- The ambience is amazing.
- One of the few first-person games that did melee combat right.
- Complete freedom, you can ignore the story completely if you want and still get many many hours of fun.
- Good both in solo or coop. Different vibe for each, solo is more intense and spooky. Coop takes away the spook factor, but adds more fun and allows for crazy building projects.
- Pretty impressive AI.
- Cannibals are incredible. From their looks, sounds, screams and growls, to their behaviour, the devs really did an amazing job designing them.
- The world is well designed, after some experience every area is easily recognisable and you almost never need to use the in-game map (which is terrible anyway).
- Cave exploration is quite unique.

[h1]The cons :[/h1]

- Some bugs were never fixed and most likely never will be.
- For a survival game, hunger and thirst quickly become a non-issue when you have a bit of experience.
- Cave exploration can be weird : too often the most dangerous areas are the most unrewarding.
- In Hard Survival mode, the calories system is poorly done, because of the sudden 6am reset. Especially since there is no way to tell what time it is when you're in a cave (despite the game being filled with wristwatches, pretty ironic).
- The weapon upgrade system doesn't make any sense at all.
- The system for quickslotting items is very obscure and not explained anywhere. You have to combine your backpack with the item you want to quickslot from the inventory screen, just weird. Thank god for search engines, I would have NEVER figured it out.
- Ironically the flashlight is the worst light source in the game
- Some areas of the world are too empty

Would highly recommend this game.. it's so creepy. The map is huge. At the beginning it is hard as you have no idea what you are doing and basically no guidance at all (on how to craft, what to craft, what to do) but once you get the hang of things it gets a bit easier in that aspect, but the creeps get bigger and badder. Much fun. Also got it on sale so worth it even more.

Great game with simple story and mechanics, two things I disliked though. One is that after finishing the game, if you pick one of two options, you don't actually get the achievement. The second one is more of a personal problem. Without guides, the weapons and tools in caves are tedious and annoying to find. However, this is a minor issue that is not relevant when talking about how good the game actually is. 8/10, definitely recommended.

The forest. Released by the developer team Endnight Games Ltd, their early work was little too new wave for my taste, but when The Forest came out in 2014, I think it really came out on its own, both comerically and artistically. The whole game has clear crisp horror aspect, and a new sheen of professionalism that really gives the game a big boost.

As a whole, I highly recommend this game, especially if you'd like to enjoy a good horror game with friends, and I'd even suggest that you don't search up the answers on the internet since it's more fun to find them yourself.

I purchased this game in early access back in 2014, when all I had was a study laptop that ran it at 5 fps. Recently, with a new laptop, I've jumped back in again and, well, its amazing. The way the survival guide and backpack inventory interface are implemented is refreshing and intuitive. The base building is simple enough to get on with but allows for any degree of complexity. The physics and combat are both satisfying and brutal. All in all, the best survival horror of its type that I have encountered, and a fantastic game to play with a friend(s).

I've spent a lot of time playing and spectating this game, definitely a fun time! The building and survival aspect isn't anything unique these days, but it has a really nice UI. The enemy is really unique for a survival game, though! It's improved a ton over the years, and it finally feels like a complete game. Admittedly, I don't love the story, but it's so much fun even if you ignore it and just focus on survival! Multiplayer is also a blast - and makes things easier, of course. 7/10
It's a fun game to play with some friends and the learning curve is small.

I came into this game with an expectation, and to put it plainly, this game blew my fucking mind. Graphics are crisp, realistic, and beautiful. Combat is responsive, sharp, and intense. Building is fun, maliable, and creative. This whole game is so damn good. Playstyles vary heavily from a peaceful, jogging-through-life style, to a badass Doom- AC feel. Godly. Holy shit there is so much to this game and so much to do. With other classic games like MC, COD, and SS falling out this was a great pick to play. Worth your time and money.

100% cannot go wrong with the game, mad  fun just exploring and building bases. Capturing natives in traps and putting them in a cage if you feel like it.

BEST horror/survival game ever. Played this all the way back in the super buggy Alpha/Beta and before Steam Achievements were even a thing.
